HEADLINE: Saving Harlem's Culture 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Harlem on the Cusp" (editorial, Aug. 26) correctly spotlighted the need for small-business support from the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone. But many Harlem residents, small-business owners and artists believe that erosion of affordable commercial space in Harlem is compromising the cultural integrity of the community. 
The diversified economic activity provided by local businesses owned largely by blacks but also Asians, Latinos and Yemeni people is essential to sustaining Harlem's unique cultural legacy. 
 Cultural impact statements must become an integral part of the empowerment zone and other community development plans. Without such review, Harlem residents will continue to have well-founded fears that the downside of Harlem's cusp is economic and cultural desolation.

DOROTHY DESIR
New York, Aug. 29, 2001

The writer is a program director, Lower Manhattan Cultural Council.

HEADLINE: Q&A; 
Self-Interest vs. Altruism: Labor's High Wire Act

BYLINE:  Michael Kazin, a history professor at Georgetown University, has written extensively about the labor movement and is the author of "The Populist Persuasion: An American History." Steven Greenhouse spoke with him.

 BODY:
Q. Has the whole idea of Labor Day and Labor Day parades become obsolete?
 Labor Day parades still have a function, partly nostalgic, partly motivational. As long as some workers believe they're a group or class apart and have a self-interest different from other groups in society, I would think they'd want to talk about some of their economic concerns and celebrate some of their achievements. That was the whole point of Labor Day originally, and it still has a purpose. 

Since John Sweeney was elected president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in 1995, union leaders have repeatedly boasted about a rebirth of the labor movement, but considering that the percentage of Americans belonging to unions has continued to drop, is that rebirth exaggerated?
There has been a rebirth ideologically. There has been a rebirth motivationally to a certain degree. Labor is certainly more open to other social movements -- immigrant rights, gay liberation, feminism, black and Latino movements -- than it was before John Sweeney's team took over in 1995. Having said that, there's no doubt that the structural and political barriers to labor's growth are immense, but I think labor is better positioned to grow than at any time in many years.
How relevant is the labor movement to the 86.5 percent of Americans who do not belong to unions?
It's available as an option, and that's very important. It's a tool or weapon that workers can use and say to their employers, "Maybe we'll join the Teamsters, maybe we'll join the Service Employees International Union." That creates pressure on employers to raise wages and benefits to forestall unionization. If labor wasn't there at all, if it represented just 1 percent of the workforce, rather than 13.5 percent, it wouldn't be a credible force. 
Ever since the 1999 protests in Seattle, much has been made of a supposed blue-green coalition between union members and environmentalists. Does this coalition remain an important force or has it crumbled as a result of labor-environmentalist divisions on energy policy?
The blue-green alliance is still very strong in the Northwest, in parts of California and some parts of the Midwest. Clearly there are issues in which environmentalists and some sectors of labor disagree. The fact that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. leadership and important unions like the service employees are open to this type of alliance is very important. It's important that unions are seeking ways to recruit young people and show that labor is not just for people in unions, but is out to make the world a better place. On my campus, the political activists on the left are very sympathetic to labor. They think about joining Union Summer, they support living wage campaigns. All these kids are environmentalists. There's no doubt about it.
Many labor leaders and union members will join the protests scheduled for late September in Washington during the autumn meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Do you think labor should be fighting the I.M.F. and the World Bank? 
I think their strategy has been a good one. They've questioned the priority of these institutions' investments and funding in the third world. Organized labor has demanded that international trade agreements and economic organizations work to improve living standards and working conditions all over that world. It's important that labor stand for economic and social justice. On the other hand, the leadership of organized labor has been wise in not putting on black shirts and saying, "Let's just smash these things." Clearly this economic order is going to be around for a long while, and labor can't get too far to the left or it will lose credibility and power and make itself vulnerable. 
Many government officials and business executives say the labor movement has been highly protectionist in light of its opposition to the North American Free Trade Agreement, the China trade deal, fast-track trade legislation and allowing in trucks from Mexico. In your view, is labor protectionist?
I think labor has two stances -- one is self-interest and one is altruistic. Even in its worst times, it has always had these two faces. On one hand, the Teamsters would like to stop trucks coming in from Mexico. That would save Teamster jobs. And of course the steelworkers would like to stop cheap imports. On the other hand, many union officials sincerely believe that every worker in the world should have a decent living, health care, pensions. They feel that if those workers don't have those things, that will undercut American workers. There is always this solidarity with working people in other countries, but then there is also a strong sense of nationalism and self-interest. It's hard to disentangle the two.
Do you think the labor movement can ever regain the energy, momentum and idealism of the 1930's?
There is still a tremendous amount of idealism today, in many ways comparable to the 1930's. There's a large proportion of workers of color in unions today. Organized labor is much more open to new immigrants, women, homosexuals than it was in the 1930's. So it's more on the cutting edge demographically than when it was predominantly white and male. From 1933 to 1945, union membership quintupled, from 3 million to 15 million. That kind of growth will not happen now for a whole range of reasons. Organized labor is a creature of industrial society, and to a large degree we're getting beyond industrial society. Workers work for companies for three years at a time, instead of their whole lives; young workers think about individual solutions to issues like health care. That's a real problem for unions. It's striking to me that labor has been more successful organizing some groups of low-wage immigrant workers than workers from Microsoft or other high-tech companies. That's heartening in the social justice sense, but it's also troublesome for labor's future.
How do you plan to mark Labor Day?
I will spend it with my family, and I will tell my kids, as I do every year, why there is a Labor Day and why there should be a Labor Day. They will probably say, "Daddy, not this talk again."

GRAPHIC: Photo (Linda Spillers for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Factory Data A Bit Upbeat For Economy 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
A small increase in new orders for goods produced at factories in July, along with signs that the deterioration in the industrial activity in the Chicago area has ebbed, raised hopes yesterday that the sluggish manufacturing sector might be stabilizing.
 But a separate report showing that American consumers were slightly more pessimistic about the economy in August kept alive concerns that consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of economic activity, could slow. 
 The Commerce Department said yesterday that the value of new factory orders rose 0.1 percent in July, to a seasonally adjusted $333.43 billion, led by orders for car parts and electrical equipment. The gain followed a 2.9 percent drop in June. 
The small increase in July orders took forecasters, who had expected a decline of 0.5 percent, by surprise.
The inventory-to-shipments ratio -- which measures how long it would take to deplete stocks fully at the current pace of business -- fell to 1.38 months in July from 1.40 in June.
And in Chicago, the local chapter of the National Association of Purchasing Management said its August index of regional business activity had rebounded to 43.5 from 38.0 in July, beating expectations for 39.8.
While that represented an improvement, economists cautioned that the index remained at recessionary levels and showed continued deterioration in business activity. A reading below 50 signifies contraction, while a reading above 50 means expansion. The index has not shown growth since September 2000, when it was at 50.3.
A separate report yesterday said consumer sentiment dipped in August, led by falling expectations for the future as corporate layoffs increased and the stock market weakened, threatening to undermine consumer spending.
The University of Michigan's August consumer sentiment index dipped to 91.5 from 92.4 in July, echoing data released earlier this week by the Conference Board. Economists forecast a reading of 93.2, down from the preliminary mid-month 93.5, the highest reading since January.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Americans Worked Longer Last Year Than in 1990
American workers have increased their substantial lead over Japan and all other industrial nations in the number of hours worked each year, a United Nations agency has found.
 The report found that Americans added nearly a full week to their work year during the 1990's, climbing to 1,978 hours on average last year, up 36 hours -- almost a full work week -- from 1990. Page A8. 

Dow Jones Ends Week Under 10,000
Wall Street ended a terrible week with a modest gain that was not enough to bring the Dow Jones industrial average above 10,000. The Dow closed up 30.17 points, or 0.3 percent, to 9,949.75. The Nasdaq composite index rose 13.75 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,805.43, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged up 4.55 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,133.58. C4.

Bush Lobbies Against Microsoft
The Bush administration urged the Supreme Court to reject a request by Microsoft to consider throwing out the findings that the company had repeatedly abused its monopoly in the software industry. C2.

Confusion Over McDonald's Contest
McDonald's is having a $10 million instant giveaway. But consumers and restaurant employees are confused about it. C2.

Cox and Comcast May Pull At Home
At Home said Cox Communications and Comcast would stop selling its high-speed Internet service in June. The move may bring At Home a step closer to bankruptcy. C4.

Hitachi to Cut 4% of Its Work Force
Hitachi, Japan's largest private employer, said it would cut 4 percent of its work force, or 14,700 jobs, by March -- 10,200 in Japan and the remaining 4,500 overseas. Hitachi, which expects a $1.2 billion loss for the year, joined Fujitsu, Toshiba and Kyocera in announcing major staff reductions recently. C3.

Factory Orders Rise Unexpectedly
The Commerce Department said that the value of new factory orders rose 0.1 percent in July, to a seasonally adjusted $333.43 billion, led by orders for car parts and electrical equipment. The unexpected gain followed a 2.9 percent drop in June. Separately, the Chicago chapter of the National Association of Purchasing Management said its August index of regional business activity rebounded to 43.5 from 38.0 in July. And the University of Michigan's August consumer sentiment index dipped to 91.5 from 92.4 in July. C14.

Groups Issue Recommendations
Two groups issued recommendations on how to involve individuals in policy decisions about the Internet's address system. C2.

Fed Seeks to Understand Spending
The Federal Reserve is trying to sort out the ways in which assets like stocks or homes affect consumer spending, Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, said. C4.

Phone Companies End Merger Talks
Royal KPN, the former Dutch state phone company, and Belgacom, its Belgian counterpart, ended their long-running merger talks, saying the slump in telecommunications stocks made agreeing on terms harder. C3.

Bayer Is in Deal for CropScience
Bayer has reached a tentative agreement to buy CropScience, an Aventis agricultural chemicals unit, for about $5 billion. C3.

U.S. Markets Closed Monday
United States financial markets and banks will be closed on Monday in observance of Labor Day. Most financial markets in other countries will be open.

HEADLINE: Master of the Mosaic That Is New York City; 
Expert Keeps Tabs on Changing Population

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
The chief demographer for New York City lives in Census Tract 274, a bucolic sliver of the Bronx next to Eastchester Bay, where an earlier generation of immigrants raised their children to believe that the sky was the limit but a good son stayed close to home.
 Joseph J. Salvo lives eight blocks from the house where he grew up. He has lived in the neighborhood for almost all of his 47 years -- except for one miserable foray into the suburbs of Washington, where his wife's office was in a shopping mall and he had to drive to Baltimore for salami. 
 Dr. Salvo is the self-described homeboy in charge of tracking New York's restless eight million people, one of the most dynamic urban populations in the world. It is a population in a perpetual state of reinvention, with newcomers pouring in from Dhaka and Abuja, while others depart for the suburbs, the Sun Belt and beyond. 
His title is director of the population division of the Department of City Planning, which keeps tabs, demographically speaking, on that enormous and mutable moving target. It is an assignment roughly comparable in complexity to that of a team of meteorologists monitoring tornadoes in the Great Plains.
There are Africans on the Grand Concourse these days; where are they settling? The Arab community is growing, but how fast and from where? Egyptian immigration is up. So are births to Mexican and Nigerian mothers around Brighton Beach. There are more Uzbeks in Queens, and they're Jewish.
The phone rings constantly in Dr. Salvo's office near City Hall. Some voice on the other end begins: Hi. I got your number from so-and-so. I understand you know everything there is to know about the city.
Then the questions:
How many gay and lesbian couples are there in New York?
What cities have the most Latinos?
How far is my apartment from the East River?
In Dr. Salvo's head resides a warehouse of facts. More than half of all babies here have foreign-born mothers, he can tell you. About 15 percent of the entire population of Guyana lives in New York. A useful indicator of neighborhood change can be found in travel-agency windows: are they pushing specials to Palermo or Tirana?
In the late 1980's, Dr. Salvo's office began noticing Bangladeshis driving cabs. The numbers showed up in the city's hack-license data. By the early 1990's, Bangladesh had surfaced at 14th place on the ranked list of countries sending immigrants to New York. By the late 1990's, it was sixth. (Ireland, meanwhile, had dropped from 12th to 35th.)
The number of New Yorkers over age 85 has increased by 20 percent since 1990, Dr. Salvo can tell you. It is possible to predict park vandalism by developing a "hangout index" -- based on the number of unemployed high school dropouts, age 16 to 21, as a percentage of the population in neighborhoods in the city.
"Somebody calls me up wanting to know how many cats and dogs there are in the city," Dr. Salvo recalled recently. "Said they wanted to know how big the cat population was. Was it bigger than the dog population? I said the census didn't get that information, maybe you should call the S.P.C.A."
And?
"They got offended: 'Why the hell doesn't . . .' "
It was Dr. Salvo's division that pointed out to the Census Bureau earlier this summer, when it released numbers on Hispanic groups in New York, that the bureau had apparently miscounted tens of thousands of Dominicans, Colombians and others, at least in part because of a change in the 2000 census form.
It was Dr. Salvo and his colleagues, too, who tracked down what they said were several hundred thousand addresses missing from the list the bureau intended to use for the census. Including the people at those addresses helped push the city's population count above the eight million mark, producing a financial and psychic windfall for New York.
These days, the seven-person population division is deciphering the census data, preparing profiles of the city's 59 community districts, advising city agencies on the implications of the numbers and mapping the racial and ethnic changes that decades of immigration have helped bring about.
"It's like one big puzzle," said Dr. Salvo, a physical scientist at heart, who grew up constructing model rockets and dissecting television sets in the family basement. "And it's a grand puzzle. You want to take it apart and put it back together and figure out how it goes together."
Dr. Salvo's parents are Italian immigrants; his mother arrived in 1920, his father in 1951. The family lived in a three-family house in Pelham Bay. Dr. Salvo's father worked in construction, 17 hours a day. Joe, his eldest son, got beat up a lot for playing with chemistry sets.
Joe Salvo went to Iona College in New Rochelle, then to graduate school at Fordham. He studied the Puerto Rican migration, and at 26 he received his Ph.D. in sociology. He was seen as the ethnic kid who would not leave home; his mentors encouraged him to go to Washington, to make a career with the Census Bureau.
But leaving was heresy. "You're not going," his mother said knowingly, the moving van at the door. Dr. Salvo moved to Washington for good, and was back in a year. Having worked in the wealth statistics branch of the Census Bureau, he joined the population division in 1982 and became director in 1993.
"I have the best job in the world because I have the best subject matter in the world," said Dr. Salvo, who learned from a visiting delegation from Turkmenistan recently that his looks would blend in nicely on the streets of Ashgabat. "Right now, New York is experiencing immigration that is changing its neighborhoods, altering its environment and doing things culturally to this city in a way that we haven't seen for a hundred years."
But change makes people uneasy. That is a lesson Dr. Salvo learned in neighborhoods he knew as a child and a young adult. For years, he said, the universal language there was: "When are you getting out? Boy, the city's going downhill. See that family that moved in next door?"
During high school and college, he worked as a youth counselor in the Belmont section of the Bronx. He learned to be careful where he took the Italian kids, he said, because they would beat up black kids. He asked why, and he said he was told it was because they were black.
The answer to fear of the unknown, he now figures, is knowing. So he makes dozens of presentations a year. If his division can serve as a source of scientific information, it is his belief that people might be less likely to listen to the anxious prognostications and prejudices of their Uncle Tony.
Change comes in cycles, Dr. Salvo contended. He said the cycles were the same, the people different; but everyone wants the same things. He said the numbers showed clearly how people came here, settled in and worked, how they raised and educated their children, where they went when they moved on.
"It makes people understand that where they're living is not a strange and alien place," Dr. Salvo said. "It's not a place that somehow has become foreign to them. Because that's how people in neighborhoods interpret it. 'We're living in a foreign country.' "
He said later: "This is the cycle. It's somebody else's turn now. The process known as New York, you benefited from, and now you're all over the country. The new groups coming in, they'll benefit the way you did. And then, ultimately, they'll yield to another group."
On a recent field trip, looking for clues, Dr. Salvo rode the No. 4 train north through the Bronx to Fordham Road, then struck out on foot, heading east, then veered south down the Grand Concourse and east again on 188th Street into Belmont, once solidly Italian.
The Italian presence was still there, but visible mostly in the specialty food shops along Arthur Avenue, now a destination for suburban pilgrims in search of ravioli. That strip seemed almost an artifact amid the evidence that Albanians and Mexicans were rapidly displacing the Italians. Dr. Salvo eyeballed the playground population and checked out the Mexican grocery stores, the Mexican flags hanging in apartment house windows, and the new mosque just a few blocks from Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church.
Dr. Salvo's work, he said, shares something with his hobby, ham radio. He has a 35-foot radio tower in his backyard, with which it is possible to send a signal out over the Atlantic and occasionally connect with astonishing clarity with a stranger halfway around the world.
"Ham radio and demography kind of go together," Dr. Salvo said. "They're both logical. They're both driven by scientific principles. One is, of course, a hard science much more than the other. One is much more human. That is the connection."

HEADLINE: Americans' International Lead in Hours Worked Grew in 90's, Report Shows 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
A United Nations agency provided some discouraging news yesterday to Americans who believe they are overworked, finding that American workers have increased their substantial lead over Japan and all other industrial nations in the number of hours worked each year.
 The report, issued by the International Labor Organization, found that Americans added nearly a full week to their work year during the 1990's, climbing to 1,979 hours on average last year, up 36 hours from 1990. That means Americans who are employed are putting in nearly 49 1/2 weeks a year on the job. 
Americans work 137 hours, or about three and one-half weeks, more a year than Japanese workers, 260 hours (about six and one-half weeks) more a year than British workers and 499 hours (about 12 1/2 weeks) more a year than German workers, the report said. The Japanese had long been at the top for the number of hours worked, but in the mid-1990's the United States surpassed Japan, and since then it has pulled farther ahead. 
"It's unique to Americans that they continue to increase their working hours, while hours are declining in other industrialized nations," said Lawrence Jeff Johnson, the economist who oversaw the labor organization's report. "It has a lot to do with the American psyche, with American culture. American workers are eager to make the best impression, to put in the most hours."
Many economists say the numbers demonstrate that the American economic boom of the 1990's provided plenty of work for tens of millions of Americans. In contrast, the economies of Europe and Japan grew far more slowly, if at all, causing many companies to cut back on the length of the workweek.
Patrick Cleary, senior vice president for human resources policy at the National Association of Manufacturers, said, "Clearly, for most of these years the increase in hours tracks outstanding economic performance in the United States, which translates into more income for all those workers, so we don't see this necessarily as bad news at all."
Among the reasons for the large differences between the United States and other countries are that Europeans typically take four to six weeks of vacation each year while Americans take two to three weeks. And while American employers kept adding overtime during the 1990's, in France the government reduced the official workweek to 35 hours.
Juliet Schor, a sociology professor at Boston College and the author of "The Overworked American," said one reason for the nation's longer average work year was that American workers seemed to be increasingly squeezed during booms and busts alike.
"All the direction seems to be for longer hours," Ms. Schor said. "In expansions, companies keep giving more work to their workers, and in recessions, there will be downsizing and fewer people working, but the workers who remain have to work longer hours to retain their jobs."
Many economists say the number of hours that Americans work each year may begin to level off now that many automakers and other manufacturers have reduced the amount of overtime assigned due to the economic slowdown.
Economists give many reasons for the increase in the number of hours that Americans work. Mothers with young children tend to work sooner and for more hours per week than young mothers did a decade or two ago. More Americans are salaried professionals, like investment bankers and lawyers, who often work 60 or more hours per week. In addition, many low-wage workers have two or three jobs to make ends meet.
In the best news for the United States, the report ranked the country No. 1 in the world in productivity per worker. It said that last year, productivity per American worker in constant 1990 dollars was $54,870, about $1,500 more than Belgium, the No. 2 nation. The report found that productivity per worker in the United States was $10,000 higher than in Canada last year, and $14,000 higher than in Japan.
But partly because of the comparatively high number of hours that Americans work, the report found that France and Belgium edged out the United States in productivity per hour. In France, which ranked first, workers produced $33.71 of value added per hour on average, compared with $32.98 in Belgium and $32.84 in the United States.
Ellen Galinsky, president of the Families and Work Institute, a research group in New York, said the large number of hours that Americans work could result in burned-out workers with lower productivity.
"Our overall productivity is high because we work more hours," Ms. Galinsky said. "But our research shows there is a possible point of diminishing returns."

HEADLINE: Developer to Run Ad Campaign Questioning Arena Deal 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS

DATELINE: NEWARK, Aug. 31 

 BODY:
One of New Jersey's largest real estate developers is planning a statewide advertising campaign that raises questions about plans for a new arena in Newark and the redevelopment of the current arena site in the Meadowlands.
 The campaign raises an issue that has been aggressively pursued by Bret D. Schundler, the Republican candidate for governor, who has called for a referendum on any arena plan. 
 The newspaper advertising campaign by the developer, Hartz Mountain Industries, is scheduled to start on Tuesday. It will run in most of the state's newspapers, said Emanuel Stern, the president of the company, which is based in Secaucus, N.J. 
Officials with the company declined to release the content of the ad, saying only that it would urge voters to raise questions with their legislators about the project.
But the ad campaign could help amplify an issue that has pitted Mr. Schundler against most of the state's political establishment and that he believes has enormous potential to resonate with voters. It also has the potential to affect an issue that could have enormous financial implications for Hartz Mountain, the owner of more than 35 million square feet of real estate in the Meadowlands.
Mr. Stern said in an interview that his biggest objection to the current proposal is that it could give exclusive rights to the Meadowlands redevelopment project to another developer without a competitive bidding process.
A special session of the Legislature is scheduled for Sept. 17 to consider amendments to the legislation championed by Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco that would allow construction of the $385 million arena in Newark. That bill, which will be considered by the Assembly Appropriations Committee when it meets on Thursday, is expected to include provisions for the even more costly plans for redeveloping the Meadowlands site of Continental Airlines Arena and for projects at Rowan University in South Jersey, which were added to address legislators' concerns that the region also receive some stimulus for economic development.
Two weeks ago Mr. Schundler addressed the Newark arena and the proposed development in the Meadowlands as a campaign issue. He has called for a statewide referendum on a project that he charged would end up increasing the state's debt. 
"We think that obviously this is an issue which involves being responsive to taxpayers, and we welcome the voice of anybody who advocates that the taxpayers have a say," said Bill Guhl, a spokesman for Mr. Schundler.
Mr. DiFrancesco's plan for the Meadowlands calls for providing hundreds of millions of dollars in state transportation improvements for the site. He also indicated that he wanted to convince a company that has proposed a massive mall on an ecologically sensitive tract of the Meadowlands to swap that land for development rights on the old arena site. 
While no formal agreement on the swap of development parcels has been reached with that developer, the Mills Corporation of Arlington, Va., Mr. Stern said that he found this "sole source contract" for a valuable development tract to be "the most egregious part" of the development plan. 
"I don't have a conceptual problem with the arena moving to Newark," said Mr. Stern, whose company owns more than $500 million in Newark real estate and has city-designated development rights on a number of parcels. "What I am against is the sole sourcing of the Meadowlands site, which is one of the most valuable pieces of property in the state. There should a bidding process."
Mr. Stern commissioned a poll by Opinion Dynamics, of Cambridge, Mass., which questioned 500 registered voters about the project and found overwhelming support for a referendum on state support for a new arena. 
Mr. Stern, a longtime supporter of Mayor Sharpe James of Newark and a contributor to his campaigns, said that he knew that his advertising campaign would not make the mayor happy, but he felt that he had to speak up before the Legislature approved the plan. 
Mayor James said through a spokesman that he was "disappointed" at Mr. Stern's campaign to "undermine" the Newark arena plan.
"I am especially disappointed since the city had bent over backwards to assist Hartz Mountain in some half billion in economic development in Newark," the mayor said through his spokeswoman, Pamela Goldstein.

HEADLINE: Canada Warms to Wal-Mart; 
From U.S. Invader to Part of the Landscape in 7 Years

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Aug. 31 

 BODY:
Maureen Donovan of Onoway, Alberta, warmed the hearts of Wal-Mart executives last month: she was the 50th Canadian to send in a petition begging the mass retailer to open a store nearby.
 "It would be a dream come true to have a rural Wal-Mart in Onoway," Ms. Donovan wrote from her acreage near that farming village of some 800 people, an hour's drive northwest of Edmonton. Ms. Donovan, a network planner for Canada Post who described herself as a "longtime Wal-Mart customer," tossed in the suggestion that she be considered as the new store's first manager. 
 Similarly, Carol Foote, a caregiver in Miramichi, New Brunswick, a city of some 19,000 people, organized a petition for a Wal-Mart last fall in the hope that its drawing power would help lift the local economy. "Our city is not growing because there's nothing to draw people here," Ms. Foote said in a telephone interview. If people from surrounding areas came to shop at a Wal-Mart, "maybe that night they'd go to the theater before they went home." With the help of two friends, Ms. Foote collected 11,276 signatures in six weeks. 
Such pleas are evidence of a remarkable shift in attitude toward Wal-Mart Stores, the world's biggest retailer, since its first foray into Canada seven years ago.
Many Canadians originally saw Wal-Mart's March 1994 purchase of 122 down-at-heel Woolco stores as an unwelcome invasion of their shopping malls. They feared that the giant from the south would drive their favorite stores out of business and impose yet another Ugly American icon on the Canadian landscape.
Wal-Mart's 179 stores have indeed become part of the Canadian landscape. But the reason is that its popularity has far outstripped that of its rivals, propelling it into top place in the country's discount retail market.
"It's basically the same strategies -- we just execute them a little differently" than in the United States, said Mario Pilozzi, chief operating officer of Wal-Mart Canada. "We've been able to identify with our customers here."
One likely reason is that Mr. Pilozzi is himself Canadian, and came to Wal-Mart via Woolco. "When they bought the racks in our stores, they bought me, too," he joked.
The invasion of Wal-Mart, which is based in Bentonville, Ark., and other mass merchandisers based in the United States, including Home Depot and Costco, has transformed the way Canadian retailers do business. And Wal-Mart, with its global heft and pervasive presence, has left the biggest footprint.
"There's no question that Wal-Mart has taken the lead and has had a major impact" on the industry, said John Torella, a retail consultant with the J. C. Williams Group in Toronto.
Wal-Mart Canada contributed an estimated 2.4 percent of the company's $191.3 billion in sales, and about 14 percent of all international sales, in the year ended Jan. 31. "The Canadian operation is a major success story for them," said Michael Exstein, a retailing analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston in New York.
Wal-Mart's move into Canada has been much smoother than most of its other foreign forays, Mr. Exstein said. One of the company's weakest links is Germany, where it has not been profitable or gained a significant share of the market since it arrived in 1997.
In Canada, "they started with what Wal-Mart does best -- information technology and logistics," Mr. Exstein said. Then, he said, "they listened to their people in Canada, and allowed them to modify things."
Wal-Mart's storefront greeters may be a little brash for some Canadians, and some customers do not like having their bags sealed as they enter a Wal-Mart store, a measure designed to discourage pilfering. But these seem to be the biggest current complaints. By contrast, the petitions, and the sales figures, show just how popular Wal-Mart has become above the 49th parallel.
The company does not disclose country-by-country sales results. But according to Kubas Consultants, a Toronto market research company, Wal-Mart Canada's sales soared 265 percent from 1994 to 2000 to the Canadian equivalent of $4.5 billion. In the period, sales at its main rival, the Toronto-based Zellers, which has 330 outlets, rose to $3.1 billion, a far more modest 46 percent increase.
Home Depot, which entered Canada the same year as Wal-Mart by buying half a dozen "big box" home improvement stores in southern Ontario, now has 73 outlets in Ontario, Quebec and the Atlantic provinces. The company does not break down sales figures, but according to estimates by Hardlines, a weekly electronic news service for the home improvement industry, Home Depot Canada sales last year were $1.8 billion.
"There's a saying that when a new Home Depot opens up, five lumberyards go out of business," said Len Kubas, director of Kubas Consultants.
According to Mr. Kubas's data, Costco's sales in Canada almost doubled, to $4.7 billion between 1994 and 2000. Costco has 60 stores in Canada.
The success of Wal-Mart and other United States chains in Canada is only partly explained by their enormous purchasing power, which enables them to offer low prices. They have also brought a degree of imagination and innovation previously lacking in Canadian retailing.
Even George Heller, president of Zellers's parent, the Hudson's Bay Company, acknowledged, "You have to give the devil its due."
Wal-Mart, he said, "has definitely had an impact over all in terms of retailing in Canada -- what they do, they do well."
The typical Wal-Mart Canada store has about 125,000 square feet, though the company has been experimenting with stores half that size in smaller communities.
Until Wal-Mart became such a threat, the Zellers outlets were, Mr. Heller said, "undersized and overpopulated" with merchandise. Zellers has pushed up its average store size from 66,000 square feet in 1994 to 93,000. Still, Mr. Heller said, "we're maybe two years away from having the real estate portfolio the way we want it."
Far from squeezing out local suppliers, the American retailers have opened new horizons for Canadian goods. With the help of the North American Free Trade Agreement, "these stores have provided an outlet for manufacturers to supply stores in Canada and the United States," said Jayson Myers, chief economist at Canadian Manufacturers and Exporters, an industry group based in Ottawa. "If anything," he said, the manufacturers "have problems gearing up to the scale needed to meet orders from major retailers selling across the continent."
One beneficiary has been the Krave's Candy Company of Winnipeg, Manitoba, which now sells a quarter of its cashew nut and caramel candy to Wal-Mart.
"Wal-Mart has really led us to water in terms of what sells," said Larry Finnson, a co-owner of Krave's. "It's a much closer working relationship than with Zellers."
Mr. Finnson cites Wal-Mart's Retail Link, a software system that allows manufacturers to monitor sales of their products at individual stores. Krave's, with annual sales of $2.6 million, recently began selling its candy to Wal-Mart stores in the United States.
Mr. Exstein of Credit Suisse First Boston said Wal-Mart's head office had the good sense to realize that Canadian managers "had better intelligence" on the local market. According to the company's 2001 annual report, Canadian Wal-Mart Stores have "become leaders in terms of generating new retailing concepts and merchandising techniques, which have been adopted both in the U.S. and abroad."
The increasingly torrid competition has forced rapid consolidation in the Canadian retail sector. About a dozen well-known chains have disappeared in the last decade, most notably the T. Eaton Company, a venerable department store chain that became insolvent. (A few Eatons outlets still exist, but Sears Canada, which is controlled by Sears, Roebuck & Company and which bought Eaton in 1999, now runs most of the stores under the Sears name.)
Changing to attract more affluent shoppers as well, Wal-Mart, whose Canadian operations are based in Mississauga, Ontario, plans to open as many as 20 stores in Canada this year, and to expand in the country at a similar pace in years to come. 
Wal-Mart, meanwhile, is putting more emphasis on its private-label offerings, from Sam's Choice cola to No Boundaries cosmetics. These products are invariably priced below established national brands as a way of building shopper loyalty. Zellers has rapidly expanded its own brands, too, including the exclusive Canadian rights to Martha Stewart merchandise. Private label has jumped from zero to 22 percent of total Zellers sales in the last three years.
Crucial to the Americans' success is a recognition of the differences between American and Canadian consumers. According to Mr. Exstein of Credit Suisse First Boston, Wal-Mart places far more advertising inserts in local newspapers in Canada than it does in the United States, "because that's what the Canadian consumer uses as a shopping vehicle." The Canadian stores also carry a wider variety of furniture, consumer electronics and pet supplies, he said.
Annette Verschuren, chief executive of Home Depot's Canadian unit, says her company has also had to adjust.
For example, the Quebec stores load up on paint, wallpaper and blinds in summer, when Quebecers tend to move, she said, adding that the large numbers of rental units in the province means that people there move more often. And unlike their United States counterparts, most Canadian shoppers "will walk out of your store, and won't tell you what the problems are," she said, so the company has to work harder "to understand what their needs and wants are."
And some Canadians undoubtedly find it amusing that the once-reviled retail invader has even given 300,000 Canadian dollars ($194,000) to commemorate another successful onslaught: a memorial being built near the beach in Normandy, France, where Canadian soldiers landed on D-Day in 1944.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Japan's Electronics Slump Takes a Toll on Southeast Asia

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Aug. 31 

 BODY:
Lean times for Japan's electronics giants used to mean good tidings for Southeast Asia. Often, they foreshadowed the opening of a Japanese factory somewhere in Malaysia, say, or perhaps the Philippines.
 Thailand -- where Fujitsu took advantage of a strong yen and low Thai salaries more than a decade ago to start making computer printers and hard-disk drives at an industrial estate outside Bangkok -- was a popular choice for Japanese companies, too. And through the 1990's, Fujitsu poured plenty of investment into the factory, which went from producing roughly 12,000 hard drives a year to churning out more than a million a month. 
 Until last month, that is, when Fujitsu said it would sharply cut production not only at the disk drive factory, but also at others in the Philippines and Vietnam as it eliminates 16,400 jobs worldwide in response to deepening losses. Even as some Japanese companies are being forced to close factories at home, much the same process is occurring at their operations around the region. NEC is cutting semiconductor workers in Malaysia. Hitachi, which announced today that it was cutting almost 15,000 jobs, mostly in Japan, is closing computer monitor factories in Malaysia and in Singapore. 
On the most elemental level, Japan's cutbacks in Southeast Asia only highlight how the severe slump in demand for technology goods from the United States and other industrial nations has reverberated around the world. But the downturn in the electronics industry has also become a powerful catalyst for even more profound shifts in Asia's economic balance. One is the slow but steady retreat by Japan as Southeast Asia's largest investor and financier. The second is the rapid re-emergence of China as the region's principal rival for investment and trade.
"It leaves Southeast Asia in a very precarious position," said William C. Belchere, head of fixed-income research at Merrill Lynch in Singapore. 
Japan's own investment figures illustrate the shifts. While Japan's direct investment around the world has fallen 36 percent in the last 10 years as it has grappled with its own economic downturn, its investment in Southeast Asia has been cut in half. Yet its investment in China has more than doubled, Japan's Ministry of Finance reports, making it the top destination in Asia. Japanese electronics companies once favored Malaysia; China now tops their Asian investment rankings.
This signifies Japan's withdrawal from a role it has played almost since China went Communist in 1949. While the United States fought in Korea and then in Vietnam, it left the job of financing development in non-Communist Asia to its World War II-enemy-turned-ally in Tokyo.
Japanese investment in Southeast Asia surged further after the 1985 Plaza Accord by the Group of Seven industrialized nations spurred devaluation of the dollar against the yen, making Japanese products relatively more expensive to American consumers. Like Fujitsu in Thailand, Japanese exporters rushed to build factories where land and labor were cheaper. Sanctions by the United States against imports of some Japanese products helped put Japanese electronics companies at the forefront of the exodus to Southeast Asia.
This influx of yen helped pay for Asia's "miracle" decade, with Southeast Asia following Japan-style development, compelling citizens to save and channeling their money through bankers to finance government-sanctioned developments, with exports fueling robust gains in jobs and incomes.
That all began to unravel in 1995, when the dollar began a sharp rise in value against the yen. Japanese banks began reeling in their $176 billion in loans to Southeast Asia, creating a credit squeeze that some economists say helped touch off the financial crisis two years later.
While the crisis set in motion politically painful efforts to rely on more genuine market forces in place of the iron triangle of governments, banks and conglomerates, the Internet boom served as a temporary anesthetic over the wounds. Asia's export machine revved back into high gear, pulling Southeast Asia's economy out of recession, but leaving the region more reliant than ever on electronics exports, particularly to the United States.
"They're overdependent on electronics," said David L. Cohen, an analyst at Standard & Poor's MMS International in Singapore. Electronics exports accounted for roughly half of Singapore's economy, according to Goldman, Sachs, and slightly more of Malaysia's. Now that demand from the United States has collapsed, Singapore's economy has fallen into recession. Malaysia's economic growth slowed to 0.5 percent last quarter after bounding ahead 8.5 percent last year.
Japan's shrinking role in Southeast Asia has now become a source of political tension. In April, finance ministers from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which groups together all 10 of the region's members, formally censured Japan for allowing the yen to decline so much, a move that helps Japan's own exports at the expense of Southeast Asia's competitiveness.
Japanese companies are clearly aware of the political dimension to their investment. "Our No. 1 priority is to develop each country's economy," said Makoto Mihara, a spokesman for Matsushita Electric Industrial in Tokyo, explaining why the company has no plans to retrench at its 58 factories around Southeast Asia. Matsushita recently posted its first loss in more than 50 years.
Like their American counterparts, Japanese electronics companies are suffering from the way personal computers, printers and many of the parts that go into them have become nearly as interchangeable as wheat or pork bellies. "They're all commodity businesses," said Hiroshi Yoshihara, an analyst at Nikko Salomon Smith Barney in Tokyo. "It's difficult to differentiate from competitors' products."
So Japanese companies are conceding defeat in those businesses in which their red ink is most profuse, and that means cutting production even at some of the lowest-cost foreign factories.
Fujitsu's Thai factory, for example, will stop making printers and hard-disk drives for desktop PC's, but will keep making disk drives for laptops and servers. Hitachi is bowing out of the monitor business. And NEC's layoffs at its chip plant in Malaysia are part of 4,000 job cuts the company will make as it consolidates its chip business and outsources production to a new venture with Hitachi.
That, of course, leaves room for further investments in more profitable products as Japanese companies continue to move offshore. And some economists think predictions of Southeast Asia's demise as an electronics center are exaggerated.
"These existing sites are not going to suddenly lose their competitiveness overnight," said Mr. Cohen at MMS International. 
Others see a clear shift by Japanese companies -- together with those from the United States and Taiwan -- toward China. "When they talk about moving offshore, Japanese companies talk about moving to China," said Andy Xie, an economist at Morgan Stanley in Hong Kong.
In the last five years, China has emerged as the largest supplier of Japanese electronic components in Asia. Even as they cut elsewhere, NEC and Toshiba plan to increase production of mobile phones in China. Hitachi is creating a venture to build air-conditioners there. And as they shut down some chip plants at home, many Japanese companies are selling their equipment on the expectation that it will be shipped to China for use there, said Jonathan Ross, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs.
"China's gravitational pull is too large," Mr. Ross said. "It's just going to suck in capital and skilled workers and become more and more important."
All this has persuaded the more farsighted of Southeast Asia's leaders that the region's days as mostly a platform for electronics exports may be numbered.
"Many of the things we are now doing, in time, China will do better and cheaper," Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong of Singapore said in a national address last month. "We will have to stay one step ahead, and move on to new activities."

HEADLINE: The Rebate Helps. Do It Again. 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Paul Krugman ("Greenspan Stands Alone," column, Aug. 31) is right that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, needs help in fighting the looming recession. Congress could provide such help with additional temporary tax cuts. 
 This quarter, from July through September, millions of taxpayers are receiving $600, $500 or $300 rebates, depending on family size. Some are saving their rebates, others are spending them now, and still others will spend most of their rebates before the year ends.
Congress should immediately enact a repeat of the rebate for the next quarter. The United States Treasury has the mailing addresses ready -- new checks could go to the same addresses in the same sequence.
Most technicians advise that a larger stimulus is needed, so Congress should double the size of each check. The rebate should be repeated every quarter until the latest economic data show that a strong economic recovery has begun.

LAURENCE SEIDMAN
Swarthmore, Pa., Aug. 31, 2001

The writer is a professor of economics at the University of Delaware.

HEADLINE: Candidates Sound Out Core Republican Issues, as Well as Each Other 

 BODY:
 Following are excerpts from yesterday's debate of the Republican candidates for mayor, as recorded by The New York Times. The debate was broadcast on radio station WNYC-AM (820) and was carried on www.wnyc.org. It was moderated by Brian Lehrer, host of WNYC's "On the Line."

Q. Mr. Bloomberg, this debate is happening in the context of a Republican primary. You're both former Democrats. You've been open about joining the G.O.P. largely to avoid the crowded Democratic primary field. Why should a registered Republican vote for you?

MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG -- Well, I was a Democrat. The Republican Party and the Independence Party both came to me. Their leadership asked me to run as a Republican for mayor. I talked to them. I agree with the Republican leadership in this state. I agree with Rudy Giuliani and George Pataki on most things. They're inclusionary Republicans, and I felt very comfortable in running with them and representing the Republican Party, and I think I'd be a great mayor and they'd be proud to have me.

Q. You agree with them on most things.

BLOOMBERG -- Sure.

Q. Things like?

BLOOMBERG -- Well, I agree with them on how we have to have some compassion for people who are left out, how we have to have good fiscal policies and make sure that we keep taxes down, how we have to build up people rather than tear them apart and make this government work for everybody.

Q. Mr. Badillo, why should a registered Republican vote for you?

HERMAN BADILLO -- Because I have been working with Mayor Rudy Giuliani since 1993. In fact, I ran with Rudy as comptroller in 1993 and carried many parts of the city such as Staten Island. I have been also working with Governor Pataki, who appointed me, first, vice chairman of the Board of Trustees of the City University and then chairman of the board of the City University. And I've agreed with the mayor and worked with him on many areas, especially in education. But, for example, I also was on the committee that selected Bill Bratton as the first police commissioner. And I have been working to improve standards, which I believe I have done, at the City University and also to improve standards at elementary and secondary education, together with the mayor.

Q. Did either of you vote for President Bush last year? Mr. Badillo?

BADILLO -- Oh yes, absolutely. Yes, I voted for the Republican ticket.

Q. Mr. Bloomberg?

BLOOMBERG -- I have said clearly I'm not going to tell anybody who I ever voted for. I'm here to pull people together, not to tear them apart. But it's obvious that almost all of the Republican leadership in New York City has endorsed me. John McCain has endorsed me. We started an ad today where John McCain said he thinks I'd be great mayor and he's in my camp.

Q. Did you vote for Rick Lazio over Hillary Clinton?

BLOOMBERG -- I said that I'm trying to pull people together, not tear them apart. Who I voted for in the privacy of the booth doesn't matter; it's what I'm going to do once I'm mayor.

Q. Did you vote for Rick Lazio?

BADILLO -- Yes. And if you want to be the mayor of New York City, as a leader in the Republican Party, you have to say that you are a real Republican, which I am. And the problem is that Mr. Bloomberg in none of his commercials says that he's a Republican. And in fact he says it doesn't really matter. . . .

Q. Mr. Bloomberg, you made campaign donations to Al Gore for president, Bill Bradley for president, Christopher Dodd, John Corzine, Nita Lowey. What should Republican primary voters think about that?

BLOOMBERG -- I've made donations to a number of Democrats. I've also made donations to an awful lot of Republicans. I've looked to see at various times whether I thought they were the right people for the job. I've been a big supporter of the governor, and I've been a big supporter of the mayor. I've said I will support the governor when he runs next year. I think he's been a good governor. I don't think one should just automatically rule out people because of party any more than I think you have to include them. Somebody that's good or isn't good, somebody you agree with or don't agree with, you can do that independent of party. . . .

Q. Mr. Badillo, under what circumstances would you raise taxes as mayor?

BADILLO -- I would not raise them under any circumstances, because the fact is that we are the most taxed city in the country. And when, for example, Mayor Dinkins increased taxes when he was mayor, the result was that we lost 400,000 jobs and that many middle-class people left the city. If we want to help the city, if we want to keep the jobs that we have, if we want to keep the middle-class people we have, we cannot continue to increase taxes. In fact I favor reducing taxes. . . .

BLOOMBERG -- Well, I don't think that anybody can prudently promise that under no circumstances, because you really don't know the future. But raising taxes when we're going into a declining economic environment is about as bad a fiscal and monetary policy as you can possibly have. We want to encourage people to come here, to bring jobs here, to invest here. And you certainly don't want to do that. . . .

Q. Mr. Bloomberg, do you have a question for Mr. Badillo?

BLOOMBERG -- Sure. Will you join my administration if I'm fortunate enough to become mayor of the city? I'd love to have the benefit of your wisdom, and I think you could be a big plus to my administration. And I'd like to know, would you do it?

BADILLO -- Well, thank you for the offer. But, no, I would not join it. I have been already a commissioner, housing commissioner, a borough president, congressman and deputy mayor. And I'm interested in running for mayor because I think that my experience qualifies me for the top job. And that is what I really think needs to be done, because only at the top job can you make the kinds of changes in the educational system which I made at the City University. So therefore, you need to be in a position to make decisions for yourself and that's why I would not join you.

Q. Do you have a question for Mr. Bloomberg, Mr. Badillo?

BADILLO -- Yes. Mr. Bloomberg, you wrote in your book, "Bloomberg by Bloomberg," that nobody should start at the top. In fact, you said you don't start English by reading Chaucer. . . . And I've said that you wouldn't send a general to fight a war who has never been in battle. What makes you think that you are qualified to be mayor of New York City with absolutely no experience?

BLOOMBERG -- Well, I -- the fact of the matter is, I do have all the experience. If you take a look, each period has a different requirement. When Rudy came in, crime was the biggest problem. His experience was as a prosecutor, not in city government. When Ed Koch came in, Ed had had only two years in city government as a city councilman but most of his experience was nine years in working in Washington. The experience you need is real-world experience. Nobody -- we don't need professional politicians. And being able to manage, being able to lead, being customer-focused, being innovative, being able to stand up for what you believe in, being accountable -- those are the skills that the mayor needs. And the real-world people that have come in, like Koch and Giuliani, have done a great job, have left the city infinitely better when they got out of office than when they came in. And I can follow them. . . .

Q. Where are you on school vouchers, Mr. Badillo?

BADILLO -- I would support school vouchers, but I don't think that they are the answer to the problem. It's a good idea to have school choice. I support charter schools. Because in having some choice, we are able to come up with ideas which we might not have thought of about how to improve the public school system. But nothing is going to replace the public school system. And increasingly overwhelmingly the issue is going to be, how do we change the public school system? And that's why I would give that a priority. The other things are peripheral issues.

Q. But yes to vouchers for private schools as far as that would go?

BADILLO -- Yeah, but it doesn't amount to anything significant.

BLOOMBERG -- I have no problems with privately funded vouchers. Publicly funded vouchers are just not going to happen in our lifetime in this city. And I agree with Mr. Badillo. You have to focus on providing the best public school education for the 1 million 100 kids that go there. I do think we should always try new things. There's nothing wrong with competition for the public school system so that they get better and they get new ideas and they feel that they have to deliver a service. . . .

Q. Is Mayor Giuliani right to be withholding money from the public schools right now? Mr. Badillo?

BADILLO -- Yes. I prepared the budget at the request of Mayor Giuliani in 1994, and I showed at that time that there was a huge amount of waste. For example, I showed that special education cost one-quarter of the budget and that the cost of special education was $25,598 per student, which is more than it would cost to send the kid to a private school in Manhattan. And the categories that they use for special education were not the categories that we approved in Congress. What was happening was that kids who were disruptive were being sent to special education and that hundreds of millions of dollars were being wasted on just that one area alone.

Q. And you were on this program at that time and there were cuts in the bureaucracy after that. And Chancellor Levy just eliminated another, what, 300 positions from the bureaucracy? Should the mayor still -- you still think the mayor should be withholding?

BADILLO -- There are more cuts on the way. I mean, the chancellor himself says that he wants to cut 1,500 positions, but he's going to do it over three years. If the positions need to be cut, why wait three years? Why not do them now? That's why the mayor wants to eliminate the Board of Education, and that's why I support the mayor on that issue.

BLOOMBERG -- There's a game being played here. The mayor is trying to force change. The only ability he has to do that is by withholding money. The bureaucracy doesn't want the change. What they always do in a case like that is, they threaten to go after the most important thing rather than the things that you want them to cut. I think in the end they'll clearly work this out. . . .

Q. Would you want Harold Levy to continue as chancellor if you become mayor?

BLOOMBERG -- Well it's much too early to tell in picking staff. And Harold Levy I know, he's an honest person, he cares very much. The results during his administration are not what we would like. He would agree with that. What you do is you have a search and you find the best chancellor that you can. If Harold Levy's interested in continuing on, he should be in the pool of people we consider.

BADILLO -- No, I would not want to keep him. He is the best example of why a business leader should not be mayor of New York City. Because the fact is that here is a man who claims to be a business leader and yet there's a cost overrun of about $3 billion in the capital budget. Which means that dozens and dozens of schools that were supposed to be built are not going to be built. And he knew about this and did not tell ----

BLOOMBERG -- Look, we can pile on Harold Levy ----

BADILLO -- Excuse me, do not interrupt, please. I did not interrupt you. He did not reveal this to the mayor or to the City Council. No. 2, he claims to have eliminated social promotion, but in fact he sent 350,000 parents letters saying that the kids would be left back if they did not pass the test. It turns out that two-thirds of them did not pass the test, and they're being promoted anyway. So therefore this is a facade, it's a mirage. And I want public officials who keep their word, and if they say that they're going to do something, they'll do it. And I would therefore not keep Chancellor Levy.

BLOOMBERG -- Blaming one guy is ridiculous. The school board knew and didn't do anything, parts of the City Council knew and didn't do anything, the group that builds all these schools knew and didn't do anything. I'm not defending Harold Levy any more than anybody else. But let's -- it's not one person. It is a whole system that is out of control, reports to nobody, and not one person. That's the trouble with politicians, they think that they can change one thing and leave the whole structure the same and get results. That's not what you have to do here.

Q. Money is obviously an issue in this race. Mr. Bloomberg, you had spent $16 million as of early August. I guess it must be over $20 million by now. Mr. Badillo, you told me before that only this week you have reached even the $250,000 in small donations required to get public matching funds. What a contrast. Mr. Bloomberg, how should people think of your campaign spending?

BLOOMBERG -- Well, I came to New York City with debts and a dream. I made all my money, and I'm spending some of it to tell people who I am and to get my message out. It's provided for under all of the laws. John McCain is campaigning for me, does an ad for me, doesn't have any problems with it. It's ridiculous to think that you can buy an election. All you can do, and if you're an outsider you have to have some money to do it, is go and tell people who you are, look them in the eye. I'm trying to go to every single neighborhood in this city and shake every hand I can and explain to people who I am, what I stand for, why they should vote for me, and what I will do after I get elected. And the money clearly helps. And I'm sympathetic to Mr. Badillo and his quest to raise money. It is very difficult, and you have this whole issue of special interests. People give money because they want access or they want influence. In my case, you don't have anybody that will have any influence or any access special from anybody else. I'm my own man, it's my money, and I have to report only to those people that I meet in every neighborhood. Not to money bundlers, not to fund raisers, not to special interests.

Q. Mr. Badillo, how do you think people should think of his self-financing?

BADILLO -- I think they should be outraged. I came to New York City when I was about 12 years old from Puerto Rico. I had no parents, I had no money, I couldn't speak the language, and I worked my way up. And I got involved in public life and I was able to move ahead because of education. And for many years, I have been working to change the campaign finance laws so that people like me can have an opportunity to move ahead and to run for major office. And what Mr. Bloomberg is doing is nullifying the campaign finance laws of New York City, which are the most liberal in the city. And the reality is that he said he is supported by the Republican Party leaders. Of course he is subject to special interests. I'm not -- I don't have any special interests because nobody have given me any real money. And so therefore I am and historically have been a truly independent candidate who takes a fixed point of view. But we cannot continue to have billionaires running for major office because that is damaging to the very fabric of democracy. . . .

Q. Considering how long you've been in politics and how many people you know, you've only barely been able to raise the $250,000 from a thousand or more donors required for the public matching funds. Is that a sign of a lack of real support out there?

BADILLO -- No, it isn't at all. It's only because people are afraid of Mr. Bloomberg's money, and I know because they've told me so. . . .

Q. Mr. Bloomberg, what do you think?

BLOOMBERG -- Nelson Rockefeller spent -- by today's standards Nelson Rockefeller spent more than anybody's probably ever spent. J.F.K. spent an enormous amount of their own money. Lots of people do that. . . .

Q. Mr. Badillo, a lot of New Yorkers who will reach the five-year federal lifetime limit on welfare this year will apply for state benefits. Should they automatically qualify?

BADILLO -- Absolutely not. I agree with Mayor Giuliani that they should be called into the jobs centers that Mayor Giuliani has established and they should be evaluated to find out why during that five-year period they were unable to find a job. And to help them to find a job but not to be getting automatic help, because if you get automatic help they'd never go off welfare. That was the problem that we had before, where we had generation after generation of people staying on welfare with no basic change.

BLOOMBERG -- The people that we're talking about generally are not those that have been able to get jobs or will get jobs. And you just can't say to them, "Well, you come in." We have to go out and outreach to them. We just -- otherwise they're going to be sleeping on the streets, their children are going to go hungry. You just can't do that. We're a compassionate society. Nobody wants to waste money, but these people need help.

Q. Automatic qualification?

BLOOMBERG -- No, I didn't say that. But we have to go out to them, not expect them to come to us.

HEADLINE: Fed Is Trying to Determine How Assets Affect Spending 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Aug. 31 

 BODY:
Hoping to get a better fix on how household wealth affects consumption, the Federal Reserve is trying to sort out the ways in which different assets -- stocks or homes, for example -- affect consumer spending, Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, said today.
 A rule of thumb used by many economists is that for every one dollar increase in a household's wealth, the members of that household increase their spending by 3 to 5 cents. The Fed has found, however, that when a home is sold, the seller's consumer spending goes up 10 to 15 cents for every dollar of capital gain, Mr. Greenspan said. 
 Such information is helpful in planning interest rate policy at a time when household wealth invested in stocks is shrinking while home values are rising. "In such circumstances, differences in the propensities to consume out of the capital gains and losses on different types of assets could have significant implications for aggregate demand," Mr. Greenspan said.
Mr. Greenspan spoke at the opening session of the Fed's annual symposium in this mountain resort, a gathering, organized by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, that draws most of the Fed's policy makers. Economists from Wall Street and academia also attended, along with a few foreign officials. It was Mr. Greenspan's first public appearance since the Fed cut interest rates last week by one-quarter of a percentage point -- its seventh cut of the year -- in an effort to revive the weak economy.
Rather than discuss Fed policy and the slowdown -- a topic that could stir up the markets -- Mr. Greenspan devoted his 20-minute speech to a neutral discussion of the Fed's efforts to sort out the wealth effect and its impact on spending. The Fed's seven interest rate cuts this year have been aimed in large part at encouraging consumers to spend and at sustaining home prices and home construction.
Because "consumer spending has amounted to 90 percent of income, it might appear that income is largely sufficient to explain consumption," Mr. Greenspan said. But the Fed's studies tell a different story. "Wealth by itself now appears to explain about one-fifth of the total level of consumer outlays," the chairman said.
Although dollar for dollar, capital gains on home sales appear to have a more powerful effect on spending than rising stock market wealth, the latter plays a bigger role in the end because of the huge scope of equity holdings, Mr. Greenspan said. "Household capital gains on directly held equities and mutual funds in recent years have been two to four times the size of overall gains on homes," he said.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Debate Becomes Battle On Credentials 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
Meeting for the first time in a debate, the Republican mayoral candidates, Herman Badillo and Michael R. Bloomberg, played up their starkly different backgrounds yesterday and defended their party credentials. Each insisted he was the right kind of Republican to lead New York City, which is overwhelmingly Democratic, at a time of economic uncertainty.
 Though neither candidate dominated the hourlong radio broadcast on WNYC-AM, Mr. Badillo, a career government official who has been overshadowed in the primary campaign, was more aggressive in trying to distinguish himself. 
 When Mr. Bloomberg talked about his vast personal wealth in the context of modest roots -- "I came to New York City with debts and a dream" -- Mr. Badillo shot back with his own humble story. 
"I came to New York City when I was about 12 years old from Puerto Rico, " Mr. Badillo said. "I had no parents, I had no money, I couldn't speak the language, and I worked my way up." 
The debate was noteworthy for Republican voters interested in hearing the two candidates interact because Mr. Bloomberg has agreed to only one other face-to-face encounter before the Sept. 11 primary.
It was held at WNYC under strict conditions. One photographer and one cameraman were permitted in the studio for the first nine minutes. After that, they were required to work through a soundproof window from an adjoining room. No print journalists were permitted in the studio, where Mr. Badillo and Mr. Bloomberg sat with the moderator, Brian Lehrer, around an octagonal table. The two candidates were separated by an empty chair.
In one of Mr. Badillo's stinging and more telling remarks, he said the tumultuous tenure of Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy should be seen as evidence that Mr. Bloomberg, a billionaire who owns a huge communications company but has never held public office, would be best advised to stay out of government.
"He is the best example of why a business leader should not be mayor of New York City," Mr. Badillo said of Mr. Levy, who worked as an executive at Citigroup before taking the schools job last year.
Mr. Bloomberg, who has been accused of ducking direct encounters with his rival, appeared mostly unperturbed by Mr. Badillo's assertiveness and sought to exude the confidence of a front-runner. He stuck to the familiar themes of his daily campaigning and refrained from making the kind of off-the-cuff remarks that have sometimes tripped him up and garnered negative media coverage.
Though he has been critical of Mr. Levy in his speeches, Mr. Bloomberg would not say yesterday whether he would keep him as chancellor, insisting that any good manager would give all applicants a fair review. And when given the opportunity to pose a question to Mr. Badillo, Mr. Bloomberg offered a not-so-subtle indication of where he thinks the Republican contest is headed: He asked Mr. Badillo to accept a job in a Bloomberg administration.
"I'd love to have the benefit of your wisdom, and I think you could be a big plus to my administration," Mr. Bloomberg said.
Mr. Badillo, who said he was overqualified for a job like that, spent much of the debate portraying Mr. Bloomberg, 59, as unfit for the city's highest office because he has no experience in governing. Whenever possible, Mr. Badillo, 72, injected his own resume into the discussion, relating experiences from his nearly 40 years in government and ticking off his previous job titles, from Bronx borough president to congressman.
When it was his turn to ask Mr. Bloomberg a question, Mr. Badillo kept with the theme of experience.
"You wrote in your own book, 'Bloomberg by Bloomberg,' that nobody should start at the top," Mr. Badillo said. "In fact, you said you don't start English by reading Chaucer." He then asked, "What makes you think that you are qualified to be mayor of New York City with absolutely no experience?"
Later, Mr. Badillo turned to another of his favorite topics: Mr. Bloomberg's fortune. He accused the self-made billionaire of damaging "the very fabric of democracy" by using his personal wealth to finance his mayoral campaign. In a campaign finance statement filed yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg, who is paying for his own campaign, reported spending $20 million on the primary race, more than 50 times what Mr. Badillo reported.
"We cannot continue to have billionaires running for major office because that is damaging to the very fabric of democracy," Mr. Badillo said. "Because you exclude 99.9 percent of the population, unless you get someone who's as stubborn as I am and is not deterred by the power of money."
In a message clearly intended for the narrow pool of Republican primary voters who will determine his fate, Mr. Badillo also challenged Mr. Bloomberg's credentials to carry the Republican banner, noting Mr. Bloomberg's long affiliation with the Democratic Party before he switched parties last fall. Mr. Badillo said he enjoys the support of grass-roots Republican groups that have not been seduced by Mr. Bloomberg's money.
"If you want to be the mayor of New York City, as a leader in the Republican Party, you have to say that you are a real Republican, which I am," Mr. Badillo said. "And the problem is that Mr. Bloomberg in none of his commercials says that he's a Republican. And in fact he says it doesn't really matter."
Mr. Bloomberg said that his success in private business gives him managerial skills that are particularly relevant as the city enters a period of economic change. He said he sympathized with Mr. Badillo's difficulty in raising money for his campaign, but he said a Mayor Bloomberg would not be beholden to special interests because of his financial independence. To bolster his claim, Mr. Bloomberg announced that Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who has been the lead architect of campaign finance reform, had endorsed his candidacy in a new television advertisement.
And as a proven entrepreneur, Mr. Bloomberg said, he would not be trapped by the old ideas of a career politician.
"The experience we need is real-world experience," Mr. Bloomberg said. "We don't need professional politicians. And being able to manage, being able to lead, being customer-focused, being innovative, being able to stand up for what you believe in, being accountable -- those are the skills that the mayor needs."
Mr. Bloomberg had a tougher time when it came to questions by both Mr. Badillo and Mr. Lehrer, the moderator, about his Republican bona fides. Though Mr. Badillo is also a former Democrat, he first ran on the Republican line in 1993 in the comptroller's race but did not officially change his registration to Republican until 1998. Mr. Bloomberg switched late last year when he made the political calculation that he could not win in the more crowded Democratic mayoral primary.
Yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg refused to disclose how he voted in last year's presidential race or in the Democratic presidential primary, when he was still a registered Democrat. He also would not say whether he voted for Hillary Rodham Clinton or Rick A. Lazio in the New York Senate race.
"I said that I'm trying to pull people together, not tear them apart," Mr. Bloomberg said. "Who I voted for in the privacy of the booth doesn't matter; it's what I'm going to do once I'm mayor."
Mr. Bloomberg used the word "compassion" several times in discussing his political philosophy -- apparently a reference to President Bush's "compassionate conservatism" -- and said it was the Republican Party leadership in New York that approached him about running for mayor.
He said that he agreed with Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, both Republicans, "on most things."
"I agree with them on how we have to have some compassion for people who are left out, how we have to have good fiscal policies and make sure that we keep taxes down, how we have to build up people rather than tear them apart and make this government work for everybody," Mr. Bloomberg said.
Despite their appeals to Republican voters, both candidates flunked the ultimate test of party loyalty when Mr. Lehrer posed it. Would the loser support the winner of the Republican primary?
Mr. Badillo declined to answer, saying it was a hypothetical question. He did not mention it, but he has also petitioned the Board of Elections to create a new party for the November general election, Citizens and Labor Unity, with him as the mayoral standard bearer.
Mr. Bloomberg said he would still be in the race as a candidate on two other lines, the Independent Party and a new party he recently established, the Student First Party.
After the debate, Mr. Badillo complained to reporters that Mr. Bloomberg would not debate more often, and Mr. Bloomberg's campaign complained that Mr. Badillo had waffled on some issues. For example, Mr. Badillo said yesterday that he supported school vouchers, but he had previously said they were unconstitutional. Mr. Badillo on Thursday joined critics of cuts in school spending, but yesterday he defended the cuts.
James S. Vlasto, a spokesman for Mr. Badillo, said his positions on the vouchers are not contradictory, but Mr. Vlasto conceded that Mr. Badillo "possibly misunderstood" Mr. Lehrer's question about school spending cuts.
