HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 09-02-01; 
Our Lies, Our Selves

BYLINE:  By John Leland; John Leland is a style reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
A couple of years ago, for professional reasons, I found myself in midair above the stomach of a man who worked for an insurance company. I stomped; the man lay motionless; I stomped again. I had enrolled in a professional wrestling school, to pursue an assignment, but also a personal obsession. At the time, wrestling was changing its focus, from the fake grappling in the ring to an intricate web of "story lines" that writers were fabricating around it, often filmed as behind-the-scenes revelations. These added a second or third layer of unreality commenting on the first. It was addicting and, in its play on the borders between truths and untruths, quite revealing. You can tell a lot about a culture by the lies it embraces. 
 The lies are piling up in interesting places these days. The Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Joseph J. Ellis recently admitted to having lied about serving in Vietnam; last month, Mount Holyoke College suspended him without pay for a year. The same week, a Los Angeles County judge named Patrick Couwenberg was dismissed for embellishing his record in the war. John Bayley, husband of the late Iris Murdoch, invented the title characters to his memoir "Widower's House: A Study in Bereavement. Or, How Margot and Mella Forced Me to Flee My Home," composing them from bits of real people and real sex. Even ad copy has found novel ways to dissemble. Sony Pictures invented a critic to produce bland blurbs for "The Animal" and "A Knight's Tale," fabrications not so much of essence as of source. The studio also admitted to planting shills in its man-on-the-street ads for "The Patriot." 
 We play, too, in large numbers, by inventing identities online, or accomplishing a similar sleight through older technologies. A recently noted fashion trend is to wear someone else's history on your T-shirt, bought off the rack. With a swipe of a credit card, you too can represent Lakeland Varsity Lacrosse, State Champs 1993.
Wrestling was simply ahead of its time: in an information economy, we are finding out, information is there not just to be bought and sold, but also to be made new and improved. The way to create a better product is to invent a better story behind it. 
As distortions go, these are not the lies of the Nixonian variety. They hew to the essential truths -- the widower's sexual reawakening, the course of Vietnam -- but twist the story behind the facts or the speaker behind the story. The ends can be financial or simply narcissistic. Inventing your credentials lets you be both subject and object, creator and created. Ellis, who wrote about Thomas Jefferson and John Adams without claiming to know them, can turn Vietnam into the Book of Joe, accessible to his students. And how nice that John Bayley can meet his semifictional characters and can watch them give him widower's love.
Two decades after English departments declared the death of the author, this hubbub of embellishment shows that the author is still very much alive, and often of as great interest as his or her text. We care whether the man who praised "The Animal" was a reviewer for The Ridgefield Press or a copywriter at Sony, or whether Ellis, in teaching his Mount Holyoke students about Vietnam, had been in the jungles. The persuasive wit of the Sony blurb, or the wisdom of Professor Ellis's lectures -- what we used to call the texts -- are just generic data on their own. Without a tweaked story enhancing their authorship, they lack brand appeal.
The story does not need to be flattering or to inspire trust. Bill Clinton, who built his brand on his gift for the artful dodge, just got a record $10 million advance for his memoirs, though you'd sooner expect a full reckoning from O.J. Simpson. David Brock, the formerly right-wing attack journalist, is flogging his new book, "Blinded by the Right: The Conscience of an Ex-Conservative," by declaring that his first book, "The Real Anita Hill," was a pack of distortions. "I'm coming forward to tell the truth now," he told N.P.R., "and that truth is I lied." Apparently, a track record of bending the truth does not discredit these new histories; it simply adds interest.
And like other lies, it pays off. Studies show that teenagers who are better at telling lies are also more popular. Beyond that, the fabrications themselves have a kind of Darwinian staying power. Peter Frost, a researcher at Rivier College in Nashua, N.H., showed students slides of a "crime scene," then gave them a script describing the crime, but with a few key details twisted (a copy of Vogue became Glamour, a hammer became a wrench). Initially the students recognized the false descriptions as misinformation. But over time, as the memories of what they actually saw faded, the misinformation lingered or even became more vivid.
For the story creators of professional wrestling or the fictional characters in John Bayley's memoirs, this is good news. Their stories will endure; we'll remember the fake movie critic long after we've forgotten "The Animal." As for me, I've given up wrestling in favor of varsity lacrosse. Did you know I was a state champ? 

GRAPHIC: Photo (Fox Photos/Hulton/Archive) Chart: "EVEN THE ANIMALS DO IT""The ability to deceive confers a reproductive advantage to organisms that by virtue of being deceptive avoid being killed and live to a reproductive age. . . . The innate hostility of surroundings in which a large part of life is spent struggling not to become food or, conversely, is spent struggling to catch food that is reluctant to be eaten, makes deception a useful item in any organism's kit. The ability to deceive is one of the many abilities or characteristics that have made some animals better equipped to survive than others. It therefore falls into the same category as long necks in giraffes, keen eyesight in birds, fleet-footedness in cheetahs and gazelles, and the sharp tooth and claw nature is famously red in. The struggle for life has favored the better mimickers and bluffers. . . . Instinct does the job for the lower animals; intelligence does it for the higher ones." From "The Concise Book of Lying," by Evelin Sullivan

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
Telling the Story of America With Masterworks

BYLINE:  By EDWARD M. GOMEZ; Edward M. Gomez is a United States corre- spondent for Raw Vision magazine.

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
AMERICANS like a good story especially about themselves. With "Picturing America," a complete reinstallation of its permanent collection of American art, the Newark Museum is now providing its own version of the national pageant from colonial times to the postmodern present. This freshly reconsidered survey of American art history is as inquisitive as it is revealing about its subject. It serves up some surprises, too.
 "From the start, we wanted to tell a story," said Joseph Jacobs, the curator of American art at the Newark Museum. "We attempted to see the art through the artists' eyes, to consider what their work meant for an emerging nation and, later, for a people examining its history and identity." 
 Since its founding in 1909, the Newark Museum has built up extensive holdings in painting and sculpture, folk art, textiles, Asian and African art, and other fields. It features a planetarium, a mini-zoo and the restored Ballantine House of 1885, the former residence of an affluent, ale-making family that has become a decorative-arts showcase.
Samuel C. Miller, the Newark's former director and current director emeritus, is credited with expanding the museum's holdings in many areas during his 25-year tenure, which ended in 1993. The last major installation of its American collection, which he oversaw nearly a decade ago, coincided with a renovation of its buildings and interiors by the Princeton-based architect Michael Graves. That presentation highlighted many of the Newark's signature treasures like "The Greek Slave" (1847), a marble statue by Hiram Powers and "Captain Jinks of the Horse Marines" (1879), a tall, painted-wood figure attributed to Thomas J. White. Connoisseurship was evident in the curatorial vision that shaped that earlier installation.
"Picturing America" shows that its organizers have assimilated the critical methods and lessons of recent decades and applied them to a new showing of the museum's American works.
"We wanted to look at the work within the broader contexts of the social, economic and cultural forces that helped shape it," Mr. Jacobs said. To that end, he and collaborators like the consulting curator Holly Pyne Connor, a specialist in 19th-century American art, and the staff designer Stephen Hutchins created an exhibition that both directly and suggestively poses questions about the making and meanings of the roughly 350 works on view. Sometimes it supplies immediate answers.
Lucy Brotman, the museum's education director, whose department played an active role in the $1 million, four-year reinstallation project, said: "We tried to anticipate visitors' questions. Plus, we thought: 'What are the questions we would like them to ask?' "
Thus, in each themed gallery, one object on display is scrutinized in what the exhibition's creators call "A Closer Look." Small text cards question and briefly explain the style, history or significance of each selected item. Viewers learn, for example, that the studiously formal "Portrait of the Four Youngest Children of William Rankin Sr." (1838), painted by Oliver Tarbell Eddy, was an homage to the seated girl in a yellow dress who is seen in the picture. The youngster had died; new research undertaken on this and other works in "Picturing America" revealed that her drooping bouquet of flowers and faraway stare, among other visual clues in the image, referred to her death.
Guest scholars like Richard Powell, a specialist in African-American art from Duke University, contributed to the reinstallation project, for which numerous artworks were newly restored. Overall, labeling in the galleries emphasizes artists' biographies less and the art's subject matter more. "We found that people generally want to know what a work is about," Ms. Brotman said.
"Picturing America" unfolds chronologically. Each gallery on two floors of the museum bears a thematic title (for example, "The Young Republic" or "The Gilded Age: Materialism and Escapism, 1875-1900") that guides visitors along a journey through American art history. Succinct remarks printed on free-standing plaque-pedestals explain the subjects, production techniques, historical references and aesthetic concerns of the works on display.
Throughout the exhibition, paintings, drawings, sculptures and decorative-art objects are shown together in an integrated way. No single work seems isolated in the kind of deliberately "neutral" setting that a typical white-box museum or commercial gallery tries to affect. Instead, "Picturing America" offers rooms painted in authentic colors of the periods whose art they represent: a rich, grassy green in an early-American gallery and stagecoach red in another for works from the Gilded Age.
The red chamber is set up salon-style, with paintings above paintings in neat rows, as they would have been hung in a high-society townhouse. There, a visitor's eye drifts from Thomas Waterman Wood's emblematic portrait, from 1884, of the good burgher Daniel S. Lathrop and his wife amidst the trappings of their wealth, to an actual, Japanese-style vase of the same era. Produced at an Ohio pottery, it resembles a ceramic vessel that is visible in the picture's foreground.
ELSEWHERE, "Picturing America" evokes the look and ambience of Alfred Stieglitz's legendary 291, the gallery that the photographer founded in 1904 at 291 Fifth Avenue to show pioneering examples of modernist art. In this section, with walls half-covered in gray burlap, artists whom Stieglitz showed are represented, including John Marin, Marsden Hartley, Morgan Russell and Georgia O'Keeffe.
Arthur Garfield Dove's "Abstraction No. 3" (1910), a tiny oil painting of rotund, purplish-gray forms, is on view; one of the museum's recent acquisitions, it is typical of the unexpected examples of strong works by major artists in small, concentrated doses that turn up throughout the collection. Another is Edward Hopper's "Sheridan Theater" (1937), with its melancholy glimpse of a lone woman, seen from the back, as she peers down at a stage from the standing-room section of what appears to be a mostly deserted auditorium.
"Picturing America" is notable for certain details, like the way it makes the point, with daguerreotypes and tintypes, that the new medium of photography had done much to displace commissioned portrait painting by the time of the Civil War. (Abraham Lincoln, looking sleepy, pops up in one such image from around 1858.)
Similarly, in its gallery of 19th-century landscapes, it dares to mix depictions of nature's majestic forms -- in pottery, a woven rug, a beaded vest -- by anonymous American Indian artisans with familiar Hudson River School vistas by the likes of Frederic Church and Thomas Cole. The eloquent Acoma, Sioux and Navajo pieces help bring the spirit-rattling, European-derived tableaus down to earth.
"It's all about trying to bring the art to life," Mr. Jacobs said. Visitors seeking a comprehensive overview of American art in the New York metropolitan area can still take in the offerings of the Metropolitan, the Whitney and the Brooklyn Museums; now, though, to overlook the way in which Newark's venerable downtown museum rounds out the picture provided by the three others is to miss an essential part of American art's special story, imaginatively told.

GRAPHIC: Photos: In "Picturing America" the Newark Museum shows off the reinstallation of its formidable collection of American art. Top, a gallery called "The Lure of Europe, 1875-1900" is painted period red; above, "Captain Jinks of the Horse Marines," 1879, a painted-wood figure attributed to Thomas J. White. (Photographs by Steven Brooke)

HEADLINE: Home Builders Settle Into Their Own Place 

BYLINE:  By NANCY DONIGER 

 BODY:
WHEN it was built in 1910, the Remington Arms Company factory with its nine-story tower in Bridgeport was the tallest building in Connecticut. The plant produced ammunition for the United States and its allies during World Wars I and II, employing 30,000 people at its peak.
 To this day, the 17 interconnected brick buildings in the factory complex dominate the East Side landscape as a lasting testament to the role the defense industry once played in the state's largest city. 
 Nowhere is the juxtaposition between the defense industry's preeminence and the post-cold-war era more manifest than at the former ammunition factory. 
Today, instead of housing America's oldest gun maker, the sprawling complex shelters a well-known housing ministry. A sign at the main entrance reads: "God's love in action: Habitat for Humanity of Bridgeport."
Last year, the Bridgeport affiliate signed a five-year lease with the Intertech Group, which owns and sublets the 987,000-square-foot complex, now called the International Enterprise Park.
Habitat is one of 39 tenants who lease space in Enterprise Park. Other tenants include cabinet makers, distributors, electronics companies, landscapers, artists and the Bridgeport Free Trade Zone.
Habitat, founded as a Christian ministry, embraces congregations of all faiths who believe in making safe and decent housing available to all people.
The Rev. Robert Knebel, who took over as Habitat's executive director in July, said that Christians, Jews, Muslims or anyone who shares the vision is welcome.
"The only kind of proselytizing that we do here is we infect people with 'habitatitis,' " Mr. Knebel said. "Our dream is to alleviate substandard housing in Bridgeport."
Before signing a lease in December 2000, Habitat occupied small warehouse spaces donated by the factory and did much of its work outside in the parking lot, Gary Hayduk, manager of the site, said.
But based on the group's substantial goals for projects in the coming years, Habitat needed more space to work year-round with a larger cadre of volunteers.
"Habitat started storing stuff in 1985 and got 15 years of free space," Mr. Hayduk said. "Now they lease space for their central warehouse, paint shop and production."
Before the munitions manufacturer pulled out of Bridgeport in 1986, Mr. Hayduk, his parents, grandparents and aunts and uncles worked a combined 200 years of service for Remington Arms. Mr. Hayduk's uncle worked in the tower where lead ingots were manufactured into gunshot.
The E. I. Dupont DeNemours Company purchased the remaining Remington Arms shares of stock in 1980 and moved its headquarters from Bridgeport to Wilmington, Del. Defense industry cutbacks and corporate consolidation led to the closure of the Bridgeport plant in 1986.
Remington Arms continues to supply ammunition to the military and sporting market from other sites. The Intertech Group purchased the Bridgeport complex in 1986 and produced shot from 1987 until 1991, through its RemGrit division, which also manufactured saw blades, lead products and shell casings, Mr. Hayduk said.
Artists especially like the high ceilings and 20-foot glass windows in some parts of Enterprise Park. Last year, Intertech sponsored an art show that attracted 500 people.
Mr. Knebel listened with interest as Mr. Hayduk described the success of the art show because Habitat is planning an open house this fall and hopes to attract an equally large number of potential volunteers and sponsors.
Habitat has set a goal of building 25 houses this year and a total of 140 houses by 2003, all financed through donations and built with volunteer labor.
Since the Bridgeport affiliate opened in 1985, volunteers have built or renovated 54 houses, all of them occupied. Another 13 are in progress and four more will be in the works this month. In terms of need, Mr. Knebel said that these figures only scratch the surface since 150 people want houses.
"Habitat is in Bridgeport because the need is greatest in Bridgeport," he said. "We are doing more than building houses. We are building lives, neighborhoods, community."
The organization makes an effort to preserve existing buildings if they have historical value, but constructing a new building is more economical, Mr. Knebel said.
Habitat is seeking to raise $2.5 million this year and $3.5 million in 2002 and 2003. Mr. Knebel said that Habitat could not single-handedly eliminate substandard housing in Bridgeport, adding that a commitment was also needed from religious congregations, the government, industry, individuals and nonprofit agencies.
Volunteers come to Bridgeport from across the nation. In August, church youth groups from Ithaca, N.Y. and North Andover, Mass., worked side-by-side in the warehouse. Earlier in the summer, a Chicago youth group helped build a house.
The majority of the 9,000 volunteers who have helped since 1985, however, come from Connecticut, Mr. Knebel said.
Habitat opened a new training division in July after merging with Youth Rebuild, a nonprofit agency that has worked since 1993 with more than 150 at-risk youths, ages 18 to 24, on over 25 Habitat houses. The trainees, referred by their probation officers or churches, earn their general equivalency diploma with the help of the program, said Gail Sullivan, the director of training.
The new division will integrate Youth Rebuild with training for Habitat families, most of whom have never been homeowners. The division will further train Habitat core volunteers, presently 65 strong, who are primarily retired people with carpentry skills who work during the week or those who help out on a long- or short-term basis, often on Saturdays.
To qualify for a Habitat house, prospective homeowners must pledge 500 hours of "sweat equity," which is pounding nails and contributing skilled or unskilled labor.
Ms. Sullivan said that it could sometimes take up to two years for families to fulfill the requirement.
Angel Hernandez, a warehouse manager, has been a Habitat homeowner for four years. He and his wife, Milagros, hold the Bridgeport record for completing their sweat equity hours in the shortest amount of time: two and a half months.
"I just kept thinking of the joy of knowing my daughter would be living in the house, and that it would be a safe place for her," Mr. Hernandez said. "Before that we were living with my in-laws, and it was very crowded.
"I spend a lot of time building other houses. I love the idea of helping other families get their home."
The actor Paul Newman sponsored the Hernandez family's house and also contributed sweat equity hours along with financial support for the construction.
To be a sponsor, an organization or individual must commit to finance part or all of the expenses and labor connected with the construction of a house.
The sponsors for 2001 include American Skandia, the Diageo Foundation, the Big Top Coalition, the Episcopal Bridgebuilders, the Lowenstein Foundation, Our Lady of Assumption RC Church and the Women Build HomeMakers Coalition.

HEADLINE: Refugee Finds His Way With Unending Work 

BYLINE:  By N. C. MAISAK 

 BODY:
IT has been nearly a quarter of a century since George Reisner fled his native Hungary for America, but he still can't talk about his escape without reliving every fearful moment. 
 It was September 1977. He was 29, a Jew in a sometimes inhospitable country, the son of an Auschwitz survivor. And he had wanted to get out of Hungary for as long as he could remember. 
 Mr. Reisner (pronounced RISE-ner) had a job pumping gas at a Shell station in Budapest. The pay was low, but he made a fair amount of money in tips and supplemented his salary by buying hard-to-find consumer goods in Yugoslavia, Poland and Czechoslovakia and reselling them on the black market in Hungary. He could well afford an expensive vacation. 
So he secured a spot on a government-sponsored tour of the United States: two and a half weeks cross-country, from Los Angeles and San Francisco to the Grand Canyon, Las Vegas, Washington and finally New York. And there, Mr. Reisner planned to disappear.
When he got to the airport in Budapest, he was jumpy. "I was so nervous that I was soaked with sweat," he said, placing his hand over his heart. "Once we took off, I started to relax because I figured that when we landed in Copenhagen to change planes, I would just get off and run if there were trouble."
There wasn't. Mr. Reisner reached New York without incident and put his plan into action. He asked permission to leave the group to meet a friend. He stood in Times Square and waved goodbye to the other members of his tour group as they boarded a sightseeing bus. As soon as they were out of sight, he ran back to the hotel, threw his clothes into his suitcase and left a note in his room: "Don't wait for me."
For three days, he hid out in Manhattan at his friend's, terrified that the Hungarian police would track him down. 
"The No. 1 reason I left was because I am Jewish," Mr. Reisner said. "My mother had always regretted not leaving Hungary after she got out of the concentration camp. Growing up, she told me, 'You're Jewish, and there's nothing you can do about it, but it doesn't mean that everyone has to know.' I always felt like people hated me, like I didn't belong there."
Mr. Reisner had done well in Budapest, and he thought he could prosper in the United States. "I was determined to make it here even if I had to live on the street," he said.
His determination paid off. Mr. Reisner, now 52, and his wife, Rutika, own Antiques & Jewels on Main, an antique jewelry shop that has become a fixture on Main Street in Huntington Village. In fact, the shop is like an Old World salon, where customers congregate to chat. 
"The shop is a treasure," said Dina McElroy of Huntington, who has been buying there regularly for nearly two decades. "They truly have become my family jeweler -- my two daughters have done all the jewelry rites of passage there. George has the most exquisite taste in jewelry and an eye for elegance."
But Mr. Reisner's success was not without struggle. He knew no English and only a couple of people in New York. One of them was his mother's cousin, who gave him a place to stay and found him a job as a go-fer at an antique jewelry shop on the Upper East Side.
"The hardest thing for me about America was understanding the system," Mr. Reisner said. "In Hungary under communism, the government took care of everyone, from cradle to grave. Over here, you have to do everything yourself." 
For Mr. Reisner that meant working seven days a week at the jewelry shop. "Eventually, I got some of my money from Hungary, and I started buying things for myself and putting them in the shop," he said. "When they sold, we split the profits."
It was a chance encounter in January 1980 that landed him on Long Island. He happened to run into an acquaintance in the diamond district who asked him, "Do you want to get married?" 
To which Mr. Reisner replied, "Why don't you give me her number first?"
The number belonged to Rutika Weiss, who had just opened a jewelry shop on Main Street in Huntington Village. Her parents were Hungarian Jews who had fled to Israel after losing most of their relatives in the Holocaust. They settled on Long Island when their daughter was 4.
"She didn't have much merchandise for the shop, so once we started going out, I would come out to help her," Mr. Reisner said. "I was still working seven days a week in the city, and I asked for one day off, then two days off. When it became serious, I asked for three days off, and they laid me off. That's when I decided to start my own business."
He and Ms. Weiss also decided to marry, which they did in June 1980. That, in turned out, was a bleak time in the jewelry business. There was a recession, and gold prices were going through the roof: at their peak, an ounce of gold sold for $850. "Christmas 1981, we almost went under," Mr. Reisner said. "We had had no customers, and we had just bought a house, so we had no money. We were down to the 24th of December. We made a large sale that afternoon that saved us, but it was an out-of-town check, and we were afraid it would bounce."
It didn't, and pretty soon, business started to bounce back. "We worked seven days a week," Mrs. Reisner said, no small feat while raising two daughters, Alexandra, now 16, and Joanna, 13. "Every year got better and better. We never took out any loans or borrowed any money. We did without a lot of things."
In between running the shop and traveling around the country to jewelry shows, Mr. Reisner completed courses in art history and jewelry appraisal at the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University.
In 1996, using savings and money they had inherited, the couple bought the shop that houses Antiques & Jewels.
Looking back, Mr. Reiser said that he has never regretted his decision to come to the United States. "The first time I was able to visit Hungary -- it was in 1986 -- I thought: 'I've lived here, and I've lived there. And I feel like America's really my home now.' "

A Diverse Island
This series looks beyond the stereotypes that sometimes taint relations between immigrants and native Long Islanders, examining immigrants' lives and how they are being woven -- or not -- into the social and economic fabric.

HEADLINE: Albany Has Schools Guessing and Cutting 

BYLINE:  By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
HOW can school districts try to budget for the coming year when they have no idea how much money they are going to get from the state?" asked Alicemarie Bresnihan, president of the Nassau-Suffolk School Boards Association.
 Educators throughout Long Island are asking the same question as they prepare for students' return to school this week without knowing how much state aid their districts will be receiving. 
 A budget proposed by Gov. George E. Pataki back in January that would increase state aid to education by $382 million -- up 2.8 percent from last year -- was rejected by the Legislature as too low. The Legislature and the governor avoided the record book for tardy budget-making by adopting a skeleton budget on Aug. 3, but negotiations over a final budget -- one that specifies disbursements to the state's 705 school districts -- remained at an impasse as officials headed into the long Labor Day weekend. 
"This is unprecedented," said Bruce Brodsky, Suffolk County's representative to the New York State School Boards Association.
But even if a deal were struck before students return to class this week, it would come too late to affect decisions that had to be made weeks earlier about important issues like teacher hiring, class size and the implementation of a prekindergarten program.
"This process has been extremely difficult without knowing how much state aid is coming in," Ms. Bresnihan said. "Some districts are more skeptical about the state's budget and have cut from what was approved in May, while others have been more willing to gamble and have gone forward with their programs."
In the Island's wealthier districts, which receive only a small percentage of their budget from state aid, the impact is less significant and may mean a small increase in their taxes. But in poorer districts, which rely more heavily on state funding, the absence of a state budget can mean drastic cuts in programs and services, as well as substantial tax increases.
In the William Floyd School District, for example, 64 percent of the total revenue comes from the state, said Rich Hawkins, the superintendent of schools, who is also president of the Suffolk Council of School Superintendents. 
"A late budget impacts those school districts that need help the most," he said. "We have already limited our spending and eliminated equipment expenditures, but now we also stand to lose up to 18 staff members and may have to cancel plans to reduce class size for our early grades. We expect to see our class size go up, while we'll also have to make cuts in our programs or drastically raise our tax rate. At a time when the state is asking for more accountability and raising the bar for learning standards, this is unconscionable." 
In Roosevelt, which receives almost 60 percent of its budget from the state, program cuts are inevitable and the district has already set its tax rate at an increase of 11.2 percent from last year, according to Mary Brisbane, a district spokeswoman. 
To make matters worse, Roosevelt is one of four Long Island districts already on an austerity plan because its school budget was defeated twice in the spring. The other districts on austerity are Sachem, Amityville and Wyandanch.
An austerity plan caps spending at 4 percent over the prior year's budget, except to cover costs of enrollment growth and debt service. For Roosevelt, this has meant having to trim its budget by $1.4 million, to $39 million. The superintendent of schools, Horace Williams, had proposed making those cuts by eliminating the district's athletic programs and laying off teachers. But the district's Board of Education recently asked that the district find alternatives to lowering the budget, arguing that too many students rely on sports for athletic scholarships to college.
In Suffolk, the Sachem School District also faces the economic hardship of an austerity plan. After a two-time defeat of its budget, the district was forced to cut the budget by $4 million, said James Ruck, superintendent of schools. This has meant the elimination of transportation for kindergarten, a cut in equipment, supplies and materials, and a reduction in teacher training.
"This is a serious problem," Mr. Ruck said. "We're bound by the rules of austerity, but at a time of more rigorous standards, cutting out staff development puts us at a disadvantage."
While many districts throughout the Island face similar problems, there has been one significant difference between districts in Nassau and Suffolk: the timing on their deadlines for setting their tax rates. 
In Nassau, the clock has run out. By Aug. 15, districts had to set their tax rates, even without knowing how much state aid would be coming to offset the property taxes. Suffolk districts, by contrast, have until the end of this month to make that decision. Administrators are hoping that a state budget will be settled by then, preventing them from having to raise taxes.
In Brentwood, if the final state budget is not in place, the district will face with a tax increase of 4 1/2 percent, said Les Black, superintendent of schools.
"People in this community can't afford that now," he said. "School districts have our feet held to the fire. While we had to have our budgets in place by May, the state has gone merrily along its way."
A late state budget has also put many question marks on construction projects planned by the majority of Long Island districts. After many districts approved bond issues for construction to accommodate rising student enrollment and to repair and renovate aging buildings, there is no assurance that districts will get the funding that was originally projected. 
In the Middle Country School District, the community approved a $33 million bond issue for expansion of its four middle schools, to meet the needs of the projected enrollment increase of 1,000 students over the next five years. The superintendent of schools, Connie Lorthridge, said: "We held off on the bids for as long as possible, because this bare bones budget wouldn't cover the costs of our project. But we've moved ahead and are hoping that the money will come through. At the same time, we're putting on hold other capital projects of boiler repairs and overdue renovations that were planned for this year in our general budget, while we wait to hear how much money we'll be getting from the state."
A $228 million project in Sachem, passed by voters last year to reconfigure the entire district, creating more space for rising enrollment, is counting on 82 percent of its funding from the state, based on the ratio under the existing formula, said Mr. Ruck, the superintendent, who added, "We're keeping our fingers crossed that the state won't take away any money that was promised for the construction."
Aside from money issues, a staffing shortage at the State Education Department has delayed approval of construction plans, further frustrating educators.
In East Hampton, where student enrollment has jumped by 3 1/2 percent since the end of June, plans call for moving the central administration office out of the middle school and into trailers to allow more room for students. Delayed by approval from the state, the trailers are now sitting in the high school parking lot, waiting to be moved by the middle of the month.
Rising student enrollment has further affected the economics of many school districts. This year student enrollment in Long Island's school districts is estimated at 480,000, with projections that the student population next year will exceed 500,000 for the first time, said Dr. Brodsky, the Suffolk representative to the state school boards association. In 1995, the student population was less than 400,000.
"More students means the need for more services," he said. "And that translates to more money. Right now, without a state budget, many school districts are in deep trouble, through no fault of their own."

HEADLINE: New Bishop Comes Ready to Do His Homework 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
WILLIAM FRANCIS MURPHY, soon to become the fourth bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, does not presume to be an expert on Long Island or the diocese of 1.5 million Catholics he will soon lead.
 "I know nothing," he said in an interview held last week at the chancery of the Archdiocese of Boston, where he is an auxiliary bishop and a top administrator. "You are looking at a very dumb guy." 
 That is a description used by no one who knows the 61-year-old priest, a Boston native who spent 13 years working at the Vatican. When he is installed on Wednesday, he will immediately become a leading public figure on Long Island. 
By several accounts, Bishop Murphy is a gregarious, charming man, energetic and enthusiastic, a devout and learned Catholic leader steeped in church orthodoxy but committed to interfaith understanding, and a seasoned administrator who listens well and then acts decisively.
Now, at an age when others look toward retirement, at the request of Pope John Paul II he is embarking on a new job that will call upon all his reserves and talents.
He succeeds James T. McHugh, who died of cancer in December after serving as the diocesan leader for less than a year.
The installation ceremony for Bishop Murphy will take place at St. Agnes Cathedral in Rockville Centre. He said farewell to Boston in a mass of thanksgiving celebrated at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross there on Aug. 9. 
Although Bishop Murphy grew up in the West Roxbury section of Boston, his years in Rome give him a European and international perspective. If nothing else, on Long Island he will have to adjust to a regional dialect, in which at its most extreme, "paahk the caah" becomes "pauwk the caw."
One of the most pressing problems he will have to address is the dwindling ranks of priests. The diocese, which has 577 priests, many of them elderly, has one of the worst priest-to-parishioner ratios -- 1 to 2,600 -- of any Roman Catholic diocese in the country. On the plus side, the diocese has the eighth-largest Catholic population of any diocese in the country and is financially among the strongest. 
As he prepares for his new post, Bishop Murphy said he would learn by listening and study. "I am beginning to do my homework," he said.
Bishop Murphy has an easy laugh and informal manner -- friends call him Bill and in the interview he slipped off his shoes while talking.
He said that one of his major goals on Long Island would be promoting interfaith understanding. Early on, he plans to seek out other religious leaders. "I want to be as collegial as I can be," he said.
In Boston, he was known as a champion of better relations between Catholics and Jews and had a close friendship with a Jewish civic leader, Leonard P. Zakim, who died of bone cancer two years ago. 
He said he would actively promote the priesthood as a vocation among young men, but in a departure from what the Rockville Centre diocese has said in the past, he declined to say there was a shortage of priests on Long Island.
"I am not going to use that term," he said. "What we have to do is show young people the opportunity for vocations in the life of the church. Young men have to be shown how wonderful and satisfying it is to be a priest." In keeping with church teachings and Catholic tradition, Bishop Murphy said he was opposed to allowing women to become priests. 
He said he was struck by the fact that the Long Island diocese had 134 parishes while the Boston archdiocese, with 2.2 million Catholics and 932 priests, had 365 parishes.
"I am sure the size of the parishes in the Rockville Centre diocese creates a tremendous challenge to a pastor trying to reach out to his people," he said. "I am not coming in with any blueprint or plan. I don't have one. I don't know enough yet. But I do think we have to take a look at that."
He said he would pay particular attention to Long Island's growing Hispanic population, which is overwhelmingly Catholic and increasingly diverse, ranging from long-established Puerto Ricans in Brentwood to Mexican day laborers whose presence on street corners in Farmingville and elsewhere on Long Island has created tensions.
"They will be aware that I am coming," said Bishop Murphy, who speaks Spanish but is not fluent in the language. He said his first parish mass would be on Thursday at Queen of the Most Holy Rosary in Roosevelt, which has a black and Hispanic congregation. 
Bishop Murphy will play a central role in setting a course for the 12 Catholic high schools and 59 Catholic elementary schools in Nassau and Suffolk. Their enrollment of about 40,000 students dropped slightly last year but has remained relatively stable in recent years, according to the diocese.
But tuition costs have been rising steadily, in part to meet salary expectations of lay teachers who now make of the majority of teaching staffs, and some families are finding the higher costs hard to meet. 
During his brief tenure, Bishop McHugh made salary increases for the lay teachers a priority but never carried out his plan to grant the raises. The schools are financed by a combination of tuition, fund-raising and parish subsidies.
Bishop Murphy said that the issue of higher salaries remained on the table, but noted that teachers in Catholic schools were paid substantially less than public school teachers in many parts of the country. 
"Obviously, if someone chooses to teach in a Catholic school, that in itself is an acceptance of an approach to education that is a mission, not just a job," he said. 
The new bishop will also preside over the corporate members of Catholic Health Services of Long Island, created by Bishop John R. McGann in 1997. The huge system, which by its own estimate provides 25 percent of all health-care services on Long Island, includes five hospitals with a total of nearly 1,700 hospital beds, three nursing homes and a variety of other medical service centers. It has 2,700 medical staff members and more than 13,500 employees. Total revenues exceeded $1 billion last year, and profits were $4 million. 
Ronald R. Aldrich, the health system's president and chief executive, said Bishop Murphy had extensive experience with a church health system in the Archdiocese of Boston. "This is a real plus for us," Mr. Aldrich said. "We feel very excited and very blessed that he is coming here."
Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Rockville Centre, which provides services and housing to the poor, the sick and the elderly, may also benefit from Bishop Murphy's experience with charities provided by the Boston archdiocese that are second in extent only to services provided by the state of Massachusetts. 
Daniel Sisto, the president of the Healthcare Association of New York State, in Rensselaer, said that hospitals in New York faced rising pressure because of cuts in federal aid to elderly and poor patients and slow reimbursement from insurers. "The Catholic system has not been immune to that," he said. "And because they have nursing homes, they have really been hit right along the continuum of care."
In reaction to just such financial pressures, Catholic Health Services joined the Long Island Health Network, whose members include non-Catholic hospitals like Winthrop-University, Mather Memorial and South Nassau. Network members cooperate in an effort to streamline services and contain costs. 
Bishop Murphy has made it clear he would follow in the steps of Bishop McHugh, an ardent opponent of abortion.
"We fulfill God's call to bring his love to the world when we preach the truth by being unambiguously pro-life, unfailingly pro-family, unalterably pro-poor," he said in his homily at the farewell mass in Boston.
In last week's interview, he said he did not support adoption of children by gays and lesbians. "I would oppose any act of unjust discrimination against people who are homosexual, and if that happens on my watch you can be sure I will protest it," he said. "But I also think a family is intended to be a man and a woman in lawful union and their offspring, either biological or adopted."
He said that while he opposed a decision by President Bush to provide federal money for research on a limited number of stem cell lines, he applauded the president for casting his decision in ethical terms.
The debate over the use of stem cells, he said, had been "reduced to nonethical questions of technology or, even worse, economics." 
"President Bush served us well because he spoke about the ethical issues," he said. "If utility is the only measure, that is anti-human."
Last week, anticipation of Bishop Murphy's arrival was running high. "Everyone is very excited that he is coming to Rockville Centre," said Msgr. Tom Hartman, the director of radio and television for the diocese who appears on the cable television program "The God Squad" and other programs on Telecare, a diocesan station. "This is one of the best dioceses in the country with among the most educated, sophisticated and influential people, and Bishop Murphy wants to come here."
Monsignor Hartman agreed with Bishop Murphy that large parishes posed a problem. "It's a huge diocese, and it has very big parishes," he said. "Some people feel as though they don't have an intimacy with their parishes, and that they are factories. He has to recognize that they are many parishes within each parish and that people go to church for different reasons. While he may not be able to build a lot of new parishes, he could look at programs that make the parishes more personal."
Monsignor Hartman's co-host on "The God Squad," Rabbi Marc Gellman, said that Bishop Murphy's mission to promote interfaith understanding would benefit from the already good relations between Catholics and Long Island's large Jewish population.
"I really believe that Long Island is a model for the rest of the country," said Rabbi Gellman, the president of the New York Board of Rabbis and the senior rabbi at Temple Beth Torah in Melville.
He said he had learned that Bishop Murphy "regularly speaks to confirmation students about the necessity of purging any shred of anti-Semitism from their Catholic identity."
Bishop Murphy said vigilance against racism and anti-Semitism was vital. "Anti-Semitism is the most ingrained prejudice of western culture," he said.
He said he would also seek out leaders of other religions,
Al-Haaj Ghazi Y. Khankan, the director of interfaith affairs and communications for the Islamic Center of Long Island, in Westbury, said that such contacts would be welcomed. "We are for strong dialogue between the Muslim and Catholic communities," he said. "There is so much to learn about each other."
He said there were about 70,000 Muslims on Long Island and more than two million in the metropolitan area. 
The Rev. Bill Brisotti, the administrator of Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal in Wyandanch, said he hoped Bishop Murphy would elevate the status of Hispanic Catholics. "They have got to rise to the next notch up," said Father Brisotti, who has worked with Hispanic Catholics for 30 years. "The 'they' must be integrated into the 'we.' " 
He said that Catholic clergy in far-flung corners of the diocese needed greater connectedness with diocesan leaders. "There is a tremendous need to encourage people out there working in the field," he said. "Right now there is a lot of frustration, and a sense that you are on your own."
Bishop Murphy prescribed prayer as the best means to surmount all problems. "We must be a community who prays," he said. "And the more we become a community of faithful prayer, the more we are going to be able to look at issues with strength and serenity, with a commitment to do what's good."

HEADLINE: First One Casino, Then Two. Now What? 

BYLINE:  By VIRGINIA GROARK 

 BODY:
FOR years, the tiny town of Union's biggest claim to fame has been its size. With 693 residents, it is the smallest municipality in Connecticut.
 But now this village nestled against the Massachusetts border near Interstate 84 is making headlines for a different reason: The Nipmuc Nation, a Sutton, Mass.-based tribe seeking federal recognition, reportedly has made inquiries about purchasing property in the town. Union residents fear the tribe, which has an agreement with a Minnesota-based casino management company, wants to make their town the site of the state's third casino. 
 "Everybody is up in arms over it," Selectman Nathan Swift said. 
Nipmuc officials said they have not committed to any real estate acquisitions and a spokesman insisted the tribe's focus is on Massachusetts. But mere speculation about a casino was enough to prompt Union to join a growing list of municipalities that are monitoring the United States Bureau of Indian Affairs as it considers handfuls of petitions filed by Connecticut groups seeking federal tribal recognition.
Across the state, 10 groups have announced their intentions to seek federal recognition, placing Connecticut among the top states in the country with the most number of groups bidding for recognition. Two tribes, of course, have already been successful: the Mashantucket Pequots and the Mohegan Indians, whose casinos generate more than $1 billion in combined annual gross revenues.
In the next two years, the Bureau of Indian Affairs could make final determinations on at least three other Connecticut-based groups: the Eastern Pequots, the Paucatuck Eastern Pequots, both of North Stonington, and the Schaghticokes Indians of Kent.
If recognized, the tribes would be given special rights that have significant consequences, like putting land into trust so it is exempt from taxes and local zoning control.
But it is the prospect of more federally recognized tribes opening casinos in the state that has created controversy and skeptics, especially because half of the Connecticut petitioners started the process after the Mashantuckets opened the wildly successful Foxwoods Resort Casino in 1992. 
"There's huge money that is backing these groups for the purpose of casinos," said Preston First Selectman Robert Congdon. "It raises the question of 'is the recognition process about preserving Indian culture or is it about building casinos'."
Aurelius Piper Jr., the chief of the Golden Hill Paugussett Tribal Council, who is known as Chief Quiet Hawk, is sensitive to such claims. Though the Paugussetts would like to open a casino in Bridgeport if recognized, Mr. Piper noted that the tribe's quest for federal recognition began nearly 20 years ago, long before gaming was an option.
"We never started off dealing with that issue," Mr. Piper said. "It was a matter of trying to house, educate, take care of members of the tribe, our elderly and our young and trying to live our culture and heritage." 
Established in 1978, the federal recognition process is a complicated and cumbersome task that requires tribes to meet seven criteria. Groups must not only trace their lineage to a historical tribe but demonstrate they have lived continuously as a tribe, both socially and politically, among other things.
While dozens of groups announced their intentions to seek federal recognition in the late 1970's and early 1980's, the stakes grew with the passage of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act in 1988, which permitted federally recognized tribes to have casinos if they obtain the proper approvals. 
That law enabled the Mashantuckets, who were recognized through an act of Congress in 1983, to open Foxwoods.
The casino's success gave new significance to federal recognition in Connecticut and spawned a second wave of petitions in the late 1990's. Between 1997 and 2000, five groups filed letters of intent to petition for federal recognition.
Suddenly, internationally known casino developers like Sol Kerzner, who became partners with the Mohegan Indians, and Donald Trump, who teamed up with the Paucatucks, set their sites on the state.
The infusion of gaming dollars and allegations that federal officials violated Bureau of Indian Affairs procedures was enough to prompt Attorney General Richard Blumenthal to deem the system "broken" and call for a moratorium on tribal recognition decisions until the process is reformed. 
"I have been very critical of the whole recognition process, because I think it's much too susceptible to improper influence of money and politics and needs to be more objective and more open and fair," Mr. Blumenthal said. 
Mr. Blumenthal and officials from three southeastern Connecticut towns have sued the Bureau of Indian Affairs and the United States Department of Interior in federal court earlier this year, claiming procedures were violated in the bureau's review of the Eastern Pequots' and Paucatucks' petitions.. As part of the court proceedings related to the lawsuit, a federal judge set a timetable for the review of the tribes' petitions, which received preliminary approval in March 2000. Under that order, the bureau is scheduled to make a final determination in early December.
The two tribes, which share a reservation in North Stonington, intend to pursue gaming ventures if they are recognized. 
Backed by Eastern Capital Development of Southport, the Eastern Pequots proposed building a casino at State Pier in New London but withdrew the plan in July after the New London City Council failed to support the proposal. 
Nancy Tyler, a spokeswoman for the Eastern Pequots, said the tribe is considering sites in other towns in the region, but she would not elaborate.
The Paucatucks have no firm development plans, because they said they believed it is premature to discuss proposals without federal recognition, Jon Crane, a tribal spokesman, said. But the tribe's intent to pursue gaming became clear when it joined with Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts. The tribe also has a business relationship with Amalgamated Industries, a Connecticut investment company.
"Assuming there is federal recognition, you can most certainly make that assumption that a casino would be part of the plan at that point," Mr. Crane said. 
In western Connecticut, the Schaghticokes, who number almost 320 and have a reservation in Kent, said they hope to receive a final determination on their petition in 2003. 
That is the time schedule set by a federal judge who is reviewing the tribe's land claims for thousands of acres owned by Kent School, the town of Kent, the federal government and others, said Tribal Chief Richard Velky.
If recognized, the Schaghticokes intend to pursue a gaming venture somewhere in Fairfield or New Haven counties, Mr. Velky said. He would not identify the tribe's financial backers.
"This is a long affair," Mr. Velky said, noting his tribe first filed paperwork with the bureau 20 years ago. "It's not done over night and even though people think it's over gaming, this is all to do with somebody's heritage and their culture."
Like the Schaghticokes, the Golden Hill Paugussetts have filed land claims, seeking thousands of acres in Trumbull, Bridgeport, Milford and Orange.
The tribe hopes to imitate the Mohegans, who used their land claims as a bargaining chip in negotiations with the state to open a casino, Mr. Piper said. 
"The tribe wants to settle the land claims to get some land for the tribe to live on as a whole," Mr. Piper said. "And then of course we would like to pursue some socio-economic development program for which they can support themselves."
Those development plans include a casino. The tribe, which has a quarter-acre reservation in Trumbull and another 102 acres in Colchester, is interested in opening a casino in Bridgeport.
It has the financial backing of developer Thomas Wilmot, whose Wilmorite Inc. owns the Danbury Fair Mall, Mr. Piper said. 
But first the Paugussetts must secure federal recognition. The tribe is in "administrative limbo" after being denied federal recognition in 1996, only to win the right to a full reconsideration of the petition in 1999, he said. Since then the tribe has sued the bureau to force it to place its petition before others on the list, Mr. Piper said. 
The other six Connecticut groups seeking federal recognition filed letters of intent to petition after Foxwoods opened.
The Mohegan Tribe & Nation, which is based in Norwich, contacted the bureau in 1992, but had not submitted any documentation as of February, according to the agency. Officials from the tribe could not be reached for comment. 
Two other tribes, the Nehantic Tribe and Nation of Chester and the Southern Pequot Tribe in Waterford, which filed letters in 1997 and 1998, respectively, could not be reached for comment. According to bureau documents, the Nehantic Tribe has not submitted documentation and the Southern Pequots have an incomplete petition.
The Pequot Mohegan Tribe, which has about 125 members, contacted the bureau in 1999, but has not submitted its documentation. The tribal chief, Van Thomas Green, said his group is distantly related to the Mashantuckets and Mohegans. He said his tribe intended to file land claims in the Norwich area, but is against gambling, he said.
"We're not trying to get rich," he said. "Money is the root of all evil." 
The Poquonnock Pequot Tribe, which has 112 members and claims to be of Western Pequot descent, filed its letter of intent to petition in 1999 after the Tribal Council debated for years the merits of seeking such status, said Paul A. Davis, a tribal spokesman. It has yet to submit its documentation.
Based in Ledyard, the group is sensitive to claims that they are simply trying to get rich. James Avery, a member of the tribal council, said he is willing to waive rights to gambling if the tribe is recognized. He said he believed most of the tribal council agrees with him, but the entire tribe would have to vote on it.
"Something that's that important we would have to put before the entire tribal body before we said we would give up gambling absolutely," he said.
The Western Pequot Tribal Nation of New Haven submitted its letter of intent to petition in November 2000. As of February, the group, which could not be reached for comment, had not submitted any documentation. 
And then there are the Nipmucs, who received a proposed positive finding by the Clinton administration on Jan. 19. The Bush administration is reviewing the decision.
Lakes Gaming of Minnetonka, Minn., is paying for the Nipmucs' federal recognition bid. In exchange, the tribe will join with the company if it pursues gaming, according to a tribal statement. 
Woodstock First Selectman Ernest Wetzel said he believed if the Nipmucs try to build a casino they will pick a site in Connecticut, because the state has allowed tribal casinos here. But he said Connecticut needs to come to terms with the impact of gambling on the state.
"Do we want to be the Las Vegas of the East?" he asked.

HEADLINE: Greenwich Goes Hollywood, and Beyond, With Film Festival 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA G. CHAMBERLAIN 

 BODY:
FILM buffs will get to mingle with filmmakers from Connecticut to California, as well as actors and actresses, Hollywood stuntmen and others from the movie industry when the first Greenwich Film Festival opens Wednesday for a four-day run.
 "Everyone in the world is captivated by films," said John Carley of Greenwich, the 35-year-old founder and president of the festival. 
 Mr. Carley, who works in a family-owned decorating and construction business, has attended film festivals from Cannes in France to Sundance in Utah. In planning the Greenwich event, however, he looked to the successful Santa Barbara Film Festival as a reference point. The two towns, he said, have much in common. 
"Greenwich is logistically situated to support a film festival," Mr. Carley said. "People can come into town and within easy walking distance can catch a screening, attend a reception and go to a workshop -- all in one day. If they arrive at the Greenwich Train Station, they'll step out into the middle of the festival."
Planning for the festival began about a year ago, he said, over the kitchen table of Maureen Lutz, the festival's director and a management consultant for nonprofits.
"When I was growing up, my dad would take me to the movies all of the time," Ms. Lutz said. "He would then talk about the actors and actresses as if he personally knew them." 
Mr. Carley's own interest in the film industry is an extension of his personal life. He once directed traffic in the rain for seven hours so a filmmaker friend could get the perfect shot.
"I have friends who went to film school and so I saw people who made some beautiful movies that never got viewed by the public," Mr. Carley said. "The feature films to be shown at our festival are all new and, as yet, undistributed. You're not going to see these films in the theater or on cable until next year."
Ten feature-length films as well as a number of short dramas and documentaries will be shown. Most of the films will have both afternoon and evening screenings from Wednesday through Saturday, at the Crown Plaza Theater, the Clearview Cinema and the Library Auditorium.
Among the feature films being screened is "Ghetto Dawgs" directed by Brian Averill. The film, about a young car thief who finds himself being pulled deeper into the dark world of drug dealing, dog fighting and murder, took first place at the recent Atlantic City Film Festival.
"The competition was quite decent and included a film with Peter Falk, so we were pretty excited about taking best picture," said Virgil Ranaudo of Jersey Bred Productions, one of the film's producers.
The film stars Drena DeNiro, daughter of Robert DeNiro, and Gianna Palminteri, who is Mr. Ranaudo's sister and one of the film's executive producers. Ms. Palminteri is married to the actor Chazz Palminteri, who is expected to attend the screenings of a number of different movies, according to Mr. Carley.
Another feature film, "Jack the Dog," a comedy about a photographer's adventures in truth and love that had its premiere at the Sundance Film Festival, has local ties. The film stars a Greenwich resident, Nestor Carbonell of the NBC sitcom "Suddenly Susan," which is now in syndication. A film having its festival premiere is "The Private Public," the story of a love triangle, directed by Dana Altman, grandson of the director Robert Altman.
The film "Revolution #9" directed by Tim McCann of Exile Productions in Piermont, N.Y. was screened previously for 100 people at the Los Angeles International Film Festival, Mr. Carley said. The film is described as a psychological thriller that examines the mental breakdown of a young man living in New York City.
More than a half-dozen workshops are planned, including a discussion of how to produce a documentary film on a shoestring that will be led by Harvey Hubbell, an independent filmmaker.
Guy Ortoleva, a lawyer and managing director of the Connecticut Film, Video, and Media Office, which is part of the state's Economic and Community Development agency, will lead two workshops: one on production incentives offered by the state and one on the legalities of filmmaking from copyright law to contracts.
"At the Greenwich Film Festival I'll have a representative with me from the Connecticut Consortium of Independent Filmmakers, which is a new trade group," Mr. Ortoleva said. "We have dozens of filmmakers in the state who may not know that someone in the next town is struggling to make a film or where there are good film crews or locations that are supportive to their filmmaking."
On Thursday evening at the Bruce Museum, a Lifetime Achievement Award will be presented to the actress Patricia Neal, who won an Oscar in 1963 for her performance in "Hud." The evening will include a screening of a short film "For the Love of May" that stars Ms. Neal. The film was written and directed by Mary McDonough of Los Angeles who played Erin in the television series "The Waltons."
"We created a special event around the screening of this film and the award to Ms. Neal," Ms. Lutz said. "Mary McDonough has lupus and proceeds from the reception and screening will benefit the Lupus Research Institute."
The award to Ms. Neal will be presented by the actress Glenn Close, who grew up in Greenwich; the two worked together in the movie "Cookie's Fortune."
The festival begins Wednesday with a reception at Saks Fifth Avenue, one of the sponsors.
Advance ticket sales have been slow, but steady, Mr. Carley said. Nearly 100 tickets have been sold for the $1,000 patron package, which includes two tickets to all events, movies, workshops and private parties. It will cost $100 for a movie pass that admits one person to all screenings and $10 for a single movie ticket, subject to availability. Admission to individual workshops costs $10 to $35, while special event tickets are $50 to $150.
Information about festival events and schedules is available at www.GreenwichFilmFestival.org. Individual tickets to all workshops and events are available at the festival's headquarters, 410 Greenwich Avenue, corner of Railroad Avenue, 2nd floor, or by calling (203) 661-4554.

HEADLINE: COUNTY LINES; 
History: Everything You Need to Know

BYLINE:  By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
YOU'VE forked over roughly the gross domestic product of Liechtenstein to send your kids to camp and they're back already? Was that the way it was supposed to work? 
 Not only are they back, but they're also about to resume the school year grind -- rising at ungodly hours, strapping on backpacks equaling the tonnage that Hannibal's elephants lugged across the Alps and studying cosines, logarithms, chemical valences, Latin and the other things you've found so useful as you've gone through life. 
 Which brings us to one of those subjects -- history. 
Experts see two big problems with studying history these days. First, is time. Between soccer practice, French horn lessons, SAT prep classes and the Intel Nuclear Bomb Making Competition, kids only have so much time for the Ming Dynasty and the Holy Roman Empire. And after elementary school, they get even busier. 
Second is memory. Was the generation that fought World War II really the Greatest Generation compared with, say, the blokes who fought the Thirty Years' War or the Crusades? Who knows? But since no one remembers anything that predates color television, who's going to argue with Tom Brokaw? But it doesn't mean he's right.
With time short and memories shorter, education experts are preparing a stripped-down history curriculum with more links to pop culture for the coming school year. 
So, if we just fast-forward past the perhaps Greatest Generation for a moment, a more relevant modern history course suitable for today's busy Z-100 listeners would begin with the Beatles, who were so Fab as to get a detergent named after them. Also important were Jerry and the Pacemakers, who were brilliant in merging pop music and advanced cardiac care, but who came came along about four decades too early to reach their target audience of decaying boomers with faulty tickers. We also went to the moon, and NASA sent along the man with the most American name possible, Buzz Aldrin, just to rub the Russians' noses in it.
Also during this time came hippies, the Grateful Dead and the Vietnam War, which gave us "Forrest Gump," "Apocalypse Now" and "Platoon." The 70's gave us "Rocky" and disco, and historians still debate who had a bigger impact on global geopolitics: Stallone or Travolta? Richard Nixon had to quit after having sex with a White House intern named Checkers and was replaced by a man named Ford who kept falling down on "Saturday Night Live." Elvis died, cementing his reputation as the most famous person in history.
In the 1980's, MTV was born, ending the feminist movement and ushering in the babe/dude/hottie/supermodel movement that shows no signs of abating now that 9-year-olds are expected to dress like hookers. Ronald Reagan was president for a long time, and the Soviet Union, still demoralized by Buzz Aldrin, fell apart. The only thing its countries stayed good at was doping athletes in the Olypmics.
Sometime in the 80's, the great Bull Market began. During this time, everyone in America became an expert on Value Investing, Momentum Investing and the New Paradigm, which said stocks of Internet Laundromats and pop-up toaster dot.coms would go up forever. Michael Jackson replaced Elvis as the most famous person in history.
In the 90's, people continued to make money. The Titanic, this really big boat full of vacationers in old-fashioned clothes, sank after it hit an iceberg. Bill Clinton provided cable TV commentators endless material so they could shout at each other at all hours of the night. O. J. Simpson did not kill his wife. Michael Jordan replaced Michael Jackson as the most famous person in history.
The world did not end during Y2K. That allowed enough time for everyone's stocks to go back down to zero, the Supreme Court to appoint the president and Britney Spears to replace Michael Jordan as the most famous person in history. 'N Sync became more popular than the Backstreet Boys. Tom and Nicole broke up but Brad and Jennifer were still together.
No one knows what the future will bring for Jenna Bush, Gary Condit, Adam Sandler and tomorrow's newsmakers, but if we're going to cram them into the history books, chances are the Concordat of Worms, Rutherford B. Hayes and a minor Shakespeare play or two might have to go to make up for it. The kids can only learn so much.
Next Week: Quantum physics made simple.

HEADLINE: Ken Burns Taps Waterbury And Its Store of Memories 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA WEISS 

 BODY:
JOSEPH CELENTANO of Waterbury, 82, will never forget the football game he attended at the old Polo Grounds in New York on Dec. 7, 1941. After the game, it was announced that Pearl Harbor had been bombed, he said, "and everyone turned around and said, 'Where's Pearl Harbor?' "
 For Gloria Brandolini, 78, the indelible moment occurred on the Waterbury Green at the end of the war, on Aug. 14, 1945. "It was like our own little Times Square," she said. "Downtown, you could not move! Everyone just converged in the center. Tears were shed -- for who came home, who didn't come." 
 Such private memories may soon be preserved on public television. Ken Burns, the documentary filmmaker, is seeking a few good cities on which to focus his next project, a documentary on World War II, and at the head of his list is Waterbury. 
"Waterbury is certainly one of our top choices," Mr. Burns said.
After the phenomenal success of his nine-part series "The Civil War" in 1990 -- with 44 awards, including two Emmys, it was more decorated than a five-star general -- "it became incredibly clear," Mr. Burns said, "that some of the ways in which the audience took to the film had to do with personally identifying with towns and individuals that were ordinary folks." So instead of tackling the full scope of the world war, he will explore how it affected American life through its impact on one or more small cities.
"We're not going to do a huge, overarching 10-part series," said his co-producer, Lynn Novick, who also collaborated with Mr. Burns on "Baseball" and "Jazz." 
"I think that if we show towns all across the country -- we distribute our interest across the geography of America -- it will be the best possible thing," Mr. Burns said. "But when we hit Waterbury, we got so excited that we began paying very close attention to it."
Why Waterbury? Despite its political travails, both past and present, it fit all their main criteria: It had an ethnically diverse population; it was conveniently located between Mr. Burns' home in Walpole, N.H., and Manhattan, where Ms. Novick, is based; and, once known as "the brass center of the world," it had a large industrial base that switched over to war production during the war.
Indeed, Waterbury-based manufacturers such as Anaconda American Brass Company, the Scovill Manufacturing Company and Chase Brass and Copper converted their operations from brass production to manufacturing cartridge clips, shell cases and time fuses for bombs. The Waterbury Clock Company (now known as Timex) also retooled to make munitions such as mechanical time fuses for bombs and gun sight units for airplanes.
The factory factor was most crucial, Ms. Novick said, "because we want to focus on not just the people who went overseas, but also try to connect that to the home front." Although many films have managed to convey either the brutality of combat or hardships endured at home, she said, "not very much has tried to really interconnect the two."
In this regard, Waterbury had one more advantage to offer their production company, Florentine Films: The Mattatuck Museum. It is in downtown Waterbury and has extensive experience conducting oral history projects. Its staff volunteered to assist with the film and has already begun interviewing local citizens.
"I'm hoping one of the things we can do is help streamline the project for them," said Marie Galbraith, the director of the museum. 
Anthony Santoro, a retired sheet metal worker, visited the Mattatuck recently to tell Ruth Glasser, a free-lance oral historian, about joining the Army Air Forces in May 1942. 
Mr. Santoro, 83, wears two hearing aids and bifocals and has deep lines etched around his mouth. But it wasn't hard to recognize him as a handsome young serviceman in a sepia-toned photo he showed of himself dressed in uniform beside his brothers Vito, who fought in the infantry, and Joseph, who also served in the Air Forces.
"This is the airplane I came home in," he said, showing a photo of "The Miss Beryl," a plane painted with the face of a shark and image of a pin-up girl. His eyes glistened as he recalled his return to Waterbury in October 1945. "My mother comes running down the stairs. What a reunion that was, three and a half years later!"
Stephen Rinaldi, 47, also visited the Mattatuck with his collection, a vast assortment of letters, photographs and other documents meticulously kept by his father. 
Family members discovered these treasures in an old trunk after Mr. Rinaldi's father, Charles, died in 1999. In numerous bulging scrapbooks, his father carefully assembled a record of his life as an Army Air Corps cryptographer. Inside, hundreds of photographs depict the distant places he was stationed, from Casablanca to the Belgian Congo. Diaries and travelogues in neat script give detailed accounts of his experiences.
Also inside are ration cards, stripes from his uniforms, and greeting cards from friends and relatives offering encouraging messages such as "'Tanks' to you, soldier! . . . The firing lines are holding up." 
"It's the best example of what the filmmakers are looking for," Ms. Galbraith said.
Mr. Rinaldi said his father had never mentioned this collection and rarely discussed the war. "The one thing that hurt him," he said, was that his father's mother died in 1944 while he was overseas and he was not permitted to return for the funeral.
If included in the documentary, such memories are destined for national exposure. "The Civil War" drew 39.5 million viewers and "Baseball," which aired in 1994, attracted an audience of 44 million.
Also available to be immortalized by Mr. Burns are members of the Crownbrook Neighborhood Association, a group of North End residents, nearly two dozen of whom met with Ms. Galbraith and Ms. Glasser to trade stories about Waterbury and the war.
For Mr. Celentano's wife, Kay, 77, the unforgettable experience was learning to drive a large truck at age 16 because, with so many people enlisted in the service, her father's bakery, Lorusso's in Waterbury, couldn't find anyone else to deliver cakes and crullers. "The men were all gone," she said.
Bill Santoro, 65, recalled participating in frequent air raid drills and city-wide blackouts. With its munitions factories and coastal location, "they figured Waterbury might be bombed," he said. Mr. Santoro was too young to be drafted, but he had an older brother stationed in Germany. His brother came back from the war. Thomas Ciarlo's did not.
Mr. Ciarlo, 74, who grew up in Waterbury but now lives in Wolcott, said his older brother, Corado "Babe" Ciarlo, was killed in action at age 21. A few months later, Mr. Ciarlo was drafted, too. Was he frightened to go?
"When you're 18 years old, you don't think of those things, really," he said. "You know you have to go, and your friends are all going, and everyone else is in there, so you just make the best of it."
Some members of that generation are now great grandparents. Many are gone. "The fact is that if we don't try to get some of these stories now," said Ms. Novick, "there may not be another chance."
She has received several calls from children of veterans offering war photographs and memorabilia kept by their fathers who are no longer living. "Those are great for us to possibly use, but it's not the same as having him here to tell us what happened," she said. "So before it's too late, we'd like to get as many people to tell their stories as possible."
Despite this sense of urgency, the documentary is not expected to air until 2005 and a decision on whether to focus on Waterbury will not be made any time soon. Mr. Burns hopes to begin work on World War II soon after his latest venture, a biography of Mark Twain, has its premiere in January. "This will be a multi-year, multi-episode affair," he said, "so I imagine by next year I will be deep into it." Yet production on "World War II" is slated to take nearly as long as the war itself.
If Waterbury is ultimately chosen, only a small crew will be on location there for a total of about 20 days, spread over the course of a year, Ms. Novick said. "So I don't anticipate a huge boon to the economy of Waterbury from our physical presence there."
Spotlighting the city in this context, however, may restore some luster to the Brass City's tarnished image. Ms. Novick has been told that Waterbury back then "was like the Rome of Connecticut," she said. "Because the factories were running 24 hours a day, people were always out. Shifts were always getting out or starting, and there were always people on the green or in town, eating, drinking, dancing, whatever, all day and all night. People would come there from other parts of Connecticut to have a good time."
Whether or not Waterbury is chosen, Mr. Burns expects to spend time in the state. His elder daughter, Sarah, 18, will be a sophomore at Yale. His younger daughter, Lilly, 14, is entering Loomis Chaffee School in Windsor. "So everything about my life, from 'Mark Twain' to my daughters, revolves around the state of Connecticut," he said.
And even if Waterbury is not prominently featured, Ms. Novick said, memories offered by its citizens are likely to be used.
She is also receptive to notable material from people with no connection to Waterbury. "What we're interested in is people who have unusual or particularly compelling stories to tell about their experiences in the war," she said, "or who had family members in the war who left behind letters, diaries or photographs that really would give a full picture of what their experiences were if they aren't here to tell us." Home movies showing soldiers at home on leave or family picnics are also welcome.
Through these personal tales, Mr. Burns hopes to illuminate the big picture.
"I think that sometimes, in our celebration of the heroics of war, we lose touch with the human cost and the human involvement," he said. He admires the way books such as Tom Brokaw's "The Greatest Generation" have allowed veterans to revisit their past and introduce others to it. "I would just like to be one of the many voices trying to collate, organize and make sense of that experience before those people pass from the scene."
Ms. Novick plans to visit Connecticut this month to meet with potential film subjects. She can be reached at (212) 662-9983 or by e-mail at ffnyc1@aol.com.

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Don't Know Much About History

BYLINE:  By PETER APPLEBOME; Peter Applebome is a deputy metropolitan editor at The New York Times.
