HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
For Schundler, a Big Rabbit To Yank Out of His Hat Now

BYLINE:  By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: PRINCETON 

 BODY:
So what will Bret Schundler do now?
 Two months ago, the Republican candidate for governor was basking in the glow of his masterly primary campaign in which he echoed his earlier, equally improbable mayoral victory in Jersey City by undoing Bob Franks, the party favorite. 
 Now Mr. Schundler has another uphill fight against James McGreevey, the mayor of Woodbridge who seems to have Forrest Gumped his way into a commanding lead in the polls by making Mr. Schundler the only issue in the campaign, and by keeping many of his own irreconcilable positions as fuzzy as possible. 
Mr. Schundler is a free-market conservative who believes the state has been too profligate with taxpayer dollars, who thinks that cronyism and self-dealing is a real problem in Trenton, and who thinks a less-regulated marketplace should be allowed to do its magic in areas like auto insurance. 
Yes, he would also like to see less choice when it comes to abortion and more choice in the matter of gun ownership as long -- he hopes people also hear him say -- as he can first build a consensus for those views.
The problem is going to be making sure people hear him.
The Labor Day weekend is here and -- except maybe for Phillies fans who have fanciful visions of playoffs in South Philadelphia -- the voters are supposed to start paying real attention to the selection of their next governor. Two months is plenty of time to play catch-up in New Jersey gubernatorial politics, so long as the space to be made up is not too great. Just think of Christie Whitman, who seemed to be sinking out of sight in the polls in the summer of 1993. 
An informal polling of political thinkers -- with an appropriate margin of error in favor of Mr. Schundler's fellow Republicans -- came up with a few predictions, or at least guesses, about what the young conservative insurgent should do.
First of all, they said Mr. Schundler would have to energize the battle for Trenton among conservatives around the country by reminding them that a victory this fall would open the campaign for control of Congress next year on a strong note.
And a Bushesque come-from-behind victory here would also add credibility to President George W. Bush's claim of a groundswell of conservative Republican support.
The Democrats will scoff, of course, but Democratic scoffing is good for Republican fund-raisers because it gets the donors' dander up. 
Mr. Schundler's fund-raising itinerary, including far-flung ventures to such places as Dallas, Nashville, and Chicago this month, suggests that he is in fact following the strategy of making his fight that of the national party as well.
And then, yes, he will go to television. For all New Jersey politicians except those named Corzine -- who starts in the spring if past experience is a guide -- the fall television push is the big chance for Republicans to redefine themselves and draw horns on opponents.
But Mr. Schundler is probably also working out an endgame for the TV campaign, that last-minute shift in atmospherics that Mrs. Whitman managed so well when she put aside her business attire and put on her famous fuzzy sweater for a stroll before the cameras with her children in tow.
No fuzzy sweaters for Mr. Schundler, please, but he has a good-looking family and they will probably get some face time in front of the camera.
Then, state Republicans would like to see Mr. Schundler wiggle off the hook of being the only issue in the campaign, where Mr. McGreevey, by skillfully and defining and misdefining Mr. Schundler's words and views, has stuck him.
He might be able to do this in two ways:
One, stopping attacking the status quo in New Jersey. Yes, the state operates in an atmosphere of low-grade corruption and mutual back-scratching, but it happens to be, after nearly eight years of Republican control in Trenton, mostly a Republican status quo. Dumping on the old ways of doing things that Mr. Schundler would like to reform only makes it easier for Mr. McGreevey to call for a change in party control.
Two, stop giving Mr. McGreevey a free ride on the issues. Mr. McGreevey says he is for teacher accountability, but he has been endorsed by the teachers union, which loathes the idea. How far would he go to get the bad teachers out of classrooms? 
Mr. McGreevey has also won the support of the state chapter of the Sierra Club by calling for the protection of open space, and the support of unions by calling for economic growth. But sewers, roads and bridges are what many of those union members want keep building And that spells sprawl.
How will he balance those two ideas?
Mr. Schundler's own championing of open space by pushing development to the older urban areas, and his notion of making union teachers compete with charter schools are both valid answers to Mr. McGreevey's positions.
In the next couple months, we'll see if the voters get to hear them.

State Grant Helps Yonkers Upgrade Wiring in Building

BYLINE:  By Elsa Brenner 

 BODY:
The Yonkers Industrial Development Agency has received a $71,500 state grant, which the city will match, to help pay for high-bandwidth telecommunications in the city-owned Nepperhan Valley Technology Center.

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY; 
In Technology, Supply Precedes Demand

BYLINE:  By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
MAYBE your Uncle Julius has told stories about how he could have bought half of Nevada for $1.50 way back when. It was all just worthless desert in those days, but now it is called Las Vegas.
 Your uncle's tales may be worth recalling, now that we are faced with a glut of long-haul fiber optic lines installed by companies eager to cash in on the Internet boom. Something like 100 million miles of these lines were laid in the last two years, and the great bulk of this capacity is unused. 
 For investors who put up the estimated $35 billion to pay for all this, it has been a disaster. Many companies involved are awash in red ink, and bandwidth brokers report plummeting prices for long-distance telecommunications capacity. Even worse, such a presumably gross misallocation of capital is bad for the entire economy; had the money been directed more profitably, output and employment would be higher and everyone would be better off. Now that the economy is weakening, America is starting to look like a high-technology Gulliver, tied down by costly Lilliputian threads of glass.
But was this really such a wholesale misallocation? Will society really suffer for the misguided enthusiasm of fiber optic investors and entrepreneurs? History suggests not. Again and again, investors have gone hog wild over new networking technologies, spent a fortune to install them and found themselves with vast overcapacity and ruinous competition. Yet eventually the capacity was always used, often for purposes never foreseen when it was installed. And in the long run, the economy was the better for it.
"The turbulence in this market is entirely predictable," said Richard R. John, a communications historian at the University of Illinois at Chicago. He noted that the American telegraph system was unprofitable for its first 15 years, and that in the early 20th century many felt that it had too much capacity, partly because it was built to accommodate huge peak loads during business hours. At first, the telegraph network was not used for what would become a main function: managing the railroad system.
"Almost all of the big-mileage railroads, once you get west of the Missouri, were built in advance of demand," said Maury Klein, a University of Rhode Island historian. Despite serious investor losses, a staggering increase in national wealth would result. "The rail network completely transformed the West," Professor Klein noted. "It created cities where none existed, and businesses where none existed."
Long ago, the railroad historian Julius Grodinsky summed up the process in words that would apply just as well to fiber optic networks today: "The story is typical of a growing industry in its pioneering stage. Competition then and now works itself out in a similar fashion. Some businessmen gain, some lose -- but the public benefits." 
In another example, the parkways of the New York area were built to give city residents a way to reach outlying beaches and state parks. But these roads also abetted the suburban development boom and soon were filled to capacity with commuters.
There are many reasons to believe that the vast new fiber optic network will similarly call forth unforeseen new applications. Adventis, an information industry consulting firm in Boston, predicts an "inferno" of bit-burning applications once high-capacity networks overcome the last-mile bottleneck -- the delay in hooking up a high-speed Internet network to homes or businesses. If that happens, it will not be the first time that communications overcapacity turned into a shortage. When telephone numbers were first allocated, who imagined that we would ever run out? And once upon a time, a million shares was considered enormous volume on the New York Stock Exchange.
And that misallocation of capital? True, the money could do something else as we wait for all that bit-burning. But history shows that this is the American way. Many European postal systems, telegraph lines and railroads were built with government money, and sometimes with insufficient capacity. But in the United States, instead of burdening taxpayers, we sell investors the equivalent of high-priced lottery tickets each time one of these technologies arrives.
The proceeds from these speculations -- the capital paid for stocks and bonds -- may seem misspent. In the long run, the results are called infrastructure, and they are what economies are built on.

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD; 
Arctic Energy Reshapes A Village

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: INUVIK, Northwest Territories 

 BODY:
IN the Arctic summer construction season, when the midnight sun only flirts with falling below the tundra, workers here are busy building a hospital, a prison, a recreation center, a housing subdivision and an apartment building, complete with an elevator, a rarity north of the Arctic Circle.
 Remote Inuvik, which is as far north of Vancouver as Mexico is south, is suddenly feeling the long reach of North America's growing desire for future supplies of natural gas. Emerging as the logistical hub for natural gas exploration and for future pipeline construction in the Canadian Arctic, Inuvik has long been a town where a lone stoplight regulates traffic in front of a Roman Catholic church shaped like an igloo. 
 In the late summer, as gas exploration rigs float their way here down the Mackenzie River, the town is bracing for big numbers of workers out on the Beaufort Sea this winter, once the ice is thick enough to support the rigs and trailer camps hauled out on skids. 
"Last year, there were over 1,000 jobs out in the delta -- this year may be 2,000," said Peter Clarkson, the mayor of Inuvik, which has 3,300 people, a mix of white settlers and Gwich'in and Inuvialuit natives. "There are more purchases -- vehicles, trucks, Skidoos. We are trying to help people better spend their money, put it into longer-term things, like home mortgages, as against the bars."
Gas was discovered here in the early 1970's. But it is North America's new energy economics that is fueling the latest boom. With about 90 percent of new power plants relying on natural gas, the United States Department of Energy predicts that American gas consumption will grow 45 percent by 2015. Although the number of American drilling rigs roughly doubled over the last 18 months, to 1,050, production grew just 2 percent in the United States in the last year, not enough to keep up with American demand, which is growing 3 percent a year. 
Not only are many American gas fields declining, but many undeveloped drilling areas, including large swaths of the Gulf of Mexico, the Rockies and the Great Lakes, are off limits to production. To meet American demand, the next great producing area is expected to be the Arctic -- with as much as 100 trillion cubic feet in the Prudhoe Bay area of Alaska, about 300 miles west of here, and about 12 trillion cubic feet offshore here, in the Canadian waters of the Beaufort Sea.
This gas, an energy development separate from the debate over producing oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska, is fueling talk of pipelines. Later this decade, construction of a 3,500-mile pipeline would funnel four billion cubic feet of gas a day from the Western Arctic to Chicago.
"Pipeline to Be the Biggest Private Project Ever in N. America," trumpeted a headline this summer in The National Post of Toronto. The article calculated that the pipeline project, estimated to cost $15 billion to $20 billion, would require twice the annual steel output of Japan, or enough steel to give each inhabitant of the world enough cutlery for six table settings.
A consortium of multinational energy companies with holdings in the two fields are winding up a $75 million study to determine pipeline routes. They expect to issue a report by year-end.
The Northwest Territories favors a 300-mile undersea line from Prudhoe Bay that would run north of the Alaskan wildlife refuge, pick up Canadian gas off Inuvik in the Beaufort Sea, travel through the Inuvik area, then south along the Mackenzie River to Alberta.
Officially neutral, Canada appears to lean toward this route, generally believed to be cheaper for producers. In July, a Canadian government research boat set sail to map the sea floor between here and the Alaskan border. A few days earlier, at the Group of 8 meeting in Genoa, Italy, an open microphone caught Prime Minister Jean Chretien telling President Bush, "One pipeline -- we could save a lot of money."
But Alaska is lobbying fiercely for a route that would parallel the state's existing oil pipeline and road south from Prudhoe Bay, then follow existing roads across the Yukon Territory to Alberta. In May, the governor of Alaska, Tony Knowles, whose pipeline slogan is "My Way is the Highway," signed into law a bill that forbids state regulators from allowing an "over the top" route from Prudhoe Bay to Inuvik.
But even though the pipeline fight is far from settled, the money flowing here shows confidence that, one way or another, Canadian Arctic gas will be flowing to North American consumers within a decade.
"Last winter, we had 180 trucks out in rent and that wasn't enough," said Bob Stack, owner of Norcan Leasing, Inuvik's largest vehicle leasing company, where late-model pickups and sport utility vehicles were parked outside the garage.
At the end of the Dempster Highway, the town's supply lifeline to the south, Judi Falsnes, owner of the Arctic Chalet Bed and Breakfast, said, "We have been full for much of the summer -- we have been turning people away."
In a neighborhood near the hospital construction site, Lyle W. Neis, general manager of Inuvik Gas, said that with the influx of new companies, "Inuvik's rental vacancy rate is essentially zero."
On Mackenzie Road, among the polar bear post cards and racks of bug repellent at Inuvik Rexall Drugs, Gene Nikiforuk, the owner, said, "It's nice to have the extra business, but people are getting priced out of homes -- people can't afford to live here."
Mr. Nikiforuk, a pharmacist who has lived here on and off for the last three decades, continued: "Rents in the last year doubled, but the people's salaries haven't."
Mr. Clarkson, the mayor, said that before the boom, a three-bedroom home sold for about $97,000. Now, he added, that same home sells for as much as $130,000. He also said single-bedroom apartments that used to rent for $485 to $520 a month now went for $650 to $780.
WITH a labor shortage, unemployment is drying up and native people are entering job-training programs.
"We are doing our best to make sure people are ready," said Nellie J. Cournoyea, chairwoman of the Inuvialuit Regional Corporation, a development group. A fervent believer that a pipeline will go through here, she added, "most everyone wants to be involved in the pipeline."
The economic boom is causing a local reversal of North America's dominant trend for populations to gradually shift south.
"Inuvik certainly is booming," Larry Bagnell, the Yukon Territory's lone member of Parliament, said wistfully after a visit here in late July. Referring to his territory's 13 percent unemployment rate, nearly double the national rate, he added, "With our unemployment, Yukoners are going up there to work."

The town, above and top, has only about 3,300 people, but gas exploration rigs like the training installation at left could attract 2,000 workers. (Pat Reece); (James Brooke/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Vivian Marino 

 BODY:
When Days Off Are Anything But
Are you relaxing this long Labor Day weekend? If not, you are certainly not alone.
 A new survey suggests that many American workers feel as much stress on their days off as they do on the job -- and that is partly because they are just as busy. 
 Sixty-two percent of workers say they have plenty of chores and personal obligations to tend to in their off hours, making their leisure time less relaxing and enjoyable. Forty-three percent said they spent some of their free time either on call for their offices or dealing with work issues. 
"Stress is an issue of failed leisure time more than just a workplace issue," said Thomas Riehle, president for public affairs at Ipsos-Reid, a market research firm based in Vancouver, British Columbia, that conducted the study last weekend. "Americans need to find a way to make leisure time work for them in order to reduce stress." 
The survey questioned 1,000 adults, 626 of them employed, throughout the United States; the results were released last week. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.
While many working Americans may be feeling stressed, they are not feeling unfulfilled. Eight-eight percent of the workers surveyed said they were satisfied with their jobs. Only 26 percent said they were seriously considering changing jobs in the next year.
"Job satisfaction remains high because work is important to Americans," Mr. Riehle said, "and if they are dissatisfied with their jobs, they tend to do something about it rather than remain dissatisfied." 

A Downturn With a Difference
Responding to the economic slowdown, American companies said they planned to cut nearly 780,000 jobs during the first half of this year, more than three times the number in the same period last year. That is pretty scary news, yet few workers appear to be seriously concerned, according to the Council of Public Relations Firms.
Last week, the council conducted a survey of 1,013 employees nationwide and found that 72 percent of them were "not at all worried" about being laid off in this weak economy. Fourteen percent were "slightly worried," 7 percent "moderately worried" and only 5 percent "extremely worried."
 Why are they still so upbeat?
"This downturn is different," said Jack Bergen, president of the trade group. 
"Despite the layoffs and other negative economic indicators, today's workers have more confidence in their ability to move forward and find another job," Mr. Bergen said. "With high job mobility becoming an integral part of the workplace during the past decade, much of the uncertainty and fear of job changes associated with previous downturns has disappeared." 
Still, workers are not always satisfied that employers are completely honest with them when it comes to the financial conditions of their companies. Fifty-four percent of those surveyed said most companies that downsize fail to communicate clearly to the surviving employees both the need for the layoffs and the outlook for the company. Only 37 percent said their own companies' communications with them were always open and honest. 

Lunch With a View of the Office
For many corporate executives, "let's do lunch" these days may mean inviting guests to pull up an office chair and share a tuna sandwich.
As layoffs have increased, so have workloads, which means that the average American executive is often too busy to venture out for lunch.
 "They may be feeling the pressure to use every bit of time they can squeeze out of a day to meet the demand," said Allen Salikof, president of Management Recruiters International of Cleveland, which last week released the results of a recent poll of more than 4,500 executives.
It found that 68 percent eat lunch at their desks at least once a week, 34 percent at least three times a week and 10 percent every day.

HEADLINE: From a Bull and a Bear, Conflicting Forecasts 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
YOU'VE heard their arguments. Whose advice -- Robert J. Shiller's or Jeremy J. Siegel's -- should you follow?
 Over the last decade, Mr. Siegel would have given investors a better return. 
 In his book, Mr. Siegel urged people to buy a broad mix of stocks, and the total market has more than doubled in value since its publication in 1994. Then, in 1999, with the Nasdaq composite index near 2,500, he presciently cautioned that many technology stocks were overvalued. He repeated the warning about a year later, after the Nasdaq index had almost doubled again and only days before it began to plummet to its current level below 2,000.
Mr. Shiller's record is more mixed. Through much of the late 90's, even as stocks continued to rise, he cautioned that their values had little basis in reality. The decline in the market since March 2000, just as his bearish book was published, has made his analysis look much better.
And what next? What do the two seers say now?
During a two-hour lunchtime discussion, both Mr. Shiller and Mr. Siegel said repeatedly that they did not like to make specific forecasts. "No one can predict the market, short run," Mr. Siegel said.
But they did offer a general framework for investors to follow. 
For those with a long time horizon -- say, 10 years or more -- Mr. Siegel's attitude has not changed much. Buy a broad mix of mutual funds with the lowest possible costs, he said. Put up to one-quarter of your holdings into funds that invest in overseas markets, including some in stable European companies. Also, invest about one-quarter of the portfolio in a fund that picks small to midsize American companies.
Some stocks -- particularly those of technology companies -- may be overvalued, Mr. Siegel said, but investors who do not need their money anytime soon are better off not trying to make many distinctions.
Almost two years ago, he sold most of his technology-heavy mutual funds. He still keeps almost all of his retirement money in stocks; his largest investment is in funds that try to match the entire United States market.
In addition to his professor's salary, Mr. Siegel makes significant money giving about 75 speeches a year to investment groups.
Mr. Shiller said stocks remained so expensive that they were likely to stay near current levels for years, much as the Dow Jones industrial average had the same value in late 1982 as it had in early 1966. "You don't have to bother with stocks at all for a while," he said. For people who cannot stand to be out of the stock market, value stocks -- those with low price-to-earnings ratios -- look most appealing.
Mr. Shiller has owned little stock since 1998. Instead, he has bought funds that invest in real estate and bonds. He is also co-owner of a company called Case Shiller Weiss Inc., which collects real estate data.
For investors who have little experience, Mr. Shiller suggests calling a Treasury Department phone number that he has memorized -- 1-877-811-SAVE -- and buying bonds that pay about 3 percent a year, on top of inflation. It is "entirely plausible," he added, that after inflation is taken into account, the Dow will be worth less in 2011 than it is today.
 DAVID LEONHARDT

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Getting A Kick Out of The Euro

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
WITH the dollar falling against the euro and American stocks still highly valued, Richard C. Pell, the co-manager of the $500 million Julius Baer International Equity fund, says American investors should be looking abroad, especially in Europe, including Eastern Europe.
 Mr. Pell took time last week to share his views. Here are excerpts. 

Q. Should people be more interested in international stocks now than they were in 1998, 1999 and even in 2000?

A. Well, I think you always have to start with the U.S. equity market. And there are times when it may be a good buy and there are times when it may be a poor buy. And right now, despite the sharp decline in stock prices in the U.S. since March of 2000, we still view the S.& P. 500 as quite highly valued. At a current level of around 1,150, we feel it is priced to return little more than Treasury bonds in the future.
We believe there are two implications of current S.& P. pricing. First, investors should probably hold more bonds and assets with a predictable rate of return than they normally would. Secondly, we believe you want to own equities of all kinds to be broadly diversified. But we think it is a particularly good time to diversify geographically into some of the foreign equity markets that have lagged the big rise in the U.S. As we look outside the United States, we view Europe as a much lower risk proposition than Japan, the other Asian countries or Latin America. Within the emerging markets, we have a particular interest in Eastern Europe.

Q. You said you expected limited returns on the S.& P. 500. Is that true of international stocks?

A. It is quite probable that nominal returns may be lower in the European market than they have been in the past, because those markets as well have enjoyed particularly strong appreciation.
Having said that, I think that Europe has a couple of advantages. First, markets aren't quite as highly priced. Secondly, we believe that U.S.-dollar-based investors in Europe are likely to get a currency kicker over the years to come.

Q. Where are you investing in Eastern Europe?

A. We are talking chiefly about the Czech Republic, Poland and Hungary. It is a play on the economic integration of Europe and the possibility of these countries joining the European Union. If there is continued progress toward economic integration, interest rates will fall in these countries, pushing stocks higher. The potential return from the banks in Eastern Europe is somewhere between 500 and 1,000 percent. Having said that, it is not a low-risk investment.

Q. What are some of the banks?

A. One of them is Bank Pekao in Poland. Another large position of ours is Ceska Sporitelna in the Czech Republic. The third name is OTP Bank in Hungary.

Q. Can a retail investor buy these stocks?

A. In some cases, like Poland, you have to register with the local authorities to buy the shares. So we find a mutual fund is the easiest way for investors to participate.

Q. What do you like in developed countries?

A. A couple of things. First, we have about 5.6 percent of our fund invested in German insurance companies, chiefly in Allianz and Munich Re. We think these companies are potential beneficiaries of three major reforms in Germany. First, pension reform; second, tax law reforms; and third, eventually, we expect the development of a takeover code in Germany.

Q. Where else are you putting your money?

A. Another sector we quite like for defensive reasons is the energy sector. We have about 8.4 percent of our fund invested in energy stocks. One of our larger positions is TotalFinaElf. This is probably one of the best upstream oil companies in the world. And it also has an interesting hedge built into the company because they have a memorandum of understanding with the Iraqi government that they can develop two major oil fields in Iraq that potentially could produce about a million barrels a day of oil. That is equivalent to 50 percent of Total's current production. A second oil company we quite like is ENI of Italy. ENI is about 2 percent of our fund. Both Total and ENI are available as American depository receipts.

Q. Do you like any other sector?

A. Right now, we have a somewhat negative view on global economic activity. So we have about 14 percent of the fund invested in sectors I guess we would call hiding places, consumer staples -- like beverage companies, foods and some of the drug companies -- and also utilities.
Another company we find kind of interesting is Vinci in France. It has a substantial concessions business. So basically what they do is design, build and operate things like motorways, bridges, tunnels, airports, car parks -- and they have contracts for operating some of the projects reaching anywhere from about 15 to 80 years.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2002 Lincoln Blackwood; 
Viva Las Vegas: A Pickup for Elvis

BYLINE:  By DAN NEIL 

 BODY:
WHAT to call the Blackwood, Lincoln's lavish something spun off from the corpulent Lincoln Navigator and the Ford F-150 SuperCrew? Is it a luxury pickup truck, a sport utility sedan or -- as the company's marketing department would have it -- a "luxury utility vehicle"? The latter would make it an L.U.V., which is positively precious.
 The Blackwood is like an automotive Rorschach test; what you call it depends on what you see in it. Given its funereal color scheme, I like to think of it as a hearse for the diminutive departed, though I know this is a minority view. 
 By any name it is the front two-thirds of a Navigator S.U.V. attached to a short-bed cargo "trunk," a carpeted 56-inch-long compartment with brushed aluminum walls and L.E.D. light bars that might have been pried out of somebody's prom limo. The cargo box is topped by a tonneau that, with some clever hinges and cams, opens and closes like a clamshell to signals from the remote key fob. The tonneau's styling includes the
crosshair badge and center ridge familiar from the hoods of other Lincolns, and this has the unfortunate effect of blurring the distinction between coming and going.
The Blackwood is ever blurring distinctions. Lincoln calls the truck's genre-bending an example of outside-the-box thinking. If only that were so. Rather, the Blackwood represents chapter-and-verse orthodoxy in Detroit, which has brought out many variations on light-duty truck platforms -- king cab, crew cab, quad cab, everything but Checker cab -- representing minimum engineering for maximum profit. You want to talk mileage? How much has Ford gotten out of the F-Series underpinnings, which in addition to the truck multitudes have seen service under the hugely successful Expedition, then the Navigator and now the Blackwood?
General Motors will soon weigh in with a luxury truck of its own, the Cadillac Escalade EXT, which will likewise share platform components with Chevy and GMC light-duty trucks, as well as with the Tahoe, Suburban and Avalanche.
Not that there is anything wrong with profit. Nor is there anything sacred about the morphologies of a pickup truck versus sport utility. But in the Blackwood's case, something has been lost in the translation: the utility. The Blackwood arrives without four-wheel-drive, a cornerstone of an S.U.V.'s appeal, never mind that buyers may not use it. The rear-drive Blackwood's sleek lines are untroubled by high-profile tires and the wheel-well clearances necessary with four-wheel drive. (The Blackwood is shod with 18-inch Michelins wrapped around lovely seven-spoke alloy wheels.)
Also, the cargo trunk is well nigh unusable. Its beautiful anodized brushed-aluminum bulkheads would be threatened by shifting cargo -- an unrestrained bag of Ping Zing golf clubs would make a mess in there -- and the tonneau cuts off capacity at a mere 27 cubic feet. My wife couldn't put a wicker patio chair in the back, so we had to cram it into the passenger compartment.
Another annoyance: Let's say a can of soup falls out of the grocery bag and rolls forward. You have to go spelunking deep into the hold to retrieve it (and hope the neighbors don't spot you with canned soup).
Finally, every glittering surface of the Blackwood, from the mirror-polished door handles and chrome-plated fuel filler door to the simulated African wenge wood trim, picks up fingerprints like the sneeze guard at Sizzler. Those integrated storage compartments in the boot? That's where you can keep the Windex.
As evidence of utility aplenty, Lincoln might indignantly point to the Blackwood's 8,700-pound towing capacity, its rear air springs, its load-leveling suspension and its Class III/IV trailer hitch. Well, I've been shopping for a good-tasting hat lately, and I'll eat it if it turns out that more than a few of the 10,000 Blackwood buyers actually use the truck for towing. The whole construction is too delicate -- in Shakespeare's happy phrase, "beauty too rich for use."
The rear gate, for instance, comprises two swing-out doors of lightweight composite. If you fail to close them in the right order (left-right) the latch mechanism could bash the door with expensive consequences.
So we have here a pickup that won't pick up. Reasonable people might ask, "Who cares?" After all, for years Americans have been buying more truck than they could possibly use. And the pickup has proved to be an exceptionally elastic concept, including everything from street-hugging low-riders to open-deck Humvees. Every summer weekend, Nascar runs racecars shaped like pickups in the Craftsman Truck Series, and the National Hot Rod Association drag-races trucks. You don't need to be Roland Barthes (or Emerson or Thoreau, for that matter) to see the pickup as a vessel into which Americans pour their cherished notions of self, individualism and independence.
But all these other iterations of the pickup actually do something. This is a truck so perverted by style and luxury that it cannot even carry the occasional lawn mower or sheet of plywood.
But can Lincoln really be held accountable? The company says its mission is to build "American luxury," and isn't the Blackwood that, in spades? In the democratic logic of a market economy, the public gets the products it deserves.
Such theoretical concerns may seem far afield from issues of horsepower (300 from a 5.4-liter V-8) and torque (355 foot-pounds at 2,750 r.p.m.) and are unlikely to trouble potential buyers, who know a cool-looking truck when they see one.
The Blackwood -- all mirror chrome, glossy paint, smoked glass and prismatic lenses -- is gorgeous, in the way that Las Vegas honeymoon suites and Elvis's jumpsuits are gorgeous. I especially like the widely spaced type that spells the name across the rear gate doors.
Even the simulated wenge wood wrapped around the cargo hold is attractive, considering that it is actually a photographic reproduction printed on adhesive laminate.
The real wenge winds up inside the Blackwood, and here Lincoln pulled out all the stops. Black on black on really black, the interior has four generous bucket seats trimmed in luscious Connolly leather, the front seats "climate controlled," with integrated heating and cooling. To have the air-conditioner blowing full blast on one's nether regions is a peculiar sensation, to say the least. You think cell phones are distracting?
The cockpit is loaded with high-end gear, much of it borrowed from the Navigator: a 140-watt Alpine stereo with in-dash CD changer and seven speakers, an optional voice-activated navigation system with superb graphics and ease of use, memory settings that recall each driver's favored settings for the seat, the mirrors and even the adjustable pedals. Other amenities include a moonroof, parking proximity alarm, overhead console and approach lights. The whole package is wrapped in an inky elegance that fits well. The assembly quality of the Blackwood is first-rate.
All this luxury raises the tonnage. The Blackwood weighs a porky 5,700 pounds, and you feel every ounce when you throw this thing into a corner. The suspension struggles to contain the shifting momentum, then gives up and goes home. The Blackwood's wallowing body roll and torpid reflexes (speed-sensitive power steering of the recirculating-ball design) mock Lincoln's assertions of sporty handling.
Acceleration from zero to 60 m.p.h. takes a little more than 8 seconds, which is pretty crisp, all things considered. But the fuel economy (12 m.p.g. city, 17 highway) is troubling, and even with four-wheel antilock disc brakes, the Blackwood decelerates like a coal train.
In short, if you liked the thrift and agility of the Navigator, you will love the Blackwood.
At $52,500 ($54,495 with the navigation system), this disingenuous pickup is genuinely expensive. When it appeared as a design study at auto shows a couple of years ago -- a time when high-tech speculators were pie-eyed with profits, and the business cycle seemed to have been repealed -- the Blackwood seemed the perfect fire extinguisher for those with money burning holes in their pockets. But a lot has happened since, and conspicuous decadence is wearing a little thin. Looking slightly absurd, Lincoln's truck arrives in black tie and tails just as the confetti is being swept up.

INSIDE TRACK: Irrational exuberance.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 8, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An automobile review of the Lincoln Blackwood on Sunday misstated the type of wood trim in the interior and the type of material that lines the cargo trunk. The interior is dark-stained oak, not African wenge; the trunk is stainless steel, not aluminum. The review also referred incorrectly to the operation of Lincoln's navigation system. Although it provides audible directions, it is not voice-activated.

HEADLINE: Meet Me at the Boutique (You Can Dust While You Wait) 

BYLINE:  By HEIDI SHERMAN 

 BODY:
LAST Thursday, after returning from a business trip that took me to Boston and back by 3 p.m., I didn't go to the office. I played hooky instead, and spent the afternoon at Hadu, my favorite dress shop in NoLIta. I didn't browse through the culottes and halter dresses. I walked straight to the rear room, threw back a couple of tuna fish sandwiches, ate about a pound of pretzels and went to work. Reorganizing the sale rack. Cleaning up the dressing room. And -- though I have no more design experience than any other New Yorker with an anthropology degree -- cutting pink leather swatches for a dress sample. I was acting as if I owned the place, even though I don't. It belongs to my friend Amy McCracken, a designer. And she doesn't pay me for my work. 
 I come often to this little store on Mulberry Street to offer my help. A bunch of my friends do, too. For our little group, this clothing boutique is a home away from home, and its 1,000 square feet a kind of family room. Hadu is where we hang out on a slow afternoon, meet before going to dinner, escape our roommates. If we were the cast of a television show it would be "Underemployed Friends" and Hadu would be our Central Perk. Besides Amy, the main characters are: Mark, a former immigration lawyer turned humor writer; Anne, an early casualty of the defunct Industry Standard magazine, who fills her days painting and writing; Dylan, a quiet, brooding independent film distributor; Oliver, a botanist from Nebraska with plans to open his own bar; and me, a travel magazine editor still doing the 9 to 5. Rather than sip lattes while bemoaning the state of singleness in New York the way they do on TV, we hang up tube dresses or reaccessorize the mannequins. 
 Most of us have been friends for about 10 years, having migrated from the University of California at Los Angeles to New York only to become victims of the economic slowdown. We've been downsized or fired, or simply grew bored and bewildered and quit our jobs to change course. We have law degrees and master's degrees, but none of us -- save Amy, with her design degree -- are using them. Someday we might. In the meantime, this unexpected pit stop on our career paths has proved surprisingly gratifying. The global economy may not need us. But Hadu does. 
It all began late last year, when Amy's lease for her dream boutique came through just as a loan to finance it fell apart. When it seemed she would have to abandon her plan, she put out an all-points bulletin to friends asking for help. Anne and Oliver invested money, and the rest of us donated time and muscle.
Amy hired a Brooklyn architect, also a friend, to help design the shop, but to keep costs down she asked us to gut and renovate the windowless ground-floor space she had leased for $3,700 a month. In the urban equivalent of an Amish barn-raising, we rolled up the sleeves on our turtlenecks and went to work.
On a Wednesday in the dreary depths of February, in an almost pagan rite of destruction, the six of us assembled to tear up the floors and hack down the walls of the dank space. Oliver, the only one with his own toolbox, served as foreman. We whacked away at ceiling beams with axes, blunt instruments I couldn't name and our bare hands. There was no heat, but Mark supplied a few cases of our favorite cheap red wine, Gato Negro, to keep us warm and in good cheer. Which may explain why we laughed when a dead rat landed on Amy's head.
We worked until after midnight and returned before dawn to clear away the evidence. In bucket-brigade formation, we passed bricks, cement blocks, slats of wood and bags overflowing with debris out the door and into a Dumpster. Though covered in dust, Anne inspired catcalls from the construction workers down the street (maybe because of the purple thong underwear peaking out from her jeans). Mark, not a fan of manual labor, complained of imminent frostbite. I griped about a hangover. We raced against the clock. We had just three hours to fill the massive bin, which was to be hauled away before 9 a.m., when, our neighbors warned us, the traffic police would make their rounds and discover our Dumpster in violation of parking, zoning and construction laws.
"I knew you were friends for life when you all woke up at dawn to shovel up the piles of tile and concrete," Amy said recently. "I didn't think most of you could wake up before noon unless there was a fire."
Oddly enough, we weren't exhausted from the hours of heavy lifting, but ready for more. We offered to come back the following week to help lay down floorboards and install a storefront window. In two months of work that felt more like play, we transformed that musty space into a sun-drenched store worthy of our friend's colorful designs.
As the store-opening deadline in May approached, we were all as nervous as Amy. To prepare for the debut-night party, she called us down to Hadu (named after her mother's real-life fairy godmother) early to explain the cash register, how to work the credit card machine and how to buzz people in the front door. We each had a task: Mark would man the bar; Anne would be in charge of finding sizes that weren't on the racks; Dylan, the most detached, would hand people pens to sign the guest book; my job was to work the register.
Nobody got paid for spending a Thursday evening helping a customer into an orange Empire-waist dress or sweeping up cups after the browsers had left. Instead, in exchange for our roles in this urban-family business, we'd get our own village center.
On summer Fridays, I can pretty much count on seeing Hadu's Ultrasuede couch and shag carpet warmed by the bodies of my old college friends, along with neighborhood regulars we've come to know. "Yesterday, eight people stopped by," Amy said the other day with mock horror. "Sometimes I have to remind all you guys that, yes, I do work here." After a long afternoon of pitching in while socializing at the shop, we pseudo-employees go home as achy and tired as if we worked there, too. Family, they say, is exhausting.
Now our little group is branching out. Oliver is designing a new bar on Broome and Forsyth Streets. Amy will design the waiters' outfits, and the rest of us will be scrubbing toilets, painting walls and pulling up stained carpets. In return, we'll get drink tickets and a port of call down the road from our living room.
At Hadu, we're all partners of a sort. For Amy, the up side of having a staff of friends is that like real family, we provide consolation when things get rough.
When neighboring NoLIta shops dropped their prices to make room for the fall season just one month after Hadu's opening, we convinced Amy to drop her prices, too, assuring her that she would still make money. And when the blue silk dress design came back from the production house with the bust disproportionately big, we girls served as new fit models so that Amy could resize the cups by hand.
Of course, sometimes, like family, we get in the way -- like the time Anne borrowed a dress from Hadu's spring collection and returned it two sizes smaller (the dry cleaner shrank it -- it's now mine); or the time one friend, who shall remain nameless, dusted the pricey bolts of pink leather with pretzel salt. But as Amy sees it, there's only one real drawback. "You guys have no problem giving me your honest opinions," she says, "and there's no shortage of them."
Yeah, I advised her to scrap the culottes she was doing for her summer line. The ones she sold so fast she couldn't keep them on the racks. Hey, what do I know, I just work here.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Take Away the Window Dressing, and Who Will Buy?

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
WITH the global economy in a stall, corporate spending at a standstill and layoffs threatening to subvert consumer spending, it is no surprise that the United States stock market is feeling overwhelmed.
 But something else is weighing on stocks. That is the creeping realization among investors that the momentous earnings reported by many companies in recent years may have been digitally remastered to include a lot of hype, embroidery and fluff. 
 This is significant. Investors coming around to this view will be less inclined to trust forecasts that company executives make. Having lost faith in a company's numbers, investors will be unable to place a fair value on its stock. In the dark on valuations, many investors will shun the shares. 
An extreme reaction? Not at all. It is precisely the payback that companies deserve for embellishing their earnings. 
The quality of corporate earnings seemed a quaint concern when stocks were racing. Now, reality in company earnings is crucial. But separating reality from fantasy in corporate earnings is harder than ever. Consider the gulf between estimates of second-quarter earnings from First Call and Standard & Poor's. While First Call said operating earnings among companies in the S.& P. 500 had fallen by 17 percent from the same period last year, S. & P. reckoned that the decline at those companies was 33 percent in the quarter. 
Because companies have much leeway in what they report as operating earnings, perhaps the best way to assess the true state of earnings is to consult government figures.
While the average annual earnings growth reported by companies in the S.& P. 500 came in at around 9 percent from 1995 to 2000, the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis says corporate after-tax profits grew only 5 percent annually. 
A report from Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, a brokerage firm, supports the government's figures. The report says the 9 percent average annual earnings growth at S.& P. companies in the late 1990's was really only 5 percent if one cancels out favorable accounting for stock options and earnings boosts that companies took from stock gains in pension plans. 
Had companies deducted the cost of options from revenue, which they need not do, annual S.& P. profit growth from 1995 to 2000 would drop to 6 percent from 9 percent, the report said. Subtract fat gains from shares held in pensions, and earnings growth falls by another percentage point. 
Another stellar aspect of the technology marvel dims under the gaze of Steve Galbraith, United States equity strategist at Morgan Stanley. He says that at many tech companies, profitability per employee grew at astounding rates in the late 1990's but is now crashing. Per-worker profits at semiconductor companies, for example, are expected to fall 77 percent this year.
This proves not only that technology is cyclical, but also that profit gains were largely a result of easy money, not of intellectual capital. "If this was somehow an intellectual-capital-driven business, there is no way you would have had this kind of degradation in profit per employee," Mr. Galbraith said. "Capital was free and they all spent it into this area."
Advances in technology were thought to have wrought a profitability miracle in the late 1990's. Now it seems the miracle was a result of a roaring stock market and accommodating capital markets. 
Experienced investors know not to confuse brilliance with a bull market. The new era version of that rule: Don't confuse profits with a bull market, either. 

GRAPHIC: Chart: "More is Less Again" shows the profit per employee at technology companies from 1991-2001. (Source: Morgan Stanley)

HEADLINE: Buy! Sell! Have a Beer! Dueling Gurus (and Pals) 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: OCEAN CITY, N.J. 

 BODY:
BOB arrived with the cold cuts. Jeremy found a chair at the lunch table that allowed him a view of both the Atlantic Ocean and the television set, tuned to CNBC. Their wives, Virginia and Ellen, sat down near them. Their teenage boys, between hanging out on the deck and going parasailing, briefly joined the adults at the table for sandwiches.
 To anyone who did not know the public personas of the two fathers, it would have looked like a perfectly typical summer afternoon at the Jersey shore. In fact, it was a gathering of the yin and yang of Wall Street. 
 Bob is Robert J. Shiller, the author of "Irrational Exuberance," the book that came out just before the Nasdaq plunge of 2000 and made him perhaps the most prominent bearish economist in the country. And Jeremy is Jeremy J. Siegel, the professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania whose bullish 1994 book, "Stocks for the Long Run," became both a cause and a symbol of the vastly increased popularity of the stock market. 
The two have become intellectual combatants, offering conflicting advice to Alan Greenspan and making frequent television appearances. Several magazines have portrayed them as dueling wise men, with Mr. Shiller saying the stock market is facing years of little if any growth and Mr. Siegel arguing that it remains the best investment around. One recent article went so far as to pose the question directly: Who is correct, Mr. Shiller or Mr. Siegel?
But behind all the apparent disagreement is a 34-year-old friendship that both men say has been the driving force for their most important work. In an academic world that rewards specialization above all else, they have pushed each other to make connections between the abstract theories of their field and the real-life events of their society.
"We become devil's advocates of each other," Mr. Siegel said.
Mr. Shiller added: "Nothing is independent between us."
The two men, both 55 and from the Midwest, met at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1967, when the alphabetical proximity of their names left them standing next to each other in line, awaiting a mandatory X-ray for all incoming graduate students. While at M.I.T., they spent hours together in libraries, apartments and delis, discussing girlfriends, the Vietnam War and the mathematical proof showing that there is no highest prime number. 
After each married, they took family vacations together, first in the Poconos and later here, on the edge of the broad white beaches of southern New Jersey. Their families grew close: Ginny Shiller is a clinical psychologist, while Ellen Schwartz, Mr. Siegel's wife, is a speech pathologist, and each couple has two boys between the ages of 14 and 21.
On a recent Thursday afternoon -- with perfect weather beckoning -- the economists sat down for a two-hour lunch at the beachfront house that the Siegels had rented and the Shillers were visiting.
The economists had spent the morning walking on the beach and talking about the lengths to which companies have gone to inflate their reported profits. At lunch, the two discussed their past and debated the economy's future, finding common ground but also sometimes interrupting each other to score a point.
MR. SIEGEL says the stock market has been undervalued for almost two centuries, that stocks deserve higher price-to-earnings ratios than they have had historically, because many people now understand their benefits and because the economy is less volatile than it once was. 
Mr. Shiller, though, thinks market declines like that of the last week will be common in coming years. He sees Mr. Siegel's arguments as similar to ones that have always been offered during speculative bubbles, like those in the 1920's and the 1960's. He says that there is no guarantee that the United States and its companies will be as successful in coming years as they were in the past. 
Their personalities match their outlooks. Mr. Siegel tends toward the gregarious -- a trim man who speaks quickly and often mentions the teaching awards he has won at Wharton. He keeps an almost constant watch on the market (and left CNBC on in the background for the entire lunch). A few nights before, when the families drove to Atlantic City, he happily took a seat at a $10 blackjack table and won about $60.
Mr. Shiller, a Yale professor who looks a decade younger than he is, will sometimes interrupt himself to offer a caveat to one of his own ideas. Rather than watching stock tickers, he will sometimes open an encyclopedia and start reading, according to his son Ben, 19. The man who worries about irrational exuberance does not gamble.
"Shiller is very earnest," said Paul A. Samuelson, the Nobel winner who taught him at M.I.T. "He is almost -- and I don't say this in a pejorative way at all -- like a hayseed boy off a farm with a straw in his mouth. He's a long-jawed, serious fellow."
Still, the long run-up in the stock market during the 1990's has caused the two friends to agree more often than their public images -- Shiller the bear, Siegel the bull -- would suggest. Both think that technology stocks remain generally overvalued, despite the sharp declines of the last 18 months. Both believe that Wall Street prognosticators like Abby Joseph Cohen are too optimistic about the short-term future. Both think that most investors need to lower their long-term expectations. But both say that for people with the longest horizons -- say, 25 years or more -- the stock market is a smart investment. 
The biggest area of common ground, however, is in their thoughts about escaping the sometimes narrow confines of academia. "When you're in an economics program, you can easily get the impression that people are just trying to prove that they're smart," Mr. Shiller said. "They're not interested in writing something that's general or descriptive."
Mr. Siegel added, "We'll take from theory what we think is relevant, and we try to think of the big picture."
It was on one of their vacations, in the Poconos in 1990, that Mr. Shiller first urged Mr. Siegel to turn his research on the long-term advantages of stocks into a book. "What Jeremy was presenting, it might sound to academics as too broad," Mr. Shiller said. "But I was saying there's another kind of writing.
"You don't have to live up to some straitjacket," he added.
The book, "Stocks for the Long Run" (McGraw-Hill), first appeared when the Dow Jones industrial average was below 4,000. (It closed on Friday at 9,949.75.) Mr. Siegel elegantly summarized his thesis with a simple chart showing the long-term returns of stocks, bonds and gold. The Washington Post called the book one of the 10 best investment books of all time.
Nine years after that conversation in the Poconos, during a phone call from their offices, Mr. Siegel told Mr. Shiller to drop his plan for an updated collection of academic essays and to write instead about investment bubbles for a larger audience. Immediately after hanging up, Mr. Shiller began working on the book that became "Irrational Exuberance" (Princeton University Press), which was published in March, 2000.
When it hit bookstores -- with the Dow around 11,000 and the Nasdaq composite index near 5,000 -- Business Week said it was "by far the most important about the stock market since Jeremy J. Siegel's 1994 'Stocks for the Long Run.' "
THE bull grew up in Highland Park, Ill., just north of Chicago, the son and grandson of presidents of a family lumber company. For as long he can remember, Mr. Siegel loved numbers and tall buildings. So after being accepted at Columbia and Yale, he chose Columbia ("Isn't that shocking?" he asked, teasing the Yale professor sitting across from him) and moved to New York to study math and to be near high-rises.
The big city also allowed him to be close to something else that had captured his imagination: the stock market. "Friday afternoons, my classes ended early, and I would take the subway all the way down to Wall Street, and I would go visit and see the close of the New York Stock Exchange," he said. 
"There was no wait, you could go right into the visitors' gallery," he added, "There was no glass up, the way it is now."
"You could really kind of get much closer to the action," he said. "It gave me a thrill. I'd just do it by myself."
Mr. Shiller, smiling, interrupted: "Almost like going to church, right?"
"Yeah, it was," Mr. Siegel said. "I didn't say any prayers while I was there, but I was in New York, which was the financial capital of the world."
"It was all there," he added.
All, except for courses that inspired him. By his sophomore year, his math classes had become so abstract that they seemed to have little connection to the bustling world around him. The next year, he enrolled in his first economics class.
"At the end of the third week, I knew I loved that subject," he said. "From that point on, I knew I wanted to be an economics professor."
Mr. Shiller, befitting his more cautious personality, found his process of discovery considerably more painful. He had grown up in a suburb of Detroit, where his father was a mechanical engineer. When the time came to pick an undergraduate major at the University of Michigan, he found himself tortured by the idea of choosing a career. On the one hand, he knew he should pick one path and follow it, so as not to waste effort. On the other hand, there were so many possibilities.
"It was very hard -- as a young person, it's dazzling to think about all the different things you could do," he said. "There are a million different occupations. You can only do one thing in life, you have only one career, and you'll never know" whether you made the right choice.
To make the decision among economics, science, journalism and law, he would leave his dormitory room and take long walks around Ann Arbor. "And then my foot started to hurt and so I went to a doctor and he said, 'This is the kind of injury we see in soldiers on forced marches.' "
Ultimately, Mr. Shiller chose economics, he said, because he thought it would allow him to work on the important problems of society, like poverty and starvation. "This is where I snapped finally," he said.
Mr. Siegel added: "It's a very different course than I took."
Their courses intersected in Cambridge, Mass., in the late summer of 1967. They had enrolled in graduate school immediately after college, in part to avoid becoming eligible for the Vietnam War draft. Before students could begin attending classes, they needed chest X-rays to confirm that they were free of tuberculosis, and they lined up in alphabetical order for the procedure.
Bored, Mr. Siegel turned to the student next to him: "I said, 'Well, where are you from, and what are you in?' " Michigan and economics, came the reply. "And we started chatting a little bit, and, I don't know, we kind of liked each other right away."
THEY spent much of their time with Theodore E. Keeler, a classmate who now teaches at the University of California at Berkeley. After evenings of studying, the three would hop on Boston's trolley-and-subway system to get late-night meals of sandwiches, hot dogs, cheesecake and hot fudge sundaes at delis in Cambridge or Brookline. "It was a reward after a long day's work," Mr. Keeler said. "And we certainly had a metabolism then that could handle all of that."
At the time, M.I.T. was arguably the most exciting place to study economics in the United States. In a typical year, Mr. Samuelson recalled, more than half of the 20 students who received National Science Foundation fellowships to study economics might enroll at M.I.T. Stanley Fischer, now the deputy director of the International Monetary Fund, and Robert Merton, another Nobel winner, were among Mr. Shiller's and Mr. Siegel's fellow students. 
But the two held their own, Mr. Samuelson said. "They were unusually good graduate students in a vintage crop of graduate students at M.I.T.," he said.
By and large, they were also typical graduate students. When they were not studying, their idea of fun often involved intellectual gymnastics that would cause many people to roll their eyes. Mr. Shiller and Mr. Keeler would quiz Mr. Siegel, supplying him with a ticker symbol and allowing him to show off his vast knowledge of the stock market by naming the company. Or they would consider the puzzle of why the shortest day of the year did not have the earliest sunset.
But no matter how obscure the theory in their seminars became -- and even 30 years ago, economic theory could become very obscure -- they tried to connect what they were studying to the society around them. "That's what attracted me to Jeremy," Mr. Shiller said. "He had this tremendous knowledge of the real world. And we'd be sitting there in lectures learning about how homohypalligic production runs, and then we'd come back and we would look at data."
In many ways, Mr. Shiller and Mr. Siegel are part of the academic establishment. Both have tenure in the Ivy League and have published many theoretical papers in respected journals. But they also worry that their field can sometimes become too narrow, particularly when it tries to achieve the certainties of physics or chemistry.
"In academic seminars, the guy runs a T-test," Mr. Shiller said, referring to a common statistical technique. "And then someone says, 'Well, but you don't know that the observations are independent, so how do you know that's a valid test?'
"And the seminar leader responds, 'Well, I'm using the so-and-so XZ-test.' And now that stops the seminar. No one knows this test.
"You snow the guy, and you move on," Mr. Shiller added.
After a few more minutes of such jokes, the careful Mr. Shiller caught himself. "Let's not make so much fun of statistics," he said. "I'm not saying it always happens. It sometimes happens."
As the years passed, the friends' very similar approaches to economics have led them to very different conclusions. 
When the first edition of Mr. Siegel's book appeared, in 1994, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index hovered below 500, and the two men shared a general view about the market: Over history, investors had generally worried too much about stocks' riskiness, depressing their values. But those people willing to buy and hold equities had reaped a high return as a result.
FOR many years, Mr. Siegel had even convinced Mr. Shiller to hold almost 100 percent of his investments in stock.
"Stocks have been chronically undervalued assets," Mr. Siegel said.
Then came the end-of-century bull market. The S.& P. 500 more than tripled between 1994 and 2000, and following the market became a national pastime. Many more people became convinced that stocks were the best investment for the long run. They became the safe bet, not the risky one, and their newly high price-to-earnings ratios -- in the 20's and 30's, not the single digits and teens -- reflected their popularity.
That raised the question at the heart of the fundamental disagreement between the two economists: Have stocks become so expensive that they will no longer offer a good return over the next decade or so? In other words, will corporate earnings need years to catch up to today's equity prices?
Mr. Siegel thinks not. Like Mr. Shiller, he doubts that technological change will cause an increase in companies' earnings. It never has in the past, they agreed, because competition quickly eliminates any advantage it produces.
But even if profits are not in a historical boom, many stocks could deserve their newly high values, so long as the future is as bright as the past has been for American companies. And it should be, Mr. Siegel says. Workers and capital continue to flow into the United States. With low inflation, the economy appears more stable than it once was. The decline in the cost of trading and in capital gains taxes makes stocks a more attractive investment than in the past.
Add it all up, and stocks are likely to deliver a 6 percent inflation-adjusted annual return -- well below the rates of the 1980's and 90's and less than what investors say they expect, but still easily better than anything else. "If I were to tell somebody with virtual certainty that, over the next 20 years, they were going to earn a 4 percent real return on stocks, boy, would they be disappointed," Mr. Siegel said. "But you know what? They wouldn't move out of them."
Mr. Shiller countered, "It sounds like it's a close call."
That is why he is more bearish. If equities appear to offer a return only slightly better than bonds -- especially the new inflation-adjusted government bonds, which are nearly free of risk -- then the riskiness of stocks becomes less appealing, Mr. Shiller added. Given the lofty hopes built into today's prices, he thinks it more likely that the future will be disappointing than that it will be a wonderland of low trading costs, low taxes, low inflation and American dominance.
"The U.S. is the most successful economy in the world," he said. "And also the 20th century was the most successful century in the history of mankind. And it's kind of a mistake to assume that the U.S. experience in the last century has to be repeated."
EVEN if that success is repeated, Mr. Shiller added, investors will probably become attuned to stocks' riskiness again at some point, driving down their price-to-earnings ratios and hurting many investors who bought equities when they were expensive. After all, there have been previous periods, like the 1920's, in which people believed that the stock market was obviously the best long-term investment, and they never held onto the sentiment for long.
"Do you think they can learn?" Mr. Siegel asked. "Do you think they could become, quote, more rational on this issue?"
Mr. Shiller responded, "They could also become less rational because the frequency of reporting business news is creating a different ambience where you see the prices going up and down constantly."
Should that happen, and the stock market were to gain only slightly for the next decade, as Mr. Shiller thinks likely, he would then consider investing in it again. For now, all he owns is a mutual fund full of international value stocks and the Kmart shares his mother gave him. But come 2011, if the S.& P. 500 is not much higher than it is today, stocks may become as good a buy as they were in 1991.
"Even so," Mr. Shiller said, turning toward Mr. Siegel, "who knows about the future? Maybe I've been too influenced by you."

PERSON: Patti S. Hart 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
Crisis Control at Warp Speed

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
INVESTORS in Excite@Home, hoping that the company can stave off bankruptcy, are keeping a keen eye on how the chief executive, Patti S.Hart, assuages its agitated creditors. It might calm the investors to know how Ms. Hart once assuaged the pig farmers. 
 Shortly after college, Ms. Hart took a sales job at GTE. Among her tasks was selling hog farm security systems, which were intended to prevent pigs from becoming too hot or too cold. The trouble was, her prospective customers hardly saw her as one of their own, precipitating a serious makeover on her part. 
 "I kind of quickly went from the girl in the Navy blue suit to wearing blue jeans and a sweater and hanging out at the local coffee shop," she said. And Ms. Hart, 45, said that was when she came to understand she had a knack.
"I realized I could see a situation, and morph into what I needed to become to solve it," she said, adding, "That's how I've made my career, bringing solutions to problem situations."
The hog farm lessons aside, Ms. Hart credits her blue-collar upbringing and a grandmother's tireless work ethic with giving her the drive and the tools to soar through the ranks of the telecommunications industry. Colleagues and friends agree that she can adapt quickly to changes in business circumstances and squeeze the most from tough situations. Those skills are being sorely tested now.
Last week, an already pressing financial crisis worsened at Excite@Home, which offers broadband service and operates the Excite portal. Creditors who lent Excite $100 million two months ago demanded half of the money back immediately, saying they had not been fully apprised of the seriousness of the company's financial straits. And two of the largest distributors of Excite@Home's high-speed Internet access, Cox Communications and Comcast, said they would end their distribution agreements in June.
A week earlier, the company's auditor, Ernst & Young, put a fine point on those straits by concluding it had "substantial doubt" about Excite's financial viability. (Excite subsequently announced that it had replaced Ernst & Young as its auditor.)
People familiar with the company say it has $100 million in cash and is burning it at $1 million a day, with the losses being accrued largely by the portal.
In April, when Ms. Hart accepted the job as chief executive of Excite@Home, she might not have known the full extent of the company's problems. The company had once been mentioned in the same breath with Yahoo and America Online, but people close to the company said it had been slammed by a downturn in the advertising market and by mistakes by previous management.
"I thought I would have a large mountain to walk up," Ms. Hart said. "I'm finding that I have to run up it."
She learned to adapt early, as a teenager in a Chicago suburb. Her father worked at a Ford manufacturing plant. Money was tight, and any spending money that she and her four siblings wanted they had to earn themselves. Ms. Hart's jobs included working in cornfields, cleaning movie theaters and teaching children to bowl. (She didn't know how herself, so she just taught them how to keep score.) 
She also internalized the lessons of her maternal step-grandmother, Georgia Gleason, who lived through the Depression, "stuffed money in her mattress" and was "the hardest-working woman on the planet," Ms. Hart said. At 91, Ms. Gleason still gets up at dawn, then often takes to the kitchen to bake peach and blueberry pies. 
"This is my stock," said Ms. Hart, who said that since she was 11 she had not taken more than a two-week break from work. And she acknowledged that the pace was unlikely to change, even in the distant future.
Her free time, what there is of it, is spent with her husband, Milledge, a private investor, and their 17-year-old son, often in pastimes like miniature golf, bowling (she says she still is not good at it) and Yahtzee. When she eventually tires of the business world, she said, she intends to invest her energy in charitable and foundation work, mentoring and in helping other women in business.
As for her own career trajectory, Ms. Hart joined Sprint in 1986 as a national account manager in sales and moved up the ranks quickly. Six promotions later, she was president and chief operating officer of Sprint's long-distance business. In June 1999, she became chief executive of a high-speed Internet access company called Telocity. She took the company public in 2000, but after a strong start, market conditions soured and Telocity ran low on cash. Ms. Hart engineered the sale of the company to Hughes Electronics for $180 million.
She says that she is adept at marketing and sales and at building relationships but that she is not particularly "financially astute." ("I don't get up in the morning and crunch numbers," she said.) Her friends in the business world credit her with a fierce work ethic and with paying attention to issues like diversity and employee relations. 
"Excite is in an operating morass and Patti is a superb operator," said Leo Hindery Jr., former chief executive of Tele-Communications Inc. and its successor, AT&T Broadband. "She is gifted in several respects. She is meticulous in her attention to detail, and she is very sensitive to employees at every level."
BUT she has not been beyond criticism. One former vice president of Telocity said publicly that Ms. Hart lacked the ability to innovate, an accusation that Mr. Hindery dismissed as sour grapes. Ms. Hart, meanwhile, said she was aware that she could wind up labeled as being associated with troubled companies.
"I have to take responsibility," Ms. Hart said, adding that she does not believe she can disassociate herself from Excite's troubles. Dealing with labels is "part of being a leader," she said, even if the trouble at Excite was seeded before her arrival: "The thing that's important to me is that I can look in the mirror and say I'm acting with the highest integrity."
Ms. Hart visualizes a few possibilities for Excite. In at least one, she said, it continues as a thriving, independent concern, but she declined to discuss details.
At least one person has complete confidence in her: Ms. Gleason said she had no doubt that her granddaughter would revive Excite's fortunes.
The grandmother does have one, seemingly uncharacteristic concern: "I wish she'd slow down a little." 
But given Ms. Hart's genealogy, and her company's circumstances, that might not happen anytime soon.

LENGTH: 800 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
No Easy Fix For Social Security

BYLINE:  By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
THE argument over the future of Social Security divides just about everybody involved into stark ideological camps.
 To most of the liberal supporters of the current system, Social Security requires only minor fixes. Solid economic growth and a bulging trust fund will protect benefits for decades, they say. If projections prove too optimistic, they half-heartedly acknowledge, the government can tax a little more here, borrow a bit more there and perhaps ask retirees, far into the future, to accept slightly less. No big deal. 
 On the other side, many conservatives contend that Social Security's flaws are so fundamental that the government has to destroy the program in order to save it. Nothing less than the introduction of privately owned investment accounts allowing people to save for their own retirement, they say, will solve the problem. They see such accounts as necessary to supplement and ultimately replace the existing pay-as-you-go system, under which working Americans are taxed to pay the Social Security benefits of their parents in retirement.
But what if each side is only half right -- and half wrong?
That is exactly the way it looks to an eclectic band of economists who are not trapped in either political straitjacket. Social Security does have a fundamental flaw, they say, but it cannot be overcome by privatizing the system.
The flaw is relatively easy to understand: soon, there will not be enough workers to easily support each nonworking beneficiary. In 1960, more than five working Americans supported each retiree; today, for every Social Security beneficiary, there are about 3.4 Americans paying taxes into the system. The current tax rate of 12.4 percent, divided equally between employees and employers, is enough to pay retirees, on average, 36 percent of the income of the typical worker and leave some extra to pay off government debt.
But by 2030, when the baby-boom generation is expected to be mostly retired, only two Americans will be working for every retiree. If today's workers are to receive a similar ratio of benefits to wages, future workers will have to sacrifice a much greater share of their earnings.
Advocates of privatization promise an escape from this relentless squeeze: simply let workers today divert a portion of their Social Security taxes into individual accounts that can be invested in the stock market. Through the magic of compounding, those investments would generate enough cash to make up for lower payments from the regular Social Security accounts.
If only it were that easy. Privatization, says Jeffrey A. Miron, an economist at Boston University, is a false promise. Professor Miron, a conservative libertarian who is no fan of Social Security, might be expected to favor some form of privatization. Instead, he says, "it would just replace one bad system with a different bad system." 
In a recent paper, he and Kevin M. Murphy, an economist at the University of Chicago, argue that the crucial point is that privatization will have no effect on the stream of Social Security benefits that the government has promised to pay. Claims that privatization solves the impending crisis are wrong, they say, just as claims that privatization harms Social Security are wrong.
David Levine has a different background, but he is just as adamant in arguing that the imbalance in society's promises to future retirees and the resources that will be available at the time is inescapable.
"There is no such thing as a financial solution to Social Security," says Mr. Levine, a retired Wall Street economist with a more liberal perspective. Even if Social Security had been set up as a real pension system, the quandary would remain just as stark. 
BUT just because he finds privatization wanting doesn't mean he thinks the current system is sustainable, either. As a society, we have to have enough people working to generate real resources not just for themselves but also for all those who aren't, he says. But as life expectancies continue to grow, the population pyramid is inverting. 
Both he and Professor Miron say that, given the choices, perhaps the fairest answer is to raise the age at which full Social Security benefits are paid in the future. Already, the retirement age is scheduled to rise to 67 from 65 over the next few decades.
But that won't be enough, particularly as improvements in health care extend life expectancy. The average 75-year-old today is probably healthier than the typical 60-year-old was when Social Security first established 65 as the official retirement age.
America is wealthier than ever and can afford a decent retirement standard for the elderly. But one way or another, these critics say, the economy cannot support millions upon millions of healthy people not working year after year after year.
