HEADLINE: The Nation: No-Show Politics; 
Suppose They Convened, but No One Came

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
TO go or not to go? 
 The United States decided last week to snub a racism conference in Durban, South Africa, by sending only a midlevel delegation to protest efforts to equate Zionism with racism and promote reparations for slavery. In a world where international meetings often provide a forum for nations to challenge or second-guess America's dominance and interests, it isn't always easy to decide when to stay home and when to plunge in and fight. 
 "They create terrific problems for American policymakers," Lee H. Hamilton, director of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, said of such gatherings. "The agenda is often taken over by voices we don't agree with." 
Mr. Hamilton, the former Democratic chairman of the House International Relations Committee, said he was ambivalent about boycotting the Durban meeting, which began this weekend, though "in general, my instinct is that the U.S. should go to these conferences and make its case."
Gaddis Smith, an emeritus professor of history at Yale, said it was a "serious mistake" for the United States to absent itself from conferences where conflict awaits, or to scale back its presence. The Bush administration is demonstrating "a head-in-the-sand attitude," Mr. Smith said. "We're more likely to be a target of anti-American rhetoric if we're not there. It says the United States has something to hide."
Ever since the Senate dashed the hopes of President Woodrow Wilson and voted to reject American membership in the League of Nations, the United States has shown itself willing to shun world gatherings it distrusts. 
At times, the mere threat of an American boycott has prompted other nations to address Washington's objections. In 1980, with tensions boiling over in the Middle East, the Carter administration derailed an Arab effort to expel Israel from the United Nations General Assembly by making clear that it would withdraw and effectively paralyze the organization.
But sometimes threats are insufficient. In 1984, the Reagan administration withdrew from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, complaining that it was wasteful, poorly managed and a stage for anti-Western propaganda. The American departure put the agency under economic pressure, and Unesco's board voted the following year to tone down its activism. But the gambit failed to produce rapid reforms. After a 17-year boycott, House lawmakers this spring finally urged the administration to rejoin a much less politicized organization.
In 1992, American officials stewed for months over whether President George Bush would attend the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. The administration opposed the two main agreements at the environmental conference -- accords to protect biodiversity and curb emissions that contribute to global warming -- but with the United States a major force in both conservation and pollution, Mr. Bush risked being blamed for singlehandedly wrecking the meeting by staying home. He decided to attend and ultimately persuaded the world leaders to water down their treaty on emissions.
In 1995, First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton led an American delegation to the United Nations Fourth World Conference on Women. Many Republican lawmakers had opposed the American participation, and Mrs. Clinton's attendance in particular, because of China's poor human rights record and their belief that the conference would endorse abortion. When Chinese security agents clamped down on demonstrators at the conference, Mrs. Clinton excoriated her Chinese hosts for their failure to tolerate dissenting views. 
Running through the American ambivalence toward such meetings are competing imperatives. With a commercial, political or military presence in virtually every corner of the globe, the United States has a unique stake in international affairs. To protect its interests, it secured a dominant role in the main institutions of the post-World War II era: the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. 
YET the American impulse has been to dismiss the international order when it is seen as running counter to the national interest or as meddling in domestic affairs. "We Americans always talk about multilateralism," said Kenneth N. Waltz, a political scientist who teaches at Columbia University. "In fact, we're unilateralists."
That perception, which is widespread among American allies as well as critics, has grown in recent months as the Bush administration has rejected the Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty with Russia and the Kyoto accord on global warming. Resentment has also built over the United States' failure to pay arrears to the United Nations.
The Bush administration learned this spring what happens when it ignores such rumblings: the United States itself gets boycotted.
For the first time in its 54-year history, the United Nations Human Rights Commission failed to approve a seat for the United States. The vote, which was seen as a rebuke to the Bush administration's foreign policy, left astonished American officials vowing to press for human rights from the sidelines.
But that's not the same as being in the game.

HEADLINE: How Long Can Consumers Keep Spending? 

BYLINE:  By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich, former labor secretary, is professor of economic and social policy at Brandeis University and author of "The Future of Success."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
The old industrial struggle was between companies and workers. The new struggle is between . . . companies and workers. But the battle isn't what it used to be. Now, it's over who's going to spend enough to keep the economy moving forward. The crunch will come if companies lay off so many employees that consumers go on a spending strike.
 Since last year, American companies have cut way back on their purchases. The economy isn't in recession only because consumers haven't cut back their spending as well. If they do, the American economy tanks. 
 A slowdown usually starts the other way around. Consumers reduce their spending because they've used up too much of their savings and can't afford or don't want to borrow more. Then companies cut back their own spending because sales are down.
This time, companies started it. They overspent in the late 90's, mostly on capital equipment and software, and then began cutting back last year at the first sign of trouble. The technology sector took the biggest hit. As profits continued to drop this year, companies stopped buying. Business investment dropped a whopping 14.6 percent in the second quarter. Investment in equipment and software fell by 15.1 percent in the second quarter, the largest drop since the comparable period of 1982. Even outside the battered technology sector, profits have been disappointing. As a result, companies have begun to target their biggest single cost -- payrolls.
Last year the economy gained 1.76 million jobs. But between March and July of this year it shed 394,000 in the private sector -- the largest monthly drops since the recession in 1991 and 1992. (We won't know what happened in August until figures come out later this week.) Since April 1998, when factory payrolls peaked, 1.2 million factory jobs have been lost. But the biggest surprise has come in the service sector. Service jobs had grown steadily for decades, recession or no recession, but since March, the number of service jobs in the American economy has not grown at all.
The job losses look even bigger when considering forthcoming layoffs. In July, companies announced that they would lay off an additional 205,975 workers, a monthly record.
Even if companies are cutting way back, the economy can still move forward as long as consumers keep spending. After all, consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity. In the second quarter of this year, consumers increased their spending at an annualized rate of 2.1 percent. That's a bit slower than in the first quarter but good enough to keep the economy going. 
But there's an obvious tension here that lies at the heart of the economy. If the job cutbacks and layoffs continue, at some point consumers are going to get worried about their own paychecks. And when that happens, they'll cut way back on spending.
This belt-tightening could happen suddenly because consumers are already deep in debt. Consumer-credit debt surged a whopping 9.3 percent last year, and it is still rising at that torrid pace. Personal debt has been growing by an average annualized rate of 8.2 percent a month since last October. Mortgage debt is way up, too. 
The interesting question is why employees have remained so irrationally exuberant. Surely not because they're getting a few hundred dollars in tax rebates or because fuel prices have eased. The easiest explanation is that the last recession is only a dim memory, so most people underestimate the risk of losing a job and hitting the wall. Almost a quarter of the current work force wasn't even old enough to have a job when the last recession blew through in 1991 and 1992. Since then we've enjoyed one of the longest periods of prosperity on record. Millions of Americans were lifted into the middle class. The rate of home ownership rose to 67.5 percent, the highest on record. Homes are Americans's biggest nest egg, and housing prices are still holding firm. So naturally there's a lot of wishful thinking that the economy will bounce back soon.
Moreover, the latest round of job cuts doesn't seem nearly as threatening as it might have years ago. By now, people are used to the idea that they might be laid off. During the 90's, the possibility of losing one's job became a permanent feature of working life. High rates of layoffs that began in the recession of 1991-92 never dropped by much. The difference was that as the economy gained speed in the 90's, people who lost their jobs could easily find new ones. Unemployment dropped to its lowest rate in three decades. But now, jobs are becoming harder to find.
Finally, after a decade of prosperity, most people have become used to a certain standard of living. They'll pull in their belts only when they feel they have no choice -- that is, when their bills grow too large or when their jobs seem at risk. 
Every announcement of more layoffs moves us closer to that moment. Consumers are already slowing their purchases of cars and other big-ticket items, according to the latest confidence surveys. If the job cuts keep up, at some point consumer confidence will take a dive, and consumers will go on a spending strike. When that happens, not even Alan Greenspan's interest rate cuts can help us.
Blather about whether the economy has "bottomed out" is meaningless. The economy might take off again, but it also might fall into a full-blown recession. It all depends on whether the Federal Reserve's rate cuts, combined with additional government spending (don't worry about the Social Security surplus, please!) encourage companies to start spending again and stop cutting payrolls before employees lose their irrational exuberance and become rationally worried.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer; 
The Slave Reparations Movement Adopts the Rhetoric of Victimhood

BYLINE:  By BRENT STAPLES 

 BODY:
My great-grandfather John Wesley Staples was born in Bedford County, Va., on July 4, 1865. Independence Day of that year was laden with symbolism because it heralded the end of slavery through the 13th Amendment. Family legend has it that John Wesley was one of the first free Negroes born in his county. But three of his siblings were born into slavery, as was his mother, Somerville, who was known in the family as an Ethiopian.
 Slavery is nearer to us in time than most Americans understand. My eldest uncle, who turns 84 this year, has often recalled meeting former slaves when he was a boy at John Wesley's farm in Troutville, Va. Had John Wesley lived to my uncle's age, he would had seen the beginning of the civil rights movement and met the great-grandson who would later become an editorial writer for The New York Times. 
 The post-slavery South was especially brutal for elderly black people who had given their working lives to their masters and could no longer care for themselves. Freedom, such as it was, was further circumscribed during the late 19th century, when Southern states were writing Negroes out of the state constitutions, denying them the right to vote, hold office or attend school. The trend was deepened by sharecropping and other forms of bondage.
Black Americans often suppressed slave memories out of horror and shame. But the Staples family embraced its story out of pride in how well John Wesley and his wife, Eliza, managed to fare in the aggressively racist environment of the South in the late 19th century and early 20th century. My great-grandparents had the benefit of a strong extended family, allowing them to pool resources, including manpower. The Staples family protected the farm and John Wesley's wholesaling business with shotguns and pistols that were evident even at the dinner table. With no school available for black children, John Wesley and Eliza joined with their neighbors and built one in a field at the intersection of their three properties.
The teacher is listed in my great-aunt Sophronia's grade school composition book as a "Miss Marion B. Brown." She worked at the one-room school in return for room and board from the families. When John Wesley died in 1940, he left behind a literate family, a thriving farm and $40,000 in cash -- a small fortune by standards of the time. This achievement paved the way for my father's generation and mine, which included the first college-bound members of the Staples family line.
Black Americans made spectacular progress beginning in the decades after slavery, moving from cotton fields to the boardroom in just over a century. But the recent debate about reparations for slavery has introduced a different narrative in which black people are cast as a victim class seeking compensation for the suffering of ancestors. The most popular version of the reparations proposal is found in "The Debt: What America Owes to Blacks," by the Africa analyst Randall Robinson. The book has gained surprising credibility on the political left while generating a considerable backlash among moderate and conservative black intellectuals. 
Targeted compensation is legal and morally just. The state of Florida made the right gesture in 1994 when it gave college scholarships to descendants from the black community of Rosewood, which was destroyed by whites in 1923 while the state did nothing. The federal government has rightly compensated modern-day Native Americans for lands taken from them in the last century. Supporters of reparations have at least a moral case when they argue that companies that enriched themselves in slavery should attempt restitution when documents are specific enough to permit it.
But the sweeping notion that individual black Americans are owed a "debt" for slavery is a bridge too far. Black families have made and lost fortunes just as white families have. There is in addition no provable connection between 19th-century bondage and specific cases of 21st-century destitution. For these reasons, a publicly financed reparations program based on ancestry is not sustainable politically.
Such a program would logically be open to millions of people who have lived as "white" for generations but are descended from enslaved black people. The program would also be available to the descendants of black slave owners, who were far more common than many people like to admit. Black masters in South Carolina, for example, were confined to the margins of society but held many of the same attitudes about race as whites. Black masters continued to hold slaves even as the Union Army prepared for its terrible march through South Carolina.
The reparations debate is part of a burgeoning discussion about the role of slavery in American history. But by blaming history alone for modern-day social ills like poverty, illiteracy and unemployment, reparations advocates are unwittingly saying that these problems are so deeply rooted as to be unsolvable. They are also subverting the true story of black people in the United States. This story is one of extraordinary achievement in the face of gargantuan obstacles. It begins in the waning hours of slavery and continues to this very day.

HEADLINE: Study Faults Unions' Math On New Jobs For Drilling 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The number of jobs gained from oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge would be far fewer than the 750,000 that many unions have said the drilling would create, says a study released today by environmental groups.
 The League of Conservation Voters and other environmental groups that oppose the Alaska drilling say the study should go far to offset the main argument -- new jobs -- that the Teamsters and other unions used to persuade 36 House Democrats to vote a month ago for the drilling, a hotly contested issue in Congress. 
 The study, by an economist with long ties to unions, is the environmental movement's latest weapon in its biggest feud with labor in years.
Many environmentalists are angry at the Teamsters and several building trade unions for playing a pivotal role in lining up enough support among House Democrats to secure approval of the drilling, a major victory for the Bush administration. 
The administration will try to persuade the Senate to approve the drilling this fall, but environmental leaders say they hope the new study will help ensure that it does not.
"Some labor unions outmaneuvered us in the House," said Deb Callahan, president of the League of Conservation Voters. "But we still think we can win this thing in the Senate."
The study, done by Dean Baker, co-director of the Center of Economic and Policy Research, faulted the 1990 study that the Teamsters and the oil industry repeatedly cited to argue that the Alaska drilling would create 750,000 jobs. 
Mr. Baker's study estimated that the Alaska drilling would create just 46,300 jobs. He concluded that the earlier study, commissioned by the American Petroleum Institute, was far off in estimating that the oil from the refuge would represent 3.5 percent of world oil production. Relying on more recent estimates, his study found that the refuge would account for 1.15 percent of world production.
As a result, he said, the Arctic drilling would push down world oil prices far less than forecast by the 1990 study, which was conducted by the WEFA Group, based in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. The 1990 study said the low prices would give the American economy a shot in the arm, creating hundreds of thousands of jobs. 
The 1990 study predicted that other oil-producing nations would do little to reduce output to push prices up once the Alaska drilling helped pull them down. Relying on estimates that the WEFA Group used in more recent studies, Mr. Baker concluded that other nations would cut production far more than the 1990 study estimated to offset output from the refuge. That, he said, would nullify much or all of the lower prices generated by the Arctic drilling.
Citing his prediction of 46,300 new jobs, Mr. Baker wrote, "Economic impacts of this magnitude are almost too small to be noticed, given the size of the U.S. economy."
Jerry Hood, a Teamsters official based in Alaska who is a special assistant to the union's president, James P. Hoffa, on energy policy, defended the 1990 study. "We are comfortable with the jobs number developed in that study," Mr. Hood said.
Some environmental leaders said the feud over Arctic drilling could jeopardize efforts by labor and environmentalists to work together on many issues, notably fast-track trade legislation.
"There's clearly been a rupture between the Teamsters and the environmental movement," said Carl Pope, president of the Sierra Club. "The Teamsters got away with casting the impression that all of labor favored the drilling, which it wasn't. It's going to be extremely important to the future of the blue-green alliance how the rest of labor helps set the record straight."
In recent days, the Service Employees International Union and the United Auto Workers have spoken out against the drilling.
Mr. Pope said he was surprised that the Teamsters would work so closely with the Bush administration on energy policy after President Bush took several anti-labor actions early in his administration.
"I don't understand how Hoffa says he's bitterly fighting the Bush administration on Mexican trucking, which he says is his top priority, and then he takes Arctic drilling, which should be a much smaller issue for the Teamsters, and he uses it to legitimize Bush by giving him a major legislative victory," Mr. Pope said.
Mr. Hoffa said supporting Arctic drilling made sense. "It provides jobs for Teamsters," he said. "It's a sound answer to the need for additional oil for the country."

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: Competition's Not Pretty in Lipstick Wars 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
When a midsize chain of New York cosmetics stores declared bankruptcy a few weeks ago, worry lines around town began to deepen.
 For nearly three decades, the chain, Cosmetics Plus, had occupied a comfortable niche somewhere between the two time-tested models for buying lipstick, mascara and so forth. The first model entailed plucking a packaged product from a drugstore shelf; the second, braving the hard sell of a department store cosmetics counter. In contrast, Cosmetics Plus specialized in midlevel to upscale beauty products in stand-alone stores and appeared successful, even expanding to California. 
 But a few years ago, the first shots were fired in the lipstick wars, as retailers like the aggressively stylish Sephora barreled into the New York market. These days, selling cosmetics has become extraordinarily competitive, with inventive marketing ploys -- for example, one manufacturer has a "studio" where a customer can have makeup applied but cannot actually buy it, and other stores hold seminars, hand out dog biscuits to customers' pets or even carry a line of grooming products for dogs.
Today, there are beauty stores for every type of customer -- even women like Barbara Goldschmidt, a massage therapist in Manhattan who wears makeup only rarely. "I don't put anything on my skin that I can't eat," Ms. Goldschmidt said recently, as she and her two teenage daughters sampled products made from fruit and grains at an Origins store.
The change in cosmetics retailing actually began five years ago, when the Body Shop, a British company that made a name for itself by avoiding animal testing, entered the United States market. The threat from the Body Shop inspired the Estee Lauder Companies to develop the equally animal-friendly Origins, which sells a "comb improvement detangler" scented with patchouli oils, a product for dogs.
The influx of Body Shops also led Intimate Brands, the parent company of Victoria's Secret, to create the Bath and Body Works chain, popular with more "girly girl" consumers.
Just as they favor blacks and neutrals in their clothing, New York women tend to wear less makeup than Sun Belt women, who wear bright colors, said Allan G. Mottus, the publisher of The Informationist, a cosmetics trade publication.
But that has not blocked the proliferation of retailers. So many cosmetics stores and spas opened in SoHo a few years ago that some people began referring to it as Lipstick Alley. One of them, Shiseido Studio, offers free classes and makeup applications but does not sell cosmetics. The idea, said Michelle Torio, the studio director, is to promote the products in a pressure-free environment.
Now the Flatiron district has become ground zero in the lipstick wars, as national retailers moved into the neighborhood to attract the young Internet workers with offices nearby. As a result, a woman feeling a sudden urge to change her lip or nail color, say, can go to any of a dozen stores on Fifth Avenue from 16th Street to 22nd Street. 
Not only can she shop in stores specializing in cosmetics, but she can also buy cosmetics at stores with other main businesses -- sampling a lip gloss called Dirty Girl, for example, at Anthropologie, a clothing and home furnishings store, or trying a "lip enhancer" called Pleasingly Plump at Victoria's Secret. Cosmetics are also available at apparel stores like Club Monaco and the Gap.
The fact that many more opportunities exist to buy cosmetics does not mean, however, that women are buying more. No one tracks overall cosmetics sales in New York, but nationally, sales increased only 3.9 percent over last year, said Carrie Bonner, a senior research analyst for Kline & Company, a marketing research company in Little Falls, N.J. This unspectacular performance has led retailing experts to predict an eventual shakeout in the market, which may have begun with the bankruptcy of Cosmetics Plus.
"The pie keeps getting cut up into smaller and smaller pieces," said Wendy Liebmann, the president of WSL Strategic Retail, a New York marketing research company that follows the cosmetics industry.
Perhaps the biggest shock wave to the industry was in 1998, when Sephora, owned by the French luxury retailer LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, opened its first United States outlet in SoHo. Using lighting to dramatic effect, Sephora aims for a theatrical experience, and refers to its sales force as cast members. It stocks traditional brands like Clarins and Clinique as well as hip labels like Urban Defense and Hard Candy. 
Beth Manhardt, 20, a student at Providence College, said she shopped at Sephora because she preferred to be let alone. "I hated having to deal with sales people," she said. "You can't try on things as easily, and they push things on you. Here, you have total freedom." 
The popularity of Sephora, which has seven stores in New York and is about to open an eighth at 67th and Third Avenue, seems to have prompted a rethinking at the department stores. At Bloomingdale's, for example, the perfume-sprayers have become deferential, if not exactly meek. Sales clerks in the cosmetics department tend to be as aggressive as ever, but these days, they immediately back off when asked to.
Industry experts, however, said these changes have yet to pay off. A slump in clothing sales has not helped. "If you're not getting apparel traffic, you're not getting cosmetics traffic," Ms. Liebmann said.
One retailer that did not respond to the new trends in cosmetics merchandising was Cosmetics Plus, a 28-year-old regional chain, with 22 stores, 18 of them in Manhattan. Cosmetics Plus had styled itself as the "American parfumerie" -- more upscale than drug stores and more convenient than department stores.
But by the late 1990's, Cosmetics Plus began looking a little tired. Instead of updating its stores, the company made an unsuccessful foray into California and dabbled in the Internet. Buying cosmetics online has little appeal for most women, analysts say, because they want to smell, touch and see the products.
On Thursday, Cosmetics Plus was authorized by the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan to hold going-out-of-business sales. Other retailers may follow. Cosmetics used to be considered recession-proof. "People might not buy an $800 suit, but they can buy a $15 lipstick," said Faith Hope Consolo, a real estate broker who handled many Cosmetics Plus leases. "It makes them look good and feel good."
But retail analysts say this piece of conventional wisdom is no longer entirely true. In an economic downturn, Ms. Liebmann said, "instead of buying three lipsticks, you buy two."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Cosmetics retailers are luring customers with spa services like the exfoliating hand treatment offered at an Origins store, left, or by letting eager shoppers try out beautifying products of all types, as Sephora does. (Photographs by Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: STATES EASE LAWS ON TIME IN PRISON 

BYLINE:  By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
Reversing a 20-year trend toward ever-tougher criminal laws, a number of states this year have quietly rolled back some of their most stringent anticrime measures, including those imposing mandatory minimum sentences and forbidding early parole.
 The new laws, along with a voter initiative in California that provides for treatment rather than prison for many drug offenders, reflect a political climate that has changed markedly as crime has fallen, the cost of running prisons has exploded and the economy has slowed, state legislators and criminal justice experts say. 
 After a two-decade boom in prison construction that quadrupled the number of inmates, the states now spend a total of $30 billion a year to operate their prisons, according to the Bureau of Justice Statistics. And with voters saying they are more concerned about issues like education than street violence, state legislators are finding they must cut the growth in prison inmates to satisfy the demand for new services and to balance their budgets.
"I think these new laws are pretty significant, with legislators taking politically risky steps that would have been unthinkable even a couple of years ago," said Michael Jacobson, a former corrections commissioner for New York City who is now a professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. 
"When the spigot stops, you are forced to look at the items that have grown the most, and inevitably, in every state, it is corrections," Professor Jacobson said.
With several states re-examining their criminal laws, including New York, Alabama, Georgia, New Mexico and Idaho, these changes are likely to hasten a decline in the number of state prison inmates, which began to fall in the second half of last year for the first time since 1972, the experts and lawmakers say.
Perhaps the most significant changes, the experts say, occurred in four states that this year dropped some 1990's sentencing laws that required criminals to serve long terms without the possibility of parole. The four are Louisiana, Connecticut, Indiana and North Dakota.
Iowa passed a similar law last spring, giving judges discretion in imposing what had been a mandatory five-year sentence for low-level drug crimes and certain property crimes, including burglary.
In May, Mississippi passed a law making first-time nonviolent offenders eligible for parole after serving only 25 percent of their sentences, instead of the 85 percent required under a law enacted in 1994. Since the earlier law went into effect, the number of prison inmates in Mississippi jumped to 37,754 this year, from 10,699 in 1994, according to state figures.
And West Virginia, which has had one of the fastest-growing prison systems, enacted a law to reduce the number of inmates by giving money to local counties to develop alternatives to prison, like electronic monitoring of people on probation and centers where probationers would report each day.
"These may be small states, and the new laws are not comprehensive reforms, but it is very significant that these are not just liberal Northeastern states," said Nicholas Turner, director of the State Sentencing and Corrections Project at the Vera Institute of Justice in New York, a research organization that is working with a number of the states to reduce prison costs and explore options instead of prison. "What has happened this year in these states implies a lot about a change in the political culture."
Some lawmakers and lobbyists say such a shift is looming in New York, where Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed softening the state's notoriously tough Rockefeller-era drug laws, and the Democratic-controlled State Assembly has insisted on even more far-reaching changes.
Perhaps the most surprising change has come in Louisiana, which has the highest per capita incarceration rate in the nation and has long had a reputation for brutal prison conditions and wide racial disparities in who is sentenced to prison.
Louisiana's new law, strongly supported by Gov. Mike Foster, a conservative Republican, and the state district attorneys' association, eliminates mandatory prison time for crimes like burglary of a residence, possession of small amounts of drugs, Medicaid fraud, prostitution, theft of a firearm and obscenity. Since Louisiana imposed mandatory minimum sentences six years ago, its prison population has increased by 50 percent, to 38,000 from 25,260, and was projected to grow to 46,000 by 2004. Under mandatory minimum sentences, state expenditures for prisons have soared 70 percent, state figures show.
"This is an attempt to bring under control a system that was bankrupting the state and was not reducing crime," said State Senator Donald R. Cravins, a Democrat who was one of the law's prime supporters. 
The situation had reached a point in Louisiana, Senator Cravins said, that "we had half the population in prison and the other half watching them," while the state spent $600 million a year on corrections and was facing a budget deficit.
"We were pouring money into a bottomless pit, but we couldn't address the real causes of crime like the lack of early childhood education," he said, a particular problem in Louisiana, which has the lowest per capita income in the nation.
Not everyone has supported the revised laws. Some legislators have been accused of being "soft on crime" and prosecutors have complained that scrapping mandatory minimum sentences takes away one of their best tools to get street criminals to plea bargain and trade information about other criminals in exchange for lesser sentences.
Stephen Mallory, a former deputy director of the Mississippi Bureau of Narcotics who is now chairman of the department of criminal justice at the University of Southern Mississippi, opposed his state's new law restoring eligibility for parole for first-time nonviolent criminals. 
"It's a joke," Professor Mallory said, because "anyone in law enforcement knows these are not first-time offenders. There is a strong likelihood that they've committed 30 or 40 crimes before and just finally got caught."
The change in the law will be costly for society, Professor Mallory said. "If you turn out someone who is a real career criminal, you will save $30,000 in prison costs, but he will do $100,000 worth of property and emotional damage in more crimes."
But State Representative Michael P. Lawlor, a Democrat who is chairman of the Connecticut House judiciary committee, says he sees another advantage to the new laws, including the one sponsored by Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, that ends a decade-old system of mandatory prison terms for nonviolent drug offenders. He said the changes would help reduce huge racial disparities in who goes to prison.
Nine out of 10 people in jail and prison in Connecticut for drug offenses are black or Hispanic, Mr. Lawlor said, but half of those arrested on drug charges are white. Part of the problem, he said, is a Connecticut law that established a mandatory sentence for selling or possessing drugs within two-thirds of a mile of a school, day care center or public housing project. 
The result, Mr. Lawlor said, is that 90 percent of cities like Hartford or New Haven are within these areas, and so poor and minority people who live in these areas end up in prison for any drug charge.
"I think this is the most significant change in criminal justice policy we have made in more than 10 years," Mr. Lawlor said. "Two or three years from now you are going to be able to look back and see the new law has made a tremendous impact on who is in prison."
And there are more states where change may soon come. The sponsors of the California referendum that was approved by voters last November mandating drug treatment instead of incarceration for first- and second-time offenders convicted of drug possession, are pushing to get a similar initiative on the ballot in Florida, Ohio and Michigan for the 2002 election.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 8, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Sunday about the easing of mandatory sentencing laws in some states misstated the number of prisoners in Mississippi, where parole eligibility was changed for nonviolent first-time offenders. It is about 19,000, not 37,754.
A related article about proposals to overhaul New York's drug laws referred incorrectly to the state's classification and punishment of some drug crimes. The top category of drug crime is a Class A felony; Class B is the third-highest.
Class B, the most frequent charge under the laws, applies to the sale of drugs in any amount, the possession of a drug between one-eighth of an ounce and 2 ounces, or the possession of any amount with the intent to sell it. The minimum sentence for a Class B felony is 1 to 3 years, not 15 years to life.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Commercial Markets Show Signs of a Slowdown

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
RESIDENTIAL real estate agents in New Jersey are still bubbling, reporting buoyant housing prices, apparently unnettled by scattered reports of cautionary signs. In contrast, midyear reports about the commercial markets -- industrial, office and retail -- provide a bit of a reality check. They also cast a bit of a pall.
 A recent report by the real estate services concern Cushman & Wakefield of New Jersey Inc. referred to a "generally declining overall picture" in the commercial market, despite basic health in the first six months. The report added that "the strong grip of the national economic slowdown is defining the forecast for the second half of the year." 
 Grubb & Ellis Research of Fairfield, N.J., reached similar conclusions, saying, "It appears that the wind has dissipated from the sails of the Northern and Central New Jersey office market, as we drift aimlessly on the open waters in mid-2001." 
GVA Williams of New Jersey analyzed statistics and trends in crucial submarkets and issued a sort of left-handed compliment. "New Jersey has not felt the effects of the general economic slowdown as severely as some other parts of the country," the midyear report said. "Demand will remain strong compared to other markets as long as there continues to be no speculative overbuilding."
Layoffs, mergers and acquisitions are generating higher vacancy rates for office space. A spate of retail bankruptcy filings -- including Bradlees, Grand Union and Lechters -- has disrupted the retail market. If there is any sector staying afloat, the midyear reports indicated, it is the industrial market.
One positive development noted in the reports was Volkswagen of America's long-term lease for 928,000 square feet of distribution space off Exit 8A of the New Jersey Turnpike and relatively close to the Port of Newark and Newark Airport. Volkswagen is expected to occupy an entire facility now under construction in Cranbury Township. 
The office market, in contrast to the industrial sector, is being hit hard, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Following are some of the major blows:
* Rising unemployment (3.6 percent in January, now 4 percent).
* A dragging telecommunications industry, including thousands of layoffs at Lucent Technologies.
* Increasing supply of sublease space as companies contract and fold.
* Rising vacancy rates in Manhattan, meaning less demand in New Jersey.
At 10.5 percent, the average vacancy rate for sublease space is the highest since year-end 1998, the report says. Vacancy rates for Class A space in northern New Jersey are 11.9 percent, up from 5.9 percent a year ago.
In Parsippany, Class A vacancy rates climbed to 22 percent, up 14 percentage points over last year. 
Franklin Township reported the region's highest overall vacancy rate, covering all classes of space, 15 percent, and that is poised to climb. Merrill Lynch is about to move to offices in Hopewell, and this will put an additional 700,000 square feet on the market in Franklin.
On the other hand, in Newark, the city's revitalization efforts are helping to maintain relative stability. The overall vacancy rate is 12.4 percent, up slightly from last year's 11.1 percent, but better than the 10-year high of 17.8 percent in 1995.
The market in central New Jersey is also holding up well. Class A vacancy rates are down, to 8.4 percent, from 10.7 percent a year ago. 
"The pharmaceutical sector is strong," said Jonathan S. Meisel, a senior director for Cushman & Wakefield. The pharmaceutical company Aventis leased 417,288 square feet near Route 78 in Bridgewater earlier this year; Cendant, the travel, rental car, real estate and finanacial services business, leased 386,079 square feet in Parsippany. Other brokers and developers noted UBS/PaineWebber's lease for 1.1 million square feet on the Hudson waterfront in the Newport Office Center VII in Jersey City. 
Still, the number of leases statewide of more than 100,000 square feet is down. Cushman & Wakefield reports 7 large leases during the first half of the year; there were 25 at midyear last year. 
GVA Williams's report asserts the office market has entered a period of "neutral absorption" when an equal amount of space is being leased and being made available. Other reports describe a flood of sublet space but consider it an opportunity because it could force landlords to reduce rental rates. 
The retail sector, according to Grubb & Ellis Research, is suffering from a slowdown. "A year ago, the New Jersey retail market was defined by strong retail sales coupled with a growing, stable economy," the Grubb & Ellis midyear report said. "Many retailers were pursuing aggressive expansion strategies to take advantage of prolific sales volumes."
"Practically overnight, we have reversed direction," it concluded.
Grubb & Ellis reports a rise of bankruptcy court filings as well as store closings. Last spring, Federated Department Stores converted most of its 24 Stern's stores to Macy's or Bloomingdale's. Five Stern's stores closed.
Some large retailers are taking advantage of available space to expand. When Bradlees closed, Home Depot, Kohl's and Wal-Mart bought 35 of the 105 Bradlees stores in New Jersey. Kohl's used the same strategy last year to enter the New Jersey market, acquiring many Caldor stores, after that chain went out of business.
Bankruptcy filings are also occurring among supermarkets. Grand Union filed for protection from creditors earlier this year, and C & S Wholesale Grocers acquired 170 of 180 Grand Union stores in New Jersey for an estimated $301.8 million, Grubb & Ellis reported. The wholesaler reportedly plans to keep some stores open as Grand Unions and sell the others to several chains -- including Pathmark, which recently emerged from bankruptcy protection itself.
Other chains are hoping to enter the market or expand, according to Grubb & Ellis, and the midyear prediction is for saturation of the retail market, more bankruptcy filings and more closing.
Despite the reports, retail development continues. Various real estate service companies have issued statements each month about leasing agreements they have arranged or about new construction projects.
Grubb & Ellis, for example, has fully leased the 66,000-square-foot Fort Lee Towne Centre, which is nearing completion.
In Edgewater, a 185,000-square-foot retail center is being built. In Woodcliff Lake, near Exit 171 of the Garden State Parkway, work has begun on 13 acres for a 120,000-square-foot shopping center. In Woodbridge, final approval has been given for plans to develop 25 acres into a Lowe's Home Improvement.
THE industrial market remains generally robust, with only about 5 percent of the total space available, according to NAI/James E. Hanson Inc., a commercial broker in Hackensack. 
But Cushman & Wakefield reported that the slowing economy is beginning to be felt in the industrial market.
Cushman & Wakefield's senior director, Frank Caccavo, said, "Constraint on future industrial development and a dramatic decrease in the number of manufacturing jobs statewide are rapidly changing the landscape of industrial inventory."
Cushman advised caution but also noted a bright side. Construction, it said, continues statewide, with projects ranging from 204,000 square feet to nearly 960,000 square feet expected to be completed by January.
In addition, more than 3.7 million square feet of industrial space was leased in Middlesex County in the first half of the year.
North/Central New Jersey continues to attract research and development centers for pharmaceutical and high technology companies; several are shopping for laboratory space.
NAI/James E. Hanson thinks the market in Central New Jersey is particularly strong, citing the development of the distribution hub at Exit 8A. But farther north, in Bergen and Hudson Counties, Hanson's midyear statement noted, outdated plants predominate -- and will require refitting.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
As Work and Life Blur, Office Furniture Goes 24/7

BYLINE:  By ALASTAIR GORDON 

 BODY:
THERE is an iconic photograph from the 1950's that shows I.B.M. offices, with row after row of secretaries and desks, an apparently endless grid of regimented, soul-blistering cubicles symbolizing the corporate mind-set of an earlier generation. These days, that conventional office layout is largely outmoded, a vestige of the command-and-control management model of the corporate Dark Ages. 
 The concept of the workplace has adapted to the changes in the economy, technology and the way people live. With laptops, the Internet, cell phones and faxes, the workplace can be anywhere and everywhere, and boundaries between work and personal space have blurred. 
 And as the economy has weakened, and as many people have found themselves suddenly downsized, more of them are venturing into the uncertain waters of self-employment and entrepreneurial start-ups, often adapting their home spaces into work spaces or moving into raw, industrial interiors with no apparent amenities. The Bureau of Labor Statistics says about 12 million workers in the United States now fall under the designation "workers with alternative arrangements." 
Clearly, the office no longer consists of the old icons -- the steel filing cabinet, the cubicle, the conference table. Big furniture companies like Knoll Inc. and Herman Miller have begun to respond to the new work attitudes with softer, curving forms that embrace rather than alienate the worker.
"Work has become transportable and ubiquitous, almost a state of mind," said Paola Antonelli, curator of "Workspheres," a recent exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan that explored new horizons in the workplace. "Work is where you are." 
The exhibition, which ran from February through April, included new products in cell phone technology, personal computing, work stations and furniture -- products that might be found at any up-to-the-minute showroom. 
But it also included provocative developments in the nomadic office. A team of Belgian and French designers created L'echarpe Communicante, or communicating scarf, a cuddly thing containing a communication system with phone, computer screen and keyboard. Wrap it around your face and you can tele-communicate as you saunter down the boulevard. And Hella Jongerius, a Dutch designer, developed a line called "My Soft Office" that included a bed with a computer screen in its mattress and a keyboard and mouse embedded in a "smart pillow."
"The ultimate symbol of rest and relaxation, of dreaming, doing nothing, sleeping, and making love has been fused with work," wrote Ms. Jongerius, describing her vision.
While the exhibition presented an optimistic, if at times naive, embrace of the new paradigm, a few designers responded to the darker side of the borderless office. Jennie Pineus, a Swedish designer, fabricated cocoonlike structures from white fabric and steel ribbing, intended to provide privacy and shelter from a stressful, intense work environment. Her "Cocoonchair" can be pulled about the body for moments of quiet reflection or napping. Her "Headcocoon" is a more portable version that can be worn anywhere, fitting over the head with small breathing holes and looking something like a beekeeper's mask. 
While such extremes may seem absurd, the integration of work and personal life is accepted by a new generation. "Younger knowledge workers believe there is value in this -- in integrating everything and having no boundaries," said Madelyn Hochstein, the president of DYG Inc., a firm in Danbury, Conn., that specializes in market forecasting. "They think it's sexy."
Her company has worked with several large corporations, including Ford Motor and Kraft Foods, forecasting social trends. For Knoll, DYG conducted field research on the changing workplace. Through focus groups and surveys it zoomed in on a group in its mid-20's, which Ms. Hochstein calls the "whatever generation." 
"If you're a business and you want to attract these bright young people, you have to recognize that the traditional boundaries between work and social life have disappeared," Ms. Hochstein said. "The whatever generation wants social integration. They have parties in the office at 2 p.m. They sleep in the office. It's become as much a home as a workplace and vice versa -- their homes have become workplaces." 
BOTH Knoll and Herman Miller have introduced lines aimed at younger companies that may have to adapt quickly to changing economic conditions and do not have the luxury of long-term space planning that more established companies enjoy. The new products are flexible, lightweight, designed to be sold over the Internet and easily shipped and assembled. And their cost may be within the reach of many fledgling businesses.
In Herman Miller's new Red line of office furniture, basic desk components start at around $300. The Red Rocket desk, for example, is organically shaped, looking something like the profile of a peanut. It comes with an adjustable-height pod to support a computer monitor and an extensive menu of accessories, like lighting fixtures and extra shelves, that clip or screw into the main framework. Instead of the standard file cabinet, there is something called a "soft storage cart," covered in fabric. 
"The new economy is about the individual," said Eric Chan, 46, a designer who helped to develop the line. "Everyone is now allowed to do whatever they want. Companies are trying to attract the best brain power and the work environment they offer is one of the big incentives."
Another variation, the Red Grasshopper, is a soft, adaptable system that has the look of NASA space equipment. Desks and storage units are wrapped in thick, protective padding. The Grasshopper uses what the company calls "soft docking" -- different components nuzzle together without precise connections. Parts can be easily moved and reconfigured. 
"Office furniture is no longer about being a status symbol," Mr. Chan said. "Everyone's a free agent now. Technology has become so mobile that everything is possible. People don't need to feel that they're working in an office. It should be fun. Why should they sit at a mahogany table? The Red system looks more like they're surfing or camping, not just sitting in a cubicle at work." 
At Knoll, Christine Barber, director of the workplace design team, explained the idea of its new line this way: "There's a backlash, a revolution against the right angle. The younger generation wants a sense of community, more visually stimulating and less monotonous work environments. They want to work as a team, not as a cog in the machine."
Ms. Barber helped to guide Knoll through a rethinking of the modular office unit. In place of the file cabinets and cubicles of the "Man in the Gray Flannel Suit" era, Knoll is gambling on a new system called the A3. The company went outside the conventional industrial design world and hired Hani Rashid and Lise Anne Couture, architects and partners at Asymptote Architecture in Manhattan who are known for their digitally-minded projects and are as comfortable designing Web sites as they are buildings. Their designs for the new trading space and Web site of the New York Stock Exchange brought them to the attention of Andrew B. Cogan, Knoll's chief executive.
Karen Stone, director of Knoll's interior design division, said, "Their approach was spatial and environmental as opposed to object-driven."
INSPIRED by airplane interiors and camping equipment, the podlike A3 unit is made from tubular steel framing covered with stretchy mesh fabric. It wraps around the office worker with womblike curves. While providing some privacy, the A3's translucent envelope provides a sense of visual continuity. The A3 can be used alone in an open loft space or as part of a grouping in a more conventional office space.
Like many aspects of corporate America, the workplace has been changing so quickly that design companies have had to compress their normal development cycles.
"You can't wait that long anymore -- it's about speed," Ms. Barber said. "We have taken a seven-year product development cycle time and condensed that down to two years because we must respond instantly to market requirements." 
The research and development phase for the A3 began in late 1999, and the prototype was unveiled in June at the NeoCon furniture show in Chicago. It should be available to the public next March.
While a more elastic work zone may offer unprecedented levels of freedom, there is a down side. Like a needy dog, the office can now follow workers everywhere. Although the Red and A3 systems may use padding or stretchy fabric to soften the edges, the tyranny of the 24-hour-work day is undeniable. It is a state that some workers now call "24/ 7," "e-mail jail" or being "in the blur." 
"It's like velvet handcuffs," said Eric Kuhn, a consultant to an international public relations firm who now lives in Paris and works on a global time clock. "The digital era has taken 9 to 5 and turned it into a constant flow of connectedness that becomes extremely demanding." 
So while a pillow keyboard or scarf communication system may appear to be on the outer fringes of plausibility, the concepts may not be far from the truth -- conjuring up a future of eternal diligence where the worker never gets a break, even during sleeping hours, but rather is eternally chained to the humming demands of technology. Very comfortably, though.

HEADLINE: Dogfight forDollars On Capitol Hill 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THE video shows a flair for the dramatic.
 A crowd anxiously watches a pilot climb into a sleek, futuristic-looking jet. The engines whine, the plane rises slowly like a hulking prehistoric bird and the onlookers explode, cheering with joy and relief. 
 The trailer for a new Tom Hanks film? Try the latest promotional video for Lockheed Martin's experimental plane, the X-35 -- better known as the Joint Strike Fighter. 
The video is part of an extravagant Lockheed promotional kit that includes CD-ROM images of test flights, glossy photographs and a videotape of the aircraft breaking the sound barrier. And that is just one piece of a multimillion-dollar lobbying, advertising and marketing campaign aimed at beating its competition, Boeing, for what could be the most lucrative military contract, worth more than $200 billion. 
"This is the future for both Lockheed and Boeing," said Richard Aboulafia, an aerospace analyst at the Teal Group, a consulting firm in Fairfax, Va. "The stakes are huge."
Lockheed is hardly the only military contractor mounting an aggressive campaign here. The season for lobbying by the military industry is in full bloom, and contractors are inundating Congress with Power Point briefings, shuttling officials to test sites and factories, hiring top-drawer lobbyists and showering lawmakers with campaign contributions.
The reason for all the activity is a confluence of major decisions expected this fall:
* The Pentagon is scheduled to award contracts not only for the Joint Strike Fighter, but also for the DD-21 destroyer, which could be the most important shipbuilding program of the next two decades. 
* The Pentagon must decide whether to block either General Dynamics or Northrop Grumman from acquiring Newport News Shipbuilding, the nation's only builder of aircraft carriers.
* As soon as Congress returns on Tuesday from its summer recess, it will begin what is expected to be a contentious debate on the size of the Pentagon budget for the 2002 fiscal year, which begins on Oct. 1. The first hearings are on Wednesday, and many Democrats are pushing to trim President Bush's proposed $33 billion increase. Though the increase would be the largest since the mid-1980's, many industry officials had hoped for more from a Republican president.
* By the end of this month, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld will complete the Quadrennial Defense Review, mandated by Congress, that will set the size and shape of the armed forces, provide a template for future budgets and help determine the fate of an array of billion-dollar programs.
* Also this month, the armed services will begin outlining their budgets for the 2003 fiscal year, the year when Mr. Rumsfeld has vowed to make major decisions on weapons programs. And because of the rapidly declining federal surplus, he is expected to require the services to find cuts to help pay for their favorite systems.
"There is no question that we probably cannot afford every weapon system" in development, President Bush said in late August. "This administration is going to have to winnow them down."
The outcome is vital to a host of major companies, including United Defense, Northrop Grumman, TRW and Raytheon. Not surprisingly, they have been furiously working the marble corridors of Capitol Hill and the pale yellow hallways of the Pentagon to keep their programs alive and well. Recent lobbying reports indicate that military contractors are likely to spend nearly $60 million on lobbying this year, less than the communications or banking industries but more than lawyers and labor unions combined. Of that total, Lockheed and Boeing together account for more than $10 million.
In recent weeks, their work has ranged far and wide.
One day in June, one of the Joint Strike Fighter prototypes at Lockheed passed a crucial test, lifting off and landing vertically. The company immediately dispatched a video of the event to CNN.
Within 24 hours, Boeing completed a similarly complex maneuver with its prototype, the X-32: taking off on a shortened runway, then hovering and landing vertically. The company quickly sent a video to CNN, too. 
But the next morning, CNN began running a segment on the Joint Strike Fighter that used only the Lockheed video. Phones began ringing and managers started screaming in Boeing's Joint Strike Fighter test office at the Naval Air Station in Patuxent River, Md. 
"My hair was turning white by the minute," recalled Denny Kline, communications director for Boeing's Joint Strike Fighter. He spent hours on the phone cajoling CNN clerks and producers to find the Boeing videotape, which was eventually spliced into the report.
SO it goes in the hottest competition for Pentagon dollars in many years. 
On Oct. 26, the Pentagon is scheduled to choose, in a winner-take-all competition, between Lockheed and Boeing proposals for the fighter-bomber, which would replace aging aircraft in three services: Air Force F-16's and A-10's, Navy F-14's and F-18's and Marine Corps Harriers. 
To the winner would go the bountiful contract to deliver nearly 3,000 of the jets by the end of the decade to the United States and Britain, which has been a partner in the program.
Along with it would go the promise of thousands more sales to other allied nations, like Turkey, Norway and Israel. And after all the planes are delivered, the maintenance, spare parts and training contracts could be worth hundreds of billions more.
The loser, many military experts and Wall Street analysts predict, may be forced out of the tactical fighter business by the end of the decade, when production of other fighters, like F-22's and F-18's, winds down, leaving only the Joint Strike Fighter.
The Pentagon has argued that the winner-take-all system will lead to lower costs and better designs. Some military officials, however, are now concerned that the armed forces will be left with just one supplier of fighter jets by 2010 and are advocating that the work be split between the two companies. But it is not clear that the bidders would even accept that arrangement, and for now, the department plans to award the contract to just one team. 
As if the fierce competition was not enough, Boeing and Lockheed have also worried that Mr. Rumsfeld may scale back or delay the program, as has been recommended by some influential military analysts. 
The concept of the Joint Strike Fighter, as developed by the Clinton administration, was for a relatively affordable workhorse plane with advanced stealth technology and electronics. At about $35 million a plane, the Joint Strike Fighter would cost one-fifth the price of the more sophisticated F-22.
To control costs, the Pentagon proposed using essentially the same aircraft for three services, with modifications to suit each one. The Navy would get a plane with longer wings that could land on carriers, the Marines one that could hover and land vertically in tight spots and the Air Force a version that would use conventional runways. The ability to share designs, parts and technological skill among the services would reduce costs sharply, Pentagon officials have said. And they contend that selling the planes to NATO and Asian allies would make it easier for the United States to conduct joint military operations overseas.
Talk within the industry and the Pentagon of the program's demise has diminished in recent weeks, as the Bush administration has called for spending $1.5 billion on the program for the coming year, enough to continue development. But that has not slowed the pace of promotion.
Over the summer, both companies shuttled reporters, Congressional aides and Pentagon officials to witness test flights at the Patuxent River base and at Edwards Air Force Base in California. Lockheed was so concerned that Boeing's prototype was receiving more attention at Patuxent River, an hour from Capitol Hill, that it briefly considered bringing its Marine Corps prototype east from California this summer. 
In the past year, both companies have bolstered their already large lobbying stables with big names. Lockheed retained Haley Barbour, the former chairman of the Republican National Committee, who has close ties to the administration. Boeing has hired Rudy de Leon, the deputy secretary of defense in the final months of the Clinton administration, to run its Washington office.
Although Mr. De Leon is barred from lobbying on military matters for one year, he was seen recently patrolling the hallways outside a House Armed Services Committee meeting, where he said he was renewing acquaintances.
The companies have also waged a battle of newspaper advertising in Washington, heralding every new testing advance with full-page glory. "If we've done this once, we've done it a thousand times," a Boeing ad boasted in The Washington Post on July 9, referring to short takeoffs and vertical landings by its Marine Corps version. Lockheed has parried with ads almost daily in The Post, highlighting the successes of its program. "Proof through performance," many of the ads say.
And with the help of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, both have worked hard to enlist support from Congress, particularly lawmakers from Texas, Missouri, Washington and California, where thousands of Joint Strike Fighter jobs are in the offing. One of the strongest selling points on Capitol Hill is that parts for the plane would be built in more than half the states. Boeing has also promised to build a $250 million assembly plant near Lambert-St. Louis International Airport; Lockheed contends that winning the contract will save 7,000 jobs in Fort Worth. 
"We've spent a good deal of time on Congress, making sure they understand the message on why J.S.F. is important," said Charles Thomas Burbage, a Lockheed executive vice president who is general manager for its Joint Strike Fighter program.
When President Bush was elected, many military industry officials quietly cheered. The industry had contributed nearly $9 million to Republican candidates last year, twice as much as to Democrats, in the hope that a Republican administration and Congress would bolster military spending sharply.
Battered by a decade of post-cold-war downsizing and consolidation, many people in the industry had hoped for a return to the heyday of the Reagan administration, when Pentagon spending on new weapons was double the $60 billion procurement budget of last year, measured in constant 2000 dollars. 
"We believe the backdrop for the sector looks good, and significant increases in the Pentagon's budget will continue well into the next decade," a report by Schwab Capital Markets predicted in January.
But things have not turned out so rosy. The slowing economy and President Bush's $1.35 trillion tax cut have sharply squeezed the federal surplus, leaving little money for significant military spending increases for years to come.
And though the Bush administration has called for a $33 billion increase in 2002, above the current $296 billion Pentagon budget, most of that growth would go toward health care, salaries and spare parts -- not the expensive jets, ships and tanks that military contractors produce.
"There is a more subdued environment now than investors had hoped for," said Byron K. Callan, an aerospace analyst at Merrill Lynch.
At the same time, the administration's talk of "skipping a generation" of weapons technology -- moving more toward robots and remote-controlled systems -- has created deep anxieties among makers of current-generation ships, jets and howitzers.
Some companies, of course, are hoping for sweeping changes that would divert dollars from traditional programs into high-technology systems, like space-based lasers, unmanned submarines and digital battlefield communications equipment. And missile defense contractors, led by Boeing, are counting on the administration to push for huge spending increases on their programs to fuel profits.
But full-scale production of many of those systems remains years away. And military contractors cannot reap large profits from research and development. The big money is in the production of heavy conventional weapons like ships and aircraft -- and those are the programs the industry is pushing hardest.
"This is an industry that has to be nurtured and sustained," said Lawrence F. Skibbie, a retired Army lieutenant general who is the departing president of the National Defense Industrial Association, a trade group representing 900 military contractors. "We just can't ignore it and then every 10 or 15 years when there is an emergency say, 'Let's produce something.' " 
In June, James P. McCarthy, a retired Air Force general who was chairman of a Pentagon panel assessing weapons programs, sent a chill through the nation's shipbuilding industry when he announced that a proposed next-generation destroyer, the DD-21, was not "truly transformational" -- the code word for favored weapons programs in the Bush administration.
Officials at the Bath Iron Works in Maine and at Ingalls Shipbuilding in Mississippi, the shipyards competing for the DD-21 contract, sprang into action. They called allies on Capitol Hill like Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, urging them to respond. And they found a sympathetic member of the panel, Stanley R. Arthur, a retired Navy admiral, to counter General McCarthy's remarks. "I certainly consider DD-21," Admiral Arthur said in a statement, "to be transformational."
WITHIN days, General McCarthy issued a statement clarifying that he was not advocating that the program be canceled or delayed. It was a hard-fought, if small, victory for the shipbuilders in a trying year for the $30 billion DD-21 program.
"We went to members of the press and said, 'This is wrong,' " a shipbuilding industry official said. "We also made sure the issue was raised on the Hill, so it wouldn't go unchallenged. But it's a difficult thing."
With the Navy having shrunk to 316 ships today from more than 500 ships in 1990, shipbuilding has been one of the most battered of the military industries. For Bath, owned by General Dynamics, and Ingalls, recently acquired by Northrop, the DD-21 program was to be the future. Yet it hangs in the balance.
The ship is intended to carry more Tomahawk cruise missiles and bigger guns than any current destroyer, to be stealthy enough for missions near shore and to operate with just one-third the crew of a typical destroyer. The Navy has proposed buying 32 of the $750 million ships over the next two decades.
"DD-21 is being designed to be the most capable, most survivable ship ever to sail the oceans of the earth," read a full-page ad that the Northrop team placed in The Washington Post in July.
That is the message trumpeted by lawmakers from the shipbuilding states in letters, Congressional hearings and private meetings with Pentagon officials.
"If you give the fire-support mission and the leap-ahead technologies of DD-21 thorough consideration, you will agree this nation needs to have available the capabilities promised by the DD-21 program," said one letter to Mr. Rumsfeld, signed by a bipartisan group of nine senators, including Ms. Collins; Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, the minority leader; and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.
Their efforts have helped persuade the administration to seek more than $600 million to continue design work on the DD-21, but the program's long-range future remains cloudy.
In June, the Pentagon delayed selecting a contractor until Mr. Rumsfeld finishes his review, raising new doubts about its fate. The program has yet to win the undivided support of the Navy itself, where some commanders would rather spend the money on new aircraft carriers, submarines or fighter jets. 
The key to survival, industry officials said, will be to have the Pentagon award a contract, allowing initial construction. Then jobs will open up in more districts, broadening the ship's support on Capitol Hill.
Almost from the day that Mr. Rumsfeld took office, it became conventional Pentagon wisdom that a mobile artillery system known as the Crusader would be canceled. It was too heavy, too expensive and did not belong in the faster, lighter force the Army is trying to build, its many critics said.
But thanks in part to an aggressive counteroffensive by the Crusader's well-connected manufacturer, United Defense, and its allies in the Army and Congress, the program shows signs of surviving. 
When, for instance, one of Mr. Rumsfeld's review panels recommended canceling the program last spring, the Army came back swinging, inundating Mr. Rumsfeld and his aides, news reporters and Congressional officials with briefings on why it must have 480 Crusaders at a cost of $11 billion.
"It is a critical requirement," Lt. Gen. Paul J. Kern, the chief acquisition officer for the Army, said in a recent interview. "Our soldiers are very good, very well trained, but we're outgunned."
Such arguments are very compelling on Capitol Hill, where many lawmakers are loath to attack the top priorities of the armed services. And United Defense, owned by the Carlyle Group, an investment firm led by Frank C. Carlucci, a defense secretary under President Reagan, helped its cause by persuading a powerful ally, Representative J. C. Watts Jr., the fourth-ranking Republican in the House, to press Mr. Rumsfeld about the Crusader.
"It still has opponents at the highest levels of the Pentagon," said an aide to Mr. Watts, who represents the Oklahoma district where the Crusader would be assembled. "But Rumsfeld is aware of its Congressional support."
CONCEIVED in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war in 1991, the computerized Crusader, with its 155-millimeter cannon, is intended to fire shells farther, faster and more accurately than any artillery gun in existence. One Crusader will do the work of several of the Army's current artillery systems, United Defense says.
"The best deserve the best," boasts a a company advertisement.
But the gun is also bulky: the Army ordered United Defense to slim down the Crusader, which rides on tracks, and its resupply vehicle to about 80 tons, from 110 tons.
The Crusader is United Defense's main new program, and the company has nurtured a close alliance with the Army to keep it alive. Artillery soldiers, for example, were intimately involved in early design phases, recommending improvements to the steering mechanism, the placement of video displays and the location of maintenance panels.
Like the Crusader, the V-22 Osprey offers a good example of how difficult it can be to cancel a program that has strong support from all three legs of the "Iron Triangle": the military industry, senior uniformed officers and Congress.
After two crashes last year killed 23 marines and raised sharp questions about the Osprey's safety, cancellation of the $40 billion V-22 program seemed imminent. Its future became even darker when the Marines disclosed in January that maintenance records had been falsified, suggesting that the Osprey -- already delayed and over budget -- was being rushed into production. 
On top of that, Vice President Dick Cheney had tried to cancel the Osprey while he was secretary of defense under President Bush's father.
Yet the Marines have never wavered in their dogged assertion that the Osprey -- which can hover like a helicopter and cruise like a airplane -- was essential to their combat strategy. No helicopter could fly as fast or as far, senior Marine Corps officers argued time and again.
The Osprey's supporters have faced a major problem getting their message out: neither the Marine Corps nor the manufacturers, Boeing and the Bell Helicopter unit of Textron, wanted to lobby too strenuously for the program, out of concerns of offending the dead marines' families, industry officials said. So it fell to the program's advocates on Capitol Hill, led by Representative Curt Weldon, Republican of Pennsylvania, to carry that load.
Mr. Weldon, whose district is near an Osprey plant, revitalized a defunct coalition of Osprey supporters in Congress and helped organize a Capitol Hill conference extolling the commercial and military uses of tilt-rotor technology. Among the speakers at that conference were Gen. James L. Jones, the Marine Corps commandant, and senior Bell and Boeing executives.
The effort has paid off: the Pentagon has asked Congress for $1 billion to buy 12 Ospreys next year, though it has delayed full production while safety features are added.
In his zest to support the program, Mr. Weldon even attacked a European company, Augusta Westland, when it tried to promote its EH-101 helicopter as an alternative to the V-22 several months ago. 
"The Marines know what they need, and no marketing effort by another company will make a difference," Mr. Weldon said in an interview. "This is not some contest to see who can hire the most lobbyists."
BUT while programs like the V-22, the Joint Strike Fighter, the DD-21 and the Crusader may receive money in the 2002 defense budget, their long-term futures are likely to remain in doubt for months, possibly years.
The shrinking budget surplus will make it almost impossible for the administration to build a missile defense system, develop "leap ahead" weapon technology and buy all the jets, howitzers, helicopters and ships that the armed services have requested. Inevitably, some programs must be cut or delayed, analysts say.
Still, it is also unlikely that any program will be killed outright; that is not the Pentagon way. Typically, unwanted programs are kept in development, stretched out over many years and gradually starved of resources. Given enough time, even the most dogged contractors will give up on programs that have no future. 
"Like old soldiers, big programs don't die," said Loren Thompson, chief operating officer of the Lexington Institute, a military policy organization based in Arlington, Va. "They just fade away." Until then, the stakes are enormous.
