HEADLINE: Investing; 
Amid BuildingBoom, Wariness on Stocks

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH KELLEHER 

 BODY:
WHILE much of the economy has sagged this year, home building has been a conspicuous exception. 
 Seven interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve have helped to keep mortgage rates low. Supply has barely kept up with demand, prices have risen, and builders have generated healthy profits. Shares of publicly traded builders have soared while the broad market has declined. 
 But home building has always been cyclical, and some investors are worried that the good times are almost over. Builders reported that July orders for new houses rose a mere 3 percent, compared with 10 percent in June. Home prices in Denver, Austin and San Francisco have weakened.
Still, several analysts argue that investing in building companies makes sense now. "I'm not trying to argue there's not cyclicality, but my whole point is, that's not the point," said Jim Wilson, an analyst at Jolson Merchant Partners in San Francisco.
He bases his optimism on his belief that mortgage rates will remain low, that tight supply will keep prices high and that immigration will fuel sales.
He recommends D.R. Horton, a company based in Arlington, Tex., that has had earnings growth for 23 consecutive years. Horton, which now trades at $25.24, has become one of the nation's largest builders by acquiring companies all over the country. "It can purchase everything at lower prices -- lumber, faucets, tools, labor," he said.
John Stanley, an analyst in New York for UBS Warburg, who is upbeat about the industry, said: "Consolidation is the primary story here. Not that the market is growing by leaps and bounds, but that a management is very ambitious and has a good track record of making acquisitions."
The top 10 builders account for 17 percent of the United States market, double the share eight years ago, and Mr. Stanley said he expected consolidation to continue. The largest builders have a national reach and are better able to weather local downturns. 
He recommends KB Home of Los Angeles, which trades at $32.37. Its stock has been hurt by fears that it is overexposed in Northern California. 
But Bruce Karatz, the chief executive of KB Home, said, "We're not just California." Last month, the company acquired Trademark Home Builders of Jacksonville, Fla. The company also operates in the southwestern and central United States and, through a subsidiary, in France.
Mr. Stanley also favors the Centex Corporation, a Dallas builder with wide geographic reach that provides financial services, pest control, lawn care and security. Centex's financial arm has given it "two earnings pistons, instead of one," he said.
Some analysts, however, are wary of building stocks. Barbara Allen, senior analyst at Arnhold & S. Bleichroeder Inc., an investment research firm in New York, said, "There is just too much optimism in the face of a slowing economy." August orders for new homes are expected to be weak, she said, and shares may decline as a result. 
The builders are bracing for that possibility. "Our foot is both on the brake and accelerator at the same time," said Stuart Miller, chief executive of the Lennar Corporation of Miami. 
Builders' stocks, on average, have traded at price-to-earnings ratios of 5 to 8, compared with the mid-20s for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Some analysts say home-building shares are being punished for poor performance during cyclical downturns.
NVR, a builder in McLean, Va., that is another favorite of Mr. Stanley, has been buying back its shares and now trades at $$161. He noted that NVR, whose business is concentrated around Washington and Baltimore, has a return on equity in excess of 70 percent this year. 
Ivy Zelman, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston in New York, said the sector was undervalued. Ms. Zelman buys when a stock's price-to-book ratio -- its share price divided by shareholders' equity per share -- is near 1, and sells when it is near 2. She favors Pulte Homes in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. and KB Home.
Despite the strengths of individual companies, Ms. Zelman said, the stocks tended to trade in tandem, and "there's negative sentiment swirling out there."
Stephen Kim, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said: "These stocks are too cheap, and over the long haul, you probably will make money on them. But over the next couple months, no."

HEADLINE: Appraisers Take Measure of Uncertainty 

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
SHORTLY after 8 a.m. one recent workday, as an endless stream of cars headed toward New York City on Interstate 684, Anthony Bucciero was in high spirits as he headed in his Jeep Cherokee for the northern Westchester County hamlet of Goldens Bridge.
 He was energized not merely because he was headed in the opposite direction of the rush hour traffic but also because he was on his way to do something he greatly enjoys -- appraising houses for banks and mortgage companies to determine their value. "I've been doing appraisals since 1988, and I've never grown tired of it," said the 33-year-old Mr. Bucciero. 
 Yet Mr. Bucciero is also aware that the real estate appraisal industry that he has known these 13 years is being transformed. The biggest transformation -- or threat, as many of the nation's 85,000 appraisers view it -- is the recent harnessing of computers to online databases, resulting in speedy valuations often without a formal appraisal. 
For the last nine years Mr. Bucciero has owned his own business in North White Plains, Epic Appraisals. On a typical work day he is in the office around 7 a.m., then off to do two appraisals before returning to the office to wrestle with paperwork, then home in time for dinner.
With a staff of 12, including five women, Epic has one appraiser each in Rockland County, Putnam County, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens, as well as two on Long Island. Mr. Bucciero does a lot of appraisals in Westchester, and some of Epic's other appraisers help out in the county. While Epic also appraises office buildings, stores and other commercial property, the company's financial pillar is residential appraisals. The value of a property as established by an appraiser determines how much loan officers and underwriters will lend an applicant for a new mortgage or for a refinancing.
Computerized valuation systems have the potential to shave millions of dollars nationwide off the costs of home ownership each year, but appraisers argue that they are a shortcut filled with potential potholes for homeowners.
Such systems have existed in some form for about a decade. But it took improvements in the technology and the adoption of proprietary models by the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac), the nation's biggest buyers of mortgage loans from banks and other lenders, to increase the trust in Automated Valuation Models, or A.V.M.'s. 
These systems provide valuations by collating such information as the age, size and most recent selling price of a house and updating the information according to how much prices on comparable houses have risen or declined since the last sale.
Greg A. Dennis, the president and chief operating officer of LandSafe Appraisal Services Inc. in Plano, Tex. -- a subsidiary of Countrywide Credit Industries in Calabasas, Calif. -- said the automated valuation models can analyze a couple of hundred "comparables," as basically similar houses in basically similar neighborhoods are called, in 30 seconds or less. In fact, he added, "The A.V.M.'s were developed in response to the lender's demand for speed."
With the electronic valuations, Fannie Mae no longer requires every new house in a subdivision to have an individual property appraisal. For some other valuations it requires only a "drive by" appraisal -- that is, a look at the property from the street. "When we can confirm that the sales price is reasonable for that property and location, we may not require an appraisal," said Mark T. Simpson, director of Fannie Mae's single-family mortgage business.
This April, Freddie Mac began authorizing the use of fully automated appraisals for the first time. After determining market value, its automated underwriting Loan Prospector software allows homeowners with good credit ratings and a down payment of at least 20 percent to skip a formal appraisal on loans up to $275,000, although the homeowner or lender can still request a standard appraisal. 
But with a Loan Prospector valuation available for $50 or $200, depending on the borrower's downpayment or credit, and with Freddie Mac estimating that electronic appraisals will save borrowers $500 million a year in appraisal fees, it is not hard to imagine which appraisal most borrowers and lenders are likely to choose -- even though traditional appraisers contend that the automated valuation models have many limitations that can be overcome only by a full on-site walk-through.
AS if the size and muscle of the Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac markets were not trouble enough for the traditional appraiser, a number of real estate and loan companies are also working to develop electronic systems, and some, like LandSafe, already have them in place. In March through May of this year, the most recent quarter for which it has data, LandSafe performed more than 100,000 automated valuation models a month, more than twice as many as it did a year earlier.
All the valuations were done in conjunction with automated underwriting, which analyzes such things as an applicant's credit and collateral in determining whether to make the loan, and prequalification, which takes into account income, assets and liabilities. None of the valuations were done in lieu of a traditional appraisal. 
With such technological tools available, it is no wonder that Tom Motta, president-elect of the 19,000-member Appraisal Institute in Chicago, recently said, "We're clearly in a new economy, and when things change, you either have to deal with it or find another business to be in."
Mike L. Austin, the president of the American Society of Appraisers, with almost 6,000 members, said there would always be a need for appraisers who do traditional appraisals. But like Mr. Motta, he is not brimming with confidence about the future. "The various appraisal societies have either stable or declining memberships," he said, "and even those whose numbers have gone up now have a lot of part-time appraisers." 
Mr. Bucciero said he had no intention of finding another business to be in, but neither is he oblivious to the challenges posed by computer technology.
As he pulls up to his first house of the day, a one and a half story contemporary home on 4.5 acres, he said of the computerized models: "They can do a lot of things fast, and they're especially good for urban areas, where houses are close together. But we're the only people going out to look at every single house and looking at it as if we were prospective buyers." 
Many other appraisers feel the same way. 
Taylor Beerbower, who founded Mulberry Street Appraisals in Fairfield, Conn., said that while the computers are making inroads, without walking through a house there is no way to see whether there is an alarm system, how many bathrooms there are or what the bedrooms and closets look like. "Even a system that's equipped to handle a lot of tract houses in the same neighborhood and built at the same time," he said, "will more than likely miss the changes that they've probably undergone in the past 40 or 50 years."
Still, while Mr. Beerbower has little faith in electronic appraisals, he does not shun modern technology. On the contrary, he employs an assistant to drive him to and from the jobs while he loads into his laptop the notes he will put into his appraisals. 
Appraisers acknowledge that they, too, occasionally miss details in a house, for example, misstating the number of square feet. "Sometimes it's because there are a lot of lousy appraisers just as there are lots of incompetents in every profession," said Ken Russ of Realty Appraisal Inc. in Nutley, N.J.
A visitor would not get that impression from tailing Mr. Bucciero during his inspections. After taking photos of the house and street with his digital camera, he measures the outside of the house with a roller tape, a device that resembles a child's push toy with a digital counter. Meanwhile, he is also observing the deck, the lawn, the gutters and roof, before beginning his tour of each room -- even climbing the pull-down stairs that lead to the attic.
During his 45 minutes at the property, he jots down dimensions and notes for the report that he will submit to the lender, in this case a mortgage broker in Purchase, N.Y. That report, usually 10 or more pages, plus the photos, will include the Uniform Residential Appraisal Report, a standard two-page form filled with details about the property, including such things as real estate taxes, the driveway surface and the condition of patio, porch and fence.
"Many owners confuse appraisers with home inspectors," Mr. Bucciero said. "We don't get into the condition of the mechanical equipment or appliances," he said, "but if we see a puddle near a boiler or what looks like a leaky oil tank, we'll suggest that the lender have an inspector go out." Because of the confusion, many homeowners think that getting an appraisal means they get a home inspection with it, he said.
Elaine Schrittwieser, an Epic appraiser working mainly in Putnam County, and one of a growing number of women in what until about a decade ago had been an almost exclusively male domain, said that although it usually takes two to four days to write up a detailed appraisal for the mortgage company or bank, "a lot of people want to know the amount of the appraisal right then and there."
And heaven forbid if the appraiser comes up with a assessment below what the owners think their property is worth -- even if, as often happens, Mrs. Schrittwieser said, "You point out to them that the closet you see in the house you're appraising is not the bedroom that they claimed it was."
Inflated expectations are, of course, unique neither to Putnam County nor to New York state. "I've had mortgage companies say to me, 'How dare you appraise that house for such-and-such,' " said Larry J. Sharpe, an appraiser who also owns Sharpe Realty in Newark. "I've also had calls from buyers, mortgage representatives, underwriters, realtors and the owners' lawyers calling to complain," he added, "and they're all singing the same song." 
The appraisers, however, say the complainers are singing off tune, confusing them (or more likely, trying to confuse them) with the difference between the appraised value of a property and the selling price -- the latter a purely arbitrary amount that a buyer is willing to pay.
"That's how you often wind up with the buyer or lender saying to the appraiser, 'If Joe Doaks wants to pay more than the house is worth, who are you to say no?' " Mr. Sharpe said. "He wants that house, and let's say he's willing to pay 10 grand more, maybe 10 grand's nothing to him. So they climb all over you."
Mr. Sharpe and other appraisers say that argument would be valid as long as the real estate market continued going up. "But when the cycle comes to a halt," Mr. Sharpe added, "you wind up in a fix like back in the 1980's when a lot of houses went into foreclosure, and the lenders took a big hit." 
With only the slightest hint that he's joking, Mr. Bucciero said, "One of the things you run into all the time is every homeowner thinking he has the nicest house on the nicest block in the nicest neighborhood." If your appraisal does not reflect that, he added, "Some of the owners go ballistic." One way they or the lender or the broker show their dissatisfaction is by "neglecting" to pay for the appraisal.
With interest rates low and the value of houses still high, some homeowners have been refinancing their mortgages, thereby lowering their monthly payments and taking cash out of the property. In the three months that ended on June 30, according to Freddie Mac, 57 percent of its loans were for mortgage refinancing, up from 52 percent in the first quarter. 
Many appraisers draw the line at cooperatives, however because, Mr. Bucciero said, "the sales of co-ops are not public information, there's no recorded deed, and in Manhattan there's no Multiple Listing Service to get the information about sales." There are no deeds because owners of co-ops own shares in the corporation that owns their building, along with the right to occupy their apartment. 
The business of appraising has seen significant changes in recent years. When Mr. Bucciero decided in 1988 to switch from being a foreclosure inspector for a bank in Connecticut to become an appraiser with a company in Pelham, N.Y., there were no requirements. "The company trained us," he said, "but soon afterward you had to be licensed." 
Licensing grew out of the savings and loan industry collapse, which led Congress to require that real estate appraisers meet certain standards, to be spelled out by the states. Mr. Austin, the president of the American Society of Appraisers, said the 50 states have roughly similar requirements, including on-the-job apprenticeship and classroom study. 
The visit on which an appraisal is based can last for less than 20 minutes for a 1,000-square-foot one-bedroom house to an hour or more for a big old Victorian. And while the national appraisal cost averaged $334 last year, according to Freddie Mac, it probably averaged $400 in the tristate area. But, depending on the size of a property and the time needed for an inspection, the cost can reach $1,000 for the multimillion dollar houses and condominiums that have dotted Manhattan and the suburbs during the last decade. 
"It sounds like a fast, easy way to make a few hundred dollars," Mr. Bucciero said. "But people don't realize the time taken up by research, writing up the reports and returning again and again. If it's a construction loan, where lenders parcel out the money as the work progresses, it's not unusual to go back seven or eight times to update the appraisal."
As he prepared to drive across the county to Croton-on-Hudson to look at a house for a mortgage banker in Newburgh, in Orange County, Mr. Bucciero added: "But I'm not complaining. I can't think of anything else I'd rather do for a living."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Racial Admissions; 
The Path to Diversity? Different Differences

BYLINE:  By DAVID J. GARROW; David J. Garrow is Presidential Distinguished Professor at Emory University School of Law.

 BODY:
A FEDERAL appeals court ruling last week striking down the University of Georgia's use of racial preferences in its freshman admissions program once again places the issue of affirmative action at the forefront of America's legal agenda. If Georgia appeals, and if the Supreme Court chooses to hear the case, the resulting decision could well be the court's most decisive statement on race since its landmark 1978 ruling in Regents of the University of California v. Bakke.
 But even if the case is not heard by the high court -- and there are many reasons why it may not be -- last week's unanimous opinion from a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit should, if properly understood, fundamentally alter the debate about the use of racial preferences in college and graduate school admissions. 
 The university admitted its first African-American students in 1961 and began meaningful desegregation only in 1970. In 1989 the federal Office of Civil Rights ruled that Georgia had completed the necessary remedial steps and that "no additional desegregation measures will be required." The university is thus unable to invoke its own history to justify a reparative motive for its use of racial preferences, and is left to defend its program only as a means of ensuring a diverse student body. 
The linchpin of the argument that student racial diversity is a "compelling" interest is the opinion written by Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. in the 1978 Bakke case, which struck down a racial quota system used by the University of California at Davis. "Ethnic diversity, however, is only one element in a range of factors a university may properly consider in attaining a heterogeneous student body," he declared.
Justice Powell said that an admissions process using race must "consider all pertinent elements of diversity in light of the particular qualifications of each applicant." To focus "solely on ethnic diversity," he held, "would hinder rather than further attainment of genuine diversity."
But that, according to last week's ruling, is exactly what Georgia's program did. The university used a numerical computation in which all nonwhite applicants were awarded an extra half-point, significantly boosting their chances for acceptance. The admissions director testified the half-point figure had been chosen from "out of the blue." 
Writing last week on behalf of the appeals panel, Judge Stanley Marcus, a New Yorker whom President Bill Clinton promoted from trial judge in 1997, found that Georgia's racial bonus "does not even come close" to meeting Justice Powell's standard. 
"Individuals who come from economically disadvantaged homes," Judge Marcus wrote, "individuals who have lived or traveled widely abroad; individuals from remote or rural areas; individuals who speak foreign languages; individuals with unique communications skills (such as an ability to read Braille or communicate with the deaf); and individuals who have overcome personal adversity or social hardship -- none of the characteristics that make these kinds of individuals 'diverse' are taken into account."
 BUT he also emphasized that his view of diversity has never been endorsed by any Supreme Court majority. Justice Powell's opinion controlled the outcome in Bakke, but it was signed only by him. 
"The status of student body diversity as a compelling interest justifying a racial preference in university admissions is an open question," Judge Marcus wrote, and "is one that, because of its great importance, warrants consideration by the Supreme Court."
Supporters of affirmative action, worried that the Georgia case's weaknesses will yield a decision ruling out racial considerations entirely, are calling upon the state's attorney general, Thurbert Baker, and Gov. Roy Barnes not to appeal. 
Affirmative action proponents would rather see significant rulings emerge from two pending cases, both of which challenge admissions programs at the University of Michigan. One involved the use of a racial bonus in undergraduate admissions; a federal trial judge upheld it last December. The other concerned racial advantages in law school admissions; a different trial judge ruled in March that it was unconstitutional. Appeals of both will be heard by a three-judge panel of the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Cincinnati on Oct. 23. The university, with no history of racial segregation in its admissions practices, will, like Georgia, be advancing only a student diversity argument.
Affirmative action questions are certainly on the minds of the nine high court justices, since on Oct. 31 they will hear for a second time a case challenging limited racial preferences in a federal transportation contracting program. Whether it be the Georgia case this fall or the Sixth Circuit's ruling on the two Michigan programs in 2002, the time when the high court will have to weigh in on the constitutionality of racial preferences in university admissions is inexorably moving closer.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/John W. and John C. Thompson; 
Thompson Plumb Growth Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
IN 1993, John C. Thompson, a newly minted M.B.A. from the University of Chicago, returned home to Madison, Wis., to help his father build the family money management business. He did almost everything from answering telephones to keeping the books. 
 "I was willing to do whatever it took to help the firm," said Mr. Thompson, now 32, "even when it meant driving four hours to River Falls, Wis., to talk to truck drivers about their 401(k) plan." 
 A year later, he became co-manager of the family's new $4 million mutual fund and helped his father, John W. Thompson, now 58, build it into the $165 million Thompson Plumb Growth fund. 
"We're looking for good growth companies selling at lower prices, anticipating some improvement in the business fundamentals that would allow the price-earnings multiple to expand and earnings to increase," the older Mr. Thompson said.
The fund returned 21.8 percent a year, on average, for the three years ended Thursday, taking secondplace among 774 large blend funds, according to Morningstar Inc. The category returned 4.1 percent, on average, versus 4.5 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500. For the 12 months through Thursday, the fund returned 29.9 percent, versus declines of 24 percent for both the category and the S.& P. 
The fund's adviser, Thompson Plumb & Associates, also runs the $75 million Balanced and $25 million Bond funds, plus $1 billion for institutions and individuals. The "Plumb" in the name is Thomas G. Plumb, a co-founder of the firm and manager of the Balanced fund.
The Thompsons use no computer screens to select the 65 or 70 stocks in the Growth fund from United States companies with market capitalizations above $1 billion. Instead, they review financial news services, read Wall Street research and attend conferences, looking for established, growing companies.
Specifically, they want companies with minimum returns on equity of 15 percent to 20 percent a year, on average, over 5 or 10 years and gross profit margins of at least 50 percent. "High margins indicate a lower level of competition in the field that the company operates in," the father said, adding that profitability could result from strong brand names, lower costs or technological advantages.
The managers often focus on companies with established consumer brands. Those stocks account for about 40 percent of the fund's assets, double the weighting that the S.& P. 500 gives such companies.
"Multiples are low, but we're still seeing good improvements in the growth rates of many consumer brand companies," the son said. "Many of them are multinational, and they would get a big boost to earnings should the dollar weaken."
To value a company, they establish historical ranges for the price-to-earnings ratio based on the 5- to 10-year history of the company and its peers. They buy shares at the low end of the range and sell when they approach or exceed the high end.
Many of their stocks are acquisition targets -- about 10 of the portfolio companies were acquired in the last 18 months. "We want to see a lot of earnings in the stocks that we buy," the father said. "Our stock selection criteria are the same as a company would use to buy a competitor or to make fold-in acquisitions." 
The fund owns shares of the Acxiom Corporation, a Little Rock, Ark., provider of data to direct marketers. Acxiom says it tracks 100,000 data sources covering every birth, death and real estate transaction in the country. The younger Mr. Thompson said the company has made an accounting change affecting when Acxiom recognizes revenue. 
"It will create a big lull in their revenues over the next 12 to 18 months," he said, "but it will help them in the long run." The company could be an acquisition target, he said, because of its desirable technology and relatively low price. The fund bought shares at $15.50 in October 1999; they are now at $12.74.
The fund's biggest position, at 4 percent of assets, is Coca-Cola, originally bought in August 1999 for $61.On Friday, it closed at $48.67. 
"It's the most recognized brand name in the world," he said. "They're going to benefit from expanded worldwide wealth. Soft drinks are still considered luxuries in China and the developing countries." 
He said he believes that earnings have stagnated partly because of continuing economic difficulties in Asia and the strength of the United States dollar, but he expects improvement when the dollar eventually weakens.
The fund also likes Merck, the drug company. "It's got a triple-A balance sheet," the elder Mr. Thompson said. "You can't get much better than that." 
Merck's earnings have grown at an annual average of 15 percent for 20 years, he added. Its shares have declined as patents have expired for drugs like Vasotec, used to treat hypertension, and Pepcid, for ulcers. That does not faze him, he said, because of new products, like Vioxx, an arthritis drug. "Merck and Coke will show earnings growth in a weakening economy, when the S.& P. companies have negative earnings." 
They first bought Merck shares at a split-adjusted $16.40 in November 1993; they now trade at $65.10

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Damaged By the Dow

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
In late 1999 -- about the time when George W. Bush first announced his tax-cut plan -- I had lunch at a beer-and-pizza joint, the sort of place that has a TV over the bar where the patrons can watch ESPN. But the TV wasn't tuned to ESPN -- it was showing CNBC. I thought to myself, "This will end badly." And it has.
 The Dow first passed 10,000 in 1999. Although the index briefly dropped below that milestone in early 2000, that decline didn't really count -- it was a perverse side-effect of truly irrational exuberance, as investors deserted the boring old Dow for the Nasdaq. Last week, on the other hand, was the real thing: a broad market decline carried the Dow past 10,000 in the wrong direction. The era of the stock-market bubble has now well and truly ended. 
 But what a mess that bubble has left behind!
By now the direct economic impact of the bubble is a familiar story. During the years of booming stock prices, which were closely linked to euphoria about the "new economy," businesses invested frantically, sinking vast sums into information technology. Now, of course, many of those businesses realize that they invested far too much. And the overhang of excess capacity is likely to keep business investment depressed for years.
That's not an encouraging thought. But the direct economic consequences of the bubble are only half the story. The bubble also had a dire effect on our national politics.
After all, it wasn't an accident that the Bush tax plan was proposed just before the bubble popped. There was an intimate relationship between stock-market mania and tax-cut mania, a relationship that ran in both directions. 
On one side, in the late 1990's the right-wing media were enthusiastic stock boosters. The editorial page of The Wall Street Journal, in particular, was extremely fond of crank theories about stock valuation, as long as they pointed upward. Remember "Dow 36,000"? And anyone who pointed out that such theories rested on fuzzy math, and suggested that the stocks could not be counted on to deliver high returns forever, was clearly a dangerous leftist -- after all, the stock market is the purest expression of capitalism, so anyone who doubts that market must be anti-capitalist, right? 
But the more important causation ran the other way: the stock bubble, alas, provided an environment in which deeply irresponsible policy proposals temporarily looked plausible.
It's important to realize how much of the late lamented budget surplus was the result of the bull market. Tax rates didn't increase between 1994 and 2000, but tax receipts as a share of G.D.P. surged, largely because of the extra taxes paid on all those capital gains. The result was a false sense that there was plenty of money in hand, that big tax cuts would fit comfortably into the budget. And the Bush tax plan was formulated when such delusions were at their height.
Now reality has started to sink in. Unfortunately, though the new realism may have come soon enough to prevent a disaster on Social Security -- for Mr. Bush's other signature policy proposal was also based on the delusions of a bubble economy -- it has come too late to prevent a disastrous tax cut.
Of course, you might wonder why Mr. Bush himself didn't have second thoughts -- why he thought that the exact same tax plan he proposed in the feverish bull-market days of late 1999 was still appropriate in the post-bubble economy of 2001. And his officials surely knew that tax receipts were dropping like a stone even as they were reassuring a docile Congress that everything was just fine.
But one thing we have learned about this administration is that it never responds to altered circumstances by changing its plans; all it does is change the sales pitch. So the tax cut was relabeled as a recession-fighting measure, a task for which it is peculiarly ill-suited. For that matter, the administration hasn't given up on Social Security privatization, either. Now that it can no longer entice people with visions of stock-market sugar plums, it has decided to scare them with imaginary crises instead.
In any case, immense damage has already been done. The stock-market bubble led to bad political decisions as well as bad business decisions; and we'll be paying the price for many years to come.

HEADLINE: A Primary Choice: Mark Green 

 BODY:
Nearly eight years with Rudolph Giuliani have helped New Yorkers appreciate what their city needs -- and needs to avoid -- in the next mayor. He has to be a leader, capable of taking the heat and pushing doggedly for his goals. He must hold onto the success in lowering crime and boosting business while reaching out to those who have been left behind. He should also be able to step outside his own ego to forge coalitions and listen to critics.
 Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, Public Advocate Mark Green, Comptroller Alan Hevesi and Council Speaker Peter Vallone are all mid-level Democratic officials who want to move up to a high-profile and high-pressure post. During the campaign, the city has watched to see who appears to be growing into the new role, handling himself with the confidence and dexterity it takes to run America's most challenging city. In the Democratic primary, Mark Green has shown the most evidence that he is evolving into a man who could be a successful mayor. 
 During his long career in politics, Mr. Green has demonstrated some, but not all, of the qualities New York City needs in its chief executive. He has always had political courage, and he does not buckle under fire. He was unafraid to take on Senator Alfonse D'Amato when other Democrats quailed at an unwinnable race. In his role as consumer affairs commissioner and later as public advocate, Mr. Green took on the tobacco industry, long before it was a safe target. He also, of course, battled frequently with Mr. Giuliani, spending years as the mayor's least-favorite Democrat until Mr. Hevesi took over the title a few weeks ago.
Mr. Green's opponents have argued that he does not have enough executive experience. But running New York City is a job so big that there may be no adequate training. Certainly as a federal prosecutor, Mr. Giuliani did not run an organization as large or as complicated as the one he took over when he was elected. Edward Koch had never managed anything more complicated than his Congressional staff. As voters, all we can do is look for the candidates who seem to have the leadership, toughness and intelligence to take command. Mr. Green scores high on all those qualities.
When the campaign began, our concerns about Mr. Green lay in other directions. We worried about his reputation for abrasiveness, for failing to listen to people he regarded as less well-informed or intelligent than himself. We wondered if he had the political finesse to reach a goal through negotiation rather than by calling a press conference. But as a candidate for mayor he has been extremely deft. By parading through the city arm in arm with former Police Commissioner William Bratton, he sent a reassuring signal about his commitment to controlling crime. Mr. Green has been in the forefront of the fight against police misconduct. Now he raises hope that his administration might be able to achieve the much-desired blend of safe streets and community-friendly law enforcement.
One of the most important jobs of the next mayor could be to weather an economic downturn, controlling costs while encouraging business growth. Mr. Green's early work toward ending mob control of commercial trash hauling -- an issue Mr. Giuliani carried into the limelight -- is a good example of how he is not afraid to tackle the entrenched interests that create unnecessary costs of doing business in the city. The city's other top priority is improving education. The candidates generally agree that teachers should get a large salary increase in return for more productivity and accountability. But Mr. Green's unusually cool relationship with the teachers' union might give him an advantage at the bargaining table.
Mr. Green is still not going to win the congeniality award in this race -- that prize would go, hands down, to Mr. Vallone. Mr. Green has an Al Gore-like difficulty in appearing comfortable while campaigning. In a city full of natural politicians, Mr. Green has always been the one who wears a suit while shaking hands on the beach. But what he lacks in ease he makes up for in effort. His statistics on number-of-churches-visited and number-of-neighborhoods-toured sometimes seem like overkill, but they do assure us that Mr. Green would be a mayor who would go anywhere and talk to anyone. Whether he will always pay attention is another question, and if Mr. Green succeeds in becoming mayor, his first challenge will be to improve his listening skills.
Republican New Yorkers may wish that they, too, had the opportunity to vote in a closely contested primary featuring several qualified candidates. But the Republican contest is a mismatch, pitting Michael Bloomberg, a candidate with a bottomless well of money, against Herman Badillo, who has been struggling to attract enough donations just to qualify for city matching funds. Because of the imbalance in this race, we believe a more appropriate time to assess the Republican nominee is once the final campaign begins and the city can get the more complete picture that real competition provides. 
On the Democratic side, both Mr. Vallone and Mr. Ferrer have surprised people by the strength of their bids for a place in a runoff, which will occur if no one receives 40 percent of the vote on Sept. 11. Mr. Vallone has the right to be proud of the job he did leading the Council from its days of powerless ineptitude into a more active role in government. If we could suspend the term limits law for one individual, it would be to keep Mr. Vallone on as Speaker. But he is not necessarily the best candidate for this higher office. He still tends to describe what he would do as mayor in terms of his relationship with the members of the Council, which is only one fraction of the job.
Mr. Ferrer has done well in the mayoral debates, and his attempt to forge a coalition between Hispanic and black officials has finally begun to bear fruit after a number of false starts. Formerly a centrist establishment Democrat, Mr. Ferrer is now running from the left, as the champion of the "other" New York. That was a good place to start. But Mr. Ferrer has so far failed to move to the next level, to show how he could take the outrage of the poor and the concerns of the working and middle classes to forge a united vision for the city. 
Alan Hevesi went into the primary as the favorite of many government insiders, who believed his work as comptroller and longtime state assemblyman made him "Most Experienced, Best Qualified," as his campaign boasted. Mr. Hevesi does have a most impressive resume, and he has also been the most convincing candidate when it comes to financial forecasts for the future, an area where Mr. Vallone in particular seems overly optimistic.
Despite all his years in office, Mr. Hevesi was relatively unknown to most voters when the race began, and his attempts to introduce himself have gone badly. His high-tech discussions of the budget went over peoples' heads. Reports surfaced about his relationship with campaign contributors that showed Mr. Hevesi might be lax about avoiding the appearance of conflicts of interest. Lately, the courtly Mr. Hevesi has mutated into the campaign's angry man, attempting to out-Giuliani the mayor himself in name-calling. But for all his slips, Mr. Hevesi has sound instincts on the economic and social problems facing the city.
Both Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Green have spent decades thinking seriously about how to best run New York City's government. Given two candidates with such impressive records, our support goes to the one whose campaign has shown the most promise for still more growth and innovation in the future. In the Democratic primary for mayor, our choice is Mark Green.

HEADLINE: STYLE; 
How Low Can You Go?

BYLINE:  By Steve Garbarino 

 BODY:
What's the lowdown? If recent trends in fashion and furniture provide any sort of bellwether, we as a nation are boosting our fragile self-esteem by making everything around us, as R.E.M. sings, "low, low, low."
 As the current economy dictates that we tighten our belts, pants -- as in bluejeans -- have dropped to levels so low that you need a bikini wax to wear them. 
And belt loops? Fuhgeddaboudit. Both pros and dilettantes are simply cutting them off. 
 Meanwhile, as evident at the recent Furniture Fair in Milan, custom furnishings have sunk to ground zero. Indeed, Nick Dine's Ravioli pillow-couch for Dune (pictured, center) looks as if it was yanked right out of a Triumph Spitfire. 
How low can we go? While mainstream glossies have flirted with cover girls showing their most nether of regions (see Jennifer Lopez's lacy lingerie shot on the June cover of Vanity Fair), it took the British magazine Dazed & Confused to actually show the unthinkable.
According to Agatha, who designs custom leather pants for the likes of Sylvester Stallone, Britney Spears, Joan Jett and Jennifer Lopez: "If you're a chick, you don't want to see jack. You have to wax. But if you're a dude, you can show . . . oh, a tiny bit."
On the flip side, Amri Leever, a 27-year-old transplanted Floridian and custom-jeans designer of the lowest common demoninator, asserts that "the new cleavage" is now best seen from the rear. But she points out: "Low isn't for everyone. You should always follow the overhang rule. If something is hanging over your belt loops, keep it covered -- unless you're going to Biker Weekend in Daytona Beach." Steve Garbarino

HEADLINE: Chinese Firm Is Punished By the U.S. For Arms Sale 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 

 BODY:
The Bush administration imposed trade sanctions today on a major Chinese arms manufacturer after failing to persuade the Chinese government to stop exports of missile technology to Pakistan.
 A senior State Department official said that the decision came as China continued to break international guidelines intended to control sales of missile parts and technology that are essential for weapons that can carry nuclear warheads. 
 Secretary of State Colin L. Powell raised the issue in talks with the Chinese leadership in July. His concerns were at the center of detailed negotiations in Beijing late last month between a State Department delegation and Chinese officials. 
Last week, Undersecretary of State John R. Bolton called on the charge d'affaires of the Chinese Embassy, He Yafei, and told him it was still possible to avoid sanctions if the Chinese took some action against the exporters. The Chinese manufacturer, China Metallurgical Equipment, a private corporation with close ties to the Beijing government, had transferred missile parts and technology, not whole missiles, the administration's announcement said. 
The sanctions come as relations between Washington and Beijing have warmed somewhat after a rocky start at the outset of the Bush administration. But it appeared that the sanctions would not cause a major rift, and it was still possible, the senior official said, that the sanctions would be waived later. 
The sanctions, which prohibit American companies from doing business with the Chinese company, are likely to be more symbolic than substantive in the broader trading relationship. 
"The goal is to stop their missile cooperation with Pakistan, and if they stop, we could waive the sanctions," the senior official said today.
President Bush is scheduled to visit China for the first time in October, and preparations are under way by both sides to make the trip as smooth and friendly as possible.
Sanctions were also being placed on the organization in Pakistan, the National Development Complex, that received the Chinese technology. 
As the administration has tried to deal with the Chinese sales of weapons technology in the last few months, it has also been debating whether to suspend issuing licenses for American telecommunication companies that place their satellites on Chinese rockets.
American aerospace companies are pushing the Bush administration to allow China to launch American-made satellites or satellites containing American parts. Any such launch requires a presidential waiver. President Clinton granted numerous such waivers, in part to reward China for curbing its sales of missile-related technology. 
But a French company whose satellite contains American parts, Astrium SAS, has recently dropped a deal involving a Chinese rocket because of American indecision, said a report this week in Space News.
Loral Space & Communications, an American satellite company, has two satellite deals pending with China, one of which has been in limbo since 1999. Loral has been unable to gain a presidential waiver while investigations were under way into assistance Loral provided China after a Chinese rocket containing a Loral satellite crashed in 1996. 
For months Loral has been in negotiations with State Department officials to try and reach a civil settlement, American officials said. The discussions, they added, include the possible payment of a multimillion-dollar penalty by Loral and changes in the company's export procedures.
A White House spokesman had no comment today on President Bush's position on issuing waivers.
As for the sanctions, they should come as no surprise to the Chinese, the senior official said. Beijing knew the details of transfers from Chinese Metallurgical Equipment to Pakistan, if for no other reason than the United States told them, the official said. The corporation, he said, was not operating outside the bounds of the Beijing government.
During negotiations with a team of Clinton administration experts last November, the Chinese agreed to limit missile exports that were in violation of the Missile Technology Control Regime. The regime, which restricts sales of specific missiles and missile parts, was signed by 32 countries, but not China. 
Over all, the Chinese are "less active traders and proliferators than they used to be," the senior official said. But they are still not in compliance with the control regime, he said.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Warren Strugatch; E-mail: libiz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Comverse Technology Announces Drop in Profits
Citing the global slowdown in business spending, which he called a recession, Kobi Alexander, the chairman and chief executive of Comverse Technology (Nasdaq: CMVT), said Tuesday that the Woodbury company's profits dropped 20 percent in the second quarter, to $50 million, compared with $62.5 million in the same quarter last year.
 Unlike many high-tech companies, however, Comverse reported that sales increased during the quarter, by 18 percent to $345 million, compared with $292 million for the second quarter of 2000. 
 In the quarter, the company took $22 million in charges associated with layoffs and investment write-downs. In May Comverse announced layoffs of about 400 employees, or 6 percent of its work force.
Mr. Alexander said in a statement, "We remain well-positioned as a leader in our major markets, and believe that these markets offer attractive opportunities for long-term growth."
Comverse, an Israeli-American company that also has offices in Tel Aviv, manufactures wireless telecommunications software and other products for sale in over 100 countries.

HEADLINE: What We Work for Now 

BYLINE:  By Jerome M. Segal; Jerome M. Segal, a senior research scholar in public affairs at the University of Maryland, is the author of "Graceful Simplicity."

DATELINE: COLLEGE PARK, Md. 

 BODY:
Despite all our concerns with self-fulfillment, most Americans work to earn money, just as their forebears did 100 years ago. The relative costs of necessities have changed, and so has a fair definition of what is necessary. But even with all our economic growth, and even with some items much cheaper than they once were, families still spend about four-fifths of their budgets for core needs, just as their counterparts did a century ago. Perhaps there should be some national introspection about how much we have really gained.
 Certainly, we have escaped the overwhelming tyranny of food. In 1901, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that in major industrial cities, the biggest expenditure item for families was food -- half of spending in low-income families and a third in more affluent ones. In 1999, food took only 15 percent of household spending, and more than a third of that spending was for food prepared away from home. For food from their own kitchens, Americans now use up only 9 percent of their budgets. They can cover that with a little more than a month of work -- probably the lowest level of work effort for food in human history. Even households in the lowest fifth of income use only 18 percent of total spending for food. 
 Something similar has happened with clothing. In 1901 it took 10 to 15 percent of the family budget, and now it takes only 5 percent.
What, then, are Americans spending their money on? A common stereotype of the pampered consumer might suggest that large amounts are going for toys and luxuries, but I found while conducting studies for Redefining Progress, a public policy organization in Oakland, Calif., that this is a misconception. Electronic gadgets, for instance, have a small place in consumer spending -- 2 percent in 2000. Entertainment takes less than 6 percent.
The largest expenditure item now is housing. Bringing together renters and owners, shelter, including utilities, takes 27 percent of our spending, compared to a very similar 25 percent in 1901. Although our homes today are much more luxurious, safe neighborhoods with good public schools remain out of reach for many.
The big growth category is transportation. In the earliest studies of consumption, transportation wasn't even a separate category; it took only 1 or 2 percent of spending. But then came the automobile, and now we devote more than 20 percent of our spending to transportation. Just to cover that, the average American family works from New Year's Day to March 14. No society in history has worked so much just to be able to get around.
A car may once have been a luxury, but as cities and suburbs have spread out, stores have disappeared from neighborhoods, and work and school have ceased to be within walking distance, nearly all Americans have become car-dependent. And with most women in the formal work force, many families have two automobiles -- not really as a matter of choice, but as a basic need.
Another work-related item virtually unknown a century ago is day care. Self-sufficiency budgets, calculated by many states to determine families' costs for basic needs, allocate 25 to 30 percent of a low-income household's spending for day care.
Though education remains only a minor category of spending -- 2 percent -- this is just on average. For families with children in college -- and college is now required for far more jobs than in the past -- this expense can be staggering.
So in a century of growing incomes and changing lives, what has been gained? While the energies of Americans are expended to obtain different items than they were years ago, what remains constant is the emphasis on the basics.
In 1901, 80 percent of spending went for food, housing and clothing. In 1999, 81 percent of spending went for food, housing, clothing, transportation and health care. A century of economic growth has certainly brought some genuine progress, but it is less clear-cut than we sometimes think.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
Public Education's Inspired but Rocky Road

BYLINE:  By JULIE SALAMON 

 BODY:
"Agitate, agitate, agitate," was the motto of Horace Mann, the 19th-century school reformer. During his tenure as Massachusetts secretary of education, beginning in 1837, he visited a thousand schools in six years and recorded his horrified reactions to the conditions he found. One school was so dangerous, he wrote, "the mice have forsaken it."
 Public education in America has always been a fractious enterprise, and complaining about it is part of our heritage. The start of each new academic year is heralded with dire predictions about the public schools and alarming visions of cutbacks, shortages and bureaucratic ineptitude. But the system is also amazing, constantly reinventing itself to absorb changes in the country's population, economics and social and political theories. The public schools have been wonderful, they've been terrible, but they haven't been stagnant, and they aren't going away. Almost 90 percent of American children are educated in them, at a cost this year of $330 billion. 
 School is starting again, so not surprisingly it's the subject of several television documentaries. It's a good crop, which includes "Kindergarten," HBO Family's charming 13-part series of half-hours, and "School: The Story of American Public Education," PBS's comprehensive and excellent four-hour survey course, which begins tonight. In addition PBS is presenting "The First Year," a 90-minute documentary that follows five new teachers through their first school year; replays of "American High," the cinema verite series it took over from Fox; and a variety of school-related programs on local public television stations. Meryl Streep, who played a teacher in "Music of the Heart," introduces many of the PBS programs and narrates "School."
Aimed at young children and their parents, HBO's "Kindergarten" takes an affectionate, hopeful approach, combining observations of the children's activities with interviews that are invariably cute or poignant. The 23 children in Jennifer Johnson's kindergarten class at Upper Nyack Elementary School in New York State seem to be having an ideal experience. They love their teacher, whom they describe, accurately, as "pretty" and, with apparent accuracy, as "happy all the time." They confront problems, like missing their parents and dealing with cranky classmates. But comforting resolutions are the norm. When one child confesses, looking ashamed, that he doesn't brush his teeth in the morning, Ms. Johnson thanks him for his honesty. "What a brave thing to do," she says.
The five young teachers featured in "The First Year" on PBS (shown in New York on Friday at 9 p.m. and elsewhere on Thursday) aren't happy all the time. Their postings are at tough Los Angeles schools, where the students' problems are often grim and resolutions not readily forthcoming. Davis Guggenheim, the film's director, takes an unvarnished approach that records without dramatic flourish the frustrations and rewards of teaching. For a while the documentary feels flat and somewhat chaotic, as the camera moves uncertainly from a teacher facing fidgety ninth graders in a "cultural awareness" class to an earnest kindergarten teacher doing stretching exercises with his charges.
But it becomes clear that while dramatically unsatisfying at times, the grainy approach of "First Year" underscores this particular reality, which is itself chaotic and gritty. Entertainment isn't the point. The kindergarten teacher, who seems especially sweet because he is a big man and so tender, doggedly tries to obtain special speech therapy for one of his students, a sad-looking boy who can barely make himself understood. The boy's parents aren't especially cooperative, and neither is the school bureaucracy. Speech therapists make appointments and break them. Another young teacher, who comes from a family of teachers, is dismayed when one of his students sketches him as a rat sitting on a toilet. A third tries to find a permanent room for her 38 students and is told a school isn't considered overcrowded unless 30 percent of the teachers have floating classrooms like hers.
Which portrait is true? The sunny picture of public school we see in "Kindergarten" or the grim view from "The First Year?" What kind of system allows for such divergence and inequity?
PBS's "School" answers this question with remarkable thoroughness and intellectual energy. Produced by sisters-in-law, Sarah Mondale and Sarah Patton, and directed by Ms. Mondale, the series is unabashedly pro-public-school but not uncritical. The producers have accumulated a mountain of information, archival clips and filmed interviews with witnesses and experts, and fashioned it into a compelling narrative. They explain how the system was shaped by individual determination and mass movements. They examine the role of religion, race and political movements in the development of public education, as well as the interaction of courts, legislatures and plain old politics. As the giant mechanism of public education has heaved and sputtered along, and an incredible amount of progress has occurred. 
The series periodically provides helpful comparative statistics on blackboards. We see that average school attendance in 1776 was less than 82 days, while now it is 14.5 years. In 1950, 13.7 percent of African-Americans above 18 had high school diplomas, compared with 77.6 percent today. 
The series recalls the heroism of black children who desegregated schools and of young women who went West to scruffy frontier towns to become teachers. We see how often a step forward crushed somebody's toes. So when schools were desegregated, many black teachers found themselves out of work. We're reminded that the battle between traditionalists and progressives didn't begin yesterday but more than 100 years ago. We learn that Gary, Ind., isn't just a song lyric in "The Music Man," but once was the home of the most progressive school system in the country. A hundred years ago Gary's public-school children, many of whose fathers were mill workers for United States Steel, had swimming pools and zoos right at school, where they also learned carpentry and sewing and acquired manners for afternoon tea. 
The Gary experiment, captured on film, looks cheerful and productive, but New York's attempt to adopt the plan failed. The curriculum's emphasis on nonacademic as well as academic subjects was regarded as part of a scheme to turn out cheap labor for large corporations. A mayoral race turned on opposition to progressive education, and New York students got back behind their desks and focused on learning proper language and good citizenship. The idea was to Americanize immigrant children, quickly and thoroughly.
The documentaries start at the beginning, when the school system sprang out of pretty much nothing. Nicholas Lemann, author of "The Big Test," observes that government-financed education is not part of the Bill of Rights, the Declaration of Independence or any other founding principle. "It was a new, radical, crazy-seeming idea," he says. It got even crazier and more radical as new waves of immigrants had to be absorbed, and the schools became the fire under the melting pot, until the notion of a melting pot became offensive. Then the schools were called on to help groups respect their separate heritages while offering a sound education and constantly redefining what a "sound education" is. 
At one time people were certain that children had a good education if they knew what their torment in hell would be if they sinned. In 1927 an I.Q. test considered this a valid true or false question: "We seldom desire food when we are very sad." After World War II educators were obsessed with instruction on hygiene and family life, until they became obsessed with creating astronauts and rocket scientists. Now testing is the White House mantra. Tomorrow it will be something else.
This program should be required homework for policymakers who make pronouncements on what schools should or shouldn't be.

HEADLINE: Entrepreneur Is Quiet About His Past And Gets New Start in Net Surveillance 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Twice, Irwin Meyer has sailed on big ideas to some degree of fortune.
 The first time was in 1977, when he found a struggling play based on a comic-strip character and helped turn it into the unlikely Broadway hit, "Annie." It earned him a Tony Award for co-producing the best musical of the year. 
 The second time was in 1999, when he discovered a technology that could scour Internet chat rooms for rumors, innuendo, opinions or lies about a particular person or company. He created a company to offer the service to any business worried about its image -- and its stock price. 
To win the trust of investors and clients, Mr. Meyer boasted of his Tony Award, and of the years he spent as a television and commercial producer in Hollywood. What he did not mention was his conviction for tax fraud, which put him in a federal prison for four months in 1982.
Some of the people who wanted to become involved with Mr. Meyer and his Internet technology took the time to check his background, though it did not stop them from working with him. Others said they looked but did not find his conviction. Many, however, were too eager to join the Internet gold rush to do much more than read the incomplete biography that Mr. Meyer submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission as a routine part of running a publicly traded company.
Mr. Meyer said he did not make a point of mentioning his conviction nor try to hide it. "I don't wear a sign," he said. "Everybody who's ever worked with me knows about my background."
The story of Mr. Meyer's reinvention as an Internet entrepreneur is emblematic of the paradoxes of the technology boom. It may have seemed that a bunch of 24-year-olds were "leveraging" the Internet -- to use the vernacular that helped start so many dot-com companies -- to take over the business world. But the larger truth is more nuanced and stranger than the notion that Daddy Warbucks invented the New Deal. And now that the boom times are over, Mr. Meyer has a mess on his hands.
At 66 years old, Mr. Meyer comes across like a college drama teacher, theatrical and assured. His approach is: Listen, I'm gonna explain something to you. And he can be very convincing, given the right audience.
When Internet stocks began their run-up, Mr. Meyer was in California and decided to shift his focus from Hollywood to Silicon Valley. In 1999, he used his foundering movie-production company in Los Angeles to create a new-economy start-up and began casting about for something to do.
He first dabbled in satellite Internet access, buying a company called eSat, but switched to Internet image-management after merging with another company, Infolocity. He changed the name of his company -- initially the Ventura Motion Picture Group, then the Producers Entertainment Group and most recently the IAT Resources Corporation -- to the jazzy-sounding NetCurrents Inc.
The company would use technology developed by Infolocity to monitor Internet chat rooms on behalf of companies willing to pay for the service. At the time, the Internet was so sexy and stock manipulation so worrisome that clients, including big names like Oracle and Office Depot, began to line up. Then the Kroll-O'Gara Company, the world's most prominent investigation company, signed an exclusive global alliance with NetCurrents to offer enhanced Internet intelligence services to corporations.
NetCurrents' heady early days are but a memory now, and so are many of its clients. It is hard to sell image-protection services to companies that cannot even afford many of their employees anymore. NetCurrents' stock, which traded for as much as $11.94 a share in March 2000, now sells for less than 11 cents. So few people want to buy it that Nasdaq has removed the stock from its market, crippling the company's ability to raise additional cash to cover losses and repay debts. NetCurrents said in its most recent filings with the S.E.C. that it had laid off all its sales representatives and technicians.
Mr. Meyer now spends his days looking for someone to invest more money in the company -- and searching the Web for anyone who might be criticizing it, or him.
The company has already sued one man, Victor Holtorf, the former chairman of one of its subsidiaries, for making disparaging remarks about Mr. Meyer on online message boards. They have since settled the suit, though Mr. Holtorf, who still owns stock in the company, said NetCurrents had not met the financial obligations of the settlement. He would not specify the obligations.
Mr. Meyer has overcome financial obstacles before. For example, he and his partner, Stephen R. Friedman, had some difficulty raising their $250,000 contribution to the budget for "Annie," according to a 1977 Washington Post article on the show, though they eventually came up with the money.
At around the same time, the two men shared in sales commissions totaling $4 million, government records say, by selling more than $20 million in tax-sheltered limited partnerships in a coal mining operation. Among the partners who bought in were celebrities like Elvis Presley, Margaux Hemingway and the singer Alice Cooper. Mr. Presley, for example, paid $505,000 and deducted $2.6 million from his taxable income for 1976.
But the S.E.C. filed a civil complaint against Mr. Meyer, Mr. Friedman and others on Sept. 21, 1978, contesting the partners' rights to any coal under a piece of property around Gillette, Wyo. The federal government owned 95 percent of the rights, and that fact cast doubt on the profits and tax benefits that Mr. Meyer and his partners had promised the investors, the S.E.C. said.
In 1980, Mr. Meyer and Mr. Friedman were indicted in a federal criminal complaint based on the coal mining partnerships. Both men eventually pleaded guilty to conspiring to assist in the preparation and filing of false income tax returns and were sentenced to prison. Mr. Meyer entered Federal Prison Camp Allenwood in Montgomery, Pa., on March 1, 1982, and was released on July 16, 1982.
The "Annie" company disassociated itself from the two men, and Mr. Meyer's lawyer, Martin R. Gold, said at the time that his client was "finished in the entertainment business," according to the archives of United Press International.
After regaining his freedom, however, Mr. Meyer moved to California, where he spent 16 years producing commercials and television programs. His company received production fees for the program "Dave's World" and for the movie "What's Love Got to Do With It?"
When Mr. Meyer turned his attention to the Internet, the most important part of his transformation was to buy Infolocity, a company run by James J. Cerna Jr., who is listed as an inventor of the technology used by NetCurrents.
To promote the company's services, Mr. Meyer appeared on the CNBC program "Power Lunch" in March 2000. "We have found in recent months, and I guess growing on a daily basis, an enormous amount of information and misinformation coming across the Net," he said on the program. Three days later, the company said it had closed a private placement of its stock, raising $8.5 million.
Before the summer was out, Mr. Meyer's reinvention as an Internet fraud expert received an impressive stamp of approval when Kroll-O'Gara teamed up its Risk Consulting Services division with NetCurrents -- in the process, receiving warrants to buy 5 percent of NetCurrents' stock.
At the time, there was no mention of Mr. Meyer's conviction for fraud, but Jules Kroll, chairman of Kroll-O'Gara, said in a recent interview that his company knew about it.
"We did exhaustive due diligence on the company, technology, directors, management and in particular the somewhat colorful history of its C.E.O.," Mr. Kroll said. "You can imagine, given what we do for a living, it was an issue for us."
He added, "I do believe in redemption, under certain circumstances."
Mr. Meyer said that he told Mr. Kroll about his jail term.
"It would be foolish of me to go into business with the world's largest investigation business that has a division that checks people's backgrounds and assume that they're not going to check my background," Mr. Meyer said.
But others did not learn of the conviction until long after they went into business with him.
Mr. Cerna said that his lawyer had investigated Mr. Meyer's background and never found the conviction. "To get in the position he's in now, he's found a way to hide it," Mr. Cerna said. "You would think, in the spirit, he should disclose that. We had no intention to get involved with anyone that has a history of fraud."
Several customers also said they were unaware of Mr. Meyer's conviction, though they said they were pleased with the service.
"It was immensely valuable to us," said Jennifer Glass, a vice president at Oracle. "We would get a heads-up on rumors and general sentiment about Oracle within the online community."
Ms. Glass and Lauren Garvey, a spokeswoman for Office Depot, said, however, that NetCurrents had discontinued its service to them without explanation.
Mr. Meyer said that he felt obligated to his shareholders. They want him to do what he has always done when he found a new business idea, like the little orphan girl, the tax shelters and the Internet security blanket.
"They're looking for me to secure another round of financing," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 12, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Sept. 3 about the career of Irwin Meyer, who set up NetCurrents Inc., which monitors the Internet for remarks about a specified person or company, referred incorrectly at two points to his past activities. One of Mr. Meyer's companies, the Producers Entertainment Group, agreed to acquire a company called eSat, but the deal was never completed; Mr. Meyer did not buy eSat. While Mr. Meyer was president of Ventura Entertainment, it acquired a company that produced television commercials. Mr. Meyer himself did not produce commercials. Mr. Meyer raised concerns about the article in an e-mail message to The Times several days after publication. This correction was delayed for research.

HEADLINE: Canadian Bank Earnings Beat Expectations 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Sept. 2 

 BODY:
Despite a rocky quarter, Canadian banks reported earnings last month that, while not matching recent years, topped analyst estimates in all but one case. 
 "There was a wariness going in" to the reporting season, said Robert Follis, an analyst at Scotia Capital, because of downturns in the economy in Latin America and the United States. 
 "We were waiting," he said, "to see how that could have translated into the banks' credit quality." 
Five of the seven major banks posted higher results for the third fiscal quarter ended July 31, despite weak market conditions. 
On average, the banks had 11 percent growth in profits from the previous year, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
The Royal Bank of Canada, the country's biggest and the only one to miss estimates, the Bank of Nova Scotia, the Bank of Montreal, the National Bank of Canada, and the Laurentian Bank of Canada all had improved quarterly profits. 
Toronto-Dominion Bank, the second largest, reported flat profits, while the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce was the only bank to report a decline in quarterly earnings. Both banks still bettered expectations. 
Canadian Western Bank, the smallest chartered bank, reports quarterly results this week. 
"I would characterize the quarter as good," said Kevin Lampo, an analyst at Edward Jones in St. Louis. "Asset quality did not show signs of deteriorating like prior periods and even though investment and merchant banking type activities declined, we saw healthy consumer and midsize business lending that offset those weaknesses." 
An early announcement by the Bank of Nova Scotia, which identified problem loans and nearly tripled its credit loss provisions in March, highlighted worries about deteriorating credit quality. A surprise increase in loan loss provisions by Toronto-Dominion Bank in June squarely focused attention on the issue. 
But investors and analysts applauded the results, sending bank stocks shooting higher and, in the case of the Bank of Nova Scotia and the Candian Imperial Bank of Commerce, touching new yearly highs. 
Fourth-quarter results will be linked to the North American economic outlook, analysts said. Further erosion in corporate profitability and continued weakness in capital markets could mean the banks will see a quarter of lackluster revenues. 
But, following eight months of interest-rate cuts by central banks in both Canada and the United States that were aimed at spurring an economic rebound in North America, most analysts predict a sturdy fourth quarter for the banks.
"The big question," said Donald Chu, an associate director at Standard & Poor's, "is what's going to happen stateside and whether or not we're going to have contagion (crossing) into Canada. And, if we do enter into a recession, how deep and how long will it be?"

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
 For the Backpacker, Headgear That Refreshes
Anyone strolling through the mountains, through a national park or even across Lower Manhattan might be startled to encounter a fellow hiker covered with a hood, a mesh over his face and a gyrating pyramid on his head. Not to worry. It could just be the latest in backpacker accessories. Patents Page C4.

Merchants Try to Access Web Sales
When there were still enough Internet retailers around for bricks-and-mortar merchants to sneer at, the catch phrase of condescension went something like this: "In my company, we have to worry about a little thing called profit." But as Internet retailing has dwindled to the extensions of the old-line merchants, ideas about profitability have become more nuanced. E-Commerce Report C2.

Canadian Banks Beat Expectations
Despite a rocky third quarter, most Canadian banks reported earnings that topped analysts' expectations, although they did not match the results of recent years. C2.

Tabloids Cry: You Stole My Headline!
A skirmish broke out at the fringes of New York City's tabloid newspaper war last week. With all the verve of children yowling "I'm the king of the castle," The New York Post and The Daily News vied for the title of king of the crybaby concept. C5.

An Accusation of Online Plagiarism
Ken Layne, a columnist with The Online Journalism Review, at the University of Southern California's Annenberg School for Communication, went to the Web last week to shame a Business Week Online reporter who, he believed, had stolen his work without credit. Bob Arnold, the editor of Business Week Online said Mr. Layne "is exaggerating." C5.

TV's 2 Hours at the O.K. Corral
On Wednesday night, CBS and NBC will go head to head for two hours with heavily promoted reality shows. This will be only the first confrontation in what is shaping up as a season-long confrontation between the two networks. C5.

Readers Speak, About 'Bespoke'
An article last week noted that the word "bespoke," a venerable English word meaning "custom made," had found its way into information technology circles. The article theorized that the use of this Briticism by an American software executive indicated that the globalization of the information technology industries may be turning British English into a lingua franca of techies. This week, readers weigh in about the use of the word. C3.

Japan Is Warned About Spending
The Japanese finance minister warned against a huge government spending package to prop up the economy. C2.

Wireless 'Churn' Is Costly
For wireless companies, keeping a customer is better than having to replace one. Telephia, a wireless research firm, has started tracking churn rates and surveying customers to determine why they had switched carriers or dropped wireless service. Most Wanted C7.

Singapore Airlines Withdraws Bid
Singapore Airlines has dropped its bid for a stake in Air-India, citing political opposition to the sale, the slowing economy and its plans to invest in the southwest Pacific. C2.

Kmart Ends Price Promotion
Kmart has removed "Dare to Compare" price promotions from its stores after a rival, Target, filed a lawsuit accusing the retailer of lying to consumers with the advertising. C4.

Software Maker Shuts Down
The software maker NetObjects Inc., 48 percent owned by I.B.M., said that it had shut down operations. C2.

A Break for Wall Street
The markets are closed today for Labor Day. They will reopen on Tuesday.
