HEADLINE: Elections Will Help Chart Course for Taiwan and Its President 

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 2 

 BODY:
Taiwan's embattled president, Chen Shui-bian, scored a rare coup last month when he supported relaxing certain restrictions on investment and trade with the mainland.
 Still, Mr. Chen's prospects for effectively governing this factionalized island or developing any consensus over policy toward Beijing remain murky. The ousted Nationalists are plotting Mr. Chen's downfall, former President Lee Teng-hui is reasserting himself as a self-styled messiah and Beijing continues to ignore Mr. Chen's calls to open talks. 
 Now all the parties are looking toward parliamentary elections set for Dec. 1 as a key to the final two years of Mr. Chen's term as president, and possibly to Taiwan's future stance toward the mainland.
"This won't just be a midterm referendum," said Chu Yun-Han, a political scientist at National Taiwan University. "It will actually decide the profile of the next cabinet." He said there was a real possibility that Mr. Chen would be forced to cede major power to his enemies in a coalition government. 
Mr. Chen won a temporary lift with his handling of his 120-member economic advisory panel. He had charged the group with finding ways to reinvigorate Taiwan's badly listing economy. The Nationalists, who had worked unceasingly to isolate Mr. Chen, were cornered into participating in this game of his design, even allowing him to put his stamp on their proposals. 
The panel's recommendations also gave Mr. Chen the cover he needed to fend off factions in his own Democratic Progressive Party that favor Taiwanese independence and are wary of deeper economic ties with the mainland.
Mr. Chen refuses to support the ideal of "one China" that Beijing demands, in effect at gunpoint, contending that Taiwan is a renegade province of China. But he has also tried to move toward the center, abandoning talk of independence, which would elicit military threats from the mainland, alarm the United States and scare his public. 
But most of Mr. Chen's initiatives, foreign and domestic, have been stymied by a divided government. He was elected in a three-way race in 2000 by a minority of voters, while the long-ruling Nationalists retained a majority in the Parliament. 
The Nationalists, led by former Vice President Lien Chan, and the second major opposition party, led by James Soong, a breakaway Nationalist, hope to improve their positions in the December elections. They want to force Mr. Chen into a coalition government in which he would give up much of his power to choose the cabinet and to set policy. 
Mr. Chen's party, D.P.P., in turn, hopes to increase the proportion of seats, now just 30 percent, it holds in the 225-member Parliament. 
"After the elections, we're likely to see a coalition of some sort," said Joseph Wu, a political expert at National Chengchi University in Taipei. "The question is, will the D.P.P. gain enough seats to dominate a coalition?"
Enter Mr. Lee, the former president. He formally remains a member of the Nationalist Party and is not expected to run for office himself, but he has thrown his "spiritual support" to the Taiwan Solidarity Union, a new party founded to push his agenda of an independent Taiwanese identity.
While Mr. Lee retired in disgrace after the 2000 elections, blamed by many Nationalists for dividing and betraying his party, he remains popular among native-born Taiwanese. Now he is campaigning for the Solidarity Union, hoping to draw out those in the Nationalist Party who share his abhorrence at the more accommodating policies toward Beijing being pursued under the leadership of Mr. Lien. Mr. Lee says the new party's winners will ally with Mr. Chen to give him a majority and stabilize the country. 
Along the way, Mr. Lee, 78, has given ample evidence of what his critics call a "messiah complex." On Saturday, he said at a Solidarity Union rally that "I want to retire but the father has a good-for-nothing son and so I have no choice," an unsubtle reference to his successor as Nationalist leader. 
Mr. Lee has tormented his erstwhile Nationalist colleagues with his disdain, and has all but dared them to expel him. But the party has avoided that, fearing a public backlash.
But Mr. Lee's re-emergence has been a mixed blessing for Mr. Chen. Analysts say the new party is apt to draw more voters from Mr. Chen's own party than from the Nationalists. And judging from Mr. Lee's statements, his new group could be as much an albatross as a savior for Mr. Chen. One of Mr. Lee's goals is to torpedo the very economic overtures to Beijing that Mr. Chen has embraced. 
"Going to China is like committing suicide," Mr. Lee told the cheering throng. If Mr. Lee's new party does add vital support for Mr. Chen, tricky new questions will arise, noted Steven M. Goldstein, an expert on Taiwan politics at Smith College. 
"How would these two big egos, Lee and Chen, ever work together?" Mr. Goldstein asked. Beijing's response, too, could be worrisome. In the minds of mainland leaders, Mr. Goldstein noted, "these are the world's two worst people."

HEADLINE: Kudus Journal; 
. . . But a Good Cigarette Is a Fantasy of Flavor

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: KUDUS, Indonesia 

 BODY:
It was one of those precious moments that seem to prove that life has meaning, a moment of inspiration -- perhaps divine inspiration -- that makes all the hard times seem worthwhile.
 "All of a sudden, out of the blue, I had it," said Djoko Herryanto, a chemist whose mission it is to find the most delicious mixture of spices to enhance the taste of Indonesia's sweet-smelling clove cigarettes. 
 "Until this day, I don't know," he said. "Did this idea come from my technical knowledge? Or did it come from 'wahyu,' a divine inspiration, a flash?" 
Indeed, his new creation does seem beyond the imagining of ordinary men.
"A taste of banana mixed with cheese and sugar sauce together with chocolate, all toasted together," he said, still breathless when he thinks about it. "That's the flavor that came to me -- Bam! -- sweet, nutty, caramelic, fruity, everything!" 
A blend of flavors like this may seem hard to imagine in a cigarette, but tens of millions of Indonesians are smoking sticks of candy like this every day. The clove cigarette, it turns out, is a great deal more than tobacco and cloves. It is a complex, infinitely variable symphony of scent and flavor. 
Usually about two-thirds tobacco, one-third clove, the Indonesian smoke known as a kretek also contains one more, often secret, ingredient: its sauce, or saus in Indonesian.
This is where divine inspiration comes in: cinnamon, pineapple, licorice, coriander, litchi nut, coffee, strawberry -- whatever delights the senses, sometimes in natural flavorings but usually (and more economically) in artificial flavors.
"If you just put in tobacco and clove, it would taste funny," Mr. Herryanto said. "The blending is like making music -- how to make the smell and the taste, the positive and the negative flavors, all come into harmony."
Indonesia's 210 million people -- mostly its men -- smoked 200 billion kreteks last year. There are some 2,000 brands, produced by about 500 companies ranging from tiny family-owned enterprises to some of the biggest and most powerful companies in the nation.
Two big producers, Sampoerna and Gudang Garam, are among the few major Indonesian enterprises that not only survived the economic collapse of the past four years but prospered. Their owners are the only two Indonesians left of a dozen who were counted among the world's richest people before the crash. 
Clove cigarettes are so popular in Indonesia that only one smoker out of 10 prefers standard cigarettes, known here as whites. It is one of the few markets in the world where American tobacco companies have failed to prosper.
"Whites are boring," said Baedowi Maroef, the director of the mid-sized Jambu Bol kretek factory here in the birthplace of clove cigarettes. And how else could it be for someone who has smoked kreteks all his life. Some brands even dip their filters in saccharine, making them even more like smokable candy.
When he is too sick to smoke, Mr. Maroef said, he holds his kreteks up to his nose and sniffs them.
Among other things, kreteks offer one of Indonesia's few guarantees of employment. Most are hand rolled and it takes about 200,000 women around Indonesia, working with incredible speed, to keep up with demand. One of the larger companies, Djarum, once held a contest, which was won by a woman who rolled 12,000 in a day.
That is nothing, Mr. Herryanto said, compared with a rolling machine in the United States, which can produce 16,000 cigarettes in an hour.
It is good work, said a roller named Rukayah, 42, her hands flying like lightning as she spoke, "because if I weren't doing this, I wouldn't have a job."
Twenty-six years on the job have given her funny dreams, she said. "Sometimes I dream that I'm locked in here with my friends, still rolling kreteks, and I can't stop," she said.
Developed in the 1880's to minister to coughs and asthma -- they were first sold in pharmacies -- kreteks were originally wrapped in corn husks, a monsoon-season boon to farmers because that made them waterproof.
Today clove cigarettes are a signature of Indonesia. The whole country sometimes seems to smell of them. In the congested cities, even automobile exhaust is sweetened by the scent of clove.
And they are intimately entwined with Indonesia's history.
"What is that you are smoking, sir?" asked a diplomat, according to an oft-told tale, addressing Indonesia's first ambassador to Great Britain 50 years ago.
The ambassador, Agus Salim, was ready with his riposte: "That, your excellency, is the reason for which the West conquered the world!"
Indeed. In the late 15th and early 16th centuries, it was the cloves of the Moluccas and the nutmeg of the Banda islands -- worth more than their weight in gold -- that drew European explorers and colonists into the South Seas.
"In this respect, clove may be seen as having played a central role in Indonesia's past and in the history of the world in general," writes Mark Hanusz in a new coffee table book called "Kretek: The Culture and Heritage of Indonesia's Clove Cigarettes" (Equinox Publishing, 2000).
In an introduction to the book, the writer Pramoedya Ananta Toer notes, "You can always tell a kretek smoker by the holes in their clothes -- caused by the crackling of the cloves."
A chain smoker since his boyhood, Mr. Pramoedya describes his love of the clove cigarette, saying, "When I moved to Surabaya, I picked up two new habits that would continue to this day -- smoking kretek and wearing shoes."
In a taste test, Mr. Herryanto, the chemist, offered a sniff-and-smoke comparison of several delicious-smelling brands. It took his expert nose to tease out the flavorings from the aroma of cloves.
Wismalak Diplomat. Sweet, strong, fruity, mostly plum, with undertones of strawberry and pineapple.
Gudang Garam. Less fruity, more spicy and fragrant with cinnamon, coriander, star anise and lovage.
Sampoerna Mild. A sweetened Marlboro with its chocolate undertone, plus clove and rum.
Nothing seems to happen in Indonesia without kreteks. Fat or slim, filtered or straight, fruity or spicy, they are everywhere. Few people seem to associate them with illnesses like lung cancer.
Asked to describe the quintessential setting for a good smoke, Mr. Maroef smiled a faraway smile. "Most obviously, almost inevitably, after meals," he said. "Or in any relaxed situation, like when you're sitting on the toilet."
His colleague at Jambu Bol, Abdul Aziz, said kreteks also go well with sports, like tennis.
Come again?
"Well, it's difficult to explain," he said. "But after playing tennis it feels really good to have a smoke."

(Photographs by Anastasia Vrachnos for The New York Times) Map of Indonesia highlighting Kudus: Kudus is the birthplace of Indonesia's aromatic cigarettes.

HEADLINE: In America; 
On the Way to Nowhere

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The celebrated boom of the late 1990's was little more than an illusion to millions of young Americans who remain undereducated, unemployed and dangerously disconnected from the nation's social and economic mainstream.
 The boom gave us a period of extraordinary economic growth and reduced unemployment to levels not seen since the late 1960's. And yet there are nearly five million people in the 16-to-24 age group who are both out of school and out of work. 
 For them, every day's a holiday. And that is not good news. These out-of-work and increasingly out-of-hope young people are coming to be known as the "nowhere kids." Trouble follows them with the persistence of night following day. They drink. They do drugs. Many of them commit crimes. And they create children they are unable to adequately care for. 
These young people live their troubled lives beneath the radar of most public-policy planners. They are jobless, but most of them are not even counted as unemployed. To be officially "unemployed" you have to be actively looking for work.
Jack Wuest, who heads the Alternative Schools Network, an organization in Chicago that offers education and employment assistance to inner-city youngsters, said of this hard-core, hard-to-reach group:
"Most lack basic job skills as well as solid literacy and numbers proficiencies, and they are neither working nor looking for jobs. They are not in vocational training. They are not in manufacturing. They are not part of the information age. They are not included in the American conversation."
A nationwide study of labor-market conditions for youngsters 16 to 24 was commissioned by the Alternative Schools Network and carried out by a team of researchers led by Andrew Sum, the director of the Center for Labor Market Studies at Northeastern University in Boston.
"During 1999," the study found, "only 54 of every 100 young adults lacking a high school diploma or a GED certificate were employed, versus 75 of every 100 high school graduates and nearly 89 of every 100 four-year college graduates." Among black high school dropouts, only 23 percent held full-time jobs.
Good economic times were not enough to lift dropouts out of the unemployment trough. The study said that young adults with limited formal schooling, especially those from ethnic-minority and low-income communities, "faced substantial barriers to employment even in a national full employment labor market environment."
Black and Hispanic youths were more likely to be out of work and out of school than white youngsters. During 1999, 13 percent of white 16- to 24-year-olds were idle, as opposed to 21 percent of blacks and Hispanics in the same age group.
The study added, "These counts of disconnected youth are conservative, since they exclude the 350,000-360,000 men, ages 18-24, in the nation's jails and prisons."
The study also said, "Since many of the 20-24-year-old disconnected women are mothers, their absence from both schooling and labor market activities increases the risk of their children being poor, placing the future generation of children at greater risk of poverty and dependency."
That's the bad news. The worse news as far as employment is concerned is that the population of 16- to 24-year-olds in the U.S. -- after declining from the early 80's to the mid-90's -- is expected to grow at an above-average rate for the next decade. Much of the increase will come from the very groups that at the moment are struggling in terms of education and employment, especially blacks, Hispanics and young immigrants.
Government leaders do not appear to be paying close attention. But, trust me, you do not want to see a big national surge in out-of-work and out-of-school young people. Especially when they will be joined on the streets over the next decade by large numbers of men released from prison.
Programs that used to provide support in the form of training and job placement for teenagers and young adults have fallen out of favor and been drastically cut over the past several years. And federal money for summer jobs for disadvantaged kids -- an important and well-regarded initiative -- is all but a memory.
We have a choice. We can pay closer attention and choose to do right by these millions of youngsters. Or we can sit back, ignore the growing problem and reap the long-term consequences.

HEADLINE: As Princeton Changes, a Black Community Fears for Future 

BYLINE:  By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 31 

 BODY:
Albert Hinds's earliest recollections are sunk into a single city block a century past.
 "I was born on the corner of Quarry and Witherspoon, my first church was on the corner of Quarry and Witherspoon, and my first school was the Witherspoon Street School for Colored Children," recounted Mr. Hinds, who turns 100 in April. 
 With his long local history and sharp childhood memories, Mr. Hinds seems as good an emblem as any for the deep roots Princeton's African-Americans have driven into the gently sloping few acres of homes, churches and small businesses bounded by John Street on the West and Witherspoon on the east, just a few minutes walk from the great university across Nassau Street to the south. 
But Mr. Hinds's remembrances of an area of town known as the John-Witherspoon neighborhood are brighter than his vision of the future. Academics, researchers and businessmen continue to pour into Princeton, raising rents and tempting property owners in John-Witherspoon to succumb to higher and higher offers on their homes. At the other end of the economic scale, hundreds of immigrant workers, most of them Hispanic, have crammed into houses in the neighborhood, drawn by Princeton's booming service industries.
"We've been pushed, pushed, pushed," Mr. Hinds said. "How much more can they push us?"
The "they" in his complaint may be market forces more than greedy landlords or poorly enforced housing rules, but Mr. Hinds knows the results without being told the numbers. According to the latest Census figures, Princeton lost 15 percent of its black residents during the 1990's. Blacks were the only group whose population fell as the borough's total grew to 14,200 from 12,150. At the same time, the number of Hispanic residents grew by 55 percent. Similarly, black home occupancy declined by a quarter, while Hispanic occupancy doubled.
A decade of boom has put pressure on black neighborhoods in any number of desirable communities around the country, perhaps most especially in the prosperous suburbs surrounding New York City.
Stamford, Conn., despite a population increase of 8 percent from 1990 to 2000, had a 7.3 percent drop in its black population; Summit, N.J., grew by 6 percent but lost 20 percent of its black residents; Mount Kisco, in Westchester County, grew by 7.5 percent but its black population declined by more than a quarter.
The trend has aroused special concern across racial and class lines in Princeton, in part because the town has a troubled history of segregation and displacement of blacks that people here are eager to live down.
Princeton has historically had a Southern flavor, perhaps best expressed by Princeton University's previous tradition as a suitable school for the Southern gentry who were loath to expose their sons to the abolitionism and radicalism at Harvard or Yale in the 19th century. Indeed, as many Princetonians died fighting for the South and for slavery as for the Union during the Civil War.
"Princeton is popular through the South because it is the one eastern school which does not enroll negroes," says a letter from a member of the class of 1928 that is posted on the Princeton Historical Society's Web site.
The university did not grant its first degrees to blacks until 1947, and then only to three men admitted under a wartime training program. Princeton's public schools remained segregated until the following year, and the university did not begin to admit blacks in real numbers until the president, Robert F. Goheen, pushed open the doors in the 1960's.
By then, Palmer Square, a collection of shops under slate-shingled roofs, had already displaced hundreds of black families and closed the John-Witherspoon neighborhood off from the more upscale Nassau Street, where stores for Rolex, Talbots and Laura Ashley now greet students passing through the university's gates. Later projects threw up a wall of apartments and parking decks that today block the view toward downtown from the head of John Street.
And much of Princeton is worried about the fate of its remaining African-American community.
"We're talking about a free black community that dates at least into the 17th century and possibly before, that has been a thriving community whose members are very invested in this town," said Maureen Smyth, assistant director of the Historical Society of Princeton. On the society's Internet site, Web pages about John-Witherspoon are more visited than any except ones on Albert Einstein.
One group troubled by the growing gentrification is Princeton Future, which came into being last year during the debate over the fate of the handful of downtown tracts still open to development.
"It's a matter of creep," said Sheldon Sturges, president of Sturges Publishing, a Web-based teaching concern, and a co-chair of Princeton Future. "The community is under pressure from parking creep, commercial creep, traffic and overcrowding."
"This is the last affordable housing in town, and the people here see their social links deteriorating," said Yina A. Moore, a transportation specialist who is on the Princeton Future board and lives in John-Witherspoon. "Houses are being taken over and that is eliminating opportunities for people to move back in."
But while gentrification may push up rents and taxes, it also rewards longtime owners who take high prices for their homes. The arrival of a few dozen well-off white families has not been nearly as upsetting to Mr. Hinds and some of his neighbors as overcrowding by immigrant workers who stream in and out of old homes that have been divided into tiny rental apartments.
The evidence is everywhere -- in increased volumes of garbage waiting for pickup, in the now common sight of men showering in back yards after a day's work, even in the refrigerators on front porches that, Mr. Sturges said, probably indicate the presence of illegal restaurants for immigrant workers.
Jim Floyd, who 30 years ago was the first black mayor of the surrounding Princeton Township, picks his words carefully when discussing criticism of his Spanish-speaking neighbors.
"The neighborhood has deteriorated because of this overcrowding and the failure to maintain garbage cleanup and enforce zoning laws," Mr. Floyd said. "Now we have this loud music, the cars driving back and forth all night. Culturally or ethnically, these occupants feel that they are having a good time, but sometimes we have to ask them to keep the noise down."
Perhaps because the efforts of Princeton Future have so far produced few results, Mr. Floyd said he placed little faith in the group. Mr. Hinds is also skeptical.
"I don't see them stopping whatever is going to happen to this neighborhood," he said. "And whatever happens to this neighborhood, it won't be good."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Princeton's John-Witherspoon neighborhood faces drastic demographic change as the effects of a real-estate boom ripple through the area. At right, 99-year-old Albert Hinds, a lifelong resident, lamented the shift. (Photographs by Keith Meyers/The New York Times)(pg. B2)

HEADLINE: BellSouth's Down-Home Strategy; 
Local Telephone Service Has Become a Haven For Cautious Company

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: ATLANTA 

 BODY:
The oak furniture. The neckties and starched shirts. The hushed banter of secretaries outside large corner offices. And the steady, predictable stream of profits generated by the dominant local telephone company in the Southeast.
 At its corporate headquarters in a nondescript high-rise here, it seems as if BellSouth remains untouched by the frenzied changes that have shaken the telecommunications world in recent years. 
 Among the seven regional Bell companies that emerged from the 1984 breakup of AT&T, only BellSouth is still, primarily, a regional phone company. A mere five years ago it was the biggest of the Baby Bells. After a wave of mergers and takeovers in the industry, however, BellSouth has been eclipsed, currently ranking No. 3 of the four remaining Bells. 
And yet, by forgoing national expansion to focus on local service in the same nine states where it has operated the last 17 years, BellSouth has found the local telephone business a haven in the storm that has ravaged so much of the rest of the telecommunications industry. Indeed, BellSouth's stumble two years ago, when it tried and failed to acquire the long-distance company Sprint for $100 billion, is now looking a lot like a lucky break. 
"We are essentially holding our own relative to other players," said F. Duane Ackerman, BellSouth's 59-year-old chairman and chief executive, a reserved Florida native with an engineering degree from M.I.T. and a career-long Bell worker. "We've made it a priority to maintain a strong balance sheet in uncertain times."
BellSouth's low-profile conservatism appears to be paying off. Telecommunications giants like WorldCom and AT&T lost billions in market value in the last year as fierce competition, especially in the long-distance business, eroded market share. Sprint's stock has tumbled more than 31 percent in the last year.
BellSouth's stock price has held steady the last 12 months, closing at $37.30 on Friday. And yet, among the Bells, only Verizon Communications -- now the largest of the group, with local telephone operations in 31 states -- has outperformed BellSouth, rising more than 13 percent in the same period. The second-largest Bell, SBC Communications, has slipped almost 5 percent in market value the last year. Qwest Communications International, the fourth of the surviving Baby Bells, has slumped nearly 59 percent.
In fact, BellSouth might have fared even better if it had not been hurt by plunging currencies in Latin America -- the one place where BellSouth has diverged from its stay-at-home strategy by investing heavily in wireless networks.
Mainly, though, BellSouth is a beneficiary of the relatively slight impact of local telephone competition in the United States to date. Although the Telecommunications Act of 1996 was supposed to stimulate competition at the local level, entering that market has proved to be dauntingly complex and costly. Even giants like AT&T have had trouble making money from entering the local phone business, and many a smaller company has died trying.
BellSouth says its rivals control 12 percent of the telephone lines in its region -- 24 percent of business customers and 5 percent of residential lines. Some small competitors, however, like IDS Telcom of Miami, suggest that BellSouth's figures are overestimates, which BellSouth denies. IDS Telcom said BellSouth may be overstating the extent of competition so that BellSouth can make the case that it should be allowed to enter the long-distance business. 
According to the Federal Communications Commission, 300 or so small companies known as competitive local exchange carriers, or CLEC's (pronounced SEE-lecks), compete with BellSouth on the local level. Together, they control about 8 percent of the total lines in the region. But many CLEC's, facing a financing drought, are having trouble expanding their market shares. BellSouth said the F.C.C. figures, which are several months old, included measurements in states like North Carolina and Florida, where new competitors or other local phone companies like Alltel already control a large part of the market.
Although BellSouth's conservatism has paid off for its core local business, the company is by no means old fashioned. Mr. Ackerman, for example, has equipped nearly all his managers with Blackberry pagers so they can wirelessly send and receive e-mail messages throughout the day -- including notes from the chief executive. 
In fact, the managers' attention to the devices during a reporter's visit often made it difficult to conduct a normal conversation, so intent was their focus on communication within the company. But the message was implicit: BellSouth's emphasis is efficient expansion rather than growth through consolidation. 
Still, BellSouth's expansion strategy faces several challenges. Chief among them, perhaps, is the effort to compete with cable companies in signing up customers for high-speed, or broadband, Internet access.
It is a race in which the cable industry's lead appears to be lengthening. Already in the United States, according to the Yankee Group research firm, there are about seven million cable-modem subscribers, compared with 3.3 million subscribers to the telephone company alternative service, known as digital subscriber line, or D.S.L.
And cable's lead may be growing faster. Richard A. Bilotti of Morgan Stanley estimates that cable accounted for 64 percent of new broadband subscribers in the second quarter, up from 59 percent in the first quarter.
BellSouth, meanwhile, had a drop in net D.S.L. additions in the second quarter -- to 78,000 from 88,000 in the previous quarter -- fueling concern that the company may not be able to reach its goal of 600,000 D.S.L. subscribers by the end of the year. BellSouth says its target is still within reach, even though the company recently raised prices for its business D.S.L. services to $79.95, from $59.95.
"When you see BellSouth raising D.S.L. prices, it's a sign that the rollout may have been more expensive than originally expected," said F. Drake Johnstone, an analyst at Davenport & Company. "It's worrisome for the long-term goal of catching up with cable."
BellSouth and the other Bells are aggressively seeking to compete with companies that provide fast Internet access over cable networks, through their support of the so-called Tauzin-Dingell bill, sponsored by Representatives Billy Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who is chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, and John D. Dingell of Michigan, the senior Democrat on the committee.
The Bells say the bill would put phone companies and cable companies on equal footing. And BellSouth, whose coverage area includes Louisiana, has been especially supportive of the bill and, in particular, Mr. Tauzin. Mr. Ackerman, BellSouth's chief executive, and 38 other BellSouth employees made contributions to Mr. Tauzin's political action committees in 1998 and 1999, according to the Center for Responsive Politics in Washington.
BellSouth faces another challenge. To win permission to enter the long-distance market, it must convince regulators that it has done enough to opened its local network to competitors.
So far, though, regulators and competitors have not been overly impressed. In July, the Georgia Public Service Commission fined BellSouth $7 million for not meeting standards in handling orders from competitors for switching customers. And regulators in Florida and Alabama are looking into complaints of anticompetitive practices at BellSouth. Competitors complain, among other grievances, that BellSouth misleads customers by blaming the CLEC's for service disruptions, even when BellSouth may be at fault.
"We don't have a fighting chance with BellSouth," said Keith Kramer, a senior vice president at IDS Telcom. "They're throwing everything they have at us to make us fail."
BellSouth says it is doing its best to treat the CLEC's fairly. And the company says it is optimistic that, despite its recent run-in with regulators in Georgia, it will receive approval this month to provide long-distance service in the state. That would allow BellSouth to enter the market by the end of this year. Other states will follow next year, the company predicts. 
At a local carrier service center here, one of three such facilities where BellSouth processes orders from CLEC's, 380 employees take orders from companies like IDS. So far, the company has hired more than 3,000 employees and invested about $1.6 billion to take orders from competitors on the local level. BellSouth says it processes 35,000 orders from the CLEC's every day. 
"On an operational level, BellSouth has improved in the last few months in terms of efficiently allowing us to sign up customers," Royce J. Holland, chief executive of Allegiance Telecom, a CLEC based in Dallas, said in an interview. "But in other ways, like overcharging us on leases and deposits, they're the masters of the stonewall."
In the last quarter, BellSouth's earnings declined 8.6 percent, to $973 million, or 52 cents a share, from $1.06 billion, or 56 cents, a year earlier. Revenue in the quarter rose 9 percent, to $7.37 billion, largely because of benefits resulting from increased data operations and from its formation last year of Cingular Wireless with SBC Communications, to create the nation's No. 2 cellular phone company after Verizon Wireless. 
The main reason for the earnings decline was the company's exposure to economic problems in Latin America, where BellSouth has operations in 11 countries.
In a classic example of the downside of currency risk, BellSouth's per-share profit was reduced 5 percent after the weakening of several Latin American currencies. Most investments in the region in licenses and infrastructure were made in dollars, but revenue in depreciating local currencies reduced the dollar value to BellSouth. 
Factoring out the currency problems, however, margins in the region climbed 33 percent in the second quarter. In fact, the company has been praised by big investors for having the most organized and extensive international strategy.
"The short-term blip in Latin America," said Mr. Johnstone, the Davenport analyst, "is something that comes along with gaining a foothold in emerging markets."

HEADLINE: Notions of New Economy Hinge On Pace of Productivity Growth 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Sept. 2 

 BODY:
Rising prosperity still bathed the nation a year ago when Alan Greenspan opened the annual symposium of Federal Reserve policy makers in this mountain resort with a confident boast that the strong gains in worker productivity that seemed to underlie the robust expansion of the 1990's would continue.
 That contention appears to haunt him today. The nation's boom has collapsed despite the faith of Mr. Greenspan, the Fed chairman, that the ever-greater efficiencies of the information age would keep on raising profits, incomes and employment at a healthy pace. Instead, the nation is barely skirting a recession, stock prices have fallen, the budget surplus is shrinking and the new economy is losing its charm. 
 Adding injury to insult, the government just last month took the accelerating productivity figures that Mr. Greenspan cited so proudly a year ago and revised them downward. Instead of growing at an annual rate of 3.4 percent in 1999 and 2000, productivity -- the amount that a worker produces in a hour -- grew at a significantly slower rate of 2.6 percent a year during the best years of the economic boom. 
"He must have an awful lot of egg on his face," Dean Baker, co-director of the Center for Economic and Policy Research, said in a telephone interview from Washington.
But don't tell that to Mr. Greenspan. With the Fed's leadership once again gathered here for this year's symposium, the message remained upbeat for the 100 or so experts from government, academia and Wall Street who were invited here. Most expressed their confidence that the vast changes wrought by computer technology are providing a solid foundation for long-run prosperity.
And despite the new figures casting doubt on some of those views, the general mood was that the new economy -- promising strong growth with little inflation -- would endure once the current slowdown ends.
"The preponderance of evidence suggests a continual increase in productivity growth," Lawrence H. Summers, president of Harvard University and Treasury secretary in the administration of President Bill Clinton, declared in an interview here, reaffirming Mr. Greenspan's optimism a year ago.
Mr. Greenspan himself sat through the conference sessions in silence, but he has made clear to other Fed policy makers that he still believes that the productivity miracle is alive and well.
Still, the latest government figures gave ammunition to critics who have long argued that the rapid productivity gains reported in the late 1990's were more of a mirage caused in part by unsustainable business investment. That also led to a spurt in growth that temporarily forced companies to use labor more efficiently.
Much is at stake in this debate. The optimists think that the productivity growth rate will stay above 2.5 percent annually over the long run. The pessimists, by contrast, think that the improvement has been more mundane, more like the 2 percent that the government now says is the average annual rate since 1990.
The impact of that seemingly small gap is enormous. Productivity is the principal contributor to economic growth. It determines whether corporate revenue is rising fast enough to increase wages and profits. When there is enough revenue and profit from productivity, companies are under less pressure to raise prices, so there is less inflation.
Similarly important, the government's projection that it will accumulate a $3.4 trillion budget surplus between now and 2011 relies on a rate of productivity growth of at least 2.5 percent. A more modest gain of 2 percent would mean that the surplus would be roughly $800 billion lower, according to Dan Crippen, director of the Congressional Budget Office.
Mr. Crippen, in a telephone interview from Washington, noted that $800 billion is enough to pay for all of the nation's military expenses for two years and to cover prescription drugs for the elderly for more than a decade. "Probably the biggest uncertainty in our projections is whether the increase in productivity is sustainable," he said.
Mr. Greenspan has argued that an accelerating rate of productivity growth is the chief explanation for the boom that started in the mid-1990's as American companies increased their investments in computer-based information technologies, including the Internet. The productivity growth rate measures the increase in output from each hour of work. From that increase, companies are able to generate higher revenue, adding to profits and to wages for workers without having to raise prices. Profits and wages did in fact rise for nearly five years. The prosperity was real.
But now that the boom has collapsed into sluggish growth, productivity's contribution to that prosperity is uncertain. The revised productivity figures suggest that temporary factors -- an exuberant stock market, excessive business investment, a surge in debt-financed consumer spending, for example -- all played important roles. The Fed's conference here was the first high-powered challenge to a growing view that the new economy lacks staying power.
"There is a lot at stake," said Martin N. Baily, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics and a former chairman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, who presented a paper at the conference. "Profits will not be as strong, and with less profits business investment in the new technologies will not be as strong and the stock market won't be strong."
There were some skeptics here. One of them, Henry Kaufman, a Wall Street economist and consultant, says that Mr. Greenspan, having committed himself to the idea of accelerating productivity, cannot easily get off that horse without frightening the markets.
But Mr. Kaufman's dissent was distinctly in the minority. Mr. Summers, co-author of a paper presented here, spoke for the majority, and so did Martin Feldstein, a Harvard economist who served for a while as President Ronald Reagan's chief economic adviser.
"The key question is whether productivity at 2.5 percent is going to continue," Mr. Feldstein said at the final session, summarizing the conference's findings. "My answer is yes. You cannot know this just by looking at the data; you have to look at the economy itself. The information revolution is going to keep us going."
The main argument for those who are optimistic about productivity centers on the belief that hundreds of thousands of companies outside the high-technology sector are still in the process of incorporating the new technologies and changing their practices. They think that these companies have considerable room to improve their efficiency.
But a few experts worry that the efficiencies might be slow in coming. "I cannot say that the optimists are wrong," Mr. Baily said. "I can only say that if I were planning the future, I would count on only 2 percent."
The overall economy can grow and generate prosperity only as fast as the work force itself grows and each worker increases his or her output. The working-age population is expanding at barely 1 percent a year, so most of the nation's gain in prosperity must come from productivity.
Mr. Greenspan has spoken of a potential growth rate of 3.5 percent to 4 percent a year. His critics -- those who doubt that the computer-based technologies are all that special -- see 3 percent, or slightly less, as the limit for economic growth.
Whatever the truth, embracing the higher figure gave Mr. Greenspan justification to hold down interest rates even as the economy surged -- and to cut rates quickly as the slowdown developed. After all, why turn off the boom to fight an inflationary threat that may never materialize?
"There is no question," Mr. Baily said, "that if you believe in the new economy, it lowers your estimate of what inflation will be. That has given the Fed the freedom to act aggressively in cutting interest rates, and the freedom to keep rates down when the upturn finally comes."
But what if those assumptions prove too optimistic? The Congressional Budget Office produced the budget-surplus projections that the Bush administration has cited to justify its $1.3 trillion tax cut. Those who want to privatize a part of Social Security would tap the surplus to help pay the costs.
So far, in making its projections, the budget office has tilted toward the Greenspan camp. It assumed, in its latest revisions announced last week, that productivity would grow at a 2.5 percent annual rate for the next 10 years, down only slightly from its earlier projection of 2.7 percent, but well above the 1.4 percent average rate of productivity growth from 1973 to 1995.
"Last January, we bought into some aspects of the new economy," Mr. Crippen said. "We did not buy into all of it. Historically speaking, our assumptions are not abnormally high."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 7, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Monday about the debate over productivity of the economy attributed a phrase erroneously to Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. While Mr. Greenspan's statements have implied that he believes the economy can achieve a maximum growth rate near 3.5 to 4 percent a year without rising inflation, he he has not publicly specified rates.

HEADLINE: Putin, Sizing Up Bush, Says the Retinue 'Makes the King' 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 2 

 BODY:
President Vladimir V. Putin said this weekend that he believes that George W. Bush has a strong reliance on a powerful circle of aides, but that this circle is still struggling over its priorities, especially in regard to the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. 
 In an interview with a Finnish newspaper held Saturday before Mr. Putin's departure for Finland today, the Russian leader was asked to evaluate the first seven months of the Bush administration. He said he found his American counterpart "a comfortable and substantive partner," but at the same time added that he had come to believe in the "correctness of the expression that it is the retinue" of aides "that makes the king." 
 "Of course, it is he who makes the final decision," Mr. Putin added, according to a transcript of the interview issued by his press service, "but we have a feeling that his team has not determined some priorities yet." 
Only when they do, he added, "will our dialogue take on a substantive character." 
The Russian leader seemed to confer a negative judgment on the quality of consultations that have been under way since the two leaders met in Slovenia and Genoa this summer. Moreover, his remarks indicated that Russian officials sense that the debate in Washington over how to proceed with missile defense is still under way and may undergo further change as the White House contemplates a battle in Congress over funding for a $60 billion project whose effectiveness has been intensely debated. 
An influential Russian legislator said here tonight that Russian officials have been urging Mr. Putin to take a "more measured tone" in speaking publicly about Mr. Bush's plans on missile defense.
"Frankly, I do not think it is in our interest to stir up an excessive dust storm on this subject," said Vladimir P. Lukin, a deputy speaker of the Russian Parliament and former ambassador to Washington. Whatever Washington does, Russia's nuclear deterrent will remain unaffected by American missile defenses for at least 10 to 15 years, he said, "so we have no need to be hysterical."
"It is the American authorities who are interested in destroying this treaty," Mr. Lukin continued, "They must deal with the problems this creates with their opposition in Congress, with their allies, with China as it increases its nuclear buildup; it is your problem how to avoid stimulating an arms race with India and Pakistan." 
And, he added, "if they have the money to build the most excessive response to the least probable threat situation, that's O.K." 
Since his first meeting with Mr. Bush, Mr. Putin has met with each of Mr. Bush's principal advisers: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who accompanied Mr. Bush to Slovenia in June; Condoleezza Rice, Mr. Bush's national security aide who traveled to Moscow in July; and Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld, who visited here in August.
Russian officials complained during the summer that they were confused by the variety of statements from Washington on whether the Bush administration plans to negotiate a new strategic accord to replace the ABM treaty and to cut nuclear stockpiles further, or whether it is preparing to act alone. 
Last month, a senior State Department official, John R. Bolton, traveled to Moscow and said in a radio interview that Washington wanted Russian agreement to amend the ABM treaty by the time Mr. Bush and Mr. Putin meet in November in Crawford, Tex. Without such an agreement, Mr. Bolton said, the United States reserved the right to withdraw under terms of the treaty. 
But Mr. Bolton asserted the next day that Washington was not laying down any deadlines. Two days later, Mr. Bush stepped in and said the United States "will withdraw from the ABM treaty on our own timetable at a time convenient to America," but he added that he had no "specific timetable in mind."
Speaking to the Finnish interviewer, Mr. Putin expressed concern that the United States under Mr. Bush might be taking the position that "America is so strong that it does not need any negotiations and any agreements." He said this represents the "most extreme" and "toughest" approach to international relations.
Despite those concerns, Mr. Putin said Russia would not overreact if the United States did decide to withdraw from the ABM treaty. Moscow would continue to work in its foreign policy to rebuild its economy while maintaining "good-natured" relations with its neighbors and main partners. He added that "we, for sure, consider the United States one of them." 
If the United States decides to abandon the treaty approach, Mr. Putin said, "Well, what is to be done? If this is the way, we can only throw up our hands. But even in this event, we will not whip up any hysteria."
In the case of NATO's planned expansion, to include Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, the Russians did lobby vigorously against the increase, only to look powerless when they lost the argument. In the interview on Saturday, Mr. Putin coined the new watchword of the Russian leadership -- "calm."
Over the last several days, both Mr. Putin and his minister of defense, Sergei B. Ivanov, have repeated this mantra in public statements, refraining from warning that Russia could react to a missile shield by putting multiple warheads on a new generation of its missiles.
With the new tone, Mr. Putin appeared to be speaking to a European audience, framing Russia's position as reasonable, consistent and stable, while suggesting that the Bush administration was teetering on recklessness.
"You said that Europe is somewhat concerned about the relations between Russia and the United States," Mr. Putin told the Finnish journalist Saturday. "I would like to calm you down. Russia, at least, is not doing anything that would complicate the international situation."
"We don't violate any of the obligations that we undertook," Mr. Putin said. "We are told that something got obsolete like 1972 ABM treaty. It's not what we say, it's what we are told. We disagree that this treaty is obsolete; nevertheless, expressing good will, we are ready for negotiations."

HEADLINE: CONGRESS RETURNS TO LARGER STAKES IN BUDGET DEBATE 

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 

 BODY:
Congress and President Bush return from vacations this week to face a vanishing budget surplus, a limping economy and a long list of competing spending priorities -- in other words, a recipe for a bruising political collision over spending and taxes.
 With the Senate in Democratic hands by one vote and the House narrowly controlled by Republicans, the political stakes are enormous, especially if a result of the debate is a budget that continues to spend Social Security taxes instead of using them to pay off the federal debt. 
 "No one expected the surplus problem and the Social Security problem to appear this quickly," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader. "Two or three months from the tax cut and here we are already." 
"The way this is resolved will have a lot to do with the next election," Mr. Gephardt said. "People's perceptions could well be formed in this period, with regard to next fall." 
As talks between Congressional leaders and Mr. Bush get under way this week, Mr. Gephardt and Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate majority leader, want the president to revise his budget request to take into account new projections of a much smaller surplus.
But Speaker J. Dennis Hastert has other ideas: making the new 10-year tax cut permanent, pushing for a cut in the capital gains tax and extending the existing tax credit for industrial research and development. A senior Republican aide said that when Mr. Hastert meets with Mr. Bush this week, he would raise these possibilities as ways of countering any further economic weakness.
Complicating the outlook in Congress, which is scheduled to reconvene on Tuesday, are sharp differences between the Republican-led House and the Democratic-controlled Senate over education, trade and energy, which are at the top of the White House's domestic agenda. Disputes also linger between the House and the Senate over campaign finance and health care.
But the immediate quandary is how to pass all 13 bills to finance next year's government programs. That task, which is supposed to be completed this month, has been immeasurably complicated by new estimates showing that Congress has available billions of dollars less than it once expected, unless it dips into the Social Security surplus. That is something both parties had promised not to do.
President Bush said last week that he wanted Congress to direct its immediate attention and the dwindling money first to his two priorities: education and a $18.4 billion increase for the military. But Republicans and Democrats said that it would be impractical, indeed nearly impossible, to take up those two issues first at the exclusion of the rest.
The military spending target looks particularly vulnerable, especially because Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld has not completed his sweeping review of Pentagon policies and programs. "We are looking at a funding request to fund a defense of the past and not one of the future," said Representative Jim Nussle, the Iowa Republican who leads the House Budget Committee. "That is not what was suggested or promised. It has a much higher hurdle to cross."
Lawmakers are also debating whether they can afford other proposals, including an energy plan proposed by Mr. Bush and approved by the House that contains $33 billion in costly tax credits, a proposed farm bill that continues crop subsidies that were to be phased out, some kind of prescription drug benefit for the elderly and assorted other tax breaks that will expire if not extended.
"There isn't anything left over," said Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the ranking Democrat on the Appropriations Committee. "The combination of an economic slowdown and the tax cut has scooped off the table everything we needed to deal with our long-term problems. It is a huge dereliction of duty."
The Bush camp has continued to say that budget targets can be met and that the picture is far from dire.
"We're dealing with historic, gigantic surpluses under any of these numbers," Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, said today on the NBC news program "Meet the Press." 
"We're not talking about cutting spending for next year," Mr. Daniels said. "Spending in the president's budget would go up over $100 billion to strengthen the economy, education and security, and we can do that, consistent with growing -- not shrinking -- surpluses, and it would be misleading to suggest otherwise."
But Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, called that view "divorced from reality, and it is so wrong on the fundamental facts that he put forward that it really underscores the nature of the confrontation that's about to take place."
While Mr. Kerry said it would be unwise to raise taxes or cut spending during an economic downturn, he added, "You have to put everything on the table, and the first step is for the president to be prepared to say, 'We may have misjudged how much money we have available.' "
Republicans, while acknowledging that the surplus shrank unexpectedly fast, said the tax cut was doing precisely what it was intended to do. "Republicans are achieving the goal of leaving Democrats with less money to spend hand-over-fist with before Congress adjourns this year," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader.
But it also made it harder to balance the budget over the coming years without using some money from Social Security taxes, which by agreement have been earmarked recently for reducing the national debt.
Last week, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office projected that the government would have to spend $9 billion of the Social Security surplus this year because general tax revenues fell short as the economy softened and taxpayers received a rebate from the new tax bill.
Next year, the projections are only a bit better. Congress is already on a course to spend $661 billion in the 13 spending bills for the 2002 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1. Aside from Social Security surpluses, there would only be $9 billion more for anything Congress wants to do next year that is not included in current plans, the Congressional Budget Office estimated.
Some Republicans in the House say they must keep their promise not to use the Social Security surplus for everyday government spending, even though analysts agree that it has little practical effect. "My personal view is that any amount of new spending, even defense spending, is not doable in the House if it threatens the Social Security trust fund," said Representative Roy Blunt of Missouri who is the chief deputy whip. "We don't have to grow the government at twice the rate of inflation."
Splitting the difference between military and education spending may be a way to satisfy both sides. 
On education, the House and Senate are still at odds over when to take action on failing schools and how to best track improvements in students' academic performance. But the biggest battle is expected to be over money. Mr. Bush requested an increase of $669 million for education in his budget. But the House wants to increase the $18 billion education budget by $5 billion, and the Senate wants to increase it by $16 billion.
Similarly, just before the recess, the House passed a bipartisan bill to overhaul the managed care system. While the bill resembles the Senate version, considerable differences remain over the scope of lawsuits. "It has not been worked out," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who leads the Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions.
In addition, Mr. Hastert expects to move quickly on a bill that would give Mr. Bush more flexibility in negotiating trade agreements, something the president considers a priority. The Senate, however, is not enthusiastic. "When are we going to do that?" asked Senator Harry M. Reid of Nevada, the second-ranking Democrat. "Is it more important than a patients' bill of rights or education? Forget about it. Do it next year."
The Senate will hold hearings on its energy plan, but the outcome, if there is one this year, is not expected to reflect the House version, which includes drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska and dozens of expensive tax breaks for the oil, coal and gas industries.
The Senate also has little interest in moving on a bill that would increase federal financing for charities run by religious groups. The House has already passed a bill for Mr. Bush's religion-based initiative.
The farm bill may be another casualty of the budget wars, with even the White House saying money must be found before the bill can be pushed through.
A prescription drug benefit for older people also appears imperiled this year, although Democrats and Republicans say $300 billion has been set aside for the next 10 years for that program and other changes in Medicare.
Mr. Kennedy said Senate Democrats would push hard for a $1.50-an-hour increase in the minimum wage, but Republicans want the wage increase to go hand-in-hand with tax credits for businesses.
And in the House, supporters of a bill to overhaul the campaign finance system still hope to force the legislation onto the floor by collecting 218 signatures from members, a fight Republicans would like to avoid. The Democrats have said they are only a dozen or so votes short.
To avoid that kind of power play on the budget, Democrats say Mr. Bush should make the first move and get the negotiations started with some concrete proposals. "The president has got to get engaged," said Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the ranking Democrat on the Budget Committee. "If he does, it doesn't have to be unpleasant."

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
House to Focus On NetAccess And Competition

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Shortly after Congress reconvenes tomorrow, the House will take up a complex bill that raises two simple, essential questions about the nation's digital future. In the effort to deliver high-speed Internet service to consumers, what is the ideal number of competitors? And should the government make that decision?
 In recent years, the battle for high-speed, or broadband, access has been dominated by two technologies. One is digital subscriber lines, or D.S.L., which use telephone wires. The other is cable modems, which use cable television lines. Despite the development of satellite and land-based wireless systems, the broadband media world will continue to be ruled by phone wires and cable lines for many years. 
 Cable lines are essentially under the sole control of the cable companies that own them, companies like AT&T and AOL Time Warner. 
The question posed by the House bill is whether the Bell local telephone carriers, companies like SBC and Verizon, should essentially have sole control of Internet access over phone lines or whether competing companies should also have a fighting chance to use those local connections.
The bill appears to have a reasonable chance of passage in the House but much stronger opposition in the Senate.
If the bill became law, it would be difficult for competitors to build a sustainable business delivering high-speed Internet service to consumers over telephone networks. Congress would basically have determined that the consumer broadband market should be a competitive duopoly of cable operators and the Bell companies, with a small role played by satellite providers.
If the House bill fails, on the other hand, the Bell companies will continue to be obliged to share many parts of their networks with outside companies. Because cable companies are generally under no such obligations, the Bell companies will continue to face costs and regulatory hurdles that cable providers do not.
The issue is really that simple: should the nation's broadband future be determined by a clean fight between two big combatants or by a messy battle among many potential competitors?
The bill in question is known as Tauzin-Dingell, for its two principal sponsors, Representatives Billy Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana and chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, and John D. Dingell of Michigan, the committee's ranking Democrat, both longtime supporters of the Bell companies' aspirations. In pressing for the bill, the Bells have adopted a time-honored technique: try to convince Congress that there is a problem and then convince Congress that the bill will solve it.
But neither assertion is quite true.
The foundation of the Bells' case is that broadband Internet access is not being introduced quickly enough and that what they describe as the slow pace of broadband deployment is hurting the economy.
In a speech two weeks ago in Aspen, Colo., before the Progress and Freedom Foundation, Thomas J. Tauke, Verizon's senior vice president for public policy and external affairs, cited the growth of a number of new communications services, including the Net.
"Trouble is, the rate of adoption of these technologies has slowed dramatically, along with the growth of the economy itself," he said. "So what's flattened the slope of the curve in 2001? The answer is the lack of widespread deployment of broadband technology."
He added, "At the very moment when the U.S. economy is mired in a high-tech slump, broadband is still in the 'beta' phase."
But in fact, broadband is already beyond the beta, or test, stage. By the end of this year, about 17 percent of the nation's Internet-linked homes, or more than 10 million homes over all, will be using broadband, according to analysts. That figure would be up from close to zero just four years ago.
The Bell companies argue that this is slow growth. But listen to what Bell executives have to say about the pace of competition in the local telephone market, which was opened to outsiders five years ago.
"The F.C.C. says that nationwide, competitors have taken about 8 percent of the lines," F. Duane Ackerman, BellSouth's chairman, said in an interview last week, referring to the Federal Communications Commission. "It's moving along at a very rapid clip."
Can 17 percent penetration of broadband be slow if 8 percent penetration of local phone competition over a comparable period is rapid?
It is hard to detect a crisis in broadband deployment. Verizon itself says that almost half of its roughly 60 million lines are capable of carrying D.S.L. and that it plans to invest $4.7 billion this year alone in high-speed data services.
The real crisis for the Bell companies appears to be that they are lagging the cable operators in winning broadband customers. By the end of the year, cable operators will have about 7 million broadband customers, compared with about 3.3 million D.S.L. subscribers, according to the Yankee Group, a research firm in Boston.
It is true that under current law the cable companies do not have to open their networks to competitors, while the Bell companies do. But that is not the reason for the disparity in cable broadband and D.S.L. subscriptions.
To begin with, the big cable companies took a lead of at least two years in widely adding Internet broadband technology to their systems. Moreover, for some arcane technical reasons, cable modems by most accounts are a superior product, faster and far more reliable than D.S.L. for most homes.
The technical gulf is clear, and on condition of anonymity, Bell executives acknowledge its existence. Those disparities are why the Bell companies want to extend optical fiber deeper into their networks, closer to the customers' homes, in hopes of approaching technical parity with the cable operators.
One of the central provisions of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 was that the Bell companies must sell direct access to parts of their networks to other companies. The core of the Tauzin-Dingell bill essentially says that as the Bell carriers extend optical fiber into their networks, other companies will not have the right to buy direct access to those new Bell lines. For many if not most outside D.S.L. companies, losing that ability would be tantamount to being put out of business. (Even under the current ground rules, D.S.L. companies are going out of business nearly every week.)
The Bell companies argue that if they make investments to improve their networks, they should not have to "unbundle," or sell direct access to, the new parts of those systems to outsiders. Many people in Washington see some merit in that argument. In the late 1990's, the F.C.C. agreed to exempt SBC and Verizon from unbundling requirements for their data systems, as long as those companies placed their data operations in separate subsidiaries. 
That arrangement, however, was overturned by a federal court last winter. So now, with the Tauzin-Dingell bill, the Bells are trying to win an unbundling exemption that is far broader than the F.C.C. had granted, and without setting up the separate subsidiaries.
Passing the Tauzin-Dingell bill would change the nation's digital landscape. In the name of embracing market forces, Congress would be determining the design.

HEADLINE: Hints of Change in Myanmar 

 BODY:
Recent weeks have brought signs that the repressive military junta that has ruled Myanmar since 1988 may be reconsidering its stranglehold on the country's democratic forces, led by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace Prize winner. Washington and other governments should encourage this process, but must maintain economic sanctions against the junta until the generals agree to end their tyrannical rule. 
 Last week, a United Nations special envoy, Razali Ismail, visited Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, for four days of meetings with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi and military leaders. Regrettably, the junta's leader, Gen. Than Shwe, declined to meet with Mr. Razali. But the opposition and the military have been talking since last fall, and last week two senior leaders of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy were released from house arrest. Nearly 200 N.L.D. members have been freed since the dialogue with the military began. But more than 1,500 people remain jailed for political reasons, including 29 N.L.D. members of the parliament elected in 1990 but never convened. 
 The military is being pushed toward dialogue by the feeble state of Myanmar's economy. International aid and foreign investment have been drastically curtailed since the 1988 coup. The economic pressure has triggered a debate within the junta, and some members now argue for compromise with the N.L.D. and the country's non-Burmese ethnic minorities. To be meaningful, such a compromise would have to include liberating Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi from house arrest and releasing all imprisoned N.L.D. members. The party must be allowed to function freely, with new democratic elections scheduled and the junta pledging to abide by the results. There must also be an end to forced labor, which remains widespread in Myanmar. 
Unfortunately, Japan seems unwilling to wait for such steps. It recently announced a resumption of development aid and is now weighing a grant of more than $20 million to modernize a power plant that serves military as well as civilian needs. The prospect of resumed foreign aid can be a useful incentive for further steps by the junta. That aid should not be granted prematurely.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL HEALTH; 
Lowering the Risk of Bacterial Meningitis

BYLINE:  By JANE E. BRODY 

 BODY:
Bacterial meningitis is not a common disease, striking about 1 person in 100,000 in the United States each year. But for several reasons, it causes alarm far out of proportion to the number of people affected. 
 First, it is highly contagious, spread by direct droplet infection -- a cough or sneeze, a kiss or even a drink from a contaminated cup, although not by casual contact or breathing the air where an infected person has been. Second, it has a high fatality rate -- up to 15 percent despite treatment and as much as 50 percent without treatment -- and can rapidly assume a fatal course that cannot be reversed by antibiotics and other treatments. Third, many who survive it are left with lifelong health problems, like learning disabilities, mental retardation, hearing loss, kidney failure and limb amputations. 
 But it is the fourth reason that accounts for much of the fear and anxiety: a disproportionate number of victims are children or young adults, with the greatest number being college freshmen who live in dormitories. 
A nationwide study in The Journal of the American Medical Association this month revealed that, while college students had a lower rate of severe bacterial meningitis than the general population of those ages 18 to 23, the rate among freshmen in dormitories was more than three times as high, or 5.1 per 100,000.
A second new study in the same journal examined all 295 cases of bacterial meningitis that had occurred among those ages 15 through 24 in Maryland in the last decade. Dr. Lee H. Harrison of the University of Pittsburgh, who directed the study, reported that although a vast majority of victims were previously healthy, nearly one in four of them died, a fatality rate more than four times as high as that found in people younger than 15.
Now, as universities are reopening their doors to full-time students, it is important to learn more about this disease, its early symptoms and appropriate treatment, and especially how most cases can be prevented through vaccination.
Federal health officials recommend that every college student be told about bacterial meningitis and made aware of potential protection from a vaccine that could prevent up to 85 percent of cases that occur in the college years. Many schools offer the vaccine through their campus health services or at special clinics.

Tricky Disease
Meningitis, an infection of the membrane surrounding the brain and the spinal cord, has many causes. Viral meningitis is more common than the bacterial form and is much less likely to cause severe illness or death; most people who get it recover on their own, perhaps with supportive treatment and sometimes an antiviral agent.
Bacterial meningitis, commonly caused by the bacterium Neisseria meningitidis and referred to as meningococcal meningitis, is sneaky. It typically starts like influenza: the sudden onset of an intense headache, fever, sore throat, nausea, vomiting and malaise. But unlike the flu, a stiff neck and intolerance of lights are frequent symptoms of the disease. Also unlike the flu, meningococcal meningitis within hours of the first symptoms can progress to delirium, coma or convulsions and invade the bloodstream, setting off a bodywide infection that attacks organs and can cause circulatory collapse, a hemorrhagic rash and gangrene.
So at the first suspicion of meningitis in any person, the case must be treated like a medical emergency, with immediate hospitalization. The diagnosis is made by examining the fluid obtained through a spinal tap. A crucial step is to identify the particular "serotype" of the causative bacterium and its susceptibility to antibiotics.
The more common serotypes in teenagers and young adults are A and C. The available vaccine protects against these and against types Y and W135. There is no vaccine for Type B, which more often afflicts young children. They are routinely protected against the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in this age group, Hemophilus influenza b, by the Hib vaccine that is administered to infants and toddlers.
In the past, bacterial meningitis occurred in epidemic fashion among military recruits in boot camps, where young men from many areas shared germs new to their fellow recruits. But in recent decades, all recruits have been routinely immunized and the disease has become rare in this population. Bacterial meningitis may occur more often in college freshmen who live in dormitories because they are likely to be in close contact and exposed to a spectrum of germs to which they are not immune.
Dr. Harrison's study, as well as several previous studies, identified several factors that appeared to increase a person's risk of getting meningococcal meningitis. Of special relevance to high school and college students is cigarette smoking, including passive smoking, and alcohol consumption, especially binge drinking. In an interview, he said smokers coughed more, increasing the chances of transmitting the infection to others, and that drinkers often shared glasses.
Dr. Harrison also said, based on an earlier study, that college students were hardly the only young people at increased risk of developing severe bacterial meningitis. The highest risk he had found was among 17-year-olds, most of whom would be in high school.
Adding to the problem of preventing bacterial meningitis is that some people become carriers of the infection; they are not sick themselves but can transmit it to others, leaving the source of the infection a mystery.

Prevention by Vaccine
For several reasons, there has been a delay of decades in recommending that all young people be immunized against the most common strains of bacterial meningitis. The vaccine, designed to protect against four strains of the N. meningitidis bacterium, is far from perfect. Because some strains are missing, it does not work in all of those who receive it, and it remains effective generally for only about three years. Still, if everyone received the vaccine, the phenomenon of herd immunity could greatly reduce the chance of infection among those at greatest risk, especially those who live for several years in close quarters.
A second factor is cost. Each immunization costs about $75, and as a public health measure it is difficult to justify mass immunization for such a rare disease. But, as Dr. Harrison noted, complex economic and other factors are involved that more than warrant protecting adolescents and young adults.
The disease is a major reason for litigation and widespread panic, he said. The occurrence of just one case in a school setting, for example, provokes a costly public health response involving immunizations, antibiotics to those potentially exposed, and a follow-up of all contacts.
Dr. Harrison, among many others, supports the two-year-old recommendation of a federal health advisory panel that college freshmen be informed about the disease and the availability of the vaccine, which is safe and effective against most of the strains that infect college students. College students can still get the needed protection; the vaccine takes effect within a week or two, and the peak incidence of bacterial meningitis is from November to March.
People already on campus would be wise to check with college health services for information about vaccine availability. Some colleges are routinely immunizing freshmen at no cost to the students.
At the same time, an improved vaccine against the C serotype is being used in Britain, and several pharmaceutical companies are trying to develop a similar product to protect against the remaining serotypes.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mary Ann Hall, a junior at the University of North Florida, is vaccinated against bacterial meningitis by Lisa Cervellera. (Associated Press)
