PERSON: Capt. Jack O. Bennett 

HEADLINE: Capt. Jack Bennett, 86, a Berlin Airlift Hero 

BYLINE:  By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Capt. Jack O. Bennett, a retired American pilot, died on Aug. 26 in Berlin, his adopted hometown, where he was celebrated as a hero of the Berlin Airlift of 1948-49. He was 86. 
 The Berlin government credited him with making the first flight, on June 23, 1948, of the effort that broke the 11-month Soviet siege of the divided city. Captain Bennett flew a Douglas DC-8 loaded with potatoes, the first of 2.3 million tons of food, fuel and other supplies delivered by the time the Soviet Union decided to back down 11 months later. 
 "Bennett, like so many of his fellow pilots, put his life on the line during the blockade to ensure the existence and freedom of Berliners in the face of the Soviet threat," a spokesman for the city, Albert Eckert, said. "Bennett embodies the change in the relationship between Germany and the United States that took place."
The crisis was one of the most perilous of the cold war. It erupted after the Western powers -- Britain, France and the United States -- decided to form a single economic unit of their German zones of occupation and to introduce the newly issued mark in their sectors of Berlin.
The Soviet Union declared the four-power administration of Berlin null and void and cutting all rail, road and water links through East Germany to the city.
No pilot flew the tricky route into Berlin-Tempelhof Airport more often than Captain Bennett. He logged two to three flights a day, for a total of 650 round trips.
"Raisin bombers," as the Berliners called them, landed around the clock at intervals of just under a minute, delivering 4,500 tons of food and goods a day and totaling 278,000 flights. But to Captain Bennett, the real heroes of that astonishing logistical achievement were not the pilots. "It was a chance to fly as often as we wanted," he said in an interview. "We were no heroes. Those were all the ones who operated the radar system and let us land safely."
Jack Bennett was born in Ebensburg, Pa., He started flying at 14. He graduated from Pennsylvania State University and studied aeronautical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He first went to Berlin in 1937 to continue his studies at the Technical University with a Rockefeller Foundation grant. 
After the war, he returned to Germany as a civilian pilot based in Frankfurt and flying the Berlin route for American Overseas Airlines and then for Pan American World Airways, until retiring in 1974.
Surviving is his wife, Marianne.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 22, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Sept. 4 about Capt. Jack O. Bennett, who piloted the first supply plane of the Berlin Airlift in June 1948, misidentified the craft. It was a Douglas DC-4; the DC-8 did not enter commercial service until the mid-1960's. This correction was delayed for research in military and commercial aviation archives to resolve conflicting information from experts and publications, some of which listed it as a DC-3; American Overseas Airlines and McDonnell Douglas are no longer in business.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-10

U.S. and Israel Walk Out Of U.N. Racism Conference
The United States and Israel left the United Nations conference on racism in Durban, South Africa. Their action was prompted by proposed conference language condemning "the racist practices of Zionism" and describing Israel's treatment of Palestinians as a "new kind of apartheid." Emergency meetings were convened to redraft the charged language in the hope of averting other walkouts. A spokesman for the European Union, which raised concerns about the language, said its diplomats would help in its redrafting. A1

From the moment the United States delegation arrived at the meeting, their marching orders were clear: engage actively in behind-the-scenes talks to moderate the conference's tone toward Israel, and do little else unless that effort succeeds. A8

The walkout by Israel, which had been attacked by a coalition of rights groups as "an apartheid regime" guilty of "ethnic cleansing and acts of genocide" against the Palestinians, thickened the pall over already troubled efforts to cobble together an Israeli-Palestinian cease-fire. Four bombs went off in various areas of Jerusalem. No one was seriously injured, but the blasts led to new clashes, leaving 2 Palestinian men dead and about 30 wounded. A8

U.S. Research on Germ Warfare
The United States has been engaged for several years in secret research on biological weapons that some officials believe tests the limits of the global treaty banning such weapons. Government officials said the research mimicked major steps a state or terrorist might take to create a biological arsenal and was intended to understand the threat better. A1

Mexico Leader Faces the Reality
President Vicente Fox of Mexico arrives in the United States today for a state visit. In an interview, he discussed his realization that he could not deliver on his promises as quickly as he wanted. A1

Mexico took over nearly half of the country's sugar mills in an effort to save a dying industry that had been subsidized for decades. Officials said they would expropriate 27 of Mexico's 60 privately operated and deeply indebted sugar mills, and then either shutter or sell them. A3

A Shakeup in South Korea
South Korea plunged into a political crisis today after all cabinet members and senior presidential aides resigned in the wake of a National Assembly vote for the dismissal of Lim Dong Won, South Korea's unification minister, who has been in charge of the government's "sunshine policy" with North Korea. South Korean opposition leaders have complained that the government is getting little in response for its aid and overtures to the North. (A3)

Macedonia Peace Moves Ahead
Parliament resumed debate about constitutional and political reforms that are crucial to the country's peace plan for ending an insurgency by ethnic Albanian rebels. A preliminary vote is expected today. A4

World Briefing A10

NATIONAL A12-17

The Right Plans Effort On Supreme Court Choice
A coalition of socially conservative groups begins a $2 million campaign this week to press President Bush and the Democratic-controlled Senate to fill the next Supreme Court vacancy with an opponent of abortion rights. The campaign comes amid the first signs of stress in the relationship between Mr. Bush and the social conservative movement over his decision to allow federal financing for some stem cell research. A1

Bush's Labor Gap
Interviews with dozens of union members at Detroit's Labor Day parade and at a Teamsters' picnic indicated that President Bush faced an uphill battle in his new campaign to win the hearts and minds of union members. They pointed to a long list of Bush positions that they oppose, including any privatizing of Social Security, the revocation of ergonomics rules, and his push for fast-track trade legislation and increased access for Mexican trucks to American roads. A16

President Bush, speaking to gatherings of union carpenters in Green Bay, Wis., and Teamsters in Detroit, expressed concern about the economy, which he described as "anemic at best" over the last year, and warned that there were still "some problems on the horizon." A16

Gore Noncommittal on 2004
Al Gore brushed aside questions on his political future at a campaign rally for the Democratic mayor of Minneapolis. But he repeatedly mentioned his narrow defeat to George W. Bush and asked the crowd what they thought of the country's direction under Mr. Bush's leadership. A15

Reno Hopes to Unseat a Bush
Janet Reno will announce today that she is entering the Florida governor's race, a longtime associate said with her permission. Ms. Reno is expected to be the favorite as she enters the Democratic primary campaign in a bid to challenge the Republican incumbent, Jeb Bush, next year. A15

2nd Fatal U.S. Shark Attack
A shark attacked a couple wading off North Carolina's Outer Banks, killing the man and leaving the woman in critical condition. The death came two days after a shark killed a 10-year-old boy in Virginia. A12

Older Drivers and Safety
A study by an insurance industry group found that drivers 70 to 74 years old were twice as likely to die in accidents as drivers 30 to 59. To help older drivers avoid and survive accidents, the report recommended bigger letters on road signs and seat belts designed to be easier on fragile shoulders and ribs. A17

The Navy Corrects the Record
New evidence has persuaded the Navy to rewrite the record of the sinking of the submarine chaser Eagle in 1945, within sight of the Maine coast, killing 49 sailors. Instead of a boiler explosion, the official cause will now be listed as a torpedo from a German submarine. The change means that those who died or were wounded will receive Purple Hearts. A15

Softening Economy Eases Hunt for Tables and Rooms
Restaurateurs in New York City, especially those whose restaurants are just below the top tier, are starting to worry about filling tables in an oversaturated market and a weakening economy. Diners who were willing to endure a three-month wait for a reservation a few months ago are now being courted with free meals, discounts and solicitous service. A1

HEADLINE: BRAAAP PADOONK (Shh) BONG BONG; 
No Wonder the City Never Sleeps, Says a Chorus of Noise Complainers

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
Most New Yorkers, especially those who live in Manhattan, probably engage, from time to time, in a conversation about noise. It might be a long-distance phone call, from someone back on the farm, or from one of those obscure cities that gets a high rating for livability in magazine surveys.
 "Hello?" the caller will scream, perplexed. "Where are you? The Gaza Strip?" 
 "No," the New Yorker will yell back, also perplexed. "I'm in my apartment. Why?" 
Oh, no reason. Just the background symphony of ice cream trucks, jackhammers, teenagers, sanitation vehicles, cars outfitted with trunk speakers but not mufflers, and the man who wishes, by way of boom box, to express his joyous presence on the corner. Only the six-week, 7 a.m. house party -- the landlord calls it renovation -- in the apartment next door, the rush-hour rumbling of the Metro-North train tracks past the kitchen window, the piteous bleating of MetroCards passing through turnstile scanners. And those are just the noises to which New Yorkers are accustomed.
Residential growth and boom-time construction have brought new noises to the city. Between Jan. 1 and July 31, the mayor's quality-of-life phone line, one of several numbers people can call to complain about noise, received 71,295 complaints, with more than 80 percent of them related to noise. (The second most frequent complaint? Blocked driveways.) 
For many community boards, noise is a top priority, and the Manhattan borough president's office has convened a Construction Noise Task Force and a Helicopter Noise Coalition. Experts say that noise can harm people's health, increase their stress levels and compromise children's ability to learn. But as noise complaints are on the rise, there is little evidence that enforcement is keeping pace. 
In 1997, the City Council increased penalties for violations of the noise code, but made it no easier to enforce regulations that require a police officer, for example, to witness a car alarm going off for more than three minutes before ticketing the vehicle. According to the mayor's management report, 4,866 noise summonses were issued by the police in the fiscal year 2000, and 2,142 noise complaints were issued in the first four months of the fiscal year 2001, an increase. 
But at the Department of Environmental Protection, which is responsible largely for stationary noise problems like nightclubs and sidewalk cafes, violations dropped from 1,650 in the fiscal year 2000 to 1,200 in the fiscal year ending in June 2001, even as complaints increased.
Geoffrey Ryan, a spokesman for the department, cautioned that many people might complain about a single problem, and that the department encourages nonlegal resolution of certain kinds of complaints. He said the number of inspectors, 39, had remained the same, though Saturday night hours had been added. The department is also reviewing the city's 30-year-old noise code and will recommend ways to update it, he said.
But a more comprehensive approach is needed, said Arline L. Bronzaft, a noise expert who has served on the city's Council on the Environment for three mayoral administrations.
People in Queens who live in the mind-numbing roar of increasingly trafficked flight paths must appeal to the Federal Aviation Administration. The permits that let repairs to the city's water mains thunder all night in Lower Manhattan, a neighborhood that has become more residential, are granted by the city's Department of Transportation. Helicopter noise is supposed to be reported to a phone line at the Economic Development Council, but the line's voice mail seems always to be full.
"There should be a coordinating office," Dr. Bronzaft said. "People have talked about a noise czar."
In every community, the sources of noise are different. North Staten Island has manufacturing zones; northwest Brooklyn has cafes spilling out onto every sidewalk and endless new construction. 
According to a breakdown provided by the Department of Environmental Protection, the Upper West Side and the Upper East Side lead the city in noise complaints. On the West Side, said Penny Ryan, the district manager for Community Board 7, an influx of big stores has made commercial air-conditioning units the top complaint (they are also the top noise complaint to the environmental department over all). The department, Ms. Ryan said, will send out an inspector to measure the sound level, but because a business owner has 30 days to fix the problem, noise can drone on and on. 
If stationary noise is difficult to silence, transient noise like horn honking can be impossible, she said. "A block can request signs, but once they're up, you have to have a police officer witness the horn honking, write a ticket and go to court." The Police Department could provide no statistics on summonses for car alarms, motorcycles lacking mufflers, or honking.
Several community leaders complained that the police cannot issue noise violations because many precincts are not equipped with, or not trained to use, a noise meter.
Downtown, one precinct has begun a program to train officers in noise metering, according to Alan J. Gerson, a member of Community Board 2 and a City Council candidate, and another is training officers to recognize loud motorcycles even when they are parked. Thomas Antenen, the chief spokesman for the department, said that he could not verify the special programs, but that each borough had noise meters that precincts can request.
Kenneth M. Moltner, the chairman of Community Board 8 on the Upper East Side, says the main noise problem is simply lack of civility. "We're one of the fastest cities to honk when the light changes to green," he said.
But one person's sound is another person's noise. Business owners that try to cooperate, like D.B.A., a bar on First Avenue in the East Village, face groans from their customers when the bar staff closes the back patio at 10 p.m. on a Saturday night. Club owners complain that the night life that has made the city famous is near extinction.
And some noise complaints result from neighborhoods in flux.
Betty Braton, the chairwoman of Community Board 10 in Queens, which includes Howard Beach, South Ozone Park and South Jamaica, said that complaints of yard parties were on the rise, partly because the Indo-Caribbean population in the district has a tradition of holding weddings outdoors. "There are cultural differences which will go away in time," she said.
Some residents cautioned that a low number of complaints does not necessarily translate to a quiet neighborhood, saying they were simply used to it. 
In fact, a recent stroll through Harlem and East Harlem, the Manhattan neighborhoods that seem, measured by complaints, to be the quietest, seemed to reveal just as many noisy cars, radios, train whistles and block parties as anyplace else.
"We have an equal number of problems," said David Givens, the longtime chairman of Community Board 11, adding that the board had consistently asked for noise meters for the local precincts without success. "The only reason why the number of complaints may not be as high is that many of the people in our community don't trust the system. And they don't believe that they are going to get results."
Perhaps surprisingly, not all people find incessant noise something to scream about. Shedene Lindsay, 21, and Dorlin Reyes, 31, are awakened each morning at 7 a.m. by construction on their block of 124th Street in Harlem, where buzzing saws herald the revival of yet another brownstone. But they have yet to complain. "It's noise for a good cause," Ms. Lindsay said. 
Sometimes, she added, the Studio Museum in Harlem, which has also been revivified by a new curator, Thelma Golden, holds parties, pumping beats out of the back of their building across the street. "But," Ms. Lindsay said, "we just jam to the music right along."

HEADLINE: In Queens, a Spirited Race For Its Borough Presidency 

BYLINE:  By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
Carol A. Gresser, a candidate for Queens borough president, broke her foot recently on the campaign trail. During four hours in the emergency room, she told anyone who would listen that she was running for office -- and why.
 In the race for a spot that is up for grabs at a time when Queens is awash in political contests, every moment counts. As primary and general elections portend a seismic political overhaul in the borough, where virtually every city-level politician is leaving office because of term limits, the campaign for borough president at times seems lost in the shuffle. 
 The contest among three Democrats -- Ms. Gresser, a former Board of Education president, and two longtime City Council members, Helen M. Marshall of western Queens and Sheldon S. Leffler of eastern Queens -- has been neither feisty nor fraught with mud-slinging.
The Republican candidate, City Councilman Alfonso C. Stabile, who represents the neighborhoods of Ozone Park and Howard Beach, is running unopposed in the Sept. 11 primary, but most are expecting the victor of the Democratic primary to take the November election.
Among the three Democrats, Ms. Marshall and Ms. Gresser have the best financing and the most substantial endorsements in a race that for the first time in decades has been a real contest. Claire Shulman, who cannot run again because of term limits, has held the seat since 1986, when she was elected with virtually no competition. Ms. Shulman succeeded Donald R. Manes, who committed suicide in 1986 amid a municipal corruption scandal.
Ms. Marshall, 71, a former teacher, is the handpicked candidate of the Queens County Democratic Organization, and she has also won the backing of Ms. Shulman. The endorsements could decide the election, and Ms. Marshall would be the first African-American elected to the borough presidency, although she has not focused on her ethnicity, campaiging heavily instead -- like her opponents -- on the theme of improving the borough's public school system.
For her part, Ms. Gresser, 64, has picked up her share of endorsements, including ones from the editorial board of The New York Times and several local labor guilds, including law enforcement unions. She is perhaps the highest-profile candidate of the three.
Mr. Leffler, who turns 59 this week, is a Harvard-educated lawyer elected to the City Council in 1978 from the 23rd District, which covers Little Neck, Douglaston, Bayside, Bellerose, Floral Park, Queens Village and Hollis. He is considered something of a maverick on the Council. The prime sponsor of 42 laws enacted since he was elected, including one that mandates recycling, Mr. Leffler portrays himself as the candidate best qualified to maximize the power of the presidency, which is more of a bully pulpit than a platform for policy making.
"I've gotten a lot done in this city," said Mr. Leffler, who has focused in his Council tenure on environmental and public safety issues and said he has kept a diary of all the laws he has initiated and sponsored.
Ms. Gresser and Ms. Marshall have both portrayed themselves as being adept at advocacy. They also point to what they say would be their virtuosity at networking and uniting disparate groups in a borough teeming with new immigrants.
Ms. Gresser, who lives in Douglaston, drew citywide attention when, as president of the Board of Education, she clashed with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over chancellor nominations and feuded with him bitterly when the mayor drove out the chancellor, Ramon C. Cortines. She was on the board for eight years.
Ms. Gresser said that her willingness to stand up to the mayor demonstrated independence but that she expected as borough president -- an office that comes with the authority to make one appointment to the Board of Education -- to work smoothly with any of the mayoral candidates. "There is that mayor," she said, "and there is the mayor."
"I can be very independent," Ms. Gresser added. "But I also know you have to make some concessions in order to get anything done."
While the Democratic candidates agree on major priorities -- reducing school overcrowding, expanding the scarce supply of low- and moderately priced housing, creating better programs for the borough's large elderly population and accelerating economic development -- both Ms. Gresser and Ms. Marshall suggested that personality and gusto would be a borough president's best tools.
"This job is what you make it," Ms. Marshall said during a break from a recent frenzied day of campaigning. "I'm known to be a fighter. I also know how to use power."
Before joining the Council 10 years ago, Ms. Marshall, who represents the 21st District, covering Corona, Elmhurst, East Elmhurst and Jackson Heights, served for nine years in the State Assembly.
During an interview in her campaign headquarters in Forest Hills, Ms. Gresser said she believed her wider name recognition would offset any advantage Ms. Marshall might have secured from the endorsements of Ms. Shulman and the Democratic organization.
Ms. Gresser and Ms. Marshall have roughly the same amount of campaign financing, and both are far better financed than Mr. Leffler, according to the latest filings with the Campaign Finance Board.
Ms. Marshall's campaign said she raised $82,000 in the last reporting period, bringing her fund-raising total to $343,731. Her campaign says that $40,000 in recent contributions is eligible for matching money, which would bring her matching fund total to $604,316. Ms. Gresser had raised $414,251 and received $415,808 in matching funds. Mr. Leffler had raised $164,424 and received matching amounts of $296,084.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Zenith Media Cuts Ad Spending Forecast

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
Zenith Media has again lowered its estimate for advertising spending in the world's largest markets, reflecting the slowdown in economies around the world.
 Zenith predicted that ad spending in the seven biggest markets, which account for 75 percent of total global spending, would total $235.7 billion in 2001, down 2.6 percent from the record level of 2000. 
 As recently as July, Zenith predicted that ad spending this year would increase 1.5 percent from 2000, a figure that had been reduced as the American economy slowed.
In the United States, ad spending is to fall 4 percent this year, Zenith predicted, joining Britain, Germany and Spain in suffering declines.
Only France, Italy and Japan among the largest markets will show growth in 2001, according to the Zenith forecast. Zenith is 50 percent owned by the Cordiant Communications Group and 50 percent owned by the Publicis Groupe.

HEADLINE: Vying to Help Businesses at Heart of Caribbean Enclave 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
On Church Avenue in Brooklyn, amid the bustle of stores selling everything from videos and cellular phones to meat patties and jerk chicken, there are clear signs of a lively political campaign. Huge posters hang in stores, slogan-covered poster boards ride atop cars roaming the streets, and candidates work frenetically at subway stations.
 The 40th Council District is a largely Caribbean enclave of Flatbush and East Flatbush, an area that 10 years ago elected the first Jamaican-born woman to serve in the City Council, Una S. T. Clarke. Because of the city's term limit laws, Ms. Clarke is ineligible to run for re-election this year. Six candidates hope to succeed her, including Ms. Clarke's daughter. 
 The race has been a relatively cordial one. But the presence on the ballot of Ms. Clarke's daughter, Yvette D. Clarke, who is director of business development at the Bronx Overall Development Corporation and who worked previously for several elected officials, has been as much an issue as the fortunes of the businesses along the busy strip of Church Avenue.
Among the candidates are Alithia Alleyne, 33, who once worked for Councilwoman Clarke and who left her job as an administrator at the Brooklyn Museum of Art to run; Jean D. Vernet, 46, a longtime housing advocate who runs the Legal Education and Assistance Program for the National Coalition for Haitian Rights; Wellington Sharpe, 56, who operates a day care business and has been involved in a number of community organizations; Frances G. Purcell, 42, an accountant and real estate broker; and Edward A. Roberts, who is a lawyer and former administrator with the Bedford-Stuyvesant Community Legal Service Corporation. Another candidate, Carl W. Thomas, a lawyer, died of a heart attack a month ago.
The candidates have given the most attention to the issue of economic development. They suggest that the small businesses along the thoroughfares need tax relief and technical advice to preserve the district's economic backbone.
"What we need is a tax abatement program for businesses that have operated less than five years," Ms. Purcell said. Mr. Vernet has called for the creation of "one-stop centers for entrepreneurial support, to help people to have access to information on contracts and technical support." Those centers, he said, would be operated by nonprofit agencies.
Ms. Alleyne said that there was a strong need for the next Council member to meet with bank officials to help businesses find more access to capital. "Many of the businesses in this area need that kind of support and need technical help," she said. "That is crucial for this district because so many of the businesses are owned by local people. And that kind of ownership is something we want to encourage."
The candidates have made proposals in other areas as well. Mr. Roberts, for example, has insisted on the need to reinstate free tuition in the City University system. "We just need to have the political will to do it," he said. "It's what I would fight for on the Council."
Mr. Sharpe proposes dealing with the issue of overcrowded schools by constructing new classroom space on top of existing school buildings. "That would help address the need for smaller class size without a large cost," he said.
Ms. Clarke has proposed that the city play a greater role in providing health care insurance to the city's least affluent residents, a particular problem in this district, which includes Kings County Hospital Center. And she wants the city to do more to promote the annual West Indian Parade along Eastern Parkway as a tourist attraction to draw visitors to the area.
Immigration has also been an issue; each candidate has roots in the Caribbean. Mr. Vernet was born in Haiti, and Mr. Sharpe was born in Jamaica. Mr. Roberts is from Trinidad, Ms. Purcell is from Grenada, and Ms. Alleyne's roots are in Barbados and Panama. 
Each of them has called for the city to provide greater assistance to immigrants.
They only threat to the cordial atmosphere of the contest has been the criticism of Ms. Clarke by many candidates, who say she is running on her name and that she has fewer credentials than her rivals. "No one in this district even knows her," Mr. Roberts said. "To have worked for some public officials is not a symbol of accomplishment in terms of serving the community."
Ms. Clarke said she is proud of her family and of the commitment to public service that she said she has inherited. Her campaign posters read, "Following in a family tradition of service to the community."
Mr. Vernet has taken the lead in fund-raising, raising nearly $49,000 and receiving $60,000 in city matching money. Mr. Roberts has raised nearly $17,000 and has received another $37,780 in public campaign matching money.
Ms. Clarke has raised nearly $49,000 but has received no matching money. Similarly, the other candidates have received no matching money. Ms. Purcell has raised $44,000, Mr. Sharpe has raised $18,000, Mr. Roberts has raised nearly $17,000 and Ms. Alleyne raised $13,500.
Ms. Clarke has been endorsed by a number of officials, including United States Representative Edolphus Towns. Mr. Vernet has been endorsed by a a number of unions, including 1199, the health care workers union, as well as by former Mayor David N. Dinkins and United States Representative Major R. Owens. 
Ms. Alleyne has been endorsed by State Senator Marty Markowitz, who is a candidate for Brooklyn borough president.

HEADLINE: Waiter, Hold the Foie Gras: Slump Hits New York Dining 

BYLINE:  By MARIAN BURROS 

 BODY:
For months, restaurants in New York City seemed impervious to the bleak economic news, but recently their phenomenal double-digit growth in sales has come to a screeching halt.
 The unluckiest have seen business drop as much as 30 percent, and the city's top restaurants, the places whose stature makes them the least vulnerable to a cooling economy, are starting to feel the chill. Even Jean Georges and its cafe Nougatine are down, according to their owner, Jean-Georges Vongerichten. 
 Gone are the $10,000 bottles of Bordeaux at Le Bernardin, the $4,000 dinners out of the wood-fired oven at Beacon. Now it's more modest dining, three courses of comfort food for $20 at the Metropolitan Hotel, and half-price wine with the pan-Latin fare at Chicama. 
On the brink of the fall season, traditionally the time when lavish new places open and the luxury factor is pumped up on menus all over town, restaurateurs are instead worrying about filling tables in an oversaturated market. There are no splashy openings on the calendar, no new Ducasse on the horizon.
Even established restaurateurs are setting their sights lower. Danny Meyer, an owner of Eleven Madison Park and Union Square Cafe, is opening a barbecue restaurant. Drew Nieporent, an owner of Nobu and Tribeca Grill, is just sitting it out. "We probably opened two restaurants a year for the last two years," he said. "This year, I'm not opening any new stores."
It's a sea change in a food-obsessed city. Diners who were willing to endure a three-month wait for a reservation just months ago are now being courted with free meals, discounts and solicitous service. 
For almost a year, sales in restaurants across the country have been steadily declining. But New York, the country's premier restaurant city, seemed to buck the trend. No more. 
Most restaurateurs are not panicking, and dining rooms appear to be bustling all over town. But a growing number of owners -- particularly of restaurants below the top tier -- are concerned enough to change the way they do business. They are revamping menus, lowering prices, offering special prix fixe meals, even instituting frequent-diner programs. Harder times for restaurants have meant, in many cases, better times for the clientele.
"At the very best restaurants it's easier to get in," said Tim Zagat, who owns the Zagat restaurant guide with his wife, Nina. "They are politer at places like Nobu. Last year they didn't even pick up the phone. Those restaurants are a lot more accessible, but once you get there they are still full."
Signs of a slowdown are everywhere. William Troy, the owner of Cascade Linen in Brooklyn, keeps a Dow Jones of napkin rentals that includes 18 of the restaurants his company services. His napkin index has seen a drop of 5.6 percent since the beginning of the year, mostly in the last three months. At DeBragga & Spitler, suppliers of top-quality meats, Marc Sarrazin, the owner, says business is down 7 to 8 percent.
Joseph Bastianich, an owner of two respected restaurants, Babbo and Esca, said wine distributors were calling him almost daily, trying to sell him premium wines that they rationed last year. At Dairyland, which sells specialty foods to 3,000 restaurants in New York, the owner, Christopher Pappas, said restaurants that usually pay weekly are taking 30 days to pay; monthly clients are taking 50 or 80 days and longer. 
Steve Hanson, who owns midpriced restaurants including Ruby Foo's and Blue Water Grill, said he was getting calls from people who wanted him to buy their restaurants. "I tell them that I buy only deeply discounted restaurants," he said, "and they may want to call me back in a couple of months."
The restaurant boom of the last 10 years appears to have produced a restaurant glut. Clark Wolf, a restaurant consultant, said New York was "overbuilt and overhyped," and competition has become fierce.
"Whatever has happened in New York City has been exacerbated by the overabundance of restaurants," said Alan Stillman, chairman of the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, which includes Manhattan Ocean Club and Park Avenue Cafe. Business is off 10 percent, Mr. Stillman said: "We see it as horrible."
Mr. Nieporent estimates that since 1995, 100,000 new restaurant seats for moderate to fine dining have become available in the city. "There are going to be a lot of closings," he said. "We hit a saturation point. We are not ready to start discounting, but we are watching very carefully."
Adam D. Tihany, who designed some of the city's best-known restaurants, including Le Cirque 2000 and Jean Georges, says his New York business has nearly come to a halt. "A lot of projects started to get canceled about one and a half years ago," he said. "The only projects we have in New York are longer term. Now most of our projects are abroad."
What is happening in New York reflects a national trend. The NPD Group, a market researcher, reports that the average American will eat out less this year than last, the first decline in 10 years.
Nationally, restaurant sales continue to rise, but at a slim 2.4 percent over the 12 months that ended on July 31, compared with 4.4 percent for the 12 months that ended on Jan. 31, according to Technomic Inc., a food consulting group. Part of that increase in dollar volume can be attributed to price increases.
An August survey of 450 restaurants by the National Restaurant Association reported that at 20 percent of them, customers are taking home more doggie bags than they did two years ago.
Scott W. Keller of DealAnalytics.com, a company that provides online research on mergers and acquisitions, said that restaurant acquisitions are "extremely hard" because of the slowdown in growth and a significant decline in profitability.
So far, the restaurants that seem most vulnerable are those in hotels, because of low occupancy rates, and those that are almost as expensive as the top restaurants. "Expensive second-tier Midtown places, caught in the tightening of corporate budgets, are getting hurt," Mr. Zagat said. Small neighborhood places are doing well because they cost about as much as a meal eaten at home.
As businesses tighten their belts, there has also been a drop in the number of bookings for private dining rooms. At Remi, Mr. Tihany said, parties have been trimmed back or canceled. Mr. Sarrazin of DeBragga & Spitler said, "It's chicken cutlet and salmon instead of steak."
But at every level, restaurateurs say that it would have been difficult to match, much less better, last year's records, even if the economy had not faltered.
Wine is the first thing diners are spending less on. At Le Bernardin, the tables are still full, but sales of expensive wines have slowed to a trickle. Business is off about 5 percent at Jean Georges and Nougatine because diners are buying cheaper bottles and skipping the final cordial, Mr. Vongerichten said. The fringe hours before 6:30 and after 10 are not filling up the way they did last year, and the early part of the week is quiet. On Sundays, Mondays and Tuesdays, Douglas Rodriguez at Chicama plans to offer a 50 percent discount on wines. Mr. Rodriguez said his business was down 30 percent from last year.
At Patria, Andrew DiCataldo said that upscale Latin restaurant has repositioned itself to be "more approachable" and has instituted an all-day $10 bar menu. The Tribeca Grand Hotel is adding a finger food menu that offers smaller portions at lower prices. And there's that $20 dinner at the Metropolitan Hotel. 
Other restaurateurs are concentrating on service. "When you are extremely busy, all you can do is manage the reservation book," said Rocco DiSpirito, chef and owner of Union Pacific. "When it isn't a 24-hour obsession, restaurateurs become sensitized. We've been focusing on the guest experience for six months now."
After a slow six months, Waldy Malouf at Beacon mailed letters to his regular customers, asking them to come back as guests of the restaurant and to bring a guest. "The mantra to the wait staff is to make the person want to come back," he said, "to eliminate any sort of snobby New York feeling on the phone and to be much more accommodating at the front door."
Rick Moonen, the owner and chef at Oceana, has chosen the sweat equity method for reducing costs, working more himself. He has also cut back on shifts so that his employees now have two days off at a time instead of one.
What fall holds depends on whether the prognosticator is an optimist or a pessimist. Most are like Mr. Hanson. "I think it's going to get really bad," he said. "Consumers are going into a panic, layoffs are just starting. People are in denial. It will start to hit right after September."
Not everyone is predicting the worst. The few upscale Wall Street restaurants, like Bayard's and Vine, say they are thriving because there is so little competition. David Rockwell, who designed Nobu and Monkey Bar, said none of his New York projects have been canceled. Mr. Vongerichten is going ahead with his plans to open his Spice Market restaurant in Lower Manhattan. "I haven't put anything on the back burner," he said.
And many more restaurateurs are hoping that by the holidays, diners will be as eager as ever.
"What was going on last year was ridiculous," Mr. Troy said. "Some restaurants that were doing O.K. shouldn't have been in business at all. So we are getting back to reality."

HEADLINE: THE RACISM WALKOUT: THE OVERVIEW; 
U.S. AND ISRAELIS QUIT RACISM TALKS OVER DENUNCIATION

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: DURBAN, South Africa, Sept. 3 

 BODY:
The United States and Israel walked out of the United Nations meeting on racism here tonight, denouncing a condemnation of Israel in a proposed conference declaration and lamenting that a meeting intended to celebrate tolerance and diversity had degenerated into a gathering riven by hate.
 South Africa rushed tonight to convene emergency meetings to redraft the declaration and program of action in the hope of averting other walkouts, and a spokesman for the European Union delegation, which also raised concerns, said its diplomats would take part in the efforts to rewrite the draft documents. 
 In announcing his decision in Washington, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said, "I have taken this decision with regret because of the importance of the international fight against racism and the contribution that the conference could have made to it." 
"But following discussions today by our team in Durban and others who are working for a successful conference, I am convinced that will not be possible," he said. 
Secretary Powell said negotiators here had failed to persuade Arab delegates to remove criticism of Israel from proposed conference documents that assail "the racist practices of Zionism" and describe Israel's treatment of Palestinians as a "new kind of apartheid." 
Questions about whether Israel should be condemned for its treatment of Palestinians and whether the West should pay reparations for slavery and colonialism have roiled conference preparations for months. Washington has said repeatedly that it would not consider language that criticized Israel or legitimized reparations for descendants of slaves. 
The fact that the United States did not send Secretary Powell to the conference, which opened on Friday, was a sore point with many of the countries represented here. The United States and Israel both sent mid-level delegations.
The decision to withdraw even those delegations dashed the hopes of thousands who have brought their fight against intolerance to a country chosen by conference organizers for its remarkable story of racial reconciliation.
Olivier Alsteens, spokesman for the European Union delegation, said it had no immediate plans to withdraw, "But if at one moment, we feel there is no other opportunity, then we will leave all together."
The American and Israeli pullout was warmly applauded by Jewish groups but greeted with great regret by South Africa and other developing countries and with anger by black Americans and their supporters. It seemed likely only to heighten the frustration and divisions between the increasingly polarized groups. 
Tonight, black Americans and their allies took to the streets here, chanting "Shame, shame U.S.A." The protesters said they were deeply disappointed that the United States could not find a way to compromise and sign an international declaration that is expected to condemn slavery and racial discrimination.
The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who has been urging the Arab League to back away from the charged language, and members of the Black Congressional Caucus also criticized the Bush administration's decision.
Representative Donna M. C. Christensen, a Democrat who is the delegate to Congress from the Virgin Islands, said, "It leaves African-Americans with no recognition of all the suffering we have had and all of the suffering we continue to have."
Representative Tom Lantos, Democrat of California and a delegation member, said he was sorry that the United States was pulling out. But he said the team, headed by E. Michael Southwick, a deputy assistant secretary of state, had no choice because the Palestinians and their supporters refused to compromise. 
The American and Israeli decision came after officials from the United States and Norway had huddled for hours in closed-door meetings with Palestinian and other Arab officials, trying to broker a deal.
Norwegian diplomats proposed new language that mentioned the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, but was fair to both sides, according to American officials. But the effort failed, and some meetings were so heated that participants ended up shouting.
"It was an ugly meeting," Mr. Lantos said in an interview. "This was not a question of persuading people. This was a question of an iron wall we were up against, and there was no give."
Arab officials blamed the Bush administration for the failure of the talks. Farouk Kaddoumi, a senior member of the Palestine Liberation Organization, accused the United States of using the dispute as a pretext to avoid serious discussion of slavery and reparations for the descendants of African slaves.
The Egyptian foreign minister, Ahmed Maher, said the Norwegian compromise document trivialized Palestinian suffering.
"The only mention of Israel is that the Palestinians and Israelis should go back to the peace process," Mr. Maher said in an interview. "That is not enough. 
"We are talking about a war waged using the most sophisticated weapons on a civilian population," Mr. Maher said. "This is a government that has taken an official decision to assassinate people. You want this conference, which deals with discrimination, not to mention these things? That is precisely what must be raised."
Polarization has also been evident in the interactions of delegates from civic groups meeting here in the hope of influencing the final declaration on racism, which is to be completed on Friday.
Last week, some Arab groups here distributed offensive literature that included posters of Jews with big noses and bloody fangs. Members of Palestinian and Jewish groups shouted at each other during competing rallies. And on Saturday, about 25 Jews walked out of a meeting of civic groups when someone suggested removing references to anti-Semitism. 
After the Jewish groups walked out, the coalition of civic groups approved a report that accused Israel of "racist crimes against humanity, including ethnic cleansing and acts of genocide" in its treatment of Palestinians. The report is not binding, and it is unlikely the language would be adopted.
"The U.S. did not reject a discussion about racism, they rejected a conference that was tainted by racism," said Stacy Burdett, an assistant director at the Anti-Defamation League, who is attending the conference. "This wasn't a discussion about legitimate issues. It was a hijacking that vilified and demonized Jews."
Mordechai Yedid, the head of the Israeli delegation, said in an interview, "Our position has always been to agree to generic language, to the suffering of people, to war, to occupations." 
"This time because the conference was so important to us and to our history as a people who suffered from anti-Semitism and the Holocaust, we have gone beyond, to specific language," he said.
Several human rights groups argued tonight that the United States should have stayed to improve the language about Israel and to show solidarity with the many suffering people in the world.
"We're very troubled by the whole Zionism as racism formulation as well, but we think our responsibility is to stay and have the conversation," said Karen K. Narasaki, president of the National Asian Pacific American Legal Consortium. "You certainly don't build your moral standing in the world by running away."
And the South African government warned that by leaving, the United States might give the impression that it was ducking tough issues, like race relations within its own borders. 
"It will be unfortunate if a perception were to develop that the U.S.A.'s withdrawal from the conference is merely a red herring demonstrating an unwillingness to confront the real issues posed by racism in the U.S.A. and globally," the South African government said in a statement.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing New Jersey's Debt Grows 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 New Jersey's mounting debt is threatening the state's long-term financial strength and its ability to pay for basic services, especially in an economic downturn, according to a report. A recession would raise serious doubts about New Jersey's ability to maintain the current levels of aid to municipalities and schools, provide property tax relief and make grants to communities and social, medical and other programs, according to the report, issued by the New Jersey Policy Perspective, a nonprofit and nonpartisan research group. 
The state's long-term debt climbed to $15.7 billion last year, from $4 billion in 1990, and the state expects to borrow at least $9 billion more over the next five years. By 2010, the state will have to pay at least $2.8 billion in debt repayments, compared with the current $1.35 billion. About 6.2 percent of the state's budget last year went to pay debt-service costs, according to James Poole, the state's finance director. But merely looking at the debt misses the accomplishments that have been achieved with it, he said.

HEADLINE: Check My Tires? Now the Fun Begins 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The only thing in life that is free is air, unless you need to buy some to inflate your tires at a growing number of gas stations in the United States. Many charge 50 cents. 
 An Aug. 30 National Briefing item reports that a national study found that a third of all light trucks and a quarter of cars have at least one substantially underinflated tire. The solution? It recommends that tire pressure be checked once a month. 
 That's where the real problems begin. I have one car, five tires and zero confidence that I'm ever riding on tires that have the correct pressure. My owner's manual gives one set of numbers, yet the plate inside the driver's side door states another. I have two tire pressure gauges, which always conflict with each other as well as with those at service stations.
All the fuss about proper inflation adds up to a lot of hot air and misspent change if more is not done by the car, tire and service industries not only to educate the public, but also to provide the proper information and technology to solve the problem.

TOM GOODMAN
New York, Aug. 31, 2001

HEADLINE: In His Own Words 

 BODY:
GEORGE W. BUSH
From remarks yesterday at a Teamsters barbecue in Detroit:
 "Now let me tell you I'm a little concerned. I'm proud of our workers; I'm concerned about the fact that our economy is just bumping along. This is a Labor Day where we can't celebrate a booming economy. For the last 12 months, let me repeat, for the last 12 months the economy has been way too slow. And people are hurting. And people are suffering. And there's families who are wondering about how they're going to feed their kids. And I understand that, and we've got help in Washington. 
 But the best thing we can do is ask the question: How do we make sure our economy grows?
And I came up with this answer: Our economy can grow best when we give people their own money back, when we give the hard-working Americans their own money back in the form of rebates so that you spend it. And that's what's going to help this economy rebound. The federal government must keep a lid on spending and remember that when the American consumer spends it is the best way to kick-start a soft economy. The biggest threat to economic vitality and economic growth is if Congress overspends."

HEADLINE: Great Expectations Of Mexico's Leader Sapped by Reality 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON and TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 3 

 BODY:
President Vicente Fox once said his path to power was "full of rocks, predators, leeches, scorpions and snakes." The road has not improved much since he won election last year. He may have made it harder by paving it with good intentions.
 His promises are a national wish list for transforming Mexico: a rapid end to conflict in Chiapas; new trade alliances with Central America to help lift this nation's south out of poverty; new jobs to keep young men from migrating to the United States; a truthful accounting of hideous crimes in Mexico's past; better salaries, training and equipment for teachers and the police; an end to government corruption. 
 With a salesman's hype, he raised expectations that he could offer same-day delivery for those hopes. 
The gaps between Mr. Fox's rhetoric and reality allow his critics to say that he acts as if he were the chairman of Mexico Inc., issuing policies and promises like business plans and projections. But Mr. Fox has realized -- slowly, say allies and enemies alike -- that he cannot govern Mexico the way he once ran Coca-Cola's operations here.
"No one can make decisions on his own," Mr. Fox said in an interview tonight with The New York Times. "And this obliges us to put a heavy emphasis on politicking in our work so that we can achieve consensus. That is an important change."
Mr. Fox proposed to build political alliances with Congress and reform Mexico's archaic tax code. The independent-minded Congress, controlled by his opponents, rejected the plan. He vowed to retool the inefficient state-run energy company. The plan remains on the drawing board. He promised to distribute a million micro-loans to support homespun businesses. Some 3,070 people have received them so far, according to the program's administrators.
He once thought that economic growth would finance his social programs, and that a newly energized federal government, fueled by his popularity, would turn his words to deeds. But countervailing political and economic forces have hit Mr. Fox's presidency like a cyclone. Mr. Fox pledged 7 percent economic growth and the creation of more than a million new jobs this year, but more than 300,000 have been lost since he took office on Dec. 1. 
The recession that gripped Mexico this summer was "a surprise," Mr. Fox said in the interview. "That has forced us to change strategy and to look for ways to stop the job losses, to look for new ways to begin growing." He said he knew that "Mexicans want to see more concrete progress; they want to see more money in their pockets."
But for now the economic decline in the United States has ended growth in Mexico, which sells roughly 85 percent of its exports to the United States. 
Luis Cruz was a bookkeeper with a business degree at a Mexico City electronics company when Mr. Fox took office. But he lost his job when the economy faltered this spring. Now he wonders aloud when and if "the president will ever accomplish anything concrete."
"Everything has changed," he said, "and nothing has changed."
Mr. Fox stood before Congress on Saturday night a visibly changed man from the dream-driven politician he was nine months ago, when he donned the ceremonial sash to become the first president of Mexico elected from the political opposition. As he gave his first state of the nation address, his voice was drained of the relentless optimism that fires most of his public discourse.
As his popularity ratings slowly descend from the clouds, so have the promises of his presidency. In flat, direct language, he acknowledged that his biggest pledges to Mexico -- promises that propelled his stunning rise to power -- have been deferred.
"Many results have not come as quickly or as fully as we needed," he told Congress. "There are obstacles, and there will continue to be obstacles. But rest assured, I will keep my promises to you." 
On one front -- in the United States, where Mr. Fox arrives late Tuesday night for a formal state visit -- he has made strides in the thorniest fields, like migration and international law enforcement. 
He may come away with only "partial agreements" on migration policy, he said, but he hopes to win a deeper trust from the United States government, based on his achievements in fighting cocaine cartels and smugglers of immigrants, and greater understanding about the key roles Mexico and Mexican immigrants play the American economy.
But foreign policy or popularity abroad will not make Mexico the nation that Mr. Fox envisions, warned a prominent political expert, Lorenzo Meyer. 
"No head of state can survive on his image abroad," Mr. Meyer said. "Fox is going to have to learn to live on his relationship with his own society and on the support that he generates at home."
Mr. Fox changed Mexico's history forever when he defeated the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which had governed Mexico since 1929. That victory shattered the sense of political apathy and cynicism that millions felt under the once-ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, a political machine that hoarded power, jobs and money. From that ground-shaking transition has sprung a more open government, an increasingly vigilant press corps, a more politically active society.
The question is how much Mr. Fox can change Mexico's future. He will succeed, he said in the interview, if he stays "close to the Mexican people, to have their support in order to govern well, and in order to have something that exists only in participatory democracies -- democratic governance, rather than an authoritarian regime."
But unlike presidents of the old regime, Mr. Fox has no political machine. He has been slow to embrace his own National Action Party, whose leaders are sometimes suspicious of him. His cabinet -- business leaders, academics and politicians of varying ideologies -- often resembles a debating society. The bureaucracy is filled with old-regime officials whose habits die hard.
And if the president cannot begin keeping his biggest pledges, the old apathy and cynicism might return, political experts say. 
"People wanted things to happen; they expected change," said Ricardo de la Pena, a Mexico City pollster. "They are beginning to question the president's failure to live up to their expectations. The popularity bonus he got after he was elected has been squandered."
Enrique Krauze, a leading Mexican historian, prefers to see Mr. Fox's glass as half full.
"It is difficult to have results after inheriting a regime that was in power for so many years," Mr. Krauze said. "The rules of politics have just begun to change, and it is more difficult to build consensus."
"We have to know how to be patient," he said. "Why? Because Mexico has already made significant political advances."
In public, Mr. Fox remains upbeat. Two Sundays ago, he bounded out of church, strode up to reporters and starting spinning his version of reality, saying he was fulfilling three big promises to the poor. 
"Micro-loans have begun," he said. "Starting tomorrow, they will be arriving to millions of Mexican men and women." The program, providing credits of up to $3,000 for the smallest businesses, is part of Mr. Fox's promise to help lift people up from poverty, a pledge many judge to be his most solemn vow. 
"Scholarships and financing for students have already begun, and are being received by all citizens and young people who want to move forward with their studies," the president went on. "Special programs to address the needs of the unemployed have already begun operating."
The president's accomplishments actually appear more modest.
Officials at the agencies that administer those programs said that 3,070 people, not "millions," had received micro-credits; that 18 percent of the promised scholarships had been granted, though the rest were in the pipeline; and that they had no statistics to show for the government's efforts to link up job-seekers with employers.
Alfredo Espinosa is president of the Mexican Foundation for Rural Development, one of 25 institutions selected to hand out micro-loans. His group, like most, has received no money from the government. Besieged by applicants, he was unable to grant a single loan. "At the moment, we've received nothing," he said. "I figure the president himself doesn't know all these details, and the people below him must have said, 'Hold it, we need more time.' "
Maria del Carmen Diaz, the federal micro-credit coordinator, said, "I had thought it would have taken us a month to get going, and it's taken six." By year's end, she hopes, 40,000 loans may be granted.
Mr. Fox needs Congress to change hidebound laws to help him accomplish some of his biggest promises. His failed efforts for tax reform provided a bitter lesson.
Congress and citizens cried out against a plan for a 15-percent levy on food and medicine. Mr. Fox thought that he could sweep aside the opposition. "Congress won't block me on fiscal reform," he told foreign diplomats in April. 
He could have gone to Congress to build support for his plan. Instead, he broadcast a television ad from the presidential mansion denouncing his opponents: "They're lying, those who say this reform will hurt the poorest," he said. "With this plan, everybody wins."
So far, only Mr. Fox has lost this battle. His tax plan is a dead letter; he damaged relations with Congress.
The debacle, said Carlos Ramirez Marin, congressional vice chairman for the PRI, showed that Mr. Fox "is a man who thinks that simply by saying something, he can make it reality."
Mr. Fox says he knows he must work with his enemies to succeed. 
"It is indispensable to show results inside this country and to give a better quality of life to our citizens," he said. "And that is my greatest struggle. That is why I get out of bed and go to work every day."

A chart yesterday with a front-page article about the progress of President Vicente Fox of Mexico toward his goals misstated the 1999 infant mortality rate recorded by Unicef in his country and in the United States. In the United States the rate was 7 deaths per 1,000 live births, not 7 percent; in Mexico it was 27 deaths per 1,000 live births, not 27 percent.

HEADLINE: At Pair of Labor Gatherings, Bush Gets Set for Fall Fight 

BYLINE:  By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 3 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he was concerned about the nation's economy, describing it as "anemic at best" in the last year and adding that there were still "some problems on the horizon." 
 But speaking during briskly paced Labor Day visits to a carpenters' union rally in Green Bay, Wis., and a Teamsters picnic here, Mr. Bush mixed into his comments a note of optimism. 
 "Even though people are hurting today -- and I know they are -- I'm confident with the basic underpinnings of the economy," he told several hundred carpenters in Green Bay. "I'm confident we can recover." 
Mr. Bush tried to use his appearances to shape the terms of the coming budget battle with Congressional Democrats at a time of a shrinking surplus. Revised estimates that even by the administration's reckoning have all but eliminated the non-Social Security surplus over the next several years leave the president and Congress little room to operate in enacting spending bills this fall. 
Democrats including the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, maintain that Mr. Bush's tax cut is largely to blame and that the president is responsible for the painful trade-offs that many expect. 
But Mr. Bush told the carpenters: "Make no mistake about it: tax relief was the right thing to do at the right time. The rebate checks are now hitting. People have got more money to spend or invest, the very things needed to make sure that we sustain economic vitality and growth. There are some second-guessers in Washington."
In addition to trying to frame the coming budget debate, Mr. Bush was also seeking to improve relations with organized labor ahead of the Congressional elections next year.
This spring the carpenters' union broke away from the A.F.L.-C.I.O., a reliable Democratic ally, and today the president of the union, Douglas McCarron, traveled to Wisconsin with Mr. Bush on Air Force One.
The political dimension of Mr. Bush's efforts was even more evident here in Detroit, where he offered extended praise to James P. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters union. The Teamsters supported Vice President Al Gore in the last election, but Mr. Hoffa recently backed the administration's effort to authorize oil exploration in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. He has also emphasized his interest in having his union strengthen its ties to the Republican Party.
Mr. Hoffa was not present at the rally here, because of what both union and White House officials described as a commitment to be in California to celebrate the end of a two-year-old contract dispute involving 800 teamsters. But, before a sparse crowd of about 300 of the union's members, Mr. Bush did his best to embrace its leader. 
"You've got a good man running the Teamsters in Jimmy Hoffa," Mr. Bush said, to great cheering. The president also said Mr. Hoffa had run the union well, an unmistakable reference to the teamsters' efforts to be freed of federal court and Justice Department supervision, imposed under a 1989 consent decree because of past corruption.
"Let me tell you another thing about Jimmy Hoffa," Mr. Bush said. "He's running a good union and in an aboveboard way, an aboveboard way. And make no mistake about it, people are beginning to notice, particularly in Washington, D.C." 
Mr. Bush's success in pushing his energy policy through the House was due in part to his ability to split some of the Democrats' allies in the labor movement away from the party's allies among environmentalists, with the Teamsters arguing that drilling in the Arctic would provide jobs. Today Mr. Bush emphasized the employment theme, saying Mr. Hoffa "understands that good sound energy policy means jobs for American workers."
Mr. Bush did not mention one issue on which he and Mr. Hoffa remain far apart: the administration's effort to grant Mexican truckers access to the United States beyond a border area 20 miles deep. The teamsters and other unions have blocked the wider access.
But Mr. Bush is committed to lifting the restrictions, which have been a major irritant in the United States' relations with Mexico, whose president, Vicente Fox, is scheduled to visit the White House this week.
In both his appearances today, Mr. Bush repeatedly tried to demonstrate a concern for working families.
"I know people are hurting," he told a crowd at a Wisconsin airport. He used the word "hurting" several times today, in a defter version of his father's 1992 campaign statement "Message: I care." 
President George Bush was defeated for re-election that year by Bill Clinton, whose corresponding message, "I feel your pain," proved more effective.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Hewlett Agrees to Buy Compaq for $25 Billion
Hewlett-Packard announced yesterday that it was acquiring Compaq Computer for $25 billion in stock, a bold move to grow as the computer business struggles with shrinking sales.
 The merger, if completed, would produce a company with revenues only slightly below those of I.B.M., the largest computer company. Both Hewlett-Packard and Compaq have recently seen revenues slide and profits fall amid an industry slowdown. Page A1. 

Tokyo Stocks Close at 17-Year Low
Tokyo stocks fell to a 17-year-low following profit warnings by high-tech companies. The benchmark 225-issue Nikkei stock average extended its losing streak to five consecutive sessions, losing 303.83 points, or 2.84 percent, to end at 10,409.68, its lowest close since Aug. 14, 1984, when it ended at 10,360.92. Page C4.

Motorola Makes Chip Breakthrough
Motorola plans to announce a breakthrough in the manufacture of semiconductors that allows high-performance materials to reside on top of standard silicon, a decades-old dream for microchip designers. The technology, which takes advantage of equipment already in use, will make it possible to make specialty chips like power amplifiers in cell phones more cheaply, Motorola said. C2.

Altered Corn Was Reported Earlier
The government and the company that developed genetically modified StarLink corn had at least some indication that the corn might be entering the human food supply more than half a year before environmental advocates discovered it in taco shells, according to a government document. C2.

Cookies and Online Privacy
Cookies, the small files placed on each Web visitor's computer that track what the visitor's machine does at a site, have changed the World Wide Web from a place of discontinuous visits into an environment in which to shop and to play. But cookies are causing worries about privacy. A recent survey by Public Opinion Strategies, a Republican polling organization, found that 67 percent of Americans identify online privacy as a concern. A1.

Bush Pays a Visit to Labor Unions
President Bush said that he was concerned about the nation's economy, which he described as "anemic at best" over the last year, and that there were still "some problems on the horizon." But speaking during Labor Day visits to a carpenters' union rally in Green Bay, Wis., and to a Labor Day picnic of Teamsters in Detroit, Mr. Bush mixed his comments with a note of optimism. A16.

Interviews with union members at a parade and a Teamsters' picnic in Detroit indicated that Mr. Bush faced an uphill battle in the campaign he began two weeks ago to win over union members. A16.

BMW Recalling 500 Vehicles
BMW, the German luxury car maker, is recalling 500 of its new Mini compact cars after factory workers noticed sparks while refueling two vehicles. C4.

New Guidelines for Analysts
HSBC Holdings is planning changes in its equity investment research following criticism of the industry by investors. The move was in response to criticism that investment banks' analysts were too positive about companies in the hope of generating more lucrative corporate finance work. C4.

Campaigns to Watch and Not Watch
It is again time to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.

Swissair Is Raising Ticket Prices
The chief executive of the financially struggling Swissair Group says it plans to raise its ticket prices to reduce debt. C4.

Financial Markets Closed
The stock market and other financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Labor Day. The overseas markets were open. The markets in the United States will reopen today.

HEADLINE: At a Labor Picnic, Mixed Reviews for Bush 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 3 

 BODY:
After trudging two miles in this city's Labor Day parade, Ford Dingman was sprawled on the grass, thirsty, tired and sounding unenthusiastic about President Bush's visit today to this cradle of unionism.
 Mr. Dingman, a burly steelworker wearing a "Union Yes!" button, praised Mr. Bush for visiting a union picnic today, but he complained that the president had done little to reverse the loss of hundreds of thousands of manufacturing jobs in the last year. 
 "I would take any support for labor from any politician," Mr. Dingman said. "But I've very skeptical about Bush. I'm a Missourian. It's show me. He's trying to open up a bit toward labor, but we're waiting to see the actions he takes."
Interviews with three dozen union members at the parade and at a Teamsters' picnic indicated that Mr. Bush faced an uphill battle in the campaign he began two weeks ago to win the hearts and minds of union members. Last year, the nation's 16 million union members voted more than two to one for Vice President Al Gore, but Mr. Bush has been working earnestly to win labor support, especially in Midwestern swing states that his advisers say may be pivotal to his re-election hopes.
As part of these efforts, Mr. Bush attended a steelworkers picnic near Pittsburgh two weeks ago, a carpenters' union training session in Green Bay, Wis., this morning and the Teamsters' annual Labor Day picnic this afternoon.
To win over labor's rank and file, Mr. Bush will have to overcome a deep sense among many union members that he is unfriendly to organized labor and that his $1.3 trillion tax cut favors the rich. Labor Day marchers pointed to a long list of Bush positions that they opposed, including his plans to privatize Social Security, his revocation of ergonomics rules, his push for fast-track trade legislation and his efforts to give Mexican trucks greater access to American highways in accordance with the free-trade agreement.
Nevertheless, many workers welcomed his efforts to reach out, while others called his visit window dressing intended to make union members forget his antilabor actions.
Jim Parrinello, a driver for Consolidated Freightways who said he voted for Al Gore, welcomed Mr. Bush's decision to spend an hour with 300 picnicking Teamsters.
"It's good to see that his door is open," Mr. Parrinello said. "Now I think he's going to listen to us on some things."
But Robert Buthia, a member of the United Auto Workers, was cynical about Mr. Bush's visit.
"It's just a facade," Mr. Buthia said as he leaned on an antique Chevrolet in the parade's staging area. "It's just to make him look good."
Mr. Buthia, who is thinking of retiring after 37 years at an auto parts plant, said he was worried about Mr. Bush's plans to spend part of the Social Security surplus.
"He's ready to cut into Social Security," he said. "Why would you want to give people a tax rebate and than have to cut $9 billion into Social Security? It doesn't make sense at all."
The parade was a festive event, with floats, thousands of marchers and flatbed trucks that carried retirees and blared Motown oldies. At the parade, union members gave mixed reviews to Mr. Bush's Detroit visit.
"As a unionist, I'm embarrassed that he's in this city today," said Norm Kujawa, who works at a Mercury Cougar plant in Flat Rock, Mich. "It's an affront to labor. His policies have been antiunion. He's in Detroit today because he's a good politician, and he knows that unions can help him."
Latanya Mitchell, a worker at American Axle Manufacturing, said, "My take is the same as any other union member -- I don't see Bush doing anything to help."
But Wayne Hall, a retired chemical worker, was more generous, saying that it was early in Mr. Bush's term and that he was waiting for the president to prove himself.
"I'd give him a B-plus for bringing dignity back to the White House," Mr. Hall said. "But he has to realize where the bread and butter comes from. He hasn't really shown it."
A big obstacle for Mr. Bush in gaining the support of union members is that many union leaders articulate a steady anti-Bush message, condemning, among other things, the fast-track trade legislation, his tax cut and his plans to privatize Social Security. Along the parade route many telephone poles carried signed, printed by the A.F.L.-C.I.O, that read, "Working Families Say Stop Fast Track."
White House officials arranged for Mr. Bush to attend the Teamsters' picnic after that union backed him on drilling for oil in Alaska, a move that angered several other unions. At the picnic, the Teamsters gave Mr. Bush a polite reception, but applauded with enthusiasm when he praised the union's president, James P. Hoffa.
"I'm very glad to see the president is reaching out to the Teamsters and to labor," Bob Golota, a United Parcel Service driver said as he waited to shake hands with Mr. Bush at the picnic. "We need our voice to be heard, whether by Republicans or Democrats."
Scott Mielnicki, a truck driver who voted for Mr. Bush, said he and his family were thrilled to shake Mr. Bush's hand at the picnic. "I think he and Jimmy Hoffa have got a special bond going, and that's good for labor. They should be able to work some things out."
In his 10-minute speech to the Teamsters, Mr. Bush aid he was very concerned about the economy, insisting that the best medicine to speed up growth was his tax cut.
But most union members interviewed were indifferent or hostile to the tax cut. More often than not, union members said their rebates of $300 or $600 were paltry.
"I didn't need the $300 more to get the country more in debt," said Dawn McQuade-Gulley, a plumber who works at the Renaissance Center complex.
Michael Grivna, a Teamster, said the money could have been used to pay for prescription drugs for needy retirees, like his mother-in-law.
Mr. Golota, the U.P.S. driver was one of the few union members to applaud Mr. Bush's tax cut, saying, "My son is in college, and the tax rebate certainly will help pay his tuition."
