HEADLINE: U.S. Germ Warfare Research Pushes Treaty Limits 

BYLINE:  This article was reported and written by Judith Miller, Stephen Engelberg and William J. Broad. 

 BODY:
Over the past several years, the United States has embarked on a program of secret research on biological weapons that, some officials say, tests the limits of the global treaty banning such weapons.
 The 1972 treaty forbids nations from developing or acquiring weapons that spread disease, but it allows work on vaccines and other protective measures. Government officials said the secret research, which mimicked the major steps a state or terrorist would take to create a biological arsenal, was aimed at better understanding the threat. 
 The projects, which have not been previously disclosed, were begun under President Clinton and have been embraced by the Bush administration, which intends to expand them. 
Earlier this year, administration officials said, the Pentagon drew up plans to engineer genetically a potentially more potent variant of the bacterium that causes anthrax, a deadly disease ideal for germ warfare. 
The experiment has been devised to assess whether the vaccine now being given to millions of American soldiers is effective against such a superbug, which was first created by Russian scientists. A Bush administration official said the National Security Council is expected to give the final go-ahead later this month. 
Two other projects completed during the Clinton administration focused on the mechanics of making germ weapons. 
In a program code-named Clear Vision, the Central Intelligence Agency built and tested a model of a Soviet-designed germ bomb that agency officials feared was being sold on the international market. The C.I.A. device lacked a fuse and other parts that would make it a working bomb, intelligence officials said.
At about the same time, Pentagon experts assembled a germ factory in the Nevada desert from commercially available materials. Pentagon officials said the project demonstrated the ease with which a terrorist or rogue nation could build a plant that could produce pounds of the deadly germs. 
Both the mock bomb and the factory were tested with simulants -- benign substances with characteristics similar to the germs used in weapons, officials said.
A senior Bush administration official said all the projects were "fully consistent" with the treaty banning biological weapons and were needed to protect Americans against a growing danger. "This administration will pursue defenses against the full spectrum of biological threats," the official said. 
The treaty, another administration official said, allows the United States to conduct research on both microbes and germ munitions for "protective or defensive purposes." 
Some Clinton administration officials worried, however, that the project violated the pact. And others expressed concern that the experiments, if disclosed, might be misunderstood as a clandestine effort to resume work on a class of weapons that President Nixon had relinquished in 1969.
Simultaneous experiments involving a model of a germ bomb, a factory to make biological agents and the developoment of more potent anthrax, these officials said, would draw vociferous protests from Washington if conducted by a country the United States viewed as suspect.
Administration officials said the need to keep such projects secret was a significant reason behind President Bush's recent rejection of a draft agreement to strengthen the germ-weapons treaty, which has been signed by 143 nations. 
The draft would require those countries to disclose where they are conducting defensive research involving gene-splicing or germs likely to be used in weapons. The sites would then be subject to international inspections. 
Many national security officials in both the Clinton and Bush administrations opposed the draft, arguing that it would give potential adversaries a road map to what the United States considers its most serious vulnerabilities.
Among the facilities likely to be open to inspection under the draft agreement would be the West Jefferson, Ohio, laboratory of the Battelle Memorial Institute, a military contractor that has been selected to create the genetically altered anthrax.
Several officials who served in senior posts in the Clinton administration acknowledged that the secretive efforts were so poorly coordinated that even the White House was unaware of their full scope. 
The Pentagon's project to build a germ factory was not reported to the White House, they said. President Clinton, who developed an intense interest in germ weapons, was never briefed on the programs under way or contemplated, the officials said. 
A former senior official in the Clinton White House conceded that in retrospect, someone should have been responsible for reviewing the projects to ensure that they were not only effective in defending the United States, but consistent with the nation's arms-control pledges.
The C.I.A.'s tests on the bomb model touched off a dispute among government experts after the tests were concluded in 2000, with some officials arguing that they violated the germ treaty's prohibition against developing weapons. 
Intelligence officials said lawyers at the agency and the White House concluded that the work was defensive, and therefore allowed. But even officials who supported the effort acknowledged that it brought the United States closer to what was forbidden. 
"It was pressing how far you go before you do something illegal or immoral," recalled one senior official who was briefed on the program.
Public disclosure of the research is likely to complicate the position of the United States, which has long been in the forefront of efforts to enforce the ban on germ weapons. 
The Bush administration's willingness to abandon the 1972 Antiballistic Missile treaty has already drawn criticism around the world. And the administration's stance on the draft agreement for the germ treaty has put Washington at odds with many of its allies, including Japan and Britain. 

The Original Treaty
During the cold war, both the United States and the Soviet Union produced vast quantities of germ weapons, enough to kill everyone on earth. 
Eager to halt the spread of what many called the poor man's atom bomb, the United States unilaterally gave up germ arms and helped lead the global campaign to abolish them. By 1975, most of the world's nations had signed the convention. 
In doing so, they agreed not to develop, produce, acquire or stockpile quantities or types of germs that had no "prophylactic, protective or other peaceful purposes." They also pledged not to develop or obtain weapons or other equipment "designed to use such agents or toxins for hostile purposes or in armed conflict."
There were at least two significant loopholes: The pact did not define "defensive" research or say what studies might be prohibited, if any. And it provided no means of catching cheaters.
In the following decades, several countries did cheat, some on a huge scale. The Soviet Union built entire cities devoted to developing germ weapons, employing tens of thousands of people and turning anthrax, smallpox and bubonic plague into weapons of war. In the late 1980's, Iraq began a crash program to produce its own germ arsenal.
Both countries insisted that their programs were for defensive purposes.
American intelligence officials had suspected that Baghdad and Moscow were clandestinely producing germ weapons. But the full picture of their efforts did not become clear until the 1990's, after several Iraqi and Soviet officials defected. 
Fears about the spread of biological weapons were deepened by the rise of terrorism against Americans, the great strides in genetic engineering and the collapse of the Soviet Union, which left thousands of scientists skilled in biological warfare unemployed, penniless and vulnerable to recruitment. 
The threat disclosed a quandary: While the United States spent billions of dollars a year to assess enemy military forces and to defend against bullets, tanks, bombs and jet fighters, it knew relatively little about the working of exotic arms it had relinquished long ago.

Designing a Delivery System
In the mid-1990's, the C.I.A. and other intelligence agencies stepped up their search for information about other nations' biological research programs, focusing on the former Soviet Union, Iran, Iraq and Libya, among others. Much of the initial emphasis was on the germs that enemies might use in an attack, officials said.
But in 1997, the agency embarked on Clear Vision, which focused on weapons systems that would deliver the germs.
Intelligence officials said the project was led by Gene Johnson, a senior C.I.A. scientist who had long worked with some of the world's deadliest viruses. Dr. Johnson was eager to understand the damage that Soviet miniature bombs -- bomblets, in military parlance -- might inflict.
The agency asked its spies to find or buy a Soviet bomblet, which releases germs in a fine mist. That search proved unsuccessful, and the agency approved a proposal to build a replica and study how well it could disperse its lethal cargo.
The agency's lawyers concluded that such a project was permitted by the treaty because the intent was defensive. Intelligence officials said the C.I.A. had reports that at least one nation was trying to buy the Soviet-made bomblets.
A model was constructed and the agency conducted two sets of tests at Battelle, the military contractor. The experiments measured dissemination characteristics and how the model performed under different atmospheric conditions, intelligence officials said. They emphasized that the device was a "portion" of a bomb that could not have been used as a weapon. 
The experiments caused concern at the White House, which learned about the project after it was under way. Some aides to President Clinton worried that the benefits did not justify the risks. But a White House lawyer led a joint assessment by several departments that concluded that the program did not violate the treaty, and it went ahead.
The questions were debated anew after the project was completed, this time without consensus. A State Department official argued for a strict reading of the treaty: the ban on acquiring or developing "weapons" barred states from building even a partial model of a germ bomb, no matter what the rationale. 
"A bomb is a bomb is a bomb," another official said at the time.
The C.I.A. continued to insist that it had the legal authority to conduct such tests and, intelligence officials said, the agency was prepared to reopen the fight over how to interpret the treaty. But even so, the agency ended the Clear Vision project in the last year of the Clinton administration, intelligence officials said.
Bill Harlow, the C.I.A. spokesman, acknowledged that the agency had conducted "laboratory or experimental" work to assess the intelligence it had gathered about biological warfare. 
"Everything we have done in this respect was entirely appropriate, necessary, consistent with U.S. treaty obligations and was briefed to the National Security Council staff and appropriate Congressional oversight committees," Mr. Harlow said. 

Breeding More Potent Anthrax
In the 1990's, government officials also grew increasingly worried about the possibility that scientists could use the widely available techniques of gene-splicing to create even more deadly weapons.
Those concerns deepened in 1995, when Russian scientists disclosed at a scientific conference in Britain that they had implanted genes from Bacillus cereus, an organism that causes food poisoning, into the anthrax microbe. 
The scientists said later that the experiments were peaceful; the two microbes can be found side-by-side in nature and, the Russians said, they wanted to see what happened if they cross-bred.
A published account of the experiment, which appeared in a scientific journal in late 1997, alarmed the Pentagon, which had just decided to require that American soldiers be vaccinated against anthrax. According to the article, the new strain was resistant to Russia's anthrax vaccine, at least in hamsters. 
American officials tried to obtain a sample from Russia through a scientific exchange program to see whether the Russians had really created such a hybrid. The Americans also wanted to test whether the microbe could defeat the American vaccine, which is different from that used by Russia.
Despite repeated promises, the bacteria were never provided.
Eventually the C.I.A. drew up plans to replicate the strain, but intelligence officials said the agency hesitated because there was no specific report that an adversary was attempting to turn the superbug into a weapon. 
This year, officials said, the project was taken over by the Pentagon's intelligence arm, the Defense Intelligence Agency. Pentagon lawyers reviewed the proposal and said it complied with the treaty. Officials said the research would be part of Project Jefferson, yet another government effort to track the dangers posed by germ weapons. 
A spokesman for Defense Intelligence, Lt. Cmdr. James Brooks, declined comment. Asked about the precautions at Battelle, which is to create the enhanced anthrax, Commander Brooks said security was "entirely suitable for all work already conducted and planned for Project Jefferson."

The Question of Secrecy
While several officials in both the Clinton and Bush administrations called this and other research long overdue, they expressed concern about the lack of a central system for vetting such proposals.
And a former American diplomat questioned the wisdom of keeping them secret.
James F. Leonard, head of the delegation that negotiated the germ treaty, said research on microbes or munitions could be justified, depending on the specifics.
But he said such experiments should be done openly, exposed to the scrutiny of scientists and the public. Public disclosure, he said, is important evidence that the United States is proceeding with a "clean heart."
"It's very important to be open," he said. "If we're not open, who's going to be open?" 
Mr. Leonard said the fine distinctions drawn by government lawyers were frequently ignored when a secret program was exposed. Then, he said, others offer the harshest possible interpretations -- a "vulgarization of what has been done."
But he concluded that the secret germ research, as described to him, was "foolish, but not illegal."
The authors have reported on biological weapons for The New York Times and based this article on material gathered for their book, "Germs: Biological Weapons and America's Secret War," which is being published this month by Simon & Schuster Inc.

HEADLINE: Dot-Commers Trade Options for Books 

BYLINE:  By AMIE PARNES 

 BODY:
Back in the reign of the dot-coms, Colvin Pitts, 22, left his computer science classes and backpack behind at Stanford University for a job as a programmer at Media3k, a San Francisco streaming media Web site that set him up with a $45,000 salary and stock options worth $70,000.
 Around the same time, Daniel Billotte, 26, dropped out of Arizona State University in his senior year to work full time at AtWeb .com, a Web site developer in Sunnyvale, Calif., for more than $63,000 and options valued in the six figures. And Joe Cavanaugh, 22, left Stanford in the middle of his junior year to devote himself full time to his own company, EmpowerD.com, a Web site intended to help disabled people. 
 "I knew when I could no longer give enough time to school and the company," Mr. Cavanaugh said. "Since Stanford would always be there and I could go back, I decided to take a shot and see how far we could take the company." 
The three were among the thousands of college students who were lured away from their math textbooks and History 101 classes by dot-com start-ups that promised riches and fame. But when Internet Armageddon came and unemployment loomed, they and many of their peers rediscovered the value of an old-fashioned ticket to career success: a bachelor's degree. And back to school they went.
"These young dot-commers began to feel unfulfilled," said Allison B. Hemming, the president of the Hired Guns, a consulting firm in New York that specializes in the new economy. "They developed these amazing Web sites and then watched them disappear, and they are coming back to school looking for something more concrete."
Their return to academia was not easy. "It's tough to walk away from something you put so much work into," said Ravi Paidipaty, 20, who began his senior year at Yale on Tuesday. Mr. Paidipaty left school last summer to start broadcastbuilders .com, which delivered broadcasts to MP3 players and cell phones but lasted only a few months. He seems almost relieved to be back. "In the bigger picture, I think it's nice to be a kid and a student for a little while longer and graduate on time with your friends," he said.
The herd instinct played a large part in the defection of so many students to cyberbusinesses. Before the bubble burst, everybody seemed to be getting in on the action, and no one wanted to be left behind.
"You're sitting in class, and meanwhile, you're hearing about people your age making millions and millions of dollars," said Zaw Thet, 21, who dropped out of Stanford in his junior year to start GetInventory.com, a Web-based supply-chain-management company. "You want to make money," too, he said.
At one point last year, Mr. Thet said, eight dot-coms were up and running in a single fraternity house at Stanford. By the end of the year, though, he had run out of money and shut his down. "It almost pains me to talk about it," he said. "We had a great team, but you can only work in the garage for so long."
He returned to school last December to pursue a double major in political science and computer science and plans to graduate next June. Meantime, he has a job -- with a Fortune 500 company. "Going back to school after being in the work force feels a little odd but it feels right," Mr. Thet said.
For some, the pilgrimage back to school was always part of the game plan. Peter Douglas, 22, a native of Potomac, Md., who graduated from Stanford in June, says he could not resist dropping out for a chance to help muscle a company from the ground up.
"I always knew I'd come back and finish up," Mr. Douglas said. "I just didn't know it would be that soon."
His adventure began in February 2000, when as a junior he took a part-time writing stint at Bluedog.com, a developer of Internet shopping tools near the Stanford campus. Before long, he was putting in 40 hours a week and growing resentful about having to go to class. So he dropped out in the spring.
"I got sucked in," Mr. Douglas said. "I became entirely obsessed with the success of the company and its product and totally immersed in the start-up world." With a $40,000 salary and a trove of stock options, he also took his girlfriend to fine restaurants, gave lavish wine parties and booked a two-week vacation to England.
Then, in August, Bluedog.com went under, and Mr. Douglas was suddenly just another unemployed dot-commer. "There was a great deal of grieving," he said. "It was really comforting to come back to school and throw myself into something more stable -- write papers, study for tests, earn my degree. No one can take those things from me." After graduation, he chose one of the oldest professions around: acting.
Stanford's dean of students, Marc Wais, says the exodus of Net-giddy students reached such proportions two years ago that the school had a problem filling campus leadership positions.
But then they came back. Mr. Cavanaugh, who left Stanford in the spring of 2000 to start EmpowerD.com, returned to school last September after EmpowerD.com died. After graduating in June, he joined a software company, and he plans to apply to business school soon.
"I'm glad I went back to school," he said. "It was a loose end I had to tie."
Mr. Billotte, who dropped out of Arizona State in the fall of 1998 to join AtWeb.com, is now making plans to return to school either this spring or next fall to complete his senior year. In the meantime, he is working full time as a software engineer at AOL Netscape in Santa Cruz, Calif.
As for Mr. Pitts, the computer science major who went to work for Media3k last year, he will be returning to school this month as a senior with few regrets. "As for my $70,000 in stock options, I could net about $200 if I sold today," he said.
As the academic year opens, the flow of students back to campuses pretty much matches the outflow two years ago. "These students need support and stability now," said Anna Copeland Wheatley, the editor in chief of AlleyCat News, a New York trade publication that specializes in dot-coms.
The Stanford Daily, the campus newspaper, even ran a story last quarter welcoming back the dot-com refugees.
"It's very humbling for the dot-commers," Mr. Wais of Stanford said. "Some of these students were C.E.O.'s of these companies, and now they're back on campus" sharing a dorm room with a roommate.

HEADLINE: British Phone Gear Maker to Cut Another2,000 Jobs 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
Two months after telling investors there would be no top-level management changes, Marconi, Britain's battered telephone equipment maker, said today that both its chairman and chief executive had quit, and that it would eliminate 2,000 more jobs, half of them in the United States. It also reported an operating loss of $329 million in the quarter ended June 30.
 The sudden departure of the chairman, Sir Roger Hurn, and the chief executive, Lord Simpson, capped one of the most spectacular corporate debacles of recent years. Created in 1999 from the General Electric Company of Britain, which is not related to the company of that name based in the United States, Marconi went on an acquisition spree. It spent some $8 billion, much of it in America, to transform itself from a military contractor into a telecommunications company -- just in time for last year's collapse of technology-related businesses. 
 Marconi has since cut back sharply, eliminating 10,000 jobs (including those announced today), or one-quarter of its work force. Its market value has collapsed as well, falling from its $50 billion peak a year ago to just over $2 billion after London trading today. The share price fell by half in one day alone, July 5, after the company reversed its previous position and issued a profit warning. 
The assurances it gave to investors at that time -- including those relating to management -- have not been borne out. Indeed, one day after the former chief financial officer, John C. Mayo, said there would be no top management changes, he was himself ousted.
"Everything they said then has completely gone out of the window," said Robin Hardy, an analyst with WestLB Panmure in London. The company has left investors with few indications of how the company will fare. The change of management, Mr. Hardy said, may restore "some but not enough" confidence to investors' view of Marconi.
Other analysts suggested that investors would be disappointed that new managers had not been brought in from outside the company. Marconi said that Mike Parton, the head of its networks unit, would replace Lord Simpson as chief executive and that Derek Bonham, a senior nonexecutive director, would serve as interim chairman until a permanent successor was found for Sir Roger.
Before the July debacle, Lord Simpson had been seen as one of Britain's top managers. Analysts said then that the company, which sold its military business in 1999, had plunged into buying phone-equipment companies like the Reltec Corporation of Cleveland and Fore Systems of Pittsburgh without a close understanding of the industry. Investors also took exception to what they saw as attempts by management to mislead them about the company's health.
The Evening Standard reported that Lord Simpson received more than $1.4 million in severance.
Mr. Parton, the new chief executive, said today that the company had begun a top-to-bottom review in response to the drastic contraction of new investment in telecommunications equipment worldwide. "I do believe there is a place in this market for Marconi," he said, "and that we will be successful."
Like its rivals, Marconi has been caught in the downdraft as phone operators, deeply in debt from buying new digital mobile phone licenses at auction, have scaled back plans to build the new networks, which are years away from making profits.
Marconi said it would save the equivalent of $840 million from the layoffs announced today, allowing it to return to profitability next year. Debt will be cut from the current level of $6.4 billion to $4.7 billion or less. And the company said today that up to $5.1 billion in acquisition-related costs will be written off, another reversal of the guidance it gave in July, when it said no write-offs were foreseen.
Marconi's shares fell 1 penny today, to 53 pence (77 cents) a share on the London Stock Exchange, after rising initially on word of the boardroom bloodletting.
While analysts said today's measures should help, the clouds of gloom over its chosen industry remain thick. A major rival, Ericsson of Sweden, said today that it saw no clear sign that the market for equipment would begin to recover next year. "No one can tell when we will see an end to the downturn," said Kurt Hellstrom, the chief executive. The comment, made at a conference in London, helped pushed Ericsson's already battered share price down more than 10 percent.

HEADLINE: WINE TALK; 
In France, Few Pickers May Mean No Nouveau

BYLINE:  By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
IT'S harvest time in the vineyards of France, and the growers are facing serious shortages. Not of grapes, but of people to pick them. 
 In Bordeaux, the largest of France's wine regions, the vendange, as the harvest is called, begins on Monday for white wines and about 10 days later for the reds. The 4,000 or so growers will need some 33,000 pickers for 10 days to a month to bring in the crop. Recruiters are working frantically to find prospects and to sign them up. 
 In Bordeaux's best-known region, the Medoc, home of world famous chateaus like Latour, Margaux and Lafite-Rothschild, 3,500 workers will be needed but only 400 had signed up as of Monday, according to the recruiters in Pauillac. 
In the Beaujolais region, in the east of France, the worker shortage is so serious that some growers there fear there may be no Beaujolais nouveau, the popular wine produced for release in November. 
"We used to be able to draw up our teams of pickers in July," Gerard Brisson, a grower in Villie Morgon told the news agency Reuters, "but for the past two years we have been able to find people only at the last moment."
The worker shortage would be even more acute if the larger properties were not equipped with picking machines. The situation in Beaujolais, which needs about 40,000 pickers, is particularly serious because the machines are banned there. Large properties throughout the rest of France use them, but hand picking is still preferred by many. 
Traditionally, vineyards in southwestern France relied on workers from Spain and Portugal, but improved economies in those countries mean fewer workers are headed for the vineyards north of the Pyrenees. The same is true for vineyards in the north, in Champagne and Alsace, where workers have often been recruited from Poland and other Eastern European countries, as well as from France's rust belt along the Belgian border. There, too, the economy has improved in recent years.
Compounding the problem is the decision this year by many French universities to begin the academic year in September rather than in October. Students have always been a principal source of seasonal vineyard workers.
So why don't the chateaus use machines instead? A modern picking machine can do the work of 100 or more pickers, and can work 24 hours a day if necessary.
The mechanical harvesters straddle the vines, slapping them with fiberglass panels. With most models, the ripe grapes, individually and inbunches, drop onto belts, which convey them to a hopper at the rear of the machine. 
That the machines are more economical for most vineyards is irrefutable. Their defenders also claim that they are more discriminating than humans because they collect only the ripe fruit, which falls off the vines easily.
The machines, developed in the United States but refined in France, can be found in every wine region in the world, including some of Bordeaux's best-known chateaus. In the United States, they are used wherever they are economically feasible, mostly in large vineyards. Few new vineyards are planted without vine rows wide enough and long enough to accommodate them. 
Even so, many growers prefer hand harvesting, especially for the most expensive wines. They cite the gentler nature of hand harvesting, which also allows the grower to pick only the best grapes.
The machines are not used at all in Beaujolais because the wine process there uses only full bunches of grapes, which are best picked by hand. Also, many Beaujolais plots are too small to accommodate the ungainly machines.
Wider use of the machines is no doubt inevitable, though, if finding skilled vineyard workers continues to be a problem. The shortage of pickers in France this year can be blamed almost entirely on Western Europe's prosperity. The pay, which is set by the French government, is hardly munificent: 43.87 francs, or about $6, an hour. Usually, food and lodging are included but taxes are deducted.
The work is backbreaking; a picker spends eight hours a day in the sun -- or worse, in the rain -- either bent over and wielding sharp cutters called secateurs, or lugging heavy boxes of fruit through the vine rows. Many quit after a few days. Several growers offer a bonus to those who remain for the entire harvest. 
In the past, skilled pickers followed the harvest, which in France, begins in the southernmost vineyards in August and ends in October in the north.
In the Rhine, in Germany, picking may still be going on in the chill early days of November. 
Many growers complain that France's social costs and burdensome bureaucracy have made grape picking far more costly than it once was. Some are cutting back on meals, and many would prefer to shut down the dormitories where they house pickers.
Francoise Janoueix, an owner of Chateau Haut-Sarpe in St.-Emilion, told Agence France-Presse that the paperwork alone was overwhelming.
"We are obliged to inform the government of every season worker we've hired at least 48 hours before the person is supposed to start work," she said. Even so, Mrs. Janoueix hopes to lure sufficient pickers this year by providing three evenings of entertainment during the harvest period. 
In less complicated times, food and wine were plentiful for the harvesters, and there was an element of fun in the harvest. Each morning, around 10 a.m., a hefty meal called a casse-croute (literally, breaking the crust) was hauled out into the vineyards to fortify the pickers until lunchtime.
Then after dinner, student pickers, who appeared to be exhausted after a day in the vines, would revive miraculously and party far into the night. Foreign pickers, often Spanish Gypsies, would sing and dance for their own entertainment and for the chateau owners and their guests.
Any anthropologist, or any farmer, for that matter, knows that harvest celebrations date back to the beginning of time and that despite meddling bureaucrats and temporary labor shortages, they will go on for a long time to come.
One harvest tradition is the gerbebaude, the final dinner for the pickers. Gerbe originally meant a sheaf of wheat. In the vineyards, it is a bouquet the harvesters present to the owner or his wife at the dinner.
In a memoir, Corinne Guisez, the owner of Chateau Faugeres, in St.-Emilion, remembered last year's gerbebaude.
"Big tables have been set," she wrote. "Zahra has prepared a succulent couscous. Alain is bringing the wine. I arrange the last flowers from the garden. The Portuguese swap addresses with the Moroccans, the policeman asks the accountant out, the Gypsy dances with Laetitia, one of the English girls. 
"Nobody knew one another on the first day, yet today, friendships have been born. There are no more barriers. In the late afternoon, everyone leaves, a bottle in hand and already thinking about returning next year. On Monday we will start the autumn work, preparing the soil for the next harvest. In the fields, life never stops. Wine is life."
There are, of course, only human harvesters at a gerbebaude.

LENGTH: 1100 words

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT; 
Recipe for a Best Seller: Analogies About Cheese or Anthills or Parenting

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY 

 BODY:
In researching their new book, David B. Yoffie and Mary Kwak observed judo classes and competitions and interviewed judo masters in the United States. They went to Japan to consult with the experts there. But their book, "Judo Strategy," is not for martial arts enthusiasts. Their target readers are business executives, and the judo lesson they teach is a strategic mind-set.
 Just as a lightweight judo master can defeat a larger opponent, they argue, a small company can challenge giant competitors. The same principles of movement, balance and leverage apply. 
 The cardinal rule of writing a business book these days seems to be: look for management lessons almost anywhere but in the business world itself. Look at sports; look at war; look at science; look at the theater; look at other cultures; look at other eras; look at anthills. They can all be instructive metaphors for running a company or supervising a work force. 
This obsession with analogies has struck a chord among managers, too. Business books are big business, with about 10,000 published in the last three years. A colorful metaphor makes a theory stand out among the crowd.
But using metaphors like judo is not a gimmick, Mr. Yoffie, a Harvard Business School professor, says. It is a useful way for business theorists to make sense of the changing economy.
In their book, which was published this year by the Harvard Business School Press, Mr. Yoffie and Ms. Kwak cited executives at Palm Computing, before it became Palm Inc., and RealNetworks. They were well practiced in judo strategy, even if they did not call it that until the authors came along.
"Metaphors can be great motivational tools because they are usually easy to understand and hard to forget," Mr. Yoffie writes in his book.
Then again, some employees would like to forget. Scott Adams, creator of the Dilbert comic strip, receives hundreds of e-mail messages from workers about the latest management fads to hit the cubicles. Recently, most of the rants concern a certain best-selling parable about mice and their meal.
"The thing that is annoying people the most is the 'Who Moved My Cheese?' book," Mr. Adams said, referring to the fable by Spencer Johnson and Kenneth H. Blanchard (Putnam, 1998), that many managers have handed out to their employees. "Most people who are complaining to me have already figured out that change happens and that they should get over it."
The taste for business metaphors goes in cycles, Mr. Yoffie says. In the postwar era, the battlefield was the preferred way to envision strategy, and the words of generals from Sun Tzu to Norman Schwarzkopf to George S. Patton to Carl von Clausewitz are still being plumbed for their leadership lessons.
The sports world has also been a popular source for business comparisons, from the late Billy Martin's tales of leadership out of the Yankees dugout to "Coach to Coach: Business Lessons From the Locker Room" (Pfeiffer, 1995), by John Robinson, the football coach at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas. Mike Krzyzewski, the head basketball coach at Duke University; Joe Torre, manager of the Yankees; and Rick Pitino, the former coach of the Boston Celtics, are also business authors.
The Antarctic explorer Sir Ernest Shackleton is likewise offered up as a lesson in corporate leadership, while Shakespeare's writings have been the basis for at least three management books. 
Now, business gurus are looking to other fields for inspiration. Like biology. The Bios Group, a company in Santa Fe, N.M., uses the behavior of ants to help analyze resource allocation, supply chains and other systems for major corporations. 
The idea sprang from naturalists' observations of ant colonies, which depend on scout ants to find the fastest route to a food source and lay a trail for others. Bios created mathematical formulas that mimic the ants' paths, and Procter & Gamble, Ford, Unilever and Boeing have all used software based on these "ant algorithms" to streamline their systems. 
If Bios covers biology, then the book by Richard Koch, "The Natural Laws of Business: How to Harness the Power of Evolution, Physics and Economics to Achieve Business Success" (Currency/Doubleday, 2001), should meet just about every college student's requirement for science courses.
Like most management theories, business metaphors have a nugget of truth in them, but backfire when taken too far. "Metaphors have distinct weaknesses," Mr. Yoffie acknowledged. "You have to know when they are useful and when they are not."
Or as Eileen C. Shapiro, a management consultant, says, you need to know what ails you before you look for a cure. 
"They are like a doctor's bag," said Ms. Shapiro, author of "Fad Surfing in the Boardroom" (Addison-Wesley, 1995). "Chemotherapy is a miracle today if you have certain types of cancer," she said. "Would you take that for your migraine? Businesses do the equivalent."
Books that look to other disciplines for management metaphors are part of a broader trend of exploring every corner of human activity for business lessons. Some motivational programs inculcate trust by having a co-worker hold the rope while you scale a cliff, for example. Mark Magnacca, founder of the Insight Development Group, urges participants in his Firewalk Experience seminars to "feel the fire within" before leading them outside to stroll barefoot over hot coals.
"It's not about walking on hot coals," Mr. Magnacca said. "It's about getting to a point where you realize you are ready to break through the fear that's been holding you back from doing what you're capable of doing."
He is writing a motivational business book centered on fire symbolism, but it will have to compete for attention. Walk into a bookstore, and you will see business books based on Aristotle, St. Benedict, "Star Trek," the Tao Te Ching, "The Wizard of Oz" and the Semper Fi way, drawn from the Marines.
Parenting, too, is a lot like running a company. That was the inspiration for the book "Peanut Butter and Jelly Management," (Amacom, 2000), in which Chris and Reina Komisarjevsky extol leadership principles they learned from raising nine children. 
Even if the analogies change, the business principles behind them are seldom new. Darrell K. Rigby, a director of Bain & Company, once counted 900 different management theories in use, and a lot of them are "just old wine in new bottles," he said. 
Even so, in a slowing economy executives are eager for anything that promises them an edge, said Ms. Shapiro, the consultant.
"This is a great time to be slogging a fad," she said. "You've got people who are just whiplashed."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Early Rally Mostly Fades As Tech Shares Stumble

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Stocks tried to stage a robust rally yesterday, but lost momentum in the last hour of trading.
 Wall Street was heartened at first by an upbeat report from the National Association of Purchasing Management that suggested that factory orders and production made a surprising rebound in August. 
 "The markets were so depressed that any little ray of hope was going to lead to a rally," said Stephen J. Massocca, president of Pacific Growth Equities, an investment bank in San Francisco.
Still, there were only gloomy forecasts from the technology sector, and investors looking to put money into stocks after a long, slow season concentrated their buying on the heavily battered retail and consumer products sectors. Investors' disapproval of the proposed acquisition of Compaq Computer by Hewlett Packard weighed on technology stocks. 
Yesterday's rally dissipated as investors gained "a sense of reality about the midquarter update from Intel on Thursday and a quickly approaching pre-announcement season," said Matthew W. Johnson, a managing director of Lehman Brothers. "The market got defensive in a hurry."
The Dow Jones industrial average benefited in part from a surge in Johnson & Johnson, which rose after one of its medical products received praise from a group of eminent cardiologists. The Dow industrials, which were up more than 200 points during much of the day, ended trading with a gain of 47.74 points, or 0.5 percent, to 9,997.56. It fell 4.5 percent in the last week, and it has now fallen 4.87 percent since Aug. 1 and 9.03 percent since June 1.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index dropped 34.65 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,770.78.
The broad Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.64 of a point, to 1,132.94.
"What's important to look at is the number of people that came back from vacation," said Mort Cohen, chairman of Clarion Partners in Cleveland, which manages about $150 million in hedge and venture funds. He was referring to fund managers.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 1.19 billion, demonstrating greater activity than in recent sessions. The average daily volume in August was 1.03 billion.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its manufacturing index rose to 47.9 in August from 43.6 in July, surpassing forecasts by some Wall Street economists that the index would rise only to 43.9. A reading above 50 would indicate that manufacturing activity is expanding, and it has been more than a year since the index was above that mark. Still, this was the highest reading since November, and the index measures a portion of the economy that suffered first and worst in the economic downturn, so Wall Street received the reading well.
Enthusiasm about the new report was evident in the stocks of such Dow components as Procter & Gamble, up $1.37, to $75.52; International Paper, up 96 cents, to $41.10; and Home Depot, up 87 cents, to $46.82.
But those gains were overshadowed by a 6.2 percent jump in Johnson & Johnson's shares. Researchers told the European Society of Cardiology yesterday that a stent coated with antibiotics, which the company developed, was successful in preventing arterial clogs in a study. Word traveled quickly to Wall Street, where the company's shares gained $3.44, to $56.15.
Johnson & Johnson's surge helped offset a sharp loss by Hewlett-Packard, another Dow component, which fell $4.21, or 18.1 percent, to $19, after it said it planned to acquire Compaq Computer for stock it initially valued at $25 billion. Compaq shares dropped $1.27, to $11.08.
Still, I.B.M., which would remain the largest computer company if that deal is completed, gained $1.54, to $101.49.
Technology stocks, which attempted to ride the rally for much of the trading day, eventually buckled under the weight of a downbeat forecast from Ericsson. Shares of Ericsson fell 97 cents, to $4.01, after the company's executives said their industry, telecommunications, was unlikely to recover next year. Qualcomm fell $4.55, to $54.30.
Shares of Intel, which is developing with Hewlett-Packard a computer server operating system that Compaq also plans to use, fell $1.11, to $26.85. The system will compete with one developed by Sun Microsystems and I.B.M. Shares of Sun fell 50 cents, to $10.95.
Cisco Systems, which introduced a few new products yesterday, fell 56 cents, to $15.77.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS; 
Dollar Rallies; Interest Rates Rise Sharply

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Interest rates rose sharply yesterday while the dollar rallied against the euro and the yen after investors were surprised by an unexpectedly strong report on manufacturing.
 But it is too early to tell if the rise in interest rates and the dollar's rally reflect a trend. So, rather than reversing directions, analysts said, interest rates and the dollar will probably trade within a range until the outlook for the economy is clearer. 
 Some analysts said that the rise in the manufacturing index of the National Association of Purchasing Management was significant, although it probably says more about the economic slump ending than about where the economy goes from here. 
But the sharpness of the moves in the bond and currency markets could be more a product of the reaction over the manufacturing data and the fact that the end of the summer doldrums and worries about the weakness of the economy had just sent interest rates too low and the dollar down too far.
By the end of last week, the yield on the Treasury's two-year note was down to 3.61 percent, the lowest it had been since the Treasury began selling the securities in 1972. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note was 4.83 percent, close to the lowest that it has been since March. The dollar was at 91.19 cents to the euro, after falling 8.3 percent since its high in July.
"I just think the market got caught up in this recession talk," said Robert V. DiClemente, chief United States economist at Salomon Smith Barney. "These interest rate levels are pushing extremes," he said of the decline of Treasury yields in August.
Referring to the dollar's move against the euro, Jeremy P. Fand, senior foreign exchange strategist at Fleet Global Markets, said, "It was unbelievably big but should not be perceived as something that will repeat itself anytime soon."
In the bond market, the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note jumped to 4.96 percent and the price, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped 11/32 to 10010/32 . The yield on the two-year note rose to 3.76 percent.
In the foreign exchange market, the dollar rose 3.3 percent as the euro was quoted at 88.62 cents. The move against the Japanese yen was much more modest, with the dollar at 119.52, up 0.6 percent from 118.80 yen on Friday.
The news that ignited this dollar rally and bond market sell-off was a report that the manufacturing index of the National Association of Purchasing Management rose to 47.9 in August, from 43.6 in July. The increase was the largest since 1996 and well above what Wall Street analysts had forecast.
While bond and dollar investors took this as positive news for overall economic expansion, any number below 50 still indicates that manufacturing is continuing to shrink. James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at J. P. Morgan, said that the monthly move "is significant enough that we should respect it."
"I think it is telling you," Mr. Glassman said, "that a huge drag on the economy is fading. But it is not telling you where we are going."
He said that he did not think that the jump in the index meant that the Federal Reserve had finished cutting short-term interest rates in its effort to revive the economy. The central bank has already cut its benchmark rate seven times this year, reducing it to 3.5 percent. Fed policy makers meet again in October.
Although Mr. Glassman said yesterday's bond market move was exaggerated, he added that it might reflect a return to a more balanced view of the economic outlook. 
"We came out of August under a cloud of gloom," he said. "We were getting overly pessimistic. Today maybe we are realizing that the world is not coming to an end."
Mr. DiClemente said "the economy is struggling to stay above water."
"But we have thrown a lot at it in the way of support," he said, including the Fed rate cuts and the $38 billion in tax rebates.
Mr. Fand said that a lot of the dollar buying yesterday came from speculators, including hedge funds, who had made big bets on the dollar falling against the euro. He said that he saw trades coming in at $200 million to $300 million each, which is one reason the dollar made such a big move.
And while he said the gloom about the economic outlook was overdone, he added that the manufacturing report did not signal that the American economy was in a rebound that would send the dollar a lot higher. "There is no reason to believe that the dollar will break the 85-cents-to-92-cents trading range," he said.

HEADLINE: A NEW COMPUTING GIANT: THE VIEW FROM TEXAS; 
Once-Strong Pillar of Houston's Economy Looks Shaky

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
There were few bright spots here during the energy slump of the mid- to late 1980's, when oil prices crashed and shiny new downtown office buildings stood half-empty. At one point, average home prices had dropped by one-fourth, and the joke was that only the seller had to bring a checkbook to real estate closings.
 A big exception back then, however, was Compaq Computer, the company founded after a bull session between engineers at a local dessert restaurant in 1982 that grew into the largest personal computer manufacturer in the nation. While the rest of Houston was buffeted by the weak oil and energy markets, Compaq rose from its headquarters campus in northwest Houston to lead the PC boom of the 1990's. 
 But the last few years brought a humbling role reversal. While Houston's oil and electricity business is booming, Compaq has been stumbling, hurt by a bruising price war with Dell Computer -- which recently took away the title of world's No. 1 PC maker -- and by a general slowdown as investors have concluded that the industry's best growth years are behind it. 
In just the last year, Compaq has eliminated 2,000 jobs in Houston. Now, with the company's acquisition by Hewlett-Packard, Houston is faced with the prospect of losing many more Compaq jobs as the two companies locate their headquarters in Palo Alto, Calif., and look for ways to slash $2.5 billion in annual costs.
Today, executives said they would cut 15,000 jobs, or 10 percent of the combined work force, assuming the deal closes next year. They did not say where those cuts would take place, but Houston "could bear the brunt" of it, said Ashok Kumar, an analyst at US Bancorp Piper Jaffray. In some areas, such as development of server computers, the two companies have a lot of overlap, Mr. Kumar said. "Usually, the surviving entity has the upper hand," he said.
Although unemployment is relatively low in Houston by historical standards, big cuts could be a blow to this city, where Compaq is the third-largest corporate employer, according to the Greater Houston Partnership, with 11,000 employees, behind the energy company Halliburton (nearly 17,000) and Continental Airlines (about 16,000). There are other major employers, including the Memorial Hermann Healthcare System, the University of Texas Medical Branch at Galveston, and NASA. But Compaq is an important factor in attempts to diversify the region's employment base. 
"Compaq has been very, very important for Houston" and for the city's efforts "to redefine itself and move away from an energy-only image," said Ray Perryman, whose economic consulting firm in Waco, Tex., bears his name. In the mid-to-late 1980's, he said, "they were the bright spot" in the local economy, helping keep the housing market in northwest Houston somewhat stable relative to other parts of town.
Compaq started 19 years ago, when the three founders sketched out a design for an I.B.M.-compatible portable computer on a place mat at a House of Pies restaurant, according to a 1991 article in The Houston Chronicle. The company topped $1 billion in sales after just five years. By the end of the decade, it employed more than 5,000 people here -- a dramatic counterweight to the tough times in real estate, energy and banking.
"They've been the banner, the poster child, for the diversification of our economy," said Jim Kollaer, the president and chief executive of the Greater Houston Partnership, the city's largest business organization. "Things would have been a lot worse" in the 1980's without Compaq, Mr. Kollaer said.
In 1982, the year Compaq was founded, he said, the city's economy was 80 percent dependent on oil; now it is less than 50 percent, in large part because of technology. More than 1,500 programming companies and 225 other types of software developers are now based in Houston, Mr. Kollaer said, saying that a lot of the credit should go to Compaq, which encouraged suppliers and vendors to move here. 
Unemployment in Houston was only 4.2 percent in July, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, as the oil business and energy-trading industry continue to have a strong year. So Mr. Kollaer predicted the economy would be able to absorb any laid-off Compaq employees.

HEADLINE: U.S. Factories Offer Hints Of Revival 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
Manufacturing, the weakest part of the United States economy, began showing signs of improvement last month, according to a survey of corporate executives released yesterday.
 Manufacturers increased their production for the first time since November, and the number of new orders they received rose for the first time in a year. Factories continued to cut jobs last month, though at a slower pace than in July, according to the survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management, a research group based in Tempe, Ariz., that polls 450 manufacturers each month. 
 The association's closely followed index -- which is calculated by combining the answers to 12 questions -- rose to 47.9, from 43.6 in July. The increase was the largest since 1996, although any figure below 50 indicates that the manufacturing sector continues to shrink. 
Investors seemed to take the report as evidence that the broad economy could be on the verge of improving. Stocks surged for a time after the report's release; the Dow Jones industrial average finished the day up 0.48 percent, at 9,997.49. The dollar rose sharply against the euro, and bond prices recorded steep drops. Page C15. 
Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said, "I'm pretty optimistic that we've hit a bottom in manufacturing." But, he added, "the recovery is going to be painfully slow." 
Separately, the University of Michigan reported yesterday that consumers were less optimistic last month about the economy's future. Two-thirds of Americans said the economy was declining, according to the university's monthly poll, and about half thought it would not begin growing at a healthy pace until late next year.
Consumers have cut back on plans to buy new cars, appliances, electronics and other expensive goods, according to Michigan's survey. The big American automobile makers said yesterday that sales had already fallen in recent weeks despite deep discounts the companies were offering.
Also yesterday, the Commerce Department reported that construction spending dipped 0.1 percent in July from the previous month, to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of $859.4 billion.
Even if economic growth remains meager for the rest of the year, the manufacturing report offered support to those analysts -- a majority -- who are saying that the economy is unlikely to worsen in the coming months.
For more than a year, manufacturers, which employ about one in seven working Americans, have been struggling badly. Sales have fallen as companies drastically cut their spending on new buildings, machinery and software, after deciding that they had been overly optimistic in 1999 and early in 2000. And the strong dollar has effectively lowered the price of imports and caused products made in the United States to become more expensive overseas. 
As a result, the makers of everything from ball bearings to semiconductors have found themselves with more products and workers than they needed, and they have responded by laying off employees, cutting back on production and trying to sell their stockpiles of goods at reduced prices.
Yesterday's report suggested that the manufacturers had begun to make a dent in their problems. Most important, analysts said, orders for new goods rose last month, suggesting that executives were becoming more optimistic about the near future. The new-orders component of the index increased sharply, to 53.1 from 46.3 in July.
When the new-orders figure substantially exceeded 50 in the past, an economic recovery usually followed shortly, said David Orr, chief economist at First Union in Charlotte, N.C..
Companies have been able to order more products and equipment because many have significantly cut their inventories this year. Overall inventory levels, after rising for 35 consecutive quarters through the end of 2000, fell in both the first and second quarters this year, according to the Commerce Department.
"Inventories have gotten so low that even moderate further gains in consumer spending are beginning to generate new orders for manufacturers," Mr. Orr said. "The dynamic the Fed has been counting on is beginning to appear."
The Federal Reserve has cut its benchmark interest rate seven times this year in an attempt to encourage consumers and businesses to spend money. 
In recent days, the price of a futures contract that follows that benchmark, the federal funds rate, has fallen, and analysts said the manufacturing report would make the Fed less likely to cut the rate again. Based on the futures contract, investors now think there is a roughly even chance that the Fed will cut rates when it meets on Oct. 2; last week, investors thought the odds of another reduction were above 80 percent.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Centers Offer More Than a Benefit Check 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN SAULNY 

 BODY:
Ginny Velarde can still recall the snaking lines and pervasive gloom of the state unemployment office she visited weekly for three months in 1970. It was "horrible, horrible, horrible," said Ms. Velarde, who lost her job in the sales office of a manufacturing company when it left New York. "Dismal, depressing, dehumanizing. I don't know how else to say it."
 Last April, Ms. Velarde was out of work again, laid off after 17 years managing a podiatrist's office on the Upper East Side. This time, though, her experience was very different. 
 "I love it," she said of the Queens One-Stop Career Center in Jamaica, which she described as welcoming, user-friendly and efficient. "I've made this place like a second home. From the moment I walked in here I found it to be a pleasant experience." 
In many cities and towns in New York and across the country, the unemployment office's long reign as a despised destination of last resort seems to be coming to an end. This is due in large part to a 1998 federal law, the Workforce Investment Act. 
The new law required states to give any resident -- unemployed or not -- access to a wide array of training, employment and educational services at a single neighborhood location. The changes are expected to be fully adopted in all states within five years.
"The unemployment office of the past is truly a dinosaur," said Emily DeRocco, an assistant secretary for employment and training at the United States Department of Labor in Washington.
Even the name of the once-dreaded offices has changed. They are becoming One-Stop Career Centers, offering job counseling and recruitment; computer training; workshops on resume writing, interviewing and starting a small business; free faxing and Internet access; sometimes even coffee and cookies. And talk at the new centers is only of employment; the "un" prefix is unwelcome.
"We've been working hard to change our image from the unemployment people to the employment office," said Linda Angello, New York State's Labor Commissioner. "There's been a change in philosophy and a change in the way we do business."
Most states have phased out the requirement that recipients show up in person each week to claim unemployment benefits and certify that they are still without a job. The jobless can now call a computerized system that allows officials to retrieve tax records and authorize benefit checks to be mailed. The only required visit is for a five-minute video orientation that explains all the available services.
Last week at the 33,000-square-foot One-Stop in Jamaica, people like Ms. Velarde were there because they wanted to be.
"The orientation was eye-opening," said Ms. Velarde, 55. "I'd worked all my life and didn't know the state had this to offer. I said, 'You know what? Don't be a fool. While you're looking for a job, use the facilities.' "
The new centers are required to provide job-search assistance and information on labor trends, and help both the unemployed and working people who are looking for advanced training or new careers.
The changes do not come without cost. Since the new program began, New York State have spent about $220 million a year on redesigning its job training programs and building the centers with grants from Washington, federal officials said.
The One-Stop concept, although developed during boom times, is expected to do a better job of finding jobs during slumps and recessions than the old unemployment offices, officials said, because the centers now have strong local control and are more efficient.
The new law required states and municipalities to create local Workforce Investment Boards to match the One-Stops to their communities. And most of these boards must be made up of executives from whatever businesses predominate locally.
"We saw in the '91 recession that certain parts of the country were hit harder than others," said Mason Bishop, a special assistant in the Employment and Training Administration of the federal Department of Labor. "Under a recession, this new system allows flexibility for the management of economic issues in a much more local way, and according to local labor market information."
For example, in Austin, Tex., the local board recently opened a special re-employment center in addition to its three One-Stops and four satellite offices to handle the 16,000 high-tech workers who have been laid off since the beginning of the year.
In New York City, which is just beginning to feel that type of economic pain, a task force created in June by its 43-member Workforce Investment Board is preparing a plan to deal with a possible surge in unemployment.
"The system was so flawed before that whatever incremental steps we've already put into effect have helped thousands of people get and keep their jobs," said Stuart M. Saft, a real estate lawyer who is chairman of the city's board. 
Representatives from the nation's 15 largest cities met in Washington to trade ideas, Mr. Saft said, about how to deal with "diverse populations, a multiplicity of languages, large numbers of people coming off public assistance, and other unique problems of large cities."
Los Angeles, for example, decided that it needed 18 centers while smaller states might have only one. San Francisco has three centers and the Chicago area has 17, officials said.
The Queens One-Stop opened just over a year ago, and is a prototype for five more that are to be opened in the city in the next two years. Each borough will have at least one center. Manhattan will have two.
Only a few visitors interviewed at the Queens One-Stop said they had less than positive experiences. Two women who identified themselves only as recent college graduates said they felt the services offered were too basic for their needs.
Complaints have also come from outplacement companies that they are being deprived of millions of dollars in business because the government is assisting laid-off workers in finding new jobs.
Mike Giuffrida, executive vice president of the Association of Career Management Firms International-North America, estimated that his members were losing $18 million to $25 million a year to the One-Stop Centers.
"The act and the regulation that implemented it all say the same thing: the government is supposed to rely on the private sector unless it can provide services more cheaply," he said. "They're supposed to bid this stuff out at the local and state level and they're not doing it. The state is coming in and saying we'll do it for free and as a result our members are losing business all across the board."
The intent of the act was not to create "a government monopoly on employment training programs," said Mr. Bishop of the Labor Department. "The intent was the opposite: to engage partners at the local level, both private and public sector."
"Whenever there is concern from a business that thinks we're trying to take its customers, we sit down with them and talk it through," he said, adding that recourse is also available from state boards, governors' offices and legislators.
Tara Sullivan, 32, who was laid off from CNN Interactive in May, first went to the employment office on West 54th Street in Manhattan and then was directed to several programs at the Queens One-Stop, including a workshop on self-employment and the development of business plans.
"My experience was remarkable," Ms. Sullivan said. "I was very impressed. They treated us like professionals rather than problems. I think the common perception of unemployment services is that they're out to get you, or prevent one from getting money. I think they want to help you get through a period when you're unemployed easily and to make that time a short time."
That is indeed the goal, said Michael Josephson, the manager of the Queens One-Stop. "The whole idea is to get people into jobs without any hassle or runarounds," he said. "We don't want people to feel like, 'Oh no! I've got to go to the Department of Labor and they're going to growl at me.' I want people to leave feeling happy."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Workers answer questions at the One-Stop Career Center in Jamaica, above. At left, Ginny Velarde, center, and Yolanda Cordijo polish their computer skills. (Photographs by Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)(pg. B6)

HEADLINE: Newark Arena Plan Faces Tough Legislative Fight 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
Two days before a critical committee meeting, the ambitious plans to build a $385 million sports arena in Newark and redevelop the Meadowlands are in the middle of a fierce political struggle that could scuttle the whole project before it ever gets to the full Legislature.
 Members of the 11-member Assembly Appropriations Committee are scheduled to meet Thursday to consider a bill to create a financing mechanism that would allow the two projects to be built. The bill was believed to have broad bipartisan support when it passed the Senate in June. It is enthusiastically backed by Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Republican. But it has since become an issue in gubernatorial politics, with the Republican nominee, Bret D. Schundler, saying the proposal should not be approved without a popular referendum. 
 Now, there is growing opposition on the Appropriations Committee, which has seven Republicans and four Democrats. Failure of the measure in the committee would likely deter the legislative leadership from calling a special session of the entire Legislature, as planned, to consider the proposals. Without such a special session, efforts to keep the New Jersey Devils and New Jersey Nets, who want a new arena, in the state would have to await action by the next governor and the next Legislature. 
"It will be a victory for the voters and for Bret Schundler if this fails," said Assemblywoman Clare Farragher, Republican of Freehold, one of the seven Republican members of the committee. "Speaking for myself, I am not in favor of it."
At least three other committee members also said they were firmly opposed. One other member said he was opposed with reservations and still another said that he had yet to make up his mind. The seventh Republican member of the committee, Assemblyman Rich Bagger of Westfield, the chairman, could not be reached for comment.
Assemblyman William Payne of Newark, one of the four Democrats on the committee, said that prospects for the measure looked bleak right now, but he said the mere fact that the bill had been introduced and come to the committee suggested that the Assembly speaker, Jack Collins, was behind it. 
"In my experience, people seldom buck the leadership in Trenton," Mr. Payne said. "As it stands now I would expect that if Speaker Collins came before the committee to support the bill, those people who are undecided or even opposed would vote for it. But even if he doesn't show up, he has a way of letting people know what he wants."
In recent weeks, aides to Mr. DiFrancesco have said that they have amended the bill to also provide a sports complex at Rowan University in South Jersey as a concession to Mr. Collins and others in that part of the state who were seeking some economic stimulus for their region from the arena deal.
Mr. Collins's position on the measure remained as enigmatic today as it was two weeks ago. While the acting governor's spokesman, Tom Wilson, said that the speaker's role in negotiations leading to the inclusion of a Rowan University sports complex "were well known," a spokesman for Mr. Collins insisted that it would be a mistake to assume that he has made up his mind.
"I think he will await the committee's final version of the bill," said Chuck Leitgeb, the spokesman, who added that at this time there were no plans by the speaker to appear before the committee.
The proposed legislation would authorize the creation of a sports and entertainment district in the area around the planned Newark arena where the proceeds of a 6 percent sales tax expected to be generated by an anticipated increase in economic activity would be used to pay off some $190 million in money borrowed to aid in the construction of the arena.
In addition, the YankeeNets, owners of the Nets and the Devils, would provide $115 million, and would operate the 18,500-seat arena under a 30-year lease. The remainder of the cost, mostly for infrastructure improvements, would be met by the Newark and Essex County governments.
To broaden support for the plan, officials agreed to create a similar taxing district at the Meadowlands site of the current Continental Airlines Arena to finance its demolition and replacement with a Disney-like family entertainment, sports and retail complex.
Privately, some legislative staff members who are close to the speaker said that while he was supportive of economic development efforts for South Jersey, he was not about to "break arms" over the arena legislation. They said that Mr. Collins understood that many of his colleagues were getting polling data showing that their constituents did not like the idea of a Newark arena or the idea of spending money for the projects without a referendum.
"He understands the political side of this and that it has given Schundler an issue," said one close aide. "That's another reason he isn't going to press them on this."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
PC Users Are Uninformed About Protecting Privacy
People shop, chat and play online, and look to the Internet for information on health care, for psychological support and even for love. Meanwhile, the technologies for monitoring and analyzing those activities grow more powerful. But when it comes to protecting privacy online, most consumers still do not even know where to start.
 Some companies offer packages for privacy, but they have not had much luck selling them directly to consumers. Privacy, it seems, is something that everybody wants but few want to pay for. Page A1. 

Stocks End Mixed After Early Rally
Stocks attempted to stage a rally, but lost momentum in the last hour of trading. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 47.74 points, to 9,997.49. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 34.65 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,770.78. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 0.64 of a point, to 1,132.94. C15.

Chrysler Sales Declined Last Month
Chrysler reported that its sales fell 24 percent last month from August 2000, surprising analysts and leading some to wonder if Toyota's sales gains would lead it to become the third-largest automaker in this country. C4.

Analogies Score in Business Books
The cardinal rule of writing a business book these days seems to be: look for management lessons almost anywhere but in the business world itself. Look at sports; look at war; look at science; look at other cultures; look at other eras. They can all be instructive metaphors for running a company. Management. C14.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Study Details Decline In Spending on Ads

BYLINE:  By Claudia Deutsch 

 BODY:
In another sign that the advertising economy is still struggling, spending by advertisers in traditional media fell 5.9 percent in the first half of 2001 compared with the corresponding period a year earlier, according to CMR in New York, a unit of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending.
 Ad spending for the first half of this year totaled just under $47.5 billion, compared with $50.4 billion from January through June 2000. 
The medium with the highest percentage decrease was national spot radio, down 22.4 percent, to $1.03 billion from $1.3 billion, followed by spot television, down 14.7 percent, to $7.18 billion from $8.42 billion. The highest increases came in syndicated television, up 5.1 percent, to $1.62 billion from $1.54 billion, and cable television, up 4.6 percent, to $5.52 billion from $5.28 billion. 
 Although General Motors spent the most on advertising in the first half of 2001, CMR reported, at $1.1 billion, it also had the highest percentage decrease among the top advertisers, down 23.5 percent from $1.44 billion. AOL Time Warner had the highest percentage increase among the top advertisers, up 21.9 percent, to $734 million from $602 million.

HEADLINE: Army Meets Recruiting Goal Early and Credits Ad Effort 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
After struggling in the late 1990's to overcome the roaring economy and a stodgy image, the Army said today that it was experiencing its most successful recruiting year since at least 1997, having met its goals for the 2001 fiscal year one month early.
 While the Army used the announcement to boast about its new, much-debated slogan, "Army of One," and the $150 million advertising campaign built around it, experts said other factors were probably more responsible for the improved numbers, particularly the slowing economy. 
 Indeed, the other three services reported today that they were also on track to meet their recruiting goals for the fiscal year that ends on Sept. 30. And the Air Force said it was having its strongest recruiting year since 1986, though like the Army, it attributed its success to aggressive promotion rather than a tightening job market. 
To dramatize what Army officials described as a major turnabout in their recruiting fortunes, the Army held an elaborate event at the Pentagon today to swear into service its 75,800th recruit of the year: 19-year-old Rodrigo Vasquez III of Karnes City, Tex., who will begin basic training next week.
"A lot of people weren't quite sure that we crazy people were headed in the right direction," the Army secretary, Thomas E. White, said in a news conference. "Well, I tell you, the proof's in the pudding. You either make the numbers or you don't. And we have exceeded those numbers in the Army of One campaign. It's working."
Last year, the Army did not meet its recruiting goal until the last day of the fiscal year. And it missed its goals in the two preceding years: narrowly in 1998, and then badly in 1999, when it fell short by 6,291 recruits. 
The Army attributed those lean years largely to the strong economy siphoning off potential recruits into better-paying jobs. But the run of failures also embarrassed senior Army leaders and spurred much soul searching in the Clinton administration over whether the Army was out of touch with young Americans. 
As a result, the Army last year replaced its advertising firm of 13 years, Young & Rubicam, with Leo Burnett U.S.A. of Chicago. And in January, it dropped its slogan of 20 years, "Be all you can be," in favor of "Army of One," which has become the centerpiece of stylish new advertisements and an elaborate recruiting Web site, goarmy.com.
The new slogan immediately drew sharp criticism from some veterans and military analysts who said it emphasized individualism over collective action. Some analysts also scoffed at the Army for running the spots not just during sporting events, as was typical in the past, but during popular programs like "Friends" and "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," as well as on MTV and Comedy Central.
"I keep telling the old guys like me who are a little concerned about the nontraditional message that we're not recruiting you," Mr. White said. "So go ask your son or daughter or your grandson or granddaughter what turns them on, and that's where you're going to find the Army."
But some experts expressed doubts about the value of the new slogan and splashy marketing campaign, arguing that economic forces were more significant in determining recruiting results. 
"It was a fortuitous circumstance for the Army that their new slogan came out at the same time that the economy was weakening," said Charles Moskos, a professor of sociology at Northwestern University and an expert on military manpower issues.
Professor Moskos argued that the images of the armed services are shaped far more by current events than by advertising. As an example, he said that during a talk before military recruiters in 1996, he asked whether the audience would rather have their advertising budgets tripled or have Chelsea Clinton join the Army. 
"They unanimously raised their hands for the Chelsea option," he said.
Such arguments have not deterred the services from intensifying their marketing efforts over the past three years. In 1999, the Air Force began running television advertisements for the first time in its history. This year, the Navy tried to update its advertising by featuring a new theme, "Accelerate your life."
And the Marine Corps, which is the smallest service and rarely misses its recruiting goals, started buying advertising on stock cars last year and is preparing to roll out a new, sharply different advertising campaign this year.
Those efforts are clearly paying off, military officials asserted. The Air Force, for instance, met its recruiting goal for the 2001 fiscal year in May, when it signed a contract with its 34,600th recruit. That is the earliest the Air Force has met its annual goal since 1986, Air Force officials said. 
Army officials also attributed their improved recruiting to the goarmy.com Web site, which has featured two-minute video "Webisodes" tracking the boot-camp experiences of six recruits.
But the campaign experienced one public relations setback when a soldier who had been featured in one of the first Army of One commercials, Richard P. Lovett, voluntarily withdrew from a rigorous 24-day screening program for the Special Forces. Army officials said Corporal Lovett plans to try again this fall.
