HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Hardware: Decrease In Chip Sales 

BYLINE:  By Andrew Zipern (NYT) (Compiled by Gary Bradford) 

 BODY:
 Worldwide sales of semiconductors fell more than 37 percent in July, to $10.86 billion, said a prominent industry trade group yesterday. The quarterly global sales report, from the Semiconductor Industry Association, attributed the slackening to the economic slowdown and excess inventories, but also indicated that highly expected new products could lead to a turnaround by the end of the year. 
"We expect sales of personal computers, communications products and a variety of hand-held devices, including newly introduced digital audio products, will accelerate demand for a broad range of semiconductors," said George Scalise, president of the group, in a statement. July sales in the European market dropped 34 percent from the month a year ago; the Americas market was down 51.2 percent, and the Asia-Pacific market was down 29.7 percent. In the Japan market, sales declined 28.6 percent from last July. More than 90 percent of semiconductor producers based in the United States are members of the industry group. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

HEADLINE: BUSH AND DASCHLE AGREE NOT TO TAP SOCIAL SECURITY 

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
The White House and the Senate Democratic leader said today that they had agreed not to tap the Social Security program to pay the government's other bills, an agreement that economists insist is almost certain to be broken this year.
 After meeting with President Bush at the White House, the Democratic leader, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, said that he had pressed the president to promise not to dip into the Social Security program to make ends meet elsewhere, and that Mr. Bush had agreed. 
 "I was looking simply today for his assurance that we're not going to do that, and he assured me of that," Mr. Daschle said afterward. "We look forward to working with him and seeking his guidance on how we avoid using Social Security." 
The White House did not dispute Mr. Daschle's account of the meeting, which was called to discuss progress on the 13 annual spending bills that Congress is required to complete before the start of a new fiscal year on Oct. 1.
Claire Buchan, a White House spokeswoman, said Mr. Bush "believes we can fund America's priorities while protecting Social Security, and that is what the president has promised in his budget."
Despite the reassuring words from the president and Mr. Daschle, prominent economists and the Congressional Budget Office say the government will almost certainly be forced to dip into Social Security revenues later this year to cover shortfalls created by the sinking economy and by the $1.3 trillion tax-cut package that Mr. Bush pushed through Congress this year. 
Mr. Bush said today that he was "open-minded" about a Republican proposal that supporters say would quickly raise money for the government through a cut in the capital-gains tax -- but there is almost no chance of passage of the plan in the Democratic-controlled Senate.
The Senate minority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois and other Republicans want Mr. Bush to support a reduction in the capital gains tax. The plan's supporters said it would raise huge amounts of money for the government in its early stages, as investors sold off stocks and other holdings to take advantage of the reduced tax.
Democrats have long opposed a cut in the capital gains tax, saying it would disproportionately benefit the wealthy, and they could almost certainly block the proposal through their control of the Senate. Mr. Bush and his economic advisers have been less enthusiastic about the plan than their allies on Capitol Hill and on Wall Street.
Economic projections released last week by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office showed that at current spending levels, $9 billion would need to be taken from Social Security this year, with billions more diverted out of the retirement program over the next several years. 
The projections did not factor in tens of billions of dollars in military and education spending that Mr. Bush is expected to propose this year, which would suggest that even more money would need to be taken from Social Security to pay the government's bills. Any move to tap Social Security would violate a promise made repeatedly by Mr. Bush and by Congressional leaders during last year's campaign, and both the White House and Congressional Democrats appeared to be maneuvering today to duck blame for a move that is probably inevitable.
Although the use of Social Security revenues for other government programs would pose no threat to current recipients of the government's retirement system, it would be politically perilous and likely to become a divisive issue in next year's Congressional campaigns, especially in House districts where large numbers of voters depend on Social Security checks.
The White House repeated today that President Bush had no intention of tapping the Social Security surplus, which is expected total about $157 billion this year.
"Funding projects out of Social Security is something the president said he wanted to avoid doing, and he pledged not to do," said the White House spokesman, Ari Fleischer. He noted that the president had vowed to tap Social Security "only in the case of war or recession."
But later in the day, the president himself appeared testy when he was repeatedly questioned by reporters during a photo session over whether he would promise to veto bills that would require the use of the Social Security surplus elsewhere in the budget.
"I can say definitely every Social Security recipient is going to get their check, and that's what the American people need to understand," he said, refusing to answer the question directly. "I understand how politics works up here. There's always that scare tactic, trying to tell the American people that the budget process is going to lead them to not get their Social Security check. That's just ridiculous."
Asked again if he would veto bills that required tapping Social Security, he snapped, "I addressed your question."
Mr. Daschle has blamed Mr. Bush's tax-cut package for the disappearance of the government's non-Social Security surplus, and he said today that Mr. Bush would be responsible for finding a way of balancing the budget without dipping into Social Security.
"This is the president's budget, and we're looking to him for his guidance on how we do that," he said. "The Democrats are going to stay within the budget we have been given. We didn't agree to that budget, but we have lived within it so far."
According to the economic projections released last week by the Congressional Budget Office, it would be virtually impossible for Mr. Bush to preserve all the Social Security surplus without abandoning his plans for an $18 billion jump in the Pentagon's budget this year or without proposing sharp cuts in politically popular domestic programs.
Mr. Bush also met separately today with Mr. Lott, the Senate Republican leader, to discuss the appropriations process on Capitol Hill. And during a brief meeting with reporters as he began the session, Mr. Bush opened the door slightly to the proposal by Mr. Lott and others to balance the budget through a cut in the capital gains tax.
"I'm open-minded," he said. "I agree with the assessment that a capital gains tax would pile up some revenues early in the process." But Mr. Bush suggested that any proposal should wait until we "take a good look-see to make sure that the stimulus package that we're now implementing works."

HEADLINE: Staying Alive in a Crowded Race; 
Upside of Term Limits: Campaign Feels, Well, Democratic

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
On July 30, Heyward Dotson, a City Council candidate in District 7 in Manhattan, learned that he would not be on the primary ballot because of a flaw in his nominating petitions. He was reported to be distraught.
 At a candidates' forum the next night, a man identifying himself as Mr. Dotson's campaign manager announced that the candidate had died. Some who were present recall mention of a heart attack; others, a description of Mr. Dotson being carted out in a body bag. There was consternation. A moment of silence. Sympathetic speeches. The dispatch of flowers and condolence cards. And the news, a few days later, that Mr. Dotson was not dead at all. 
 A hoax? A tragicomic misunderstanding? The evidence is inconclusive. Mr. Dotson said that he had retreated to his mother's house in Staten Island after being disqualified, and returned home to learn he was dead. 
Then, as if one resurrection were not enough, a State Supreme Court judge restored him to the ballot for the election on Tuesday. "I survived," he said, not specifying to which of his comebacks he was referring.
The saga added even more color to a race already saturated with it. District 7 is sprawling and diverse, stretching from 123rd to 218th Street, covering Manhattanville, West Harlem, Hamilton Heights, Washington Heights and Inwood -- and it has a field befitting it. There are 10 Democrats on the primary ballot, so many that candidates start staking out subway stops at 6:30 a.m. because there are barely enough to go around.
The district, which, with its layers of history, its immigrant enclaves and its evolving ethnic and economic mix, could represent a microcosm of the city. There are an estimated 53,537 African-Americans, probably the district's largest voting bloc, living in housing projects, freshly renovated brownstones and everything in between. In Washington Heights and, increasingly, in West Harlem, there is a large Dominican population. An estimated 47 percent of the district's 162,232 residents are Hispanic (although just over 4,000 Hispanics appear to have voted in the last primary, according to an analysis conducted by the campaign of Daryl G. Bloodsaw).
In Inwood and Washington Heights, there are Irish-Americans and Orthodox Jews, along with a growing number of gays, artists and actors (not to mention gay artists and actors). There are more whites moving to West Harlem (although there are fewer whites in the district as a whole since 1990), the vestiges of a Cuban population and the beginnings of a Russian colony.
The district will be selecting a new councilman for the first time since the 1978 election of Stanley E. Michels, who cannot run again because of the city's new term-limits law. Mr. Michels opposed term limits, and he concedes that his district has yielded an abundance -- some say an overabundance -- of candidates with records of activism and achievement. "Very good people," he said.
State Senator David Paterson called it "a great race -- a classic," and added, "It is exactly what term limits was designed to create."
Indeed, the upside of term limits is evident in the energy and enthusiasm of the candidates: each one believes success is possible. (And there are no polls that say otherwise.) Maybe because of that wide-open feeling, and because many of the candidates know each other, the race has a cozy, democratic feel. And since the Council primary will probably draw at most 15,000 votes, personal contacts -- made by knocking on doors, visiting street fairs or cruising stoop-sitters at night -- might matter a great deal.
This is making for some exhausted candidates. "Sprawling is not the word," said one of them, Jackie Rowe-Adams, of the district's size. "Out of control is the word."
It was not that way when Mr. Michels was first elected. But when the Council map was redrawn in 1990, District 7 was stretched like Gumby. The end result had the shape of an ungainly lobster, with one claw oversized and the other emaciated.
Mr. Michels, who is white, said the district had been reconfigured to enable a black candidate's election. "I fooled them," he said.
But this year, a black candidate may have the edge. That would be Robert Jackson, a field services director for the New York State Public Employees Federation, a tenant leader, and a school board president. But he is best known as the lead plaintiff in the successful lawsuit brought by the Campaign for Fiscal Equity against the state to secure more money for city schools. He is in a district with some of the city's most crowded schools, making education his campaign's focus.
Mr. Jackson was hand-picked as a candidate by Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell, the Manhattan Democratic leader, well before the lawsuit was won. Mr. Farrell is managing the campaign's details, even designing posters and mailings. As a result, the other candidates are referring to Mr. Jackson as the machine candidate.
Mr. Jackson's reply: "I'm no one's yes person. I'm an independent person who works collaboratively."
Mr. Jackson has some important endorsements, including, in recent days, Mr. Michels, who had been thought to be tacitly backing another candidate, Mark D. Levine; and C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president.
But he is no shoo-in. There are plenty of other viable contenders, including Mr. Levine, who founded a community-based credit union in Washington Heights that has made hundreds of loans and last year expanded to a second branch in West Harlem. Mr. Levine has made economic development his main issue.
He is one of two candidates who show how Council races can become big-money races. He has raised $110,174, 14th out of all candidates citywide. His contributions include $2,500 apiece from Courtney Love, Gwyneth Paltrow, David Geffen, Jeffrey Katzenberg and Edward Norton, a childhood friend. 
He has also raised a significant amount from his hometown of Columbia, Md., for a total of $58,005 from out of the city.
The other big-money candidate is Mario A. Torres, a vice president at the Battery Park City Authority, where he has helped female and minority-owned businesses gain access to the authority's contracting opportunities. He has raised $89,681, including a significant amount from construction and real estate businesses, but has also returned some $10,000 in contributions. Still, he has raised enough -- including $32,689 from out of the city -- to place 28th out of all Council candidates.
Mr. Torres, whose campaign pledges included everything from more computers in schools to more money for the district's parks, comes across as a political professional, complete with a press secretary. He officially began his campaign with a catered affair, with wine and beer, at the Dyckman Marina, and rented a bus to bring up residents of the Grant Houses to thank them for supporting his petition drive.
Daryl G. Bloodsaw, an advertising and marketing executive, has not raised much money, but has a cadre of zealously dedicated, mostly female, volunteers. He has made West Harlem's drug problem -- it is widely considered the cocaine wholesaling center of the Northeast -- the central issue of his campaign. In February, he organized a "state of emergency" summit about the drug problem with elected officials that is credited with helping to spark a police crackdown in recent months.
Mr. Jackson, Mr. Levine and Mr. Bloodsaw are the only candidates to receive matching funds from the city so far, meaning that they met the requirement of raising a total of $5,000 from 50 voters in their district.
More candidates: Tony Spencer has been active in West Harlem/Hamilton Heights for about 30 years. He is New York City Director of the National Black Leadership Commission on AIDS, and a lieutenant colonel in the National Guard. He, too, sees the drug trade as a major issue. "I love Stanley and think he did a wonderful job," he said of Mr. Michels, "but he didn't grab this before it got out of hand."
Victor Armando Bernace graduated from Harvard Law School, taught high school in the Bronx, and now runs a law practice helping mostly Dominican cabdrivers resolve traffic disputes. He put $7,500 of his own money into the race.
Mr. Dotson was the first Rhodes Scholar from Staten Island and a star basketball player at Columbia University. He worked for Alan G. Hevesi and Assemblyman Keith Wright, and describes himself as "the only pro-tenant candidate in the race," saying the district is facing a crisis of affordable housing.
Jackie Rowe-Adams is the only woman in the race. She is a former community board and school board member and works as recreation manager for Jackie Robinson and Morningside Park, which she says she took "back from the drug dealers." She called herself "the people's candidate."
Michael Hughes is a reporter for the Washington Heights-Inwood Report, who looks and talks as if he is an old-time policeman. "I've been here 44 years, during the gangs and the drugs in the 70's and the crack epidemic," he said. "It makes me step back to see these guys coming in now that crime's down -- now their biggest issue is cars double parking and dogs barking." Pedro Morillo, another candidate, did not return a reporter's phone call.
Most of these candidates are pointing to their biographies along with their records. Mr. Bernace told of his experiences in foster care and as the child of a welfare mother. Ms. Rowe-Adams described losing two sons to urban violence. Mr. Levine's literature features his Puerto Rican wife, while Mr. Hughes frequently mentions that his wife is of Caribbean descent. Robert Jackson volunteers that his campaign director is a white woman.
Daryl G. Bloodsaw, meanwhile, was Daryl G. Barnes until a few years ago. He said he changed his name to honor his mother.
The candidates have been collegial, even complimentary, toward each other. But occasionally the gloves have come off. When the announcement of Mr. Dotson's death was made, Mr. Bernace rose to say that Mr. Dotson had been removed from the ballot because the "Democratic machine" challenged his petitions, and that Mr. Dotson had been devastated.
The machine, Mr. Bernace said, had killed him.
A resuscitated Mr. Dotson, in turn, implied that the county organization had helped spread the false rumors of his demise.

HEADLINE: Today's Special? Discounts All Around 

BYLINE:  By FLORENCE FABRICANT 

 BODY:
IN the heyday of New York restaurants -- which faded something like the day before yesterday -- there was often that tendency to beg just a little. You might turn on your most charming telephone voice to negotiate a reservation, for instance. Or act just a little too grateful for small favors in the dining room.
 Being allowed into the place at all (with just an hour's wait at the bar) was a privilege. Courteous, prompt service was a gift. A visit from the chef? Wonderful. And did that little repast cost less than a week's salary? A bargain. 
 Anyway, if you didn't take advantage of all this treasure, you were sure someone else was right behind you who would. And that wasn't paranoid -- it was often true. 
But, my fellow diners, the tables have turned. With the general economic regression, competition from new places opening on every corner and the growing fear of a catastrophic dining slump in this restaurant metropolis, many of the once confident culinary establishments are now the ones doing the pleading. To keep those tables filled, they're trying everything from newfound graciousness to gimmicks that would seem familiar on supermarket coupons.
A number of restaurants are offering special menus designed to be less expensive, there are more straightforward discounts on dinner these days, free or cheap wine is increasingly common, and as part of the meal deal there might even be savings on completely unrelated products, like 10 percent off at a music store.
Promotions are nothing new in the restaurant business, of course. What's dazzling now is the pervasiveness of the marketing ploys, the sheer creativity of some of them, and the candid admissions that they are being driven by a deepening anxiety in a city that may have opened more restaurants than it can handle, especially in the current business climate.
Alan Stillman, the chairman of the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, never a stranger to the world of promotion, is pegging the price of Friday's lunch in all his group's restaurants to the Nasdaq close on Thursday, and offering Champagne with dinner at the Manhattan Ocean Club.
At some restaurants, the uninitiated may not immediately recognize how much the establishment is willing to sacrifice: the $65 two-course lunch at Alain Ducasse is less than half the going rate for the standard lunch. And the discount lunch includes wine.
Several months ago, Strip House began offering a low-price Sunday evening wine list. Peter Glazier, an owner, said the promotion would be introduced in his other restaurants, Monkey Bar and Michael Jordan's: The Steak House, at the end of the month.
"Restaurants are losing 12 to 15 percent right now," Mr. Glazier said. "You have to find new sources of revenue. That's why we're starting to serve breakfast at Jordan's and we're turning the retail shop into a lounge." 
At Chicama in the Flatiron district, Douglas Rodriguez is setting up a frequent-diner discount and rebate program with a special membership card. At Union Pacific in the Flatiron district, where tasting dinners can cost $155, Rocco DiSpirito, the chef and co-owner, is also taking aggressive steps. "I want this place to represent more than just special-occasion dining," he said. "There are several Off Broadway theaters around here, so I'm adding a two-course pretheater dinner for $45, and I'm hoping to set a slightly less formal tone."
You could call it a classy version of the early-bird special. 
Other restaurateurs, not just in New York, have joined a discount reservation service. Dinner Broker, a company that went online about a year ago (www.dinnerbroker.com) with a system of off-peak restaurant discounts (and also the flip side, surcharges for hard-to-get prime-time reservations), now has about 300 restaurant accounts in more than 36 American cities, and in Toronto, Vancouver and London. 
"When we started, about two-thirds of our business was for the premium reservations, but it's changed and now about 80 percent of it is discounts," said Ben Dehan, the chairman. 
The special $20.01 lunches -- a promotion that began in New York with $19.92 lunches in 1992 -- have stretched summer-long. This year, 42 places will continue the lunches through December, double the number that offered them until the end of the year last year. Boston began a similar promotion this summer. The complete list of New York restaurants offering the lunch special is available from the Convention and Visitors Bureau, 810 Seventh Avenue, or from www.nycvisit.com.
For many of the top restaurants, and those with a loyal neighborhood clientele, making sure that the customers are happy may be enough. But these days, across the board, restaurateurs have recognized that they can't afford to sit on their laurels. As Mr. Dehan put it, "the most expensive thing in a restaurant, for the restaurateur, is an empty table."
Here are some special promotions.

HEADLINE: Business Travel; 
The debate over airport runways continues as readers respond to proposals by Delta's chief.

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
This is the second installment of comments from readers responding to Leo F. Mullin, chief executive of Delta Air Lines. In an interview in an earlier column, Mr. Mullin had insisted that the best way to deal with mounting airport delays and congestion was to build 50 miles of new runways at major airports.
 "THERE is no passenger-capacity crisis at the nation's airports," contended Joe Brancatelli, who writes an outspoken online travel column for Biztravel.com. 
 "The problem is an aircraft problem," he said. "Airlines continue to add more flights using smaller aircraft, and then they expect the American people to pay for their arrogance -- in which they push smaller planes through an overtaxed hub-and-spoke system."
Gerald Rothstein added: "Smaller planes have been substituted for larger ones on virtually all routes. When airline managers ignore the effects of this on congestion and just blame the government -- and neighborhood activists opposed to airport expansion -- they are just trying to deflect the blame from themselves."
Joseph E. Illick of San Francisco objects to airports gobbling up more land. "Leo F. Mullin's attitude toward airport expansion -- it must happen, no matter what the human and environmental cost, because the economy demands it -- reflects not only an arrogant stance toward humanity and the environment, but a narrow-minded view of what constitutes the economy," he said. "Mr. Mullin likens the air transport system of today to the rail system of a century ago. And look what has happened to the railroads. Is it not possible that 100 years hence our progeny will see abandoned airstrips?"
Don Carlson asked: "Where is it written that airline profits take precedence over the interests of people who are affected by the 50 miles of new runways he wants to build across the country? No, thanks, Mr. Mullin. I'm a business traveler, but I don't want the public to pay your price for my convenience."
Karen McClellan, vice president of the aviation division for the Institute for International Research, offers some encouragement for Delta's boss.
"It is refreshing to see a C.E.O. be articulate in what needs to happen to increase airport capacity," she said, adding that other solutions include perhaps increasing "airspace capacity" by revising current standards for keeping planes five miles apart, as well as using new technologies that enable closer takeoffs and landings.
John Heilner, a travel management consultant, said, "The solution involves aggressive use of peak, off-peak pricing of flights." He suggested that "significant differentials" of 25 to 50 percent in landing fees be imposed for peak hours at high-volume airports, for a trial period. "Savings on off-peak flights must be large enough to motivate a change in behavior and a shift in demand to these flights," he said.
Eric Oddleifson of Cohasset, Mass., suggested that "the polluters (i.e., the airlines) pay for the damage they will inflict" in increased noise and in decreased property values for people living near airports. "There are 65 million people affected by jet noise and emissions pollution" living in areas where jet noise ranges from significant to severe, he said. 
Meanwhile, he welcomes an emerging "new paradigm" involving increased use by businesses of small aircraft that carry six to eight passengers and fly among lesser used regional airports. "These aircraft are quiet, efficient, and utilize the 3,000 existing airports," rather than just the 25 major hubs where congestion is centered, he said.
James Fallows, the author of "Free Flight: From Airline Hell to a New Age of Travel" (PublicAffairs, 2001), said that the proposal for major runway additions "illustrates the limit the airline system is unavoidably hitting." He added, "It is fundamental to the airlines' pricing model that traffic be concentrated in hubs," which accounts for a disproportionate increase in congestion at major airports.
Laying down ever more runways is "politically unrealistic and conceptually weak," he said. As he did in his book, Mr. Fallows contended that novel aircraft designs advanced by NASA and others will usher in a new aviation era in which small, efficient and cheap corporate and owner-operated jets will help alleviate hub congestion by acting as "air taxis" with vastly expanded use of smaller regional airports. 
James Trunzo, an architect in Boca Raton, Fla., argued that "short-term patches," like building more runways, simply added to the "confused mess we call airports today." 
"There is a complete failure to integrate transportation systems -- that is, all of the cars, trucks, buses and trains that should ideally flow seamlessly and efficiently in your travels," he said. "Is it unreasonable to ask for organization and simplicity of purpose to all that concrete and glass?" he asked of airports, calling for smarter "big picture" planning focused on a "fully integrated model" incorporating the "entire surrounding transportation infrastructure," rather than the mere "piling on" of more runways.
Mark Brennan of New York wrote: "Building more runways sounds like a good solution until one recognizes that the real problem is that runways today (and presumably those to be added in the future) are not allocated economically. We have heavy demand for runways because the price of using one is the same regardless of whether I land on it by myself in a private plane, or a 747 with 400 passengers uses the same strip."
The problem will persist, he said, "until we charge usage fees for runways" by "auctioning off the landing rights" to the highest bidders.
Baylor Lancaster of New York objected to Mr. Mullin's comment that runway construction needs to take the same priority over neighborhood opposition as highway construction often does. Runway expansion, like highway expansion, will only lead to more traffic, she said, offering the notorious snarls of the highways in Atlanta, Delta's home, as an example. 
"Besides, if the number of runways were increased, where exactly does Mr. Mullin propose parking all those extra planes once they've landed?" she asked. "You can be sure Mr. Mullin would be back in your column arguing for larger terminals soon after the new runways were finished, no doubt causing additional 'community disruption.' "
Dan Woog of Westport, Conn., took issue with estimates cited by Mr. Mullin and others that domestic air traffic will necessarily grow to a billion a year from the current 680 million. "There are only a million or so variables that could come into play, ranging from a stunning rise in videoconferencing (and no, not with today's technology), to a global recession," he wrote.
James Baird accused airline executives of a "tradition of poor planning" and suggested they get on a plane and visit countries like Japan that have adapted to worse runway shortages than ours. 
"Tokyo, one of the world's largest metro areas with over 25 million people, is served by two airports with a total of three runways," he said. "Take-off delays are minimal," he added, because "virtually all aircraft are wide-bodies" big planes like 747's that carry 500 passengers. 
Though Amtrak conceded recently that its nearly year-old experience with high-speed rail between new York and Boston has had disappointing results, fully integrated rail systems work well elsewhere, Mr. Baird said, adding, "Short distances, 300 miles or less, are efficiently supplemented by high-speed rail."

HEADLINE: Detroit's Big Three May Shuffle as Chrysler Struggles 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
General Motors. Ford. Toyota?
 The overseas assault on Detroit's Big Three continued yesterday as the Chrysler Group reported that its August sales fell 24 percent from the year-earlier period. That surprised analysts and led some to wonder if the continuing sales gains by Toyota Motor would lead it to become the nation's third-largest automaker, vaulting past Chrysler, a unit of DaimlerChrysler. 
 "It seems inevitable that this is going to happen," said Stephen J. Girsky, a Morgan Stanley analyst. "You'll have to redefine the Big Three as G.M., Ford and Toyota." 
Chrysler's sharp sales decline came as the auto industry reported overall sales in August at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 16.4 million vehicles, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank, a data service in Southfield, Mich.
While that shows a slowdown from the surprisingly strong first half of the year and the record pace of last year, analysts and economists say it is still historically strong. The industry is on pace to have its third-best sales year. But, they add, General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler are likely to continue to struggle as foreign automakers flood the sports utility vehicle market.
Diane C. Swonk, chief economist for Bank One, said the industry sales number was evidence that American consumers were resilient. But domestic automakers, she said, have something to worry about.
Since Chrysler became a unit of DaimlerChrysler in 1998, it has been losing market share. Last November, Daimler sent Dieter Zetsche, a top German executive, to take over as Chrysler's chief executive to stem the losses. In the first half of this year, the company lost about $1.3 billion as his turnaround plan began. 
Though all of the Big Three have suffered this year, Ford and G.M. held up better against the gains foreign brands like Toyota, Lexus and BMW made in sport utility vehicles in August. G.M. reported a 7 percent decline in overall sales, but an increase of 7.1 percent in light trucks, which includes S.U.V.'s. Ford reported a 7.5 percent decline in overall sales, but only a 1.5 percent drop in light trucks. 
Chrysler, meanwhile, had a market share of 11.3 percent of the United States vehicle market in August, according to a projection by David Bradley, an analyst at J. P. Morgan Chase. By comparison, Toyota has 10.9 percent of the American market. Most analysts said that the August margin between the two was the slimmest yet seen. "If I look back over history, I can't find a market share that low for at least a decade," said Mr. Bradley, referring to Chrysler. "It's pretty bad."
For the year, through August, Chrysler has a 13.5 percent market share of the United States car and truck market, according to a projection by Gary Lapidus, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs. Toyota has a 10.1 percent market share. That represents a full percentage point decline for Chrysler compared with the first eight months of last year, and a full percentage point increase for Toyota.
"I find them disconcerting," Mr. Lapidus said of Chrysler's declining market share. "The numbers are pointing up for Toyota and down for Chrysler."
The sales figures "don't thrill us, by any means," said Christine Cortez, a vice president for sales and marketing for the Chrysler Group. Ms. Cortez said there were two factors that mitigated the August sales slump. 
In August 2000, sales were unusually high because Chrysler was trying to sell its excess supply of minivans at reduced prices. And this August, it had fewer older-model Ram pickup trucks to sell because it had been readying a new model for the fall.
But analysts said that could not explain all of the declines. The company's sport utilities, which fell 27 percent, were hit hard. Though Chrysler has made some inroads with its new Jeep Liberty, sales of the Grand Cherokee were off 40 percent compared with August 2000. 
"We have so many new competitors," Ms. Cortez said. "We have so much going on in that segment."
At Toyota, sales jumped 7.2 percent in August, including a 23.6 percent increase in sales of light trucks like the Tacoma pickup and the Highlander sport utility vehicle.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Don't Count On It

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
In the 1970's and 1980's one often read about remote mountain villages where people stayed healthy and vigorous into their 90's, with some individuals reaching extraordinary ages. How did people in these simple, traditional societies achieve such longevity? 
 The answer, it turned out, was that people in simple, traditional societies aren't very good at counting. There were some quite old people in those villages, but they weren't as old as they thought they were. Of course, one reason people were vague about their ages was that in their societies nothing important hinged on getting the numbers right. 
 In one respect, the story of our vaunted "new economy" is similar. In the last few years of the 1990's the data just kept getting better, culminating in an estimated 5 percent growth rate for real G.D.P. in 2000 -- not an unusual growth rate for a poor country playing catch-up, or for an economy recovering from a recession, but amazing for an advanced economy late in an economic expansion. How did we do it?
The answer, it seems, is that we weren't very good at counting. Last month's revision by government statisticians marked down U.S. growth rates in each of the last three years, with the biggest markdown for 2000. At 4.1 percent growth was good, but not as good as we thought it was. 
But there's one difference between us and the villagers: In our society numbers matter a great deal, and fuzzy math can have nasty consequences.
It's clear in retrospect that we shouldn't have taken the original estimates of economic growth too seriously. Anyone who has looked at how economic statistics are constructed knows that they are based as much on educated guesswork as on hard facts. And the guesswork gets more speculative as the economy's center of gravity shifts away from solid, physical products to more ethereal stuff; the biggest item in last month's revision involved a reduction in estimates of business investment in software.
Nonetheless, people who should have known better treated the estimated growth rates as solid data, and in particular took to heart their apparent message that the best was yet to come. According to the figures, the U.S. economy wasn't just growing fast, it was growing at an accelerating pace. And if that continued, all of our worries about the long run -- about the burdens of providing pensions and health care to an aging population -- would simply melt away in the face of a red-hot economy. 
Chief among the what-me-worriers was none other than Alan Greenspan. His crucial January testimony in favor of big tax cuts began with a paean of praise for the productivity revolution, "the key factor driving the cumulative upward revisions in the budget picture," and cited with approval long-term projections of an "on-budget surplus under baseline assumptions well past 2030." Seven months later the productivity estimates had been revised downward, and the on-budget surplus was gone.
Mr. Greenspan is still optimistic about long-run growth, as are many other people; they argue that a productivity revolution driven by information technology has decades to run. I would respectfully submit, however, that these optimists have no idea what they are talking about. I don't mean that they're necessarily wrong; I mean that history has repeatedly made fools of people who try to predict future technological developments, let alone the implications of those developments for long-term economic growth. 
And most of the mistakes have been in the same direction. Since the 1960's, futurists have consistently overestimated the future rate of technological progress and economic growth. (Rent "2001: A Space Odyssey" or read Herman Kahn's "The Year 2000" if you don't believe me.) The only major upside surprise was the productivity surge from 1995 to 2000 -- and that, it turns out, was partly a figment of our statistical imagination. 
So how should our society conduct itself now that the recent past is not what it used to be? Any villager could tell you the answer: Hope for good news but don't count on it. That is, don't commit yourself to tax cuts and spending promises you may not be able to afford.
But of course we have already made those commitments. So the question becomes, will our leaders ever admit that they made a mistake, that we may not be able to afford the full tax cut after all? And the answer is obvious: We should live so long.

HEADLINE: Kim Struggles As Ministers Quit in Seoul 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SEOUL, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
As President Kim Dae Jung struggled to rebuild his government after a mass cabinet resignation, it appeared today that the big loser may have been his "sunshine policy" toward North Korea, the outstretched hand that is widely admired overseas but increasingly derided at home.
 Overseas, Mr. Kim is known for winning the Nobel Peace Prize after he visited Pyongyang last year in an attempt to bridge a half-century of enmity on the Korean Peninsula. But at home, his popularity has withered on the vine, falling in opinion polls from 80 percent in the hopeful days of the Pyongyang summit meeting to below 20 percent today. 
 Plagued by economic worries, South Koreans say they are fed up with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, who accepted food aid but then cut off the family reunification visits that began last year after the summit meeting, and who demands free electricity but has refused to fulfill promises on opening north-south road and rail links. Most galling, the North Korean leader has yet to reciprocate Mr. Kim's gesture with a visit to South Korea.
"The sunshine policy is failing, because the government just pushes money into North Korea," Chang Sung Hee, an assistant marketing manager, said here today. "It seems that North Korea just gets what it wants. While South Korea keeps giving this money, in the end we are getting nothing. We feel really dumb and stupid."
In March, South Korean officials were angered when President Bush appeared to pull the rug out from President Kim at a joint news conference in Washington. Mr. Bush expressed skepticism that North Koreans would live up to international pacts and said that the negotiation policy was under review.
Afterward, the North suspended all official contacts with the South.
Six weeks ago, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said on a visit here that the administration backed the sunshine policy, adding that the United States was prepared to meet the North Koreans "anywhere, at anytime" with "no preconditions."
Washington and Pyongyang have not yet held high-level meetings. 
As weeks turned into months, President Kim looked increasingly desperate as he virtually begged the North Korean leader to come on down for a visit. Although the North Korean leader had the time this year for a trip to China and a 24-day train tour of Russia, he has not had time for Mr. Kim, a liberal politician who staked his career on the opening to the North.
On Sunday, the North Koreans apparently realized that they had overplayed their hand as the South Korean National Assembly prepared to vote a motion of no confidence in Unification Minister Lim Dong Won, point man for the sunshine policy. In a clumsy last-minute move, North Korean officials wrote a letter to Mr. Lim saying that after a six-month hiatus they were ready to talk again.
It was too late. On Monday, President Kim's critics rode a wave of skepticism and won an overwhelming vote of no confidence.
The vote fractured President Kim's parliamentary majority and prompted all cabinet ministers and senior staffers to submit resignations. Today, a presidential spokesman said a new cabinet would be announced by the end of the week.
But the crisis, growing as politicians are gearing for the presidential race in December 2002, makes President Kim look like a lame duck before his time. In South Korea, a president cannot run for re-election.
"He is kind of stunned," said Park Nei Hei, dean of business at Sogang University. "I don't think he can push as hard as he used to. He will have lots of trouble with every issue he faces." 
From sidewalks to editorial columns today, the criticism largely centered on anger over the stalled sunshine policy.
"We give too much," said Cheol Soo Kim, manager of a paper company. "We don't have any results after three years of talks. Only 200 family members made reunification visits."
Support is eroding for aid to the North as South Koreans watch their economic growth rate slide, hitting 2.7 percent for the second quarter of the year compared with 9.7 percent in the same quarter last year.
"Kim Jong Il should have honored his promise to make a return visit before the post-summit euphoria cooled down in the South," The Korea Herald editorialized this evening. "He should not have exploited President Kim's vision and good will."
The sunshine policy is not dead, President Kim pledged today. "I will push forward with the sunshine policy without being distracted," he said at a luncheon here.
"I will make efforts to improve North-South Korean relations and North Korea-U.S. relations," he said, referring to a meeting here next month with President Bush. South Koreans hope that by visiting this modern capital, within easy range of North Korean artillery, Mr. Bush will be impressed by the importance of negotiating with the North.
With the North Koreans now talking again about talking, Seoul is widely expected to respond in a few days with a formal proposal to resume cabinet-level talks.
The effort to normalize relations on the peninsula received a big boost today from President Jiang Zemin of China, who arrived on Monday in North Korea. Mr. Jiang is the first Chinese head of state to visit the secretive country in 11 years.
According to the New China News Agency, Mr. Jiang urged his North Korean counterpart to improve relations with the United States and Japan, saying China would "support all rational proposals to this end." Mr. Jiang also discussed sharing electricity and food aid to North Korea, a country where poor weather and Communist farming practices contributed to widespread hunger that might have killed up to two million people in the 1990's.
In Beijing today, a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman said Kim Jong Il would be welcome to attend the meeting of Asia-Pacific leaders next month in Shanghai. 
But the short-term window for working with South Korea may be this fall. After the presidential campaign season starts in January, a visit by the North Korean leader could quickly spiral into a partisan issue. And a victory by the conservative opposition party, the Grand National Party, could signal a change of course for relations with the North.
"The time factor is critical," Mr. Park, the university dean, said of President Kim. "People already call him a lame-duck president."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Jiang Zemin of China, left, being welcomed in Pyongyang by North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, at the start of a three-day visit. (Korea News Service via Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Rivals Covet Giuliani's Crime Data, Not His Ways 

BYLINE:  By KEVIN FLYNN 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gets mixed reviews from many of the men who want his job, but not when it comes to crime. All six major candidates have acknowledged his crime-fighting prowess. Yet even as they assure voters that they will retain successful anticrime strategies, the Democratic candidates on the Tuesday primary ballot are outlining tactics that differ sharply from Mr. Giuliani's approach.
 Mr. Giuliani funneled more than $80 million a year into a program known as Operation Condor, which pays officers to work a sixth day in a week. Several candidates have called it a waste of money. 
 The mayor's police commanders often de-emphasized neighborhood beat patrols in favor of putting specialized units in high-crime areas. Several candidates have said they would reverse that policy. 
Aggressive street units that stopped and searched people in hopes of finding career criminals or illegal guns were viewed by the Giuliani administration as an essential enforcement tool. Several candidates have said the units were overused and often used racial profiling in deciding whom to stop.
In fact, in matters of both substance and tone, many aspects of the crime plans put forward by the Democrats bear little resemblance to those pursued by Mr. Giuliani. On the Republican side, both Michael R. Bloomberg and Herman Badillo have said they will largely continue Mr. Giuliani's program, aside from a minor tweak here or there.
"This election," Mr. Badillo said in an interview, "is about whether we want to continue the progress that the city has made under Giuliani or whether we want to go back to the situation as it was in 1992."
As Democrats often note, crime began to dip in the Dinkins administration, but the decline accelerated greatly under Mr. Giuliani and now stands at a 30-year low. Whether any candidate will be able to match Mr. Giuliani's record will remain an unanswered question for many months.
Certainly other cities, like San Diego, have enjoyed drops in crime without using New York's approach, and some criminologists say a robust economy and a decline in the use of crack had as much to do with falling crime rates as any police strategy.
"Rudy was the beneficiary of some demographic trends," Mr. Bloomberg said in an interview. "But to not give Rudy credit for making a difference in this city seems to be ridiculous."
The Democrats -- Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president; City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi; Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker; and the public advocate, Mark Green -- have largely avoided criticizing the effectiveness of Mr. Giuliani's crime-fighting strategy and focused instead on the extent to which they say that strategy undermined the Police Department's relationship with blacks and Hispanics.
All of them have expressed respect for Compstat, a Giuliani innovation in which commanders began to use computers to map crime patterns. All have said they would continue to hold commanders accountable for crime in their precincts, as Mr. Giuliani has. Several, including Mr. Ferrer, have said they would continue efforts to seize illegal guns. Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Vallone even said they would consider retaining Mr. Giuliani's current police commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik. The commissioner has since said that he will leave with Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Hevesi said in an interview that he credited Mr. Giuliani with having "brought in the best brains in police science, lots of initiatives here in police methodologies that are now being replicated all over the country and the world."
Yet when they detail their own crime-fighting approaches, the Democrats express varying degrees of dissatisfaction with many of the core tactics that Mr. Giuliani's commanders employed.
Mr. Hevesi said he thought that many of the strategies, developed to respond to rampant crime, were no longer suited to a city in which crime has declined.
"Continuing to reduce the crime rates, we want to keep doing that," he said in an interview. "But you do that by heavier doses of community policing. That's requiring precinct commanders to be in regular, institutionalized contact with community leaders, church leaders, elected officials, to develop a focus, to develop priorities, to develop strategies. It's to put cops on the beat who have good relationships with the store owners and with the local community groups so that there is an exchange of information, so that there's trust."
Mr. Vallone similarly said that, for all the success of Mr. Giuliani's task forces, like undercover units that patrolled to seize guns, he wants to see officers posted in places where they are a visible deterrent.
"I want to see these cops," Mr. Vallone said in an interview. "I want to see them in the community. I don't want this -- what Mayor Giuliani has done, to my great chagrin, is to de-emphasize neighborhood community policing, patrol strength in precincts, and emphasize to a greater extent than necessary the centralization of the police and sending them out whenever a problem occurs."
Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Green have expressed similar support for community policing. Mr. Ferrer has even suggested that Mr. Green should explain why he has accepted support from William J. Bratton, Mr. Giuliani's first police commissioner, who Mr. Ferrer contends shares responsibility for what he characterized as divisive patrol strategies.
"Community policing was dismantled in the very opening days of the Giuliani-Bratton police administration," he said. "That planted the seeds for an enormous number of problems that we've seen develop over the last eight years."
Mr. Bratton has said the patrol tactics he began were necessary at the time, but should have been replaced after he left as commissioner with less aggressive strategies because crime had declined.
For their part, police officials maintain that they have been practicing community policing for years, but they define the concept differently. Instead of assigning young officers to walk beats and serve as neighborhood problem solvers, they said that commanders had been designated to direct the community policing effort by meeting with community leaders in their precincts. 
In general, Mr. Giuliani's police commanders have shied away from enforcement strategies that spread officers across a precinct to patrol individual blocks, or beats. Officers deployed in such sentrylike fashion, a Giuliani police official once said, resembled scarecrows who could not do much to frighten the birds.
Instead, the favored approach for several years has been to concentrate officers in areas with identified crime problems, as indicated by the pin dots on a crime map, even if that meant leaving more placid areas lightly patrolled.
Jack Maple, the late police strategist credited with devising many of the department's recent tactics, called the approach "putting the cops on dots."
In the last year, Mr. Kerik has tried to increase precinct staffing a bit, in part to address complaints about a lack of manpower in some neighborhoods. But the primary deployment strategy, officials said, continues to be the assignment of officers not as deterrents but as pursuers who track criminals in areas where crime is most prevalent.
In many instances, commanders looking to pay for the extra concentration of officers in a high-crime areas have used overtime money provided through Operation Condor. Police officials have called the program an essential tool. 
But several Democrats, including Mr. Green, have called it wasteful. Mr. Green said it was difficult to fathom why the city needed to pay so much overtime when it already employs what is by far the largest municipal police force in the country.
"I'd rather invest $15 million in Beacon schools and the Family Rehabilitation Program than in unnecessary overtime for Operation Condor," he said in a speech this year.
Mr. Green said he agreed that the police should stop and search people acting suspiciously, but he said the Giuliani administration had allowed the number of unwarranted stops to grow unchecked.
"There is extraordinary anecdotal and statistical evidence that there is a level of racial profiling on the streets of New York, where such a high percentage of young black and Latino men are stopped, frisked and harassed for no serious law enforcement reason," Mr. Green said in an interview.
Mr. Vallone, Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Hevesi have all voiced similar concerns that the police under Mr. Giuliani did not pay sufficient attention to civil liberties. But they said their attention to those concerns should not obscure their support for the rigorous enforcement of the law, including "quality of life" offenses.
"I want the pendulum to swing to the middle," Mr. Ferrer said in an interview. "It should not take a wild swing. I happen to believe in proactive policing, and that should not shock anybody."

HEADLINE: A NEW COMPUTER GIANT: THE OVERVIEW; 
Bold Move Will Test Executive's Skill

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Only a month ago, there were doubts about Carleton S. Fiorina's longevity as the chief executive of the Hewlett-Packard Company. H.P., as the big computer and printer maker is known, was suffering badly in the industry slump. The Silicon Valley rumor mill, analyst comments and media reports all suggested that Ms. Fiorina, 46, was in trouble.
 The speculative chorus became so loud that a few Hewlett-Packard board members spoke out in her defense, but the questions persisted. 
 Many of those doubts have been erased for the moment, particularly inside the company, with the announcement on Monday that Hewlett-Packard plans to buy Compaq Computer, a deal that would make Ms. Fiorina the leader of a combined company that will rival I.B.M. in size and reach. Both Ms. Fiorina, who joined Hewlett-Packard two years ago, and her bold move have been endorsed by the board. 
"Carly embarked on a several-year strategy when she came to H.P., and we knew there would some tough times," one board member said. "We're not happy about the company's performance recently, and no one could have predicted the steep falloff in technology spending in the economy."
"But the board is behind her totally and totally behind her strategy," the director said.
Yet Ms. Fiorina, her leadership skills and her blueprint for a new Hewlett-Packard will be tested in the coming days and months, analysts said. In the fast-moving computer industry, big mergers rarely succeed. The companies involved tend to focus on combining operations and lose their competitive edge, a pitfall that hampered Compaq after it acquired the Digital Equipment Corporation in 1998, analysts say.
Indeed, Wall Street seemed to be betting yesterday that the company's competitors stood to gain the most from the merger. In the market for information technology services, both companies compete against I.B.M., whose shares rose $1.54, to $101.49. In the market for personal computers, the two companies are struggling to compete against Dell Computer, whose shares rose 93 cents, to $22.31. By contrast, the price of both Hewlett-Packard and Compaq shares declined.
"On the PC side, this merger doesn't seem to solve a lot of problems," said David Yoffie, a professor at the Harvard Business School. "On the services side, the combined company still will not have a services business that can go head-to-head with I.B.M."
If Ms. Fiorina cannot persuade investors of the merits of the $25 billion deal, the merger may collapse. 
Wall Street's unfavorable reaction appeared to be largely because the combined company would be increasing its stake in the personal computer business, which is in the throes of slumping sales and a savage price war. The new Hewlett-Packard would have about 19 percent of the worldwide PC market, moving ahead of Dell's 13 percent global share. But Dell has a leaner, more profitable PC business than either Hewlett-Packard or Compaq.
In a morning conference with analysts, Ms. Fiorina and Michael D. Capellas, the Compaq chief executive who will become president of the combined company, fielded so many questions about the PC business that Ms. Fiorina concluded with an appeal to look beyond personal computers.
In recent months, as her talks with Mr. Capellas progressed, Ms. Fiorina said they even "looked carefully" at getting out of the personal computer business. But they rejected that option, she said, because PC's are an important part of the "bundle" of technology and services that corporate customers want.
The merger plan faces a regulatory review by antitrust authorities in the United States and Europe. Until those hurdles have been cleared, Hewlett-Packard and Compaq cannot begin the work of pruning overlapping lines of business and melding the two corporate cultures. So Ms. Fiorina and Mr. Capellas were reluctant to discuss their plans in detail.
Still, they gave every indication that the traditional desktop PC business would not be at the strategic core of the new company. When asked about the combined company's standing in the PC market, Mr. Capellas replied that he was focused less on overall market share than on "next-generation access devices" like wireless hand-held computers.
And when asked about where the streamlining is likely to be greatest, Robert Wayman, Hewlett-Packard's chief financial officer, said that the "intensity" of those efforts would probably be greatest in the PC business. Notably, the press release announcing the merger referred to PC's as "access devices" -- the phrase Compaq has adopted to try to distance itself from the battered personal computer business and to suggest that PC's are a link to more profitable operations like services and data-serving computers that are at the hub of corporate networks.
The merger with Compaq, Ms. Fiorina insisted, is a deal that "makes sense in good times or bad," but she conceded that "tough times" brought things to a head. What began nearly a year ago as a conversation with Mr. Capellas about sharing technology, she said, gradually escalated into a merger deal. For the last few months, Hewlett-Packard directors were informed of the progress of the talks. 
In part, the move made sense to both sides because both companies had been moving in the same direction. Under Ms. Fiorina, Hewlett-Packard has been trying to shift into more profitable computer services. It agreed earlier this year to purchase Comdisco's disaster-recovery business, while last year it negotiated to buy the information-technology consulting arm of PricewaterhouseCoopers, but those talks collapsed. Compaq, too, has tried to move into the huge field of supplying companies with packages of hardware, software and services instead of selling them individual pieces of information technology.
But that is a highly competitive and fragmented market. Companies like I.B.M., E.D.S., Sun Microsystems, Oracle and others are pursuing the same "enterprise" market of helping corporations with long-term programs for utilizing Internet technology to work more closely with suppliers and customers. 
Such technology spending, to be sure, has slowed and has been stretched in the current downturn. But the enterprise market still represents the most stable, lucrative area in the information technology industry, as I.B.M.'s strong financial results suggest.
Executives at Hewlett-Packard and Compaq said they thought that the planned merger would ensure that the combined company was a major player in that sector. Corporate customers, Mr. Capellas said, increasingly want to "purchase information technology as a utility" and he added that only a few companies will have the ability to be such full-service digital utilities. "And we're absolutely going to be one of them," he said.
Getting there, however, will require both skill and leadership, especially from Ms. Fiorina, who will head the new company. Since joining Hewlett-Packard in 1999 from Lucent Technologies, Ms. Fiorina has become a well-known executive. She has been articulate and outspoken on public policy issues, and she has been featured in the company's marketing campaign.
"H.P. has a visible leader, and somehow that's important when market conditions are difficult," observed Esther Dyson, publisher of Release 1.0, an industry newsletter. "A company needs to define itself, and not only in terms of its products and services. It needs a leader people can rally around."
Her capacity for decisive leadership, most of all, was the reason the Hewlett-Packard board selected Ms. Fiorina after an extensive search. She started her career in her mid-20's after a failed marriage, a stint teaching English in Bologna, Italy, and time spent earning an M.B.A. from the University of Maryland. She then rose rapidly up the ranks at AT&T and later the Lucent spin-off.
In Ms. Fiorina, who has remarried, the board saw a "renaissance person," the board member said, with the experience and outlook needed to reinvigorate a highly respected company that had been slow to adapt to new technologies like the Internet. "What people call leadership and charisma," he added, "is really clarity of vision and the ability to communicate clearly."
Those skills will be put to the test as Ms. Fiorina tries to sell the deal to Wall Street, antitrust authorities, customers, suppliers and employees.

HEADLINE: Gramm Joins Republicans Who Plan to Quit Senate 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, an ardent conservative whose intellect, tenaciousness and willingness to buck consensus made him a major figure in two decades of Washington budget battles, announced today that he would not seek re-election next year.
 "Remarkably, the things I came to Washington to do are done," he said. 
 Mr. Gramm, a Republican, switched parties after gaining national attention as a Democratic apostate in the House who sponsored Ronald Reagan's 1981 budget cuts and tax cuts. Today he recalled that role as he said that he had made good on his promises to fight for less government and lower taxes. 
"The budget is balanced," he said at a news conference, his wife, Wendy, at his side and his staff arrayed in rows behind him. "First working with President Reagan and then with President Bush, we cut taxes twice. Never in American history has so much power been passed back from the federal government to the states and counties and cities and the people than in the last 25 years." 
Mr. Gramm, 59, is the third senior Republican to say he will not seek re-election next year, adding a new element of uncertainty to the 2002 race at a time when the Democrats control the Senate by just one vote.
A former economics professor who unsuccessfully sought the Republican presidential nomination in 1996, Mr. Gramm has long been one of Washington's leading fiscal conservatives, known for mastering complicated subjects. He delighted in his reputation for being caustic, even mean, joking to at least one audience that he did have a heart: "I keep it in a quart jar on my desk."
But today he showed a different side, choking up several times and appearing near tears as he thanked his family and his staff for their support. He said his decision to leave the Senate came after "a long and difficult period of soul-searching."
His announcement, quickly following the declaration by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, that he would not seek a fifth term, caused political analysts to speak of a changing Senate.
"Jesse Helms was the foremost social conservative in the Senate, and Phil Gramm was the foremost economic conservative in the Senate," said Marshall Wittmann, a Congressional analyst at the Hudson Institute.
Republicans said they were confident they would have the advantage in President Bush's home state, and Mr. Gramm insisted that a "Republican will win my seat." 
Democrats said the retirements would bolster chances of increasing their majority. Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, 98, has said he will step down at the end of his term after seven decades in politics. Republicans are watching Senators Fred Thompson of Tennessee and Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico.
"It's one more competitive race where we didn't expect to have one," James M. Jordan, the executive director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. 
Mr. Gramm was first elected to Congress as a Democrat in 1978, and quickly won a seat on the Budget Committee by promising Democratic leaders he would be a team player. Instead, he became co-sponsor of Mr. Reagan's cuts even as he attended Democratic strategy meetings.
When Democratic leaders tossed Mr. Gramm off the Budget Committee in retaliation, he quit the party and resigned from the House. He triumphantly won as a Republican in a special election. The next year he was elected to the Senate.
There, his passion remained fiscal, and he was instrumental in pushing through a law requiring budget cuts if deficits were not reduced. 
"He was a brilliant tactician," said a former Republican senator, Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, who co-sponsored that law. "His strength was his knowledge and his quickness and his ability to see daylight and run for it. His weaknesses are, I think, Phil could be kind of hard on people sometime."
It was his weakness that showed when he sought the Republican presidential nomination in 1996. While he raised vast sums of money, his abrasiveness haunted him in early contests in small states. He dropped out before the New Hampshire primary, with polls showing him far behind.
He threw himself back into the Senate, rising to chairman of the Banking Committee, until Democrats took control of the Senate in June. He fought hard to kill President Bill Clinton's plan for universal health coverage and produced a plan for turning Social Security into a system in which workers controlled their retirement accounts. 
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi today called Mr. Gramm "probably the most important utility player we have in the Senate."
Mr. Gramm showed he knew how to conciliate in the impeachment trial of Mr. Clinton. With one of the Senate's leading liberal Democrats, Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, he convinced colleagues at a critical moment that the Senate could let the trial begin and defer a decision on summoning witnesses. 
But more often he has been the fierce partisan. Today, tart as ever, he belittled Democrats for their criticism that Mr. Bush's tax cut was depleting surpluses. "I mean, these are the same people that for the next three months are going to be screaming for more spending," he said. 
Mr. Gramm said he did not know what he would do next but did not close the door to a federal appointment, although he seemed to be leaning toward a career in the private sector. "If Coca-Cola called me up today and offered me $50 million to put the fizz back in Coke's stock, I might be tempted," he joked.
Mr. Gramm's decision is expected to set off a free-for-all for his seat. Republicans said possible candidates from their party included two House members, Henry Bonilla and Joe L. Barton, and John Cornyn, the Texas attorney general, and David Dewhurst, the land commissioner. Likely Democratic contenders included Ron Kirk, the Dallas mayor; former Attorney General Dan Morales; Representative Ken Bentsen; and Ed Cunningham, a lawyer.

HEADLINE: Big Belgian Beer Maker Posts 63% Rise in Profit 

BYLINE:  By PAUL MELLER 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Sept. 5 

 BODY:
With an economic slowdown threatening, everything from computers to camisoles may be piling up unsold on store shelves. But consumers are still in the mood for a cold one, especially in the United States, if the earnings reported today by Interbrew, the giant Belgian brewer, are any guide.
 Interbrew said net profit rose 63.6 percent in the first half of 2001, to 200.2 million euros (about $177.7 million), compared with the 2000 period. A string of acquisitions, most notably that of Bass Brewers in June, and a good performance in emerging markets and the United States accounted for the 56 percent rise in sales, to 5.05 billion euros (about $4.4 billion). 
 Excluding the Bass acquisition, which is still being reviewed by British antitrust regulators, year-to-year sales growth was smaller -- 34.8 percent -- but profit growth was greater, 66.5 percent.
Interbrew's chief executive, Hugo Powell, said that British antitrust authorities were expected to rule on the Bass takeover by the end of this month. Regulators originally blocked the deal, but their ruling was overturned by a British court in May; they are now expected to approve it on condition that Interbrew sell some of Bass's brands in Britain.
Western Europe was the company's weakest region in the first half of the year. Sales were steady, but pretax profits eroded by about 10 percent.
Revenue growth was strongest in emerging markets in Asia and central Europe, where sales rose almost 25 percent, to 629 million euros ($559 million). The company increased its sales in the United States by 9.8 percent to 848 million euros (about $753.7 million), Interbrew said.
Interbrew's acquisitive appetite has not abated. The company said today that shareholders of Beck & Company, the brewer of Germany's leading export beer brand, unanimously approved Interbrew's August takeover offer. Interbrew bought a controlling stake in another German brewer, Diebels, in July.
Like Bass, the Beck acquisition is subject to approval by competition regulators in Europe and the United States. Mr. Powell said he expected to close the deal in the first quarter of 2002.
Interbrew calls itself "the world's local brewer"; Rolling Rock and Labatt's are among its well-known brands in the United States and Canada.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
As the economy falters, the tensions between advertisers and agencies rises, a new survey says.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE sluggish advertising economy is already causing rifts in relations between agencies and advertisers, according to an annual survey, as those reporting they have felt the slowdown describe serious consequences ranging from lower-quality campaigns to less teamwork to more of a focus on money.
 The results of the survey, which asked leaders at client companies and agencies to evaluate the effectiveness of their working relationships, show that "among those affected, the economy is really taking its toll," said Nancy L. Salz, president at Nancy L. Salz Consulting in New York, who offered a preview of the 2001 Salz Survey of Advertiser-Agency Relations. 
 "Everything depends on the economy," she added. "We're entering into a time of greater tension." Salz Consulting sponsors training seminars in agency relations and advertising development for marketers including American Express, Clorox, General Motors and the Kraft division of Philip Morris. 
The results are particularly interesting because the 2001 survey, which Ms. Salz has sponsored since 1986, was taken in April -- well before it became apparent that there would be little or no chance of an improvement in the advertising climate for the year.
The survey, conducted by Thurm Marketing and Consulting in Princeton, N.J., is being released by Ms. Salz today against a gloomy backdrop of budget cutbacks and layoffs that had the trade publication Advertising Age speculating in a front-page article this week that 2001 could end with "the biggest year-on-year percentage decline in ad spending since the Great Depression." It was referring to data compiled by the Universal McCann media agency in New York showing that the sharpest one-year decrease in American ad spending, 8.1 percent, came in 1938.
In an interview, Ms. Salz was nowhere near as depressed as to cite the Depression, to paraphrase a lyric of Stephen Sondheim's from "Follies." This is primarily because relations between clients and agencies are suffering "less than might be expected," she said, given the current climate.
For instance, when asked to rate the quality of work from their agencies on a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 highest, the mean rating from advertisers was 7.1, only a tenth of a point lower than 2000.
And when advertisers were asked to predict the effect on sales if the agencies working for them were able to do "their best work for you 100 percent of the time," they estimated a sales increase of 27.7 percent -- the highest response to that question since 1997. By comparison, when advertisers responded to that question in the 1991 survey -- the last time ad spending fell compared with the previous year -- they estimated a much lower sales increase of 21.1 percent if they could get their agencies' best work all the time.
There is now "a greater belief in what really effective advertising can do for a brand," Ms. Salz said, but there are also "higher expectations for advertising," which can be a double-edged sword for agencies under the gun in a weak economy, to mix weapons references.
The survey results were mixed, too. On the negative side, advertisers responding that there was more tension in relationships with their agencies rose to 36 percent from 30 percent last year, while agencies responding that there was more tension in relationships with clients doubled, to 54 percent from 27 percent in the 2000 survey.
Both sides also said they thought there was an increased focus on money in their relations: advertisers, to 42 percent from 32 percent, and agencies, to 71 percent from 54 percent.
And among those advertisers and agencies describing themselves as "greatly" or "somewhat" affected by the economy, there were far more negative responses than among those describing themselves as "slightly" or "not at all" affected.
The advertisers more affected reported "half as much teamwork" in their agency relations as those less affected, Ms. Salz said, "nearly twice as much tension, twice as much focus on money and twice as many hassles." (Ms. Salz was not trying to be casual; the wording of the question included "hassles.")
And the agencies more affected reported "less than one-third as much teamwork" in their client relations as those less affected, she added, "over twice as much tension, 50 percent more focus on money and far more hassles."
And yet, there were bright spots, too, Ms. Salz said, as "other internal dynamics of the advertiser-agency relationship have either maintained or surpassed last year's levels."
For instance, "the percentage of agencies reporting more teamwork" in relations with clients "is at a survey high," she added, of 50 percent, which is important because "those advertisers reporting more teamwork in their agency relationships rated their advertising 22 percent higher than those reporting less teamwork."
And while agencies responded that they were able to do their best work for 54.2 percent of major clients compared with 65.4 percent last year, the percentage for 2001 "is only slightly below the survey average of 58.2 percent," Ms. Salz said, adding that the result for 2000 may have been "an anomaly" stemming from "the unique advertising executions the agencies developed for their dot-com clients."
Dot-com clients. Now there's a phrase that conjures up memories, eh?
