HEADLINE: Courting Blacks and Latinos, Ferrer Is Walking Fine Line 

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS and ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Fernando Ferrer leapt onto a stage at the headquarters of the hospital workers union yesterday and declared that his candidacy was built on the support of an ideological "coalition of conscience," and not simply a coalition of black and Latino voters seeking to elect New York's first Puerto Rican mayor.
 "When we have a city that doesn't work well for all New Yorkers, that is why I'm running for mayor," Mr. Ferrer said exuberantly, accepting the endorsement of 1199/S.E.I.U., New York's Health and Human Service Union. 
 "The 'other New York' is everywhere in this city where people feel the city hasn't worked well for them," he continued, adding, "The other New York is not some narrow coalition." As Mr. Ferrer spoke, he looked across a cheering audience that was almost entirely nonwhite. Mr. Ferrer then invited officials supporting him to the stage, producing another mostly nonwhite tableau. 
The scene yesterday reflected the underlying duality of Mr. Ferrer's candidacy as he enters the final week of a Democratic primary in which, once again, ethnicity and race promise to be a central factor in determining the outcome.
On one hand, his advisers assert that the key to Mr. Ferrer's victory in a crowded field is his success at rallying black and Latino voters, whose numbers are increasing at a faster clip than campaigns can calculate, along with white liberals, who tend to turn out in large numbers.
But if Mr. Ferrer is perceived as running a campaign driven by ethnic appeals -- suggested by some of his recent television and radio advertisements, as well as his decision to campaign with the Rev. Al Sharpton -- he risks pushing away those white voters who his aides say are integral to his electoral calculation.
As it is, many Democrats believe the direction Mr. Ferrer has taken in this campaign already -- he has run more to the left and against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani than any Democrat since David N. Dinkins in 1993 -- is going to make it difficult for him to win his party's nomination and the mayoralty. 
Roberto Ramirez, the Bronx Democratic leader and one of Mr. Ferrer's senior advisers, has from the earliest days sketched out a campaign in which late polls would show Mr. Ferrer moving ahead -- a poll on Tuesday by Quinnipiac University suggested precisely that -- and Latino voters would rush to Mr. Ferrer's candidacy and push him over 40 percent next Tuesday and into the runoff two weeks later. 
But the results of this underlying conflict in the Ferrer campaign have become increasingly evident in the final days of this campaign.
Mr. Ferrer the candidate avoids direct appeals based on race and ethnicity, which his aides have strongly advised him to avoid. But his campaign has quite explicitly appealed for black and Latino votes, with the use of precisely aimed television and radio advertisements, campaign literature and the choice of issues, like an emphasis on racial profiling by the police.
So it is that at his rally with the health care workers yesterday, Mr. Ferrer took pains to avoid describing his campaign in anything other than ideological terms, talking about the need for less expensive housing and for spending more on schools. As he campaigns, Mr. Ferrer likes to point to the prominent white support he has picked up so far, like the endorsements of former Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. And he sometimes tells people not to vote for him solely because he is Puerto Rican.
By contrast, in one Ferrer television advertisement, a young black couple walk together down a dark street, looking on nervously as a blue police siren flashes by. On the radio, in time purchased mostly on black radio stations, the Rev. Al Sharpton implores listeners to choose Mr. Ferrer because he understands "our community," while Representative Charles E. Rangel, the Harlem Democrat, says in an ad first shown yesterday that Mr. Ferrer understands "our problems."
In a Spanish-language television commercial, a sea of Puerto Rican flags flash across the screen while a narrator reminds viewers that "Fernando Ferrer es uno de nosotros." ("Fernando Ferrer is one of us.") On the campaign trail, he frequently speaks Spanish before predominantly Latino audiences.
And in recent days, Mr. Ferrer has been increasingly attacking Mark Green, whom he views as his principal rival for black support, for his endorsement by William J. Bratton, who was the first police commissioner under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
A Ferrer leaflet given out in Harlem shows a handcuffed Mr. Ferrer being led away by the police during a protest against the shooting death of Amadou Diallo, a black man killed by the police. The other pictures on it show Mr. Ferrer with Mr. Sharpton and other black leaders, including Mr. Rangel and C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president. The only white person in the ad is Ruth W. Messinger, the former Manhattan borough president who ran for mayor in 1997.
Mr. Ferrer's advisers say that he is simply conducting campaigns the way they have been conducted for years, and taking advantage of his own ethnic heritage much the same way, for example, Mr. Giuliani appealed to pride among Italian-Americans or Edward I. Koch campaigned among Jews.
And no one has suggested that in trying to assemble a coalition of blacks and Latinos, Mr. Ferrer is excluding any voters. Mr. Ramirez repeatedly argues that even in this changing city, Latinos and blacks alone will not make Mr. Ferrer New York's next mayor.
"Let's be honest, if you are talking about racial profiling, then it would be odd to have a white couple in a TV spot," said David Axelrod, Mr. Ferrer's media adviser. 
Mr. Ferrer said, "If some people believe that a message of hope and opportunity is some kind of zero-sum game, that to give somebody hope you have to take it away from somebody else, I'm here to tell you that that is dead wrong."
Beyond that, he and his aides say that Mr. Ferrer's advocacy for the other New York is based on economics, rather than ethnicity, aimed at people who were left out of the economic boom of the last several years. But even among Mr. Ferrer's supporters the campaign has been clumsy at times, trying to juggle these complicated forces, which perhaps accounts for the low level of white support he has in some polls. 
By contrast, when Mr. Dinkins campaigned to be New York's first black mayor in 1989, he left no doubt he was trying to assemble a coalition that included black and Latino voters, but described his effort as trying to assemble a "gorgeous mosaic."
"He's been fairly explicit throughout the race, and then he denies that he's doing it," said Joe DePlasco, Mr. Green's spokesman. "We do not make racial appeals. What we do try to do is speak to every community."
As suggested by Mr. DePlasco's remarks, Mr. Green's campaign seems aware of the risks inherent in Mr. Ferrer's strategy, and seems inclined, at a time each man views the other as his main rival, to take advantage of it. Mr. Green, who has generally avoided engaging any opponents, yesterday took caustic note of the fact that Sonny Carson, a black political activist who calls himself "antiwhite," told The Village Voice that he was backing Mr. Ferrer.
"I think people like Floyd Flake, Calvin Butts and David Dinkins should jump off the white bandwagons and join what is happening," Mr. Carson told The Voice.
Mr. Green, asked about that, said: "I always thought it's improper to impute the views of a supporter to the candidate. But if you ask me about Sonny Carson, my last recollection was he said he is not anti-Semitic, he was antiwhite. And when someone is an unrepentant racist and anti-Semite, I'd have nothing to do with him on a campaign like this."
Mr. Ferrer responded that he did not seek Mr. Carson's support, and added, "If he does it on the basis of race and ethnicity, I reject it."
With the makeup of the city changing so quickly, and primaries so unpredictable, a critical question in the week ahead is the ethnic makeup of the primary vote on Sept. 11. vote. Mr. Ferrer's advisers are counting on a historically high turnout as part of their calculation.
John Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at the City University of New York Graduate Center, said that based on past patterns, he expected the whites to make up about half the turnout, with blacks a third and Latinos up to 15 percent. Although the Hispanic population has been climbing quickly, its registration and turnout rate is still relatively low, he said.
That could change with this race, Mr. Mollenkopf said, particularly if Mr. Ferrer succeeds in exciting ethnic passions about his candidacy. 
"For the first time, there is a Latino candidate with a good shot at winning," he said. "Will Ferrer be able to galvanize the Latino vote in the same way that Dinkins galvanized the black vote? We don't know."

HEADLINE: The Politics of a Promise 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 

 BODY:
For all the partisan fighting over the disappearing federal budget surplus, Republicans and Democrats are in lock step on one issue: the desirability of sticking to their promises not to use any money intended for Social Security to pay for other programs.
 The reality is that meeting that goal for the next few years will be difficult if not impossible, especially if the economy does not perk up. Recognizing that they are headed toward breaking their promises, both parties are putting strategies in place to minimize any political penalty -- and to make sure they are not seen as being the first to violate that benchmark for fiscal responsibility. 
 Democrats are doing their best to blame President Bush and his tax cut. 
The administration is trying to shift the focus from the budget to the economy, saying that the tax cut was essential to averting a recession and that the revenue shortfall is largely a result of a slowdown that started a year ago under President Bill Clinton.
But in their relentless focus on the politics of the surplus, Democrats and Republicans alike have been almost silent on the question of whether maintaining a fiscal policy that was developed in a period of boomlike prosperity and rising surpluses still makes economic sense.
In a sharp slowdown that is still threatening to become something worse, good economics could end up conflicting with political imperatives.
The issue is being debated behind the scenes in Washington, and among economists. And the debate is likely to get far more intense if the economy does not recover in coming months.
Textbook economics suggests that a government should seek to stimulate a weakened or contracting economy through some combination of lower taxes and higher spending. It was just that theory that led Congress and the administration to send rebate checks this summer to people who pay income taxes, putting $38 billion into the hands of consumers.
But the tax cut was formulated when Washington had a surplus to play with outside of Social Security. For the next few years, the only surplus will come almost exclusively from Social Security, money that the two parties agree should be used only to reduce the national debt.
If the economy remained weak, Congress and the administration would find themselves not only in a squeeze on spending but constrained from giving the economy another boost through further tax cuts. 
If they took their commitment to maintaining the Social Security surplus literally, they could even find it forcing them to raise taxes and cut spending as the economy weakened -- the opposite of what economic theory says would be the correct response.
Even some backers of the Social Security commitment say there is sure to be a re-examination of the issue.
"It's a complicated question," said Robert E. Rubin, who as treasury secretary in the Clinton administration as much as anyone created the policy of leaving the Social Security surplus untouched.
Mr. Rubin said he was not ready to rethink the policy. But he said that if there was going to be a debate, it should encompass the broader issue of shoring up the long-term fiscal outlook, which he said was badly undermined by Mr. Bush's 10-year, $1.35 trillion tax cut.
"The economically sound thing to do is debate it in the context of fixing the long term," Mr. Rubin said in an interview. "The re-establishment of a sound fiscal position was central to the good things that happened in the eight years through 2000, and it's critically important going forward."
In economic terms, analysts said, spending part of the Social Security surplus -- projected by the administration to be $171 billion next year -- would do no discernible harm in the short run.
"There's no economic consequence to a modest use of the surplus," said Thomas Gallagher, a political analyst with the International Strategy and Investment Group, an investment-advisory firm.
Should the economy remain weak and Congress and the administration stick to their policy of not touching the Social Security surplus, it could deprive the government of an important economic tool, leaving the Federal Reserve without much additional help from fiscal policy.
Mr. Gallagher said, "To the extent we may be into a post-bubble economy characterized by weak demand for a period of time, where an active policy of fiscal stimulus would be appropriate, sticking to this doctrine would appear to preclude that."
Spending part of the Social Security surplus would not by itself have any immediate effect on the government's ability to pay Social Security benefits.
But both parties have made much of their commitment to paying off the national debt, a goal that would be attained more slowly, at best, if Washington returned to a regular policy of spending part of the Social Security surplus. 
And by their own slogans -- promising to prevent "raids" on the Social Security and Medicare trust funds -- Democrats and Republicans have left at least some voters with the impression that their retirement benefits could be at risk right away if fiscal discipline erodes.
A case can be made that the economy has benefited, and will continue to benefit, from showing financial markets and investors around the world that the United States government can keep its finances in order.
As a result, both parties are convinced there could be a heavy political price to pay if they are judged to have put other priorities ahead of the health of the old-age programs.
"Social Security trumps everything else, except the economy," said Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster. "Candidates better have a darned good reason -- and it better be a dire reason -- for messing with the so-called trust fund."
While Republican members of Congress remain fixated on not dipping into the Social Security surplus, Mr. Bush is taking a more flexible stance. He has dodged questions about whether he would veto spending bills that required use of the Social Security money. And he has spoken of how his promise not to use the Social Security surplus for general purposes would be withdrawn in the case of war or recession.
Administration officials have not defined what they would consider a recession, but have hinted that it would not necessarily have to mean the classic definition of two consecutive quarters in which the economy contracted.
Democrats do not have a clear strategy either. They are trying to force Mr. Bush to say how he would pay for his proposal for more military spending, and how the budget could accommodate bipartisan calls for more spending on education and the creation of a prescription drug benefit for the elderly, without dipping into Social Security.
Beyond that, though, they have done little more than hint that they might want to revisit Mr. Bush's tax cut, to scale back or eliminate some provisions that are scheduled to take effect in coming years. That course, though, has obvious political and economic problems.
"This is not simply business as usual," said Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the senior Democrat on the House Budget Committee. "We've got a problem. And if the economy gets any worse, then we've got an even bigger problem."

HEADLINE: Mr. Fox Comes to Washington 

 BODY:
All the pomp and circumstance of Vicente Fox's arrival on the South Lawn of the White House yesterday could not mask the diminished expectations of the Mexican president's state visit to Washington. With both the American and Mexican economies stalled and the blush off Mr. Fox's reform presidency, a lot less will come of the visit than the two leaders hoped when they set the date earlier this year. Given the depth and complexity of the relationship between the neighboring nations, that may not be a bad thing. 
 There is no doubt that this is a time of greater interdependence, and warmer ties, between the United States and Mexico. The improved relationship is reflected in growing cooperation on immigration, drug trafficking and other traditionally nettlesome issues. Mr. Fox, who defeated the long-ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party in last year's election, enjoys a democratic legitimacy that his predecessors could not claim and a good personal rapport with President Bush. 
 Good will, however, cannot instantly solve the divisive issues that still strain relations between the nations, especially the illegal movement of hundreds of thousands of Mexicans across the border. Last February the two presidents directed aides to fashion a broad new deal on immigration by the time Mr. Fox came to Washington. 
That proved unrealistic. The White House considered legalizing the status of a large portion of the more than three million Mexicans working illegally in the United States by incorporating them into an expanded guest-worker program. But after gauging the opposition on Capitol Hill and watching the downturn in the American economy, the White House now favors a more gradual approach, and seems unsure when a deal can be reached. 
Mr. Fox did not hide his impatience yesterday when he challenged Mr. Bush at the welcoming ceremonies to reach an agreement by the end of the year. While the Fox timetable may make for good politics in Mexico, Mr. Bush needs more time to build political support for an agreement that resolves the immigration problem in a responsible way that benefits both countries.
Economic stagnation in the United States has also limited Mr. Fox's options on a range of domestic issues. Mexico, now the United States' second-largest trading partner, is integrated as never before into the American economy in the aftermath of the North American Free Trade Agreement. As a result, the slowdown north of the Rio Grande has produced a recession in Mexico. 
The economic problems have hindered Mr. Fox's plan to increase public spending to combat poverty. Combined with his failure to sell his legislative program to opposition parties that control the Mexican Congress, the recession has hampered the Fox administration's reform agenda. 
Mr. Bush and Mr. Fox had reason to toast one another last evening at the first state dinner to be held by Mr. Bush and his wife, Laura. There has never been a better relationship between Mexican and American presidents. Even so, celebrations to mark the completion of a new immigration agreement will have to wait.

HEADLINE: U.S. Diplomat Said to Protest China Actions On First Boston 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Sept. 5 

 BODY:
The United States ambassador to China, Clark T. Randt Jr., decided not to attend a dinner with Chinese officials tonight, apparently in protest over China's recent blacklisting of Credit Suisse First Boston. The investment bank angered Beijing by inviting senior Taiwan government officials to speak at conferences it sponsored earlier this year.
 The United States Embassy in Beijing declined to comment, and a State Department official in Washington would say only that Mr. Randt had skipped the dinner, aimed at promoting investment on the mainland, because "it was not convenient." But other American officials said Mr. Randt made his decision after China withdrew an invitation to Credit Suisse First Boston. 
 China recently removed Credit Suisse First Boston from the list of underwriters for a multibillion-dollar stock offering planned by the China Unicom Group, China's second-largest telecommunications company. China was apparently punishing the bank for having invited Taiwan's finance minister, Yen Ching-chang, to give the keynote speech at a conference in Hong Kong in March. 
The bank, a subsidiary of the Credit Suisse Group of Zurich, further angered China by arranging a five-nation European tour for officials from Taiwan to promote the island's economy and companies.
China's move against Credit Suisse First Boston led two other investment banks, Goldman, Sachs and Merrill Lynch, to drop plans to sponsor a similar promotional tour of the United States, Taiwan officials say.
China regards Taiwan as a province. And though Beijing has increasingly encouraged commercial ties with Taiwan, it has also continued to retaliate against countries or companies that afford the island's leaders official status abroad, or even refer to Taiwan as a country. 
Occasionally, China presses companies to join in its propaganda campaign. Last year, Coca-Cola dropped a mainland advertising campaign that featured a Taiwan pop star after she angered China by singing the Taiwan national anthem at the inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian.
But the State Department apparently viewed China's latest rebuke as going too far. 
"When it had an immediate effect and made Goldman and Merrill both run for cover, that's what made the State Department decide to come up with a response and send a message," said a senior staff member on Capitol Hill. Officials in Washington said that China should not go unchallenged if it played politics in the economic arena, particularly as it prepares to join the World Trade Organization.
China Unicom; Goldman, Sachs; and Merrill Lynch all declined to comment, as did officials at the China Securities Regulatory Commission. 
A Credit Suisse First Boston spokesman in Hong Kong also declined to comment, other than to say that "this is a serious matter and is a priority for our senior management."
John J. Mack, the new chief executive of Credit Suisse First Boston, has close ties in China. Before he resigned as president of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter early this year, Mr. Mack was a director of the China International Capital Corporation, an investment bank that is a joint venture between Morgan Stanley and the state-owned China Construction Bank.
The ambassador's action suggests that the brewing contention over the Credit Suisse First Boston ban is not likely to end soon. It also highlights Mr. Randt's close ties to the investment banking community. Before his appointment this spring as ambassador, Mr. Randt worked as a mergers and acquisition lawyer in Hong Kong, representing both Chinese companies and American investment banks. 
He was largely responsible for getting Credit Suisse First Boston's American subsidiary, then called the First Boston Corporation, the job as lead underwriter of China's first public stock listing in the United States nearly a decade ago. 
But Mr. Randt has also seen China punish investment banks before. In the early 1990's, Beijing barred Morgan Stanley from underwriting a portion of a $4.2 billion share offering by China Telecom Hong Kong Ltd. after the investment bank angered Beijing by predicting a sharp decline in Hong Kong and Chinese share prices. Mr. Randt worked on the share offering.
Chinese investment bankers expressed surprise today that the ambassador would take any action, official or unofficial, in response to the controversy, which most people here expected to disappear after Beijing's message had sunk in with the investment banking community.
"It's not going to help Credit Suisse First Boston," said a prominent Chinese banker in Beijing, adding that a protest by the United States government would only anger Beijing.

HEADLINE: DEFENDING BUDGET, BUSH AIDES TAKE FIGHT TO CONGRESS 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO and LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 

 BODY:
President Bush's budget director and defense secretary mounted a vigorous defense of the Bush budget today in separate appearances on Capitol Hill, insisting that the administration and Congress could protect the Social Security surplus and still increase military and education spending.
 But Democrats intensified their attacks against Mr. Bush, blaming his $1.35 trillion tax cut for the shrinking federal surplus and asking him to submit a budget that would protect Social Security funds. 
 "This is a result of the Bush budget and the Bush tax cut," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, of the dwindling surplus. "Certainly, they're the architects of our current economic condition, and I think we have to turn to them for leadership now as we find our way out of the box that has been created." 
Coming on Congress's first full day back at work, today's jousting opened what is expected to be a bitter fight over the budget, as Congress tries to enact spending bills by Sept. 30, the end of the fiscal year.
Throughout the day, each side sought to blame the other for the shrinking surplus and position itself to avoid responsibility for what many economists consider the inevitable: using surplus Medicare and Social Security money to pay for spending increases. News analysis, Page A18. 
Last week, the Congressional Budget Office reported that the government would almost certainly have to use Social Security revenues to pay bills this year because of the economic downturn and the tax cut. The report also predicted that Congress would have a relatively small $2 billion surplus outside the Social Security system next year, not enough to cover just the increases in the Pentagon budget needed to keep up with inflation.
In testimony before the House Budget Committee today, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the director of the Office of Management and Budget, urged Congress "to honor" President Bush's budget, asserting that surplus Social Security money would not have to be spent if lawmakers did not exceed the spending plan.
"The budget, as proposed by the president, and the budget resolution that now sits before the Congress, if not exceeded, will allow the funding of our nation's priorities -- defense, education, debt reduction -- all consistent with the full protection of the Social Security surplus for debt reduction," Mr. Daniels said.
In the Senate, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld told a subcommittee that the Pentagon would need "every nickel" of the administration's proposed $33 billion increase in military spending to begin repairing decrepit bases, replacing aging equipment and improving benefits for the troops.
A pressing problem for Mr. Rumsfeld is that if Congress adds spending to the president's budget -- as it almost always does -- and if both parties stand by their promise not to touch the Social Security surplus, the money would probably come out of the Pentagon budget. 
For the 2002 fiscal year, which begins on Oct. 1, Mr. Bush has requested an additional $18.3 billion for the Pentagon and a $669 million increase for education. Republicans and Democrats have proposed raising the president's education request by $5 billion to $16 billion.
House Republican leaders are also pushing for a new, immediate tax cut package, including a reduction in the capital gains tax, that they say would boost the economy. The White House has been open but not enthusiastic about those proposals.
With the economic terrain shifting so rapidly, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri and the minority leader in the House, reiterated today his request to Mr. Bush to write a new budget, one that would reflect the stumbling economy and the slimmer surplus.
"Ever since the budget was presented, we have seen increasingly pessimistic or increasingly different budget forecasts and economic forecasts, and the economy has changed before our eyes," Mr. Gephardt said. "I would hope the president would give us a new budget in light of the completely new numbers that we're looking at."
But the administration immediately rejected that demand. In Mr. Rumsfeld's testimony, he said that the extra Pentagon spending sought in the Bush plan was vital to the nation's security. 
"The budget request does not solve the problems of the department," Mr. Rumsfeld said. "It begins to repair the damage that's been done by a long period of underfunding."
Mr. Rumsfeld also warned the Democrats against trying to reduce Mr. Bush's proposed $8.3 billion budget for missile defense, saying that any cuts to the program would weaken the president's hand in negotiating with the Russians on a new strategic framework to replace the 1972 Antiballistic Missile treaty.
"To the extent the Russians develop a perception that the United States is not interested in going forward in providing defense against ballistic missiles or that we're split on that issue, obviously it's in their interest to not come to any agreements with us," Mr. Rumsfeld said.
In a sign that the Democrats face internal divisions over military spending, Senator Daniel Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, told Mr. Rumsfeld that he would do everything in his power to make sure the Pentagon receives its full $329 billion budget request. But Mr. Inouye also warned that the fight would be difficult.
"Many of our colleagues are going to be reluctant to cut into Medicare and Social Security to pay for defense," said Mr. Inouye, who is chairman of the subcommittee on defense appropriations. "Politically, they worry that the voters will penalize them for raiding Social Security."
But Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, who is the ranking Republican on the Budget Committee and a member of the appropriations defense subcommittee, said next year's surplus would be large enough to accommodate the administration's entire Pentagon budget. And even if it is not, Mr. Domenici suggested, dipping into surplus Social Security revenues, as Congress did for decades, might stimulate the economy.
"How do we get the American economy to come back?" Mr. Domenici said in the subcommittee hearing. "I don't believe you cut spending when you have this kind of recession."
With Democrats deferring on what should be done to correct the situation, leaving it to Mr. Bush to make the first move, Republicans in the House and Senate seemed at odds over what course to follow.
Representative Dick Armey, the majority leader from Texas, reiterated his commitment to leaving the surplus untouched and said he was pushing for a package that would include a cut in the capital gains tax, expanding trade, and making permanent a tax credit on research and development.
Mr. Armey also said House Republicans are considering making Mr. Bush's 10-year tax cut permanent. Another proposal, he said, involved setting aside any money that exceeded the budget spending limits, a procedure that is called sequestration.
Mr. Bush had a lukewarm reaction to a cut in the capital gains tax when he met with Congressional leaders on Tuesday. And Senate Democrats called the idea dead on arrival. 
Those Democrats, however, backed away from suggestions that the president's tax cut be rescinded. 
"There's no way that's going to happen this year," said Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. "We shouldn't have a tax increase in the midst of an economic slowdown."

HEADLINE: At G.E., Whither The House Jack Built?; 
His Successor Faces Skeptics And a Market Less in Awe

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Officially, the baton does not pass until tomorrow. That's when Jeffrey R. Immelt takes over the top spot at the General Electric Company, and John F. Welch Jr. leaves. Tonight, there are the going-away festivities: some 200 people will gather at Crotonville, G.E.'s management school, for a roast of their departing chairman and chief executive. "I'm going to get hammered," Mr. Welch laughingly predicted.
 But of course, the transition has been in progress for months. Since November, when Mr. Immelt was anointed as Mr. Welch's successor, G.E. aficionados have bandied about the question: Can "the House That Jack Built" thrive without Jack? 
 Mr. Welch and Mr. Immelt, both premier contrarians, see that as a decidedly silly question. 
"I'm inheriting a company with no burning platform, no business sucking up cash, every business returning its cost of capital," Mr. Immelt said good naturedly, fielding questions earlier this week at a G.E. suite on the 53rd floor of 30 Rockefeller Plaza, the Manhattan skyscraper that houses NBC's studios and many G.E. corporate offices. 
Mr. Welch, holding court down the hall, seemed similarly sanguine about his soon-to-be-ex-employer's prospects.
"G.E. has grown through all kinds of cycles," he said. "I'm excited to be leaving, and I'd be feeling horrible if I had doubts about Jeff."
Still, Mr. Immelt's challenges are enormous. Investors' uncertainties about G.E.'s prospects in the stagnant economy have taken a toll on its stock, which closed yesterday at $41.70, 30 percent below its peak of $60 in August 2000. At the same time, G.E. is moving into a world where so-called knowledge products -- software, services, Internet-related processes and the like -- will determine whether it continues to stand above its competitors.
"Jeff must manage businesses whose mix is changing from tangible products to intellectual content," said Nicholas P. Heymann of Prudential Securities.
Indeed, for all the demurrals, G.E. under Mr. Immelt will necessarily become a different place from what it was under Mr. Welch -- if not immediately in substance, certainly in style. Mr. Welch, a scrappy hockey player in high school, wears his emotions openly. Ask about G.E. employees, and his face lights up.
"We are a family, and I'll miss them terribly," he said.
Ask about persistent accusations that G.E., which has made good on its earnings predictions every quarter for decades, manages its numbers to mask deteriorating earnings, and the storm clouds gather.
"We don't manage earnings, we manage businesses," Mr. Welch responded, calling those who say otherwise "brain-dead idiots." He added, "You can't fool with cash flow, and ours is great."
By contrast, Mr. Immelt -- who at 45 looks like an older and somewhat chunkier version of the football player he was in college -- speaks in even tones, and exudes an unflappability and easy humor. But his resolve is as steely as Mr. Welch's, and, at least publicly, his assessments of G.E.'s virtues are pretty much the same.
"G.E.'s people are its strength," he said, "and developing them will take up half my time."
And what about those intimations of squishy numbers?
"We give investors certainty and visibility," he said, his tone not changing one whit. "We've said our earnings will grow 15 percent this year, and we meet our commitments to analysts."
That is getting harder to do. In 1981, when Mr. Welch took the helm, G.E. earned $1.7 billion on revenue of $25 billion. Last year, it made $28 billion on $130 billion in revenue. Under Mr. Welch, G.E. typically acquired 100 small companies a year; analysts say it will take twice that many now to maintain double-digit growth.
Wall Street is becoming a harder sell, too. The David L. Babson Company, an investment firm, sold its General Electric stock six months ago, when it first looked as if G.E.'s hopes of acquiring Honeywell would be dashed by European antitrust regulators and Babson figured that investors would no longer be willing to pay a big multiple of G.E.'s earnings for the stock. "G.E. used to have category-killer economics, and that kept its P.-E. high," said Anthony M. Maramarco, a Babson managing director. "But it's already maximized operating margins."
Mr. Immelt says he is not worried. "This isn't a $130 billion one-product company, but a group of businesses operating in growing industries," he said.
Still, acquiring Honeywell would have helped a lot. Mr. Welch was not at all coy about his plans to reduce Honeywell's work force of 120,000, and G.E. had ferreted out many ways to make Honeywell's operations far more efficient.
Buying Honeywell, a $25 billion industrial company, would also have given G.E. more breathing room to expand its fast-growing finance business, GE Capital, last year already a $56.5 billion business. G.E. recently paid $5.3 billion to buy Heller Financial; more such big purchases could tip its portfolio too much toward financial services.
G.E. has a triple-A credit rating, and its stock usually trades at 30 to 40 times its earnings. Credit agencies and investors are rarely as generous to financial services businesses as to industrial or technology companies. And while highly successful, GE Capital earns a return on assets of only about 1.4 percent, in line with that of other financial companies.
G.E.'s industrial businesses, on the other hand, average an 8.4 percent return, well above the 5 percent of most such companies.
"They run the risk of reducing their profitability if they keep expanding GE Capital, and they will deserve a much lower P.-E.," said Robert Friedman, an analyst with S& P Equity Research.
Thus, Mr. Immelt must now set a new growth path for General Electric -- and sooner than he had expected. Mr. Welch, who planned to stay until year-end to help integrate Honeywell, moved up his retirement date after the deal fell apart.
Mr. Immelt will also have to find his own way of preventing the stigma of being a conglomerate from further reducing G.E.'s stock price. For decades, conglomerates have been out of favor on Wall Street, and investors have demanded a discount on their share prices. G.E.'s potpourri of businesses certainly qualifies it for the conglomerate label, but Wall Street's faith in Jack Welch, experts say, kept G.E. from that fate.
"Jeff Immelt has to demonstrate quickly that G.E.'s excellent institutionalized management system, not Jack Welch, set G.E. apart from other conglomerates," said Michael Hammer, a management consultant in Cambridge, Mass.
Many other G.E. watchers say he should be able to do that. "Jack Welch was a visionary, but he wasn't the vision," said Jeffrey A. Krames, an editor and author of books about Mr. Welch. "He created a company where 300,000 diverse people are delivering on that vision."
But that well-oiled machine may be developing creaks. G.E. has long used stock options as a prime compensation tool and motivator. Some warn that, with the stock losing its luster just as the patina of working for Mr. Welch fades, other companies might woo away much of General Electric's talent.
"G.E.'s famous deep bench may thin out," Mr. Hammer warned.
Mr. Immelt insists that attrition is low. "People stay for head, heart and wallet, and this remains a great place for them to be," he said.
Mr. Immelt can also expect more pressure from environmentalists, as the company continues to fight an order by the Environmental Protection Agency to dredge the Hudson River of hazardous PCB's, once used in electrical transformers and left there from manufacturing operations years ago.
Mr. Welch said he would have readily met with environmentalists to explain why G.E. thinks that the dredging order is a mistake. Environmentalists acknowledge that they never asked. "Meeting with Jack Welch didn't seem to hold any promise," said Ned Sullivan, president of Scenic Hudson. "I'll give Mr. Immelt the benefit of the doubt, and I intend to reach out to him."
No one suggests that G.E. is in serious trouble. But it wasn't when Mr. Welch took over, either. Many of the innovations that Reginald Jones, his predecessor, introduced -- carving the company into hundreds of strategic business units, or turning planning into an art form -- were then considered leading-edge.
"Welch pulled apart that much-admired system," said Christopher A. Bartlett, a Harvard Business School professor. More important, he stripped the company of bureaucratic impediments. "Jack was marvelous at creating simplicity out of huge complexity," said Noel M. Tichy, a professor at the University of Michigan Business School.
Mr. Welch soon applied his catchy slogan -- fix it, sell it or close it -- to every G.E. business. He sold some 200 that were not dominant in their markets, and bought hundreds of others to bolster the remaining ones. And early in his tenure, he fired close to 100,000 people -- the genesis of his nickname, Neutron Jack, after the weapon with the capacity to wipe out people without destroying buildings.
"He made plenty of mistakes, but he rectified them," Mr. Bartlett noted, citing as examples the acquisitions -- and later, divestitures -- of RCA and Kidder Peabody.
By the end of the 80's, Mr. Welch was ready to deconstruct G.E.'s culture. He created systems for sharing ideas and for spotting and developing employees with high potential. He became personally involved in the evaluations of G.E.'s 400-or-so top executives. He regularly taught classes at Crotonville -- nearly 40 miles north of midtown Manhattan -- and insisted that other executives teach, too.
Today, corporate America is dotted with chief executives who cut their eyeteeth at G.E. and are now emulating Mr. Welch. "He believed in lean and mean," said Robert D. Fagan, who was with G.E. from 1976 to 1985, and is now chairman of Teco Energy in Tampa, Fla. "He'd insist that you make your numbers, but he'd let you decide how to do so."
Many G.E. alumni say they learned more at Crotonville than at any university. "He turned Crotonville into the glue for G.E. culture," said Robert L. Nardelli, who left to become chief executive of Home Depot after he lost a three-man race to succeed Mr. Welch. The other candidate, W. James McNerney Jr., runs Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing.
Paradoxically, Crotonville is high on Mr. Immelt's list of things to tinker with: He is switching the emphasis of the executive training courses from general management to achieving growth and serving customers. G.E.'s quarterly management meetings may go soon, too.
"They seem silly," Mr. Immelt said, "now that so much information is available with the Internet."
Mr. Welch will watch all this with interest, of course -- but from afar. "I'm not selling $1 worth of G.E. stock," he said, "but my hands-on relationship with the company will be zip."
He is relishing the chance to travel with his wife, play more golf, work as a consultant to other chief executives and promote his book, which came out this week.
As for Mr. Immelt, if he survives as long as Mr. Welch did, he will presumably put his own firm mark on G.E.
In his 20-year reign, Mr. Welch mounted four major initiatives: he turned a largely domestic company into a global behemoth; he moved G.E.'s businesses toward selling more services; he instituted Six Sigma, a complex statistical process that has produced immense cost savings, and, although he spurned the idea of e-business for several years, he finally pushed each G.E. executive into exploiting the Internet.
For now, Mr. Immelt is content to tweak, not revolutionize.
"I know G.E.'s portfolio of businesses will have to change eventually," he said. "But there's no reason to add a fifth initiative now."

HEADLINE: MEXICO PRESIDENT URGES U.S. TO ACT SOON ON MIGRANTS 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 

 BODY:
Making the first state visit of the Bush administration, President Vicente Fox of Mexico today urged the United States to commit to a speedy timetable for agreement this year on broad, politically sensitive proposals for the treatment of millions of illegal Mexican immigrants. 
 Among the proposals being discussed by high-level officials in both governments is one that would give legal status to some of the 3.5 million Mexicans working illegally in the United States. 
 "We must, and we can, reach an agreement on migration before the end of this very year," Mr. Fox said, "which will allow us, before the end of our respective terms, to make sure that there are no Mexicans who have not entered this country legally, and that those Mexicans who have come into the country do so with the proper documents." 
Offered within the first hour of his arrival at the White House, President Fox's challenge did not surprise Mr. Bush's top aides, who said they were aware of Mr. Fox's desire. But it did add a new sense of urgency to an issue that faces a significant fight from conservative political forces in the United States. 
Aides to Mr. Fox, the first Mexican president to be elected from the political opposition, said the statement, made on the South Lawn, was aimed at making clear that while Mexico is willing to take time to forge a new immigration agreement that benefits both countries, it does not intend to let the negotiations drag on for years. 
The statement differed from Mr. Fox's earlier statements about the timetable for a deal on immigration. To some political analysts, it seemed too ambitious a goal, though bold pronouncements against the odds have become the signature of Mr. Fox's public discourse. A year ago, the last time Mr. Fox visited Washington, as president-elect, he stirred imaginations by urging the United States to make the border more open to the flow of workers.
In welcoming President Fox to the White House, Mr. Bush spoke only in general terms about the negotiations, saying Mexico and the United States "must work in a spirit of respect and common purpose." 
But in an afternoon briefing with reporters, his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, stopped short of committing the White House to a deal this year. She emphasized that President Bush had to negotiate immigration agreements with Congress and various political and business sectors, saying the discussions involved "a lot of moving parts." 
"We are going to work as hard and as fast as we can to achieve the goal," she said. "But as both presidents have emphasized, we do not only want to make a deal, we want to do it right." 
The welcoming ceremony for President Fox was replete with a 21-gun salute and a Revolutionary War-era marching band. President Bush called the visit "recognition that the United States has no more important relationship in the world than the one we have with Mexico," language that past presidents have usually reserved for Britain and Japan. 
Breaking comfortably into Spanish, President Bush said, "El que tiene un buen vecino, tiene un buen amigo" -- "He who has a good neighbor has a good friend." 
President Bush's opening words also emphasized the importance of strengthening social and cultural ties, rather than the fight against drug trafficking and Mexico's struggle against corruption, another departure from the typical discourse between past presidents.
Tonight Mr. Bush entertained Mr. Fox and his new wife, Marta Sahagun de Fox, his former press secretary, at a state dinner. 
For his part, President Fox underscored that Mexico has become one of the United States' most important trading partners, second only to Canada, and contended that immigrants have fueled economic growth on both sides of the border.
He pressed the United States government to quickly "build new conditions of fairness" for undocumented Mexican immigrants "whose hard work is a daily contribution to the prosperity of this great nation." 
Calling immigrants "national heroes," Mr. Fox has made immigration issues a priority for his nine-month old government. Mr. Bush, to the surprise of many of his Republican supporters, has done the same, entertaining ideas about legalizing migrant workers that go beyond anything previously considered in Washington.
Aides to President Fox said it was important for the presidents to reach a formal agreement on immigration this year so that it could be presented to their respective congresses before the spring, particularly before the start of the 2002 campaigns in the United States. The Senate is currently controlled by Democrats, from whom Mr. Fox expects greater support for the immigration proposals. 
But the complexities of getting a deal done quickly -- if at all -- became clear as soon as talks began this spring between Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Mexico's foreign minister, Jorge G. Castaneda. 
Mr. Bush's aides realize that the notion of accepting some of the millions of Mexican workers believed to be in the country illegally could raise enormous opposition among conservatives in Congress. The economic downturn has further narrowed Mr. Bush's options, while making the relief valve of sending workers north all the more important to Mr. Fox. 
In recent days Mr. Bush's aides have become vague about the talks, which cover everything from control of the border, to expanded guest-worker programs, to what would amount to an amnesty for some illegal workers. But President Bush has said he would never issue a "blanket amnesty." 
Adding to the White House's problems are growing protests by other immigrant groups about the favoritism inherent in special deals for Mexicans.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 7, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about the visit of President Vicente Fox of Mexico referred incorrectly in some copies to Democratic control in Congress. The Democrats control the Senate, not the House.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Under pressure from a Dutch court, the fight over control of the Gucci Group may be resolved.

BYLINE:  By Suzanne Kapner 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
The dispute between the French billionaires Francois Pinault and Bernard Arnault for control of the Gucci Group has proved something of an embarrassment for the Dutch legal system.
 And so it was with renewed vigor that Dutch investigators recently approached the parties involved to push for a settlement of their two-and-a-half-year-old ownership dispute. 
 Since March 1999, investigators have been examining whether the Italian fashion house Gucci, which is incorporated in the Netherlands, acted improperly when it issued shares to Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, which is controlled by Mr. Pinault, to thwart a takeover by Mr. Arnault's LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton. 
The deal gave Gucci $3 billion to spend on acquisitions, including the Yves Saint Laurent fashion house, and effectively halved LVMH's stake in Gucci, to 20 percent.
The French moguls and Gucci's chief executive, Domenico De Sole, have been locked in an uncomfortable dance ever since, with the loss of face almost as important as the loss of money.
Now the last-ditch diplomacy on the part of the Dutch court, which was expected to offer its latest ruling in the case later this month, may finally bear fruit. The settlement talks are at an advanced stage and a deal could be announced within days, people involved in the discussions said yesterday.
"The real difference this time is that investigators are sitting on top of this process and telling the parties they need to settle," one person close to the negotiations said.
Given the stormy history of the situation, however, these people held out the possibility of last-minute problems that could unravel a complex three-stage deal.
According to the plan, which was reported yesterday in The Financial Times, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute would pay about $95 a share for 40 percent of LVMH's holding, which would increase its stake in Gucci to 50 percent. In New York yesterday, shares of Gucci rose $6.88, to $85.35.
Then, in November, Gucci would pay all shareholders except Pinault-Printemps-Redoute a special dividend of $7 a share.
Finally, LVMH and all of Gucci's other shareholders would have the option to sell their stakes for $101.50 a share in March 2004, when an agreement expires that requires Pinault-Printemps-Redoute to receive approval before increasing its Gucci stake.
All three companies confirmed they were in talks to resolve the situation, but would not provide details. LVMH shares fell 1.35 euros ($1.12), or 2.5 percent, to 52.65 euros ($46.77). Pinault-Printemps-Redoute shares fell 4 euros ($3.55), or 2.7 percent, to 142.5 ($126.60).
People involved in the negotiations said one remaining issue was when Pinault-Printemps-Redoute would officially take control of Gucci. The Italian company has maintained that it would not give up control unless Pinault-Printemps-Redoute made an offer to all its shareholders, not just LVMH. Such a stipulation is not required under Dutch law, permitting an acquirer to take "creeping" control of a company by acquiring shares on the open market without issuing an offer to all shareholders.
Because the terms of the current deal do not require Pinault-Printemps-Redoute to make that offer until 2004, Gucci would like to retain some measure of control, even though Pinault-Printemps-Redoute will own 50 percent of the shares, these people said.
Analysts and investors hailed a possible resolution of the conflict, which would provide a windfall for LVMH and permit all three companies to end the raft of legal bills and distractions at a time when the business climate has toughened.
Although consumer spending has largely remained strong despite the global economic downturn, LVMH warned in March of more difficult conditions in 2001 because of slowing growth prospects in major economies, most notably in North America. Three months later, Gucci reported first-quarter results that fell short of analyst estimates and lowered its sales and profit forecasts for the entire year. Although Gucci said at the time that the shortfall was mainly a result of the higher costs of revamping Yves Saint Laurent, which Gucci bought in 1999, the economic climate also played a role in the tempered outlook.
Pinault-Printemps-Redoute is expected to report first-half profits today that increased 9 percent, to 295 million euros, or $260 million, compared with 271 million euros ($240 million), according to a consensus of 15 analysts.
Talks to end the dispute collapsed last year when Gucci rejected a $100-a-share offer from Pinault-Printemps-Redoute as too low.
Legal battles erupted afresh in March, after a Dutch court ordered a review of Gucci's initial agreement with Pinault-Printemps-Redoute.

HEADLINE: Brazil to Exempt Stock Trades From a Tax 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil Sept. 6

 BODY:
Waving Brazilian flags and carrying signs reading "Save Our National Market," workers at the Sao Paulo stock market, the Bovespa, interrupted trading for an hour this afternoon to protest government measures that they say have caused trading volume on the exchanges to plummet, as investors switch to trading stocks of Brazilian companies in New York, where transaction costs are lower. 
 A cheer went up from the trading floor a few minutes into the trading halt, when the news arrived that the government had agreed to exempt stock trades from a tax of 0.38 percent on all financial transactions. The Finance Ministry said that the exemption would take effect before the year ended, but did not specify a date. 
 The tax is the main culprit blamed by traders for the steep fall in average trading volume on the Bovespa, to about 350 million reais ($136 million) a day this year from a peak of 1.2 billion reais ($1.08 billion) a day in 1997. The tax, called the C.P.M.F., makes it roughly twice as expensive to trade a Brazilian blue chip on the Bovespa as it is to trade it as an American depository receipt on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Without the C.P.M.F., there is more chance that we would buy through the Bovespa, since you would have a similar, if not lower, transaction cost in Brazil," said Bill Rudman, head of the Latin America group at WestAM, a British money management company. 
Thirty-two of Brazil's largest companies have A.D.R.'s that trade in New York, including Petrobras, the state-controlled oil company; Embraer, which makes commercial jets, and almost all the country's phone companies. In some cases, trading volume in the A.D.R.'s exceeds that of the underlying shares on the Bovespa.
The New York Stock Exchange has actively wooed Brazilian companies, including organizing a "Brazil Day" for Friday, with some 20 Brazilian companies set to meet with institutional investors to drum up interest in their A.D.R.'s. The protest today was timed to anticipate the Brazil Day event.
Brazilian brokers and traders say they do not object to A.D.R. trading, only to having to compete with it at a disadvantage. The situation has become so bad, they say, that the Bovespa has not had enough trading volume over the last few months to cover its operating costs.
"It's laughable that we are the ninth economy in the world, yet trade only 350 million reais per day," said Raymundo Magliano Filho, the president of the Bovespa. "The Bovespa is a national patrimony, and we need the government to support us."
Beyond relief from the transaction tax, the protesters also called today for the government to scrap a plan to raise the rate of income tax on stock market profits to 20 percent, to match that levied on bond income. 
Experts say that even if the government did all that the protesters ask, the Bovespa will continue to be depressed by the economic crisis in neighboring Argentina and an energy crisis at home that has crimped industrial production.
Nor is merely leveling the playing field likely to bring international investors flocking back to the Bovespa, analysts say; what is needed is new blood.
"If we can manage to list medium-size companies in Brazil and put them together with smaller, even individual, investors, that could be the route to restoring growth at the Bovespa," said Aloisio Lemos of Lopes Filho & Associados, a Rio de Janeiro consulting firm. "Of course, that's not something that will probably happen this year, or even next."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Traders at the Bovespa stock market in Sao Paulo, Brazil, interrupted trading for an hour yesterday, protesting a tax on stock trades. They cheered when the government agreed to exempt stock trades. (Angela Prada for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Problem With Analysts: You Get What You Pay For 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
EVERY bear market must have a scapegoat. After all, when so many people lose money, it cannot just be because they made bad investment decisions.
 Seven decades ago, in the aftermath of the 1929 crash, it was the short-sellers who were tarred and feathered. Short sales were "the greatest evil that has been permitted or sanctioned by the government that I know of," said one congressman. The shorts were accused of driving down prices, bankrupting investors and causing the Depression. 
 In subsequent market retreats, there have been other villains, notes James Chanos, himself a well-known short-seller. In the early 1970's, it was the go-go mutual fund managers of the 1960's. Program traders took the blame after the 1987 crash. A decade ago, it was junk bonds.
In each instance, there was a grain of truth in the vilification. But the talk was overblown. Limits were imposed on short-selling in the 1930's, but for some reason neither the economy nor the stock market quickly recovered.
So it is now with this bear market's scapegoat: Wall Street analysts. Amid Congressional hearings, Wall Street is scrambling to impose new rules to curb abuses. Some firms now say that they will not allow analysts to own stocks they are recommending. A New York pediatrician got a $400,000 settlement from Merrill Lynch after claiming he lost money by following bad advice from Henry Blodget, Merrill's Internet analyst. 
There are problems with Wall Street analysis, but they were apparent long before prices plunged, and the reforms now being made will not solve them.
Consider Mr. Blodget. He gained fame as an early fan of Amazon.com. The Internet bubble coincided with the emergence of CNBC as an investment force, and he became a media star. 
At Merrill, Mr. Blodget replaced an analyst who had taken a more cautious view of Internet valuations. With the bubble inflating, it was the bullish analysts who appeared to be right. Since there were no profits anywhere in sight, other "metrics" had to be found to evaluate stocks. Some wonderfully creative ones were invented.
Such metrics, which were based on anything but cash flow, seemed absurd to some of us at the time. But they were explained, and investors could evaluate them. It was also obvious that Merrill, like its competitors, was quite happy to recommend stocks of investment banking clients.
But if the problems were clear, why did Merrill pay the doctor? It offers the normal public relations gobbledygook nonanswer, but the real reason may be embarrassment that a client's account was concentrated in two very risky stocks, an imprudent strategy in any market.
As investigations proceed, some outrages may turn up. It is offensive for analysts to sell shares they are endorsing, and more disclosure is clearly a good idea. But rather than bar analysts from investing in stocks they follow, investment banks might do the reverse. They could require analysts to follow their own advice, buying a couple of weeks after they recommend a stock, and selling only after their clients are advised to get out.
But that would not attack the real problem: money. With commissions on share trading continually falling, it is not investors who provide the cash for Wall Street bonuses. The money comes from investment banking fees, and the companies that direct those fees want praise, not criticism.
Investors who want good research will have to pay for it. Until a mechanism is devised to pay Wall Street for quality advice, no new rule is likely to produce it.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Fall Again; 2 Indexes Risk Retracing April Lows

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks ended near their lowest levels in two and a half years yesterday as bleak earnings forecasts and slack economic data drove the Dow Jones industrial average back below 10,000.
 Bonds rallied after a report showed further contraction in services businesses. 
 "The overriding concern is the economic slowdown," said Peter Coolidge, senior equity trader at Brean Murray. How long and how much? If those questions could be answered, then you would see a bottom to the market. But the best prospect for the market is best guesses -- that's not enough. The market is saying, 'Show me the money; show me the turnaround.' " 
The euro rose against the dollar, to 89.53 cents from 88.64 cents on Wednesday, after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its gauge of service-sector activity fell in August, to a four-year low of 45.5.
The Dow dropped 192.43 points, or 1.92 percent, to 9,840.84. sliding back below the 10,000 level.
Technology stocks again had a worse day, with the Nasdaq composite index losing 53.37 points, or 3.03 percent, to end at 1,705.64. The Nasdaq posted its third consecutive losing session, and its seventh daily decline in eight. It is threatening to breach a two-and-a-half-year closing low on April 4 of 1,638.80, and is now down 30.96 percent for the year.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 25.34 points, or 2.24 percent, to 1,106.40. It is teetering near the April 4 low of 1,103.25.
Declining issues on both the Big Board and Nasdaq outnumbered those advancing by a margin of more than 2 to 1.
Intel, one of the 30 stocks in the Dow average and a Nasdaq heavyweight, fell $1.37, to $26.10, in regular-session trading on expectations that it would lower revenue estimates. After the bell, Intel said its quarterly sales would be "slightly below the midpoint" of its earlier forecast; its shares rose to $26.75 after hours.
The National Association of Purchasing Management set the bleak tone early in the day. Its monthly nonmanufacturing, or services, index fell for a second month, to 45.5 in August from 48.9 in July. Economists had expected a reading of 49.4. The drop followed a rise on Tuesday in the group's manufacturing index, which spurred some hopes of an economic revival starting late in 2001. "The bigger picture here is maybe the service sector is taking over in terms of the weakness," said Ian Morris, chief United States economist at HSBC Securities in New York.
Adding to pessimism was a sales warning by Motorola, the big mobile phone maker, which helped knock the wind out of technology stocks. Motorola dropped $2.46, to $13.94. 
Gap Inc., the apparel chain, reported a 17 percent drop in same-store sales last month and warning that it was not likely to meet its third-quarter sales forecast. Gap shares plunged $4, closing at $15.
Retail sales over all rose 2.8 percent for the month, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index issued yesterday. 
The 10-year Treasury note rose 22/32, to a price of 101 4/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.86 percent from 4.94 percent on Wednesday. The 30-year Treasury bond rose 28/32, to 99 16/32. Its yield fell to 5.41 percent from 5.47 percent.

HEADLINE: Report Counts Computers In Majority of U.S. Homes 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 

 BODY:
More than half of the households in the United States had at least one computer last year, and more than 40 percent were connected to the Internet, a Census Bureau report released today said.
 In addition, 65 percent of children ages 3 to 17 had access to a computer at home in 2000, up from about 55 percent in 1998. Of children in that age group, 30 percent logged onto the Internet, compared with 19 percent in 1998, the report found. 
 Census figures showed that 54 million households, or 51 percent, had one or more computers in 2000, up from 42 percent in 1998. It was the first time computer ownership surpassed 50 percent, the report said. 
The bureau surveyed about 50,000 households in August 2000. (The data are separate from the census, which did not include questions on computer access or Internet use.)
"This is such a big shift, and it happened so fast," said Eric C. Newburger, a statistician with the bureau who wrote the report. "Years from now we will look back on this as a watershed year, when computers went from a special thing in a home to a common appliance."
Forty-four million households, or 42 percent, included a family member who used the Internet at home last year, the report said. When the bureau first collected data on Internet use in 1997, 18 percent of households had Internet access.
Many people are shopping, checking stock quotes and reading news online. And among those who use the Internet, 73 percent of children and 88 percent of adults said they exchanged e-mail messages regularly.
But the survey found significant discrepancies in computer ownership and Internet use along age, racial and economic lines. 
Among households with incomes of $75,000 or more, 88 percent had a computer and 79 percent went online. In households with incomes below $25,000, 28 percent had a computer and 19 percent used the Internet.
Sixty-six percent of Asian and Pacific Islander adults said they had a computer at home, the highest of any racial or ethnic group. Among other groups, 61 percent of white adults said they owned a computer, while 37 percent of black adults and 35 percent of Hispanic adults said they did.
The oldest adults in the nation had the lowest rates of computer ownership and Internet use. About 28 percent of those 65 and over said they owned a computer, and 13 percent said they used the Internet.
Schools have "leveled the playing field," the report said, for children with no computer at home. Nearly 90 percent of children used computers at school, the report said.

HEADLINE: Scoopful of Ice Cream to Help Truancy Go Down 

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

 BODY:
First there was whole language. Then there was constructivist math. Now ice cream may be the latest weapon in the arsenal of raising student achievement.
 In a drive to increase student attendance, Harold O. Levy, chancellor of New York City's public schools, promised yesterday to serve favorite foods -- like ice cream -- in school cafeterias on Mondays and Fridays, the days that children eager to stretch out their weekends are most likely to be absent. 
 Speaking during a five-borough tour on the opening day of school for 800,000 elementary and middle school children, the chancellor also said that he would like to see tests scheduled at the beginning and end of the week, rather than in the middle. That way, children would lose points on their grades if they were not present.
"First off, we are going to have tests on Mondays and Fridays instead of during the week," Mr. Levy said as he visited Public School 194 in Harlem. "There will be small rewards. The food will be better on Mondays and Fridays."
Ice cream Mondays and Fridays may not be just another educational fad, nutritional experts said. National studies have shown a definite correlation between enjoyable as well as nutritious meals and school performance and attendance.
Studies in Baltimore, Boston, Philadelphia and Minneapolis have indicated that when children ate breakfast in class, where they could socialize in an intimate, friendly environment, they improved their test scores and attendance, said Agnes Molnar, director of child nutrition programs for the Community Food Resource Center, an advocacy group that studies nutrition and poverty.
"It sounds great," she said of Mr. Levy's idea.
Mr. Levy can deliver the favorite foods because the chief of food services works directly under him. But he said that he cannot force superintendents and principals to schedule tests on particular days, nor would he want to override their educational judgment. But he said superintendents like Thelma Baxter in Harlem had informed him of the attendance problem on Mondays and Fridays, so he expected them to be cooperative.
David Ernst, spokesman for the New York State School Boards Association, said special ice cream and test days were not a strategy for improving attendance that he had heard in other districts. More common, he said, is the punitive approach, like a program in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., that allows parents of truants to be charged with endangering the welfare of a child, a misdemeanor.
"Whimsy from 110 Livingston Street?" Mr. Ernst said disbelievingly. "I guess, what's the downside?"
Kevin F. Gill, executive director of the school system's Office of School Food and Nutrition Services, said yesterday that he was a bit leery of using food as a reward and that ice cream was expensive. But, he added, "I can live with ice cream on Friday." 
As for Monday, he said he would try to think creatively. "Kids like chicken, pizza and Italian food," Mr. Gill said. "We could move the broccolini to Wednesday."
Mr. Gill said that high school students could prove especially hard to entice, even with chocolate fudge sundaes. They tend to like eating lunch out, he said.
This is not the first unorthodox proposal for Mr. Levy, a former corporate lawyer who became head of the New York City school system 20 months ago. Early in his tenure, he proposed offering free airline tickets as a reward for teachers who helped their students get better test scores, though the idea was later dropped.
The chancellor acknowledged that the correlation between poor attendance and low performance might reflect other factors as well, like homelessness, poverty and unemployment.
"Which way causality runs is not clear to me," Mr. Levy said. "But the point I'm making is much more rudimentary. If a child doesn't attend, that child will not learn. Attendance is a quid pro quo. It is a necessary minimum."
Citywide, average daily attendance is 92 percent, and "that's not good enough," he said. At Public School 194, which he visited yesterday, attendance averages just 88 percent, he said.
Schools opened on Wednesday for the city's 281,000 high school students. Despite talk of budget cuts among politicians and school officials, elementary and middle schools appeared to open smoothly yesterday, though there was some shuffling of teachers and aides, and many after-school remedial programs have been indefinitely postponed.
Mr. Levy charmed a roomful of first graders at P.S. 1 in the South Bronx by reading the book "Chicka Chicka Boom Boom" aloud and prompting them to sing the alphabet song. Having elicited the conundrum that both coconuts and cows give milk, he encouraged the children to ask their teacher to explain how that could be.

HEADLINE: Virus Is Killing Thousands of Salmon 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
A virus that kills Atlantic salmon but is harmless to people is spreading in fish farms in eastern Maine, forcing the destruction of hundreds of thousands of valuable fish and threatening endangered wild salmon, state and federal officials say. 
 The disease was first detected in the 1980's in Norwegian and Scottish fish farms, then appeared in New Brunswick fish pens in 1996 and crossed the border into Cobscook Bay in Maine in March. 
 The discovery in recent days of several more infected fish in pens in the bay prompted state officials on Wednesday to impose emergency rules barring boats from leaving infected areas and requiring fish farmers to notify officials immediately when an infected fish was found. Infected fish and fish exposed to them must be removed and killed, although some may still be sent to market. 
The Boston Globe reported the restrictions yesterday.
The highly contagious disease, infectious salmon anemia, affects a fish's kidneys and circulatory system. It causes the fish to bleed internally and usually die. Much remains unknown about how the virus spreads, although it is known to move in the water and from fish to fish in crowded pens. Juvenile and adult fish are affected.
The anemia has forced the destruction of millions of fish in Europe and Canada in recent years as fish farmers on both sides of the Atlantic have tried to contain its spread. Maine fish farmers have killed more than 900,000 fish since March, state officials said yesterday. 
Several fisheries experts said that in the countries where the disease was most established, close surveillance had prevented large outbreaks. They said it was likely to be kept at bay in Maine as well.
In the short run, though, it could be a costly blow to a Maine enterprise that had grown in a decade from nearly nothing to an industry worth $100 million a year, state officials and aquaculture companies said.
Fish that have reached their adult size of 8 to 10 pounds can still be sold, cutting the financial losses somewhat. So far, state and industry officials said they had not been able to estimate the economic cost of fighting the virus.
The state's fish farmers plan to seek aid from a Department of Agriculture program that compensates farmers for herds of livestock lost to illness. 
"We're looking for the same kind of assistance any terrestrial farmer would have open to them," said Sebastian Belle, the executive director of the Maine Aquaculture Association, a trade group. 
Mark F. J. Kesselring, a project manager for Stolt Sea Farm, said, "This is a very serious disease and economic loss and a problem for the industry, but, in the long term, I believe it's manageable." 
Mr. Kesselring's company has fish pens in bays on both the Canadian and American sides of the border, including Cobscook Bay, along the Canadian border, the only place in Maine where the disease is known to have struck. More than half of Maine's 800 acres of salmon pens are in the bay, said Andrew Fisk, the aquaculture coordinator for the Maine Department of Marine Resources.
Mr. Kesselring said that disease outbreaks were a fact of life for farmers raising animals, whether they have hooves or fins.
"The difference is that with terrestrial livestock, we've had thousands of years of history to deal with," he said. "Aquaculture is only about 20 years old, so there are some learning curves to be gotten through."
Biologists said it remained unclear whether the virus was accidentally imported to North America from Europe or had always existed in the wild on both sides of the Atlantic but had remained unnoticed, with widely dispersed wild fish dying and disappearing unseen. Several experts said it could be that the disease had only come to light with the recent burgeoning of salmon aquaculture, which packs thousands of fish into floating cages. 
New England newspapers have focused increasing attention on the problem in recent months because of the threat the virus poses not only to the growing aquaculture industry but also to the already imperiled stocks of wild Atlantic salmon.
Strains of native salmon that breed in eight of Maine's rivers were given endangered status by federal wildlife agencies last November. 
Some scientists said the large populations in fish farms could serve as breeding grounds for the virus and that occasional escapees from the floating cages could spread it. 
But other experts said it was unlikely that the virus would have a significant impact outside the dense collections of raised fish, though many said it was better to err on the side of caution by aggressively culling fish when there was an outbreak.
Many private environmental groups have criticized the nascent aquaculture industry as playing down the risk of disease and pollution from the moored pens, where the fish are fed for a year or two until they reach market size. 
"Density creates an environment in which a virus that might be very random and rare in the wild can concentrate," said Peter Shelley, the vice president of the Conservation Law Foundation in Boston. 
Mr. Shelley said the industry in Maine had been in denial for years about diseases in farmed fish.
"There are right places and ways to do this and practices that could minimize issues like viral outbreaks," he said.
Industry officials defended their practices. Many companies have divers who inspect pens for dead fish twice a week and all the fish are removed and killed as soon as an infection is spotted, they said.
