HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Unemployment Up to 4.9%, Its Highest Level Since '97
The nation's unemployment rate jumped sharply in August to 4.9 percent from 4.5 percent in July, the biggest one-month rise since 1995 and its highest level since 1997, dashing hopes that the bleak economic climate was starting to improve. In August, according to the government's Bureau of Labor Statistics, businesses eliminated more than 100,000 jobs, suggesting that the economy remained at risk of falling into a recession. And companies, in an effort to halt profit declines, made further cuts this summer in the number of hours worked by their employees.
 A month ago, the Labor Department offered some reason for optimism, finding that manufacturers in July made the fewest number of job cuts in almost a year and reporting a rise in the number of people in the labor force -- those with a job or actively looking for one. But the August numbers erased nearly all of the hopeful signs. Page A1. 

President Bush said "too many people are losing their jobs," and he cast the surge in the unemployment rate as a reason for Congress to advance his economic agenda by expanding trade agreements and reducing energy costs while holding down spending. A9.

Court Questions TV Takeover Rules
A federal appeals court in Washington signaled its intention to strike down two regulations that have prevented the nation's biggest broadcasters, cable companies and media conglomerates from expanding by taking over local television stations. A1.

AMR Expects Losses in Second Half
AMR, the parent of American Airlines and Trans World Airlines, expects to post losses in the third and fourth quarters because of higher costs and fewer passengers. The company said the third-quarter loss would be "considerably larger" than its loss of 68 cents a share in the second quarter. C4.

Genetic Corn Risk Found Negligible
Genetically modified corn poses a "negligible" risk to monarch butterflies, according to a series of papers that will soon be published. The papers represent the most comprehensive peer-reviewed publications on a question that has been at the heart of controversy over genetically modified crops. C2.

UPN Is Sued by its Chief Executive
Dean Valentine, the president and chief executive of UPN television, has sued the network, contending that the broadcaster owes him up to $22 million in promised bonuses. Mr. Valentine, who was hired away from the Walt Disney Company in September 1997, accused UPN of arranging a financial incentive plan that differed from the terms that the company agreed to when he joined the network. C14.

Australian Bank's $2 Billion Blunder
The National Australia Bank, the country's biggest, bungled its foray into the American mortgage market by overlooking risk management fundamentals and by making a simple computer error. The mistakes forced the bank to write off $1.75 billion this week. C3.

India to Intervene in Dabhol Dispute
The government of India will intervene in a dispute between the Enron Corporation and the Indian state of Maharashtra over the Dabhol Power Company, which is controlled by Enron and is the largest private foreign investment in India. C3.

BP Pulls Out of China Gas Pipeline
BP, China's biggest foreign investor, pulled out of the bidding to help build a $14 billion natural gas pipeline that was designed to help development in the western provinces, reflecting concern about the plan's profitability. C3.

CBS to Drop Challenge of Fox Show
CBS and the producers of the top-rated television program "Survivor" agreed to drop their copyright-infringement lawsuit against the "Boot Camp" show of the Fox network. C4.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Stocks Slump on Fears Economy Won't Recover Quickly

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
A weak employment report further depressed stock prices in both the United States and Europe yesterday as hopes faded for a quick economic recovery.
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 20.62 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,085.78, as it fell below 1,100 for the first time since October 1998 and became the first major American index to fall below the lows reached this spring. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average declined 234.99 points, or 2.4 percent, to 9,605.85, with such economically sensitive stocks as Boeing, Caterpillar and United Technologies leading the losses. But it remains above its spring low of 9,389.48. 
The report that the unemployment rate rose to 4.9 percent in August was viewed as indicating that the American economy was continuing to decline and spurred talk that the economy would shrink this quarter.
"People have wanted to see some definitive sign of a bottom in the economy so they could feel more comfortable about earnings," said Charles H. Blood Jr., a market strategist at Brown Brothers Harriman. "This report certainly does not do that."
The sell-off has been even worse in Europe, where growth also appears to be slowing. In recent weeks several technology companies, among them Sun Microsystems and Novellus Systems, have said they see signs of stability in American business but that overseas sales are surprisingly weak.
The major stock indexes in all major European countries fell 5 percent or more this week, with a large part of the losses coming yesterday. Markets in Britain, France, Spain, Italy and Germany are all at their lowest levels since 1999 or earlier.
It is not just the stock market that appears to be warning of a weakening economy. Industrial commodities have been falling sharply, with one index of such prices at its lowest level since 1986. Treasury bond interest rates are also falling, reflecting an expectation of lower growth and a flight of investors to the safety of government securities. The 10-year Treasury yield is down to 4.78 percent, while the yield on two-year Treasuries is at 3.49 percent. In late May, when hopes for a recovery were rising, those yields were 5.51 percent and 4.31 percent, respectively.
"The bond market, the stock market and the commodities market are all saying, 'More easing, please,' " said Robert J. Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company. Economists now seem convinced that the Federal Reserve will lower rates again at its next meeting, in October, something that was not deemed a sure thing only a few days ago, and there is growing speculation that the cut will be by half a percentage point, rather than the quarter point some expected.
It was the sharp fall in technology companies, first of their stock prices beginning in the spring of 2000 and then of the underlying businesses, that set off the stock market decline in America and then the economic slowdown. But yesterday, technology companies generally suffered smaller losses than many other stocks. Intel fell 21 cents, to $25.89, the day after it said business was meeting its lowered expectations.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 17.94 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,687.70, but that was the smallest loss for a major index. It also remains above its spring low, of 1,638.80. Microsoft fell 62 cents, to $55.40, the day after the Justice Department disclosed that it would no longer seek to break up the company.
Hewlett-Packard, up 38 cents, to $18.08, and Compaq Computer, up 24 cents, to $10.59, rose for the first time since they announced plans to merge. Even with the gains, however, they are down 22 percent and 14 percent, respectively, since the deal was announced on Monday night.
Byron Wien, a strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said the unemployment report showed the economy was worse than people had thought. But he added that he thought the stock market could bottom by the end of October, turning back up well before the economy does. "Some tech stocks have suffered enough," he said, and might be close to their lows now. He pointed to EMC, which fell 53 cents, to $13.35, and Cisco Systems, which fell 4 cents, to $14.36.
Concerns that consumers are starting to react to rising unemployment by cutting back on spending affected some retail stocks. Home Depot fell $2.60, to $40.95. For the week, it fell $5, or 10.9 percent.
Financial companies are also coming under increased scrutiny as investors look for signs of deterioration in credit quality. Conseco fell 89 cents, to $7.11, bringing its loss for the week to $2.07, or 22.5 percent. TheStreet.com, citing leaked documents and interviews with former employees, reported Conseco had pressured employees to extend loans to avoid having to report that more loans were in default. The company called the allegations "tiresome and wrong" and said it had acted properly.
AOL Time Warner, down $2.81, to $32.28, was the biggest contributor to the daily decline in the S.& P. 500, which fell 4.2 percent for the week and has now lost 8.4 percent of its value in two weeks, for the worst two-week performance since April 2000, just after the market began to fall after a sustained bull market.
While the Nasdaq composite was the strongest of the major indexes yesterday, it fell 6.5 percent over the week, the second consecutive week that it had lost more than 5 percent of its value.

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-6

Sharon Skeptical on Talks; Favors West Bank Buffer
Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said that although he had authorized talks with Yasir Arafat to try to produce a cease-fire in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, he doubted they would amount to anything. Although the conference on racism was to have ended yesterday, the delegates in South Africa vowed to keep negotiating to achieve consensus on a declaration of goals for racial harmony. It's Williams vs. Williams
Venus Williams and Serena Williams will play each other for the United States Open title today, after the sisters won their semifinal matches against Jennifer Capriati and Martina Hingis, respectively. D1

Yanks' Catcher Suspended
Major League Baseball suspended Jorge Posada for six games and fined him $3,500 for his dispute with an umpire. The suspension was stayed pending his appeal. D5

BUSINESS DAY C1-16

Rethinking Rules on Big Media
A federal appeals court signaled it would strike two regulations that keep big broadcasters, cable companies and media conglomerates from acquiring local television stations. A1

Stocks' Slide Steepens
The S.& P. 500 fell 20.62 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,085.78, becoming the first major American index to fall below the lows reached last spring. It was also its first close below 1,100 since October 1998. The Dow tumbled 234.99 points, or 2.4 percent, to 9,605.85, and the Nasdaq fell 1.1 percent. C1

Japan Falling Into Recession
The output of goods and services in the second quarter contracted at a 3.2 percent annual rate. C1

States' Warning on Microsoft
Some state attorneys general in the Microsoft antitrust case said they would press for tough sanctions and would pursue the company on their own if they believed Justice Department remedies were too weak. C1

SECTION: Section A; Column 4; National Desk; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 80 words

HEADLINE: National Briefing West: California: Benefits Bill Goes To Governor 

BYLINE:  By Robert B. Gunnison 

 BODY:
 The Legislature sent to Gov. Gray Davis a union-supported bill to increase benefits for employees hurt on the job. 
The bill, passed by the Senate on Thursday, would raise the maximum weekly temporary disability benefit to $230 from $140 over the next five years. Twenty-two states pay more than California. Mr. Davis, a Democrat, has twice vetoed similar measures, saying that increased workers' compensation benefits would hurt the state's economy. Robert B. Gunnison (NYT)

 BODY:
 A chart yesterday with a front-page article about the effect of rising unemployment on workplace relationships misstated the cause of a 100-job reduction at CommScope Inc. of North Carolina, a manufacturer of broadband cable. It is the slowing economy. The company is not under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
